WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 1.--Herbert S. Graham, the notorious lawyer who has figured prominently in the United States courts at Pittsburg, Williamsport, and county court here on numerous charges and who is now imprisoned here for larceny, was this afternoon brought from jail on an order by the District Attorney.

Coroner Levy had a hard time of it yesterday in his continuation of his inquest in the killing by electric shock of Thomas Murray, the electric light lineman. Only one of a half dozen summoned witnesses appeared.

The motion for an injunction made by James M. Hill of the Union-Square Theatre to restrain Margaret Mather from performing with Gilmore and Tompkins, was argued yesterday before Judge Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, Chambers. Mr. Hill was in court accompanied by his counsel, Mr. A. H. Hummel, who read the ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 1.--The announcement by the Chicago, Burlington and Northern Railway that on Monday next rates between Chicago and St. Paul and Minneapolis, via that line, would be reduced to the basis of 40 cents per 100 pounds, first-class, was the principal subject of conversation in local railway circles today.
WASHINGTON, June 1.--The following telegram has been received at the War Department in regard to the recent Indian scare.

Daniel Frohman, Manager of the Lyceum Theatre, was one of the passengers of the steamship Lahn, which arrived yesterday. Mr. Frohman's trip to Europe was a flying one, and it is scarcely seven weeks since he left this city.
ELMIRA, N.Y., June 1.--A serious accident, by which two men lost their lives, occurred at the junction of the Erie and Southern Central Railways, about 20 miles east of this city, this evening.

CONCORD, N.H., June 1.--Senator Chandler and Mrs. John U. Hale and her daughters, Mrs. Kensley and Mrs. Chandler, have decided to erect a statue of John P. Hale in the State House yard, to be of the same size as the Daniel Webster statue. The artist has not yet been decided upon, but it is thought that Alexander Doyle of New-York City will be chosen.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 1.--The Hon. R. B. Langdon of Minneapolis, a delegate to the Republican Convention, says that with Blaine out of the way he feels free to act as he pleases, the Minneapolis Convention having declared positively for Blaine, to the exclusion of Gresham and every other candidate.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 1.--The State Democratic Convention adjourned at 3 o'clock this morning. D.W. Bain, Treasurer; W.L. Saunders, Secretary of State; T.F. Davidson, Attorney-General, and S.M. Finger, Superintendent of Public Instruction, were renominated by acclamation.
LONDON, June 1.--The steamship Island, (Dan.,) Capt. Skjodt, from New-York May 19 for Christiania, , passed Dunnet Head to-day.

NORWALK, Conn., June 1.--The body of Mrs. J. Butler of New-Canaan was found this afternoon suspended by a rope from a beam in an old outbuilding near her home on Tonerstreet. She had been dead several hours.
ERIE, Penn., June 1.--John Rayen was arrested to-day at the races by Deputy United States Marshal Hickernell, and committed to jail to await a hearing upon a charge of embezzlement.

P.J. Cafferty, who came on from Montreal in search of his wife and got shot by her brother, William Knox, May 26, recovered sufficiently to appear in the Yorkville Court yesterday against Knox, who stated that he was knocked down several times in the hallway of his residence, after which he defended himself with his revolver.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 1.--Ithaca, the twenty-ninth city of the Empire State, today celebrated its inception with no end of noise and display. One event alone dimmed the general rejoicing. Shortly after 12 o'clock last night the ...

Judge Benedict of the United States Circuit Court yesterday afternoon heard argument on the order he issued requiring the District Attorney of New-York County to show cause why "Boodle" Alderman Henry W. Jaehne ...
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 1.--The Syracuse Stove company failed to-day. The liabilities are $50,000. Judgements for $37,200 were filed to-day, mostly in favor of local banks.

The Tammany Hall men and the County Democrats will leave for St. Louis to-day. Tammany will start at 2:30 P.M. and the County Democracy will leave four hours later. Both factions will leave the Grand Central Station, and will travel on special trains, consisting of baggage and sleeping cars.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1.--Drafts, sight, 17 ; cents; Telegraphic, 22 cents.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 1.--Capt. Howard Patterson, Principal of the New-York Navigation School, passed through here to-day on the steam yacht Skylark of New-York.

Mayor Latrobe yesterday received the following letter from Thomas G. Downey, pay department United States ship Vandalia, from Honolula, Hawaiian Islands, dated May 9, 1888: "I sent you some papers per steamer ...
The closing races of the Spring meeting of the Country Club Steeplechase Association at Pelham were run yesterday under very favorable conditions.
The earnings of the Louisville, New-Orleans and Texas Railway for April were officially reported yesterday, aggregating $159,773 64, an increase of $34,831 56.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1.--Peter Campbell fatally shot Michael J. Eady here last night. Campbell is Eady's father-in-law, and a quarrel arose in Eady's store over alleged mistreatment of Mrs. Eady. Eady ordered Campbell out and tried to drive him with a scales' weight, whereupon Campbell fired.
MONTREAL, June 1.--A meeting of the gray goods section of the Dominion Cotton Manufacturers' Association was held here today to consider the question of over-production.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 1.--The trial of Pete McCartney, the counterfeiter, was begun yesterday before Judge Billings and a jury. McCartney appeared as his own counsel, his former lawyer having withdrawn from the case.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 1.--The PorterBurrall matters have again come before the public. In this instance the results do not suit Mrs. Frederica Porter-Burrall, the lady most interested, and who is now in London, England.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1.--Judge Thurman received a long telegram this evening from Tammany Hall pledging their allegiance and urging that he consent to allow his name to go before the convention. Mr. Thurman was called upon this evening, and was found in a very happy mood.
The regular meeting of Plymouth Church was held last evening, after the Friday evening prayer meeting and the adjourned business meeting. The only subject considered was ...

The birds of the Florida coast are fast disappearing before the guns of the plume hunters. There is an especial scarcity of the great American egret, the snowy heron, the Louisiana hen, the reddish egret, Ward's heron, and the little blue heron. Birds that were common ...
LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 1.--The total lockage for the month of May at this port was 1,918, of which 854 were east-bound boats and 1,020 west-bound and 44 cribs of timber.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--The Board of Officers appointed on April 18 to examine into the claim of John B. Read has been ordered to reconvene in this city at 10 o'clock to-morrow for further consideration of the claim. Leaves of absence have been granted Second Lieut. Charles P. George, Sixteenth Infantry, for four months, and Cadet Eben E. Winslow, Second Class, Military Academy, for one month.
AUBURN, N.Y., June 1.--This was the great day of the State shooting contest, the shooting for the Dean Richmond Cup being witnessed by several thousand spectators.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 1.--The other day, Levi Roberts of Newton was notified that he was the indorser for a note for $2,100 held by a Grinnell bank. He pronounced the note spurious, and last night Alva C. Mershon, whose father is one of the first settlers of Newton, was arrested and lodged in jail for the forgery.

PARIS, June 1.--All the morning newspapers praise the speech made by M. Goblet, Minister of Foreign Affairs, in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday, in reference to the utterances of Herr Tisza, the Hungarian Prime Minister, and describe it as firm, measured, and patriotic.

CINCINNATI, June 1.--The sixth day at Latonia was pleasant, the weather being cool and clear. The track was a trifle slow, but in excellent condition. Mr. Sheridan arrived last night and started the horses in fine style. It was a good day for the bookmakers, as not a first favorite won.
A gentleman who has just returned from an extended foreign tour was asked yesterday why he had not brought home from Egypt, among other curios, a mummy.
The Quebec Legislature is to be asked to vote a sum of money to prevent the exodus to the Unites States. It appears that in one week not less than 200 persons, men, women, and ...

Theodore A. Hector and his wife, Delia, of 147 West Sixteenth-street, were held in $1,500 bail each in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on the charge of forcibly detaining Carrie Haight and ...
SEATTLE, Wyoming, June 1.--The crew of the British ship Silverdale mutinied when two days out from Port Discovery. She was lumber laden for Melbourne, Australia.

BOSTON, Mass., June 1.--At the annual meeting of the American Tract Society yesterday the following officers were elected: President--William C. Chapin; Vice-President--The Rev. J.A. Gordon; Executive Committee--Will iam C. Chapin, Russel Sturgis, Jr., William H. Wardwell, the Hon. James White, and Eben ...
CHICAGO, June 1.--A middle-aged man, who looked like a prosperous country mer chant, walked into a tobacconist's store in the American Express Company's Building this afternoon and bought two cigars.

BOSTON, June 1.--There was a large gathering at the Boston and Albany Railroad station this afternoon to see the 3:10 special train bearing the delegations to the St. Louis Convention off. It was a fine make-up.
David H. McAlpin has presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art Karl Hubner's painting. "The Poacher's Death." This well-known picture was for many years in the old Dusseldorf Gallery in this city.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1.--Mr. Blaine's letter positively declining to be a candidate before the Chicago Convention is more keenly regretted by the Republicans of Nebraska than in any other State. He was unanimously their first choice.

ALBANY, June 1.--Dr. David Murray has arranged an attractive programme for the twenty-sixth University Convocation, to be held in the Senate Chamber July 10, 11, and 12, comprising topics that pertain to the immediate interests of higher and secondary education in ...

A curious and sensational attempt at highway robbery was made between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, in Thirty-second-street, last night. John Miller, who gives his age as 17, and who looks more like 25, walked up to Thomas Boyle, age 29, of 204 East Twentyninth-street, and, pulling out a revolver, put it against his breast and said:

I mentioned last week that a new wing has been added to Balmoral. I learn that it is to be appropriated to the use of Princess Beatrice and Prince Henry of Battenberg and their children. It is a notable addition to the castle, ...
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 1.--The Democratic State Convention took a ballot for Governor this forenoon which resulted as follows:

BEAUFORT, N.C., June 1.--A waterspout struck here at about 3 o'clock this afternoon capsizing several small craft and fishing schooners. The crew of the schooner James Rumley saved themselves by clinging to purseboats. The schooner Minnie was driven ashore.

NASSAU, New-Providence, May 28.-- The sponge trade is lively; plenty is offering at good prices. The Greek spongers who arrived last Fall to engage in the sponge fisheries have found the business unprofitable, and not being able to compete with the native gatherers have abandoned the effort, and will at once sail for home. General business is dull.

Under the protection of the 25 special detectives who went to Verplank's Thursday the new workmen in the brick yards of Messrs. Fisher King at once resumed work, and yesterday two more yards were started up.
Edmund C. Stanton and Herr Anton Seidl of the Metropolitan Opera House landed yesterday from the North German Lloyd steamship Lahn. They were met by scores of friends.

Judge Lawrence heard arguments yesterday upon the writ prohibiting the City Court from proceeding further with its order requiring the Sheriff to show cause why he should not be punished for contempt in failing to furnish suitable accommodations for the Judges.
An unknown soldier of the regular army was run over and killed by a train at the Emmett-street station in Newark last night. He was about 35 years old.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 1.--Superintendent of Banking Paine has issued a certificate authorizing the National Bank of Genesee, at Batavia, to do business under the State system under the name of the Bank of Genesee. The capital is $75,000. A.N. Cowdin is President and Trumbul Cary Cashier.
BALTIMORE, June 1.--Another grave was filled in the Booth lot at Greenmount Cemetery to-day and the remains of Mrs. John Sleeper Clarke were laid beside those of her father, Junius Brutus Booth.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 1.--The Gen. G. K. Warren bronze monument is to be erected at Gettysburg on a native boulder, on the smooth face of which will be the following inscription:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 1.--The Sheldon Axle Works some days ago announced a reduction of wages to a portion of their men to take effect this morning. The employes affected refused this afternoon to accept the reduction and many of them quit work. The strikers, are expert workmen and were brought here from Auburn, N.Y., by the company.

John P. Lockwood, having pleaded guilty to an indictment for forgery in the second degree, was sent to State prison for seven years and six months yesterday by Recorder Smyth in Part III., General Sessions. Lockwood said he resided at Rye.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 1.--The most interesting political news here at present is the statement, made on the best authority, that the Hon. George G. Sumner of this city will not be a candidate for the Democratic nomination of Governor this year.

The Seventh Regiment Band will give concerts on the Mail in Central Park to-day and to-morrow at 4 P. M. Beginning to-day, Arnold, Constable Co. will close their store at noon on Saturdays during the Summer months.

It is a great shame that there should not be a buffet at Buckingham Palace on drawingroom days, where tea and coffee could be obtained by ladies after they have passed through the throne room, for the rule is that nothing is supplied, except brandy or sherry, and then ...

John Howard, who, until a few days ago resided at 825 Dean-street, Brooklyn, was held for examination by Justice Walsh yesterday on a charge of stealing $75 and some valuable jewelry from the trunk of Henry Powlton, who lives at 833 Dean-street. Powlton and Howard ...
VIROQUA, Wis., June 1.--Andrew Grandstaff, the murderer of old Reuben Drake, his wife, and two grandchildren, was captured while in bed last night by a Pinkerton detective and two local officers.
TANGIER, June 1.--The Sultan has given his sanction to the exportation of bones for a year, beginning on July 12.

PETERSBURG, Va., June 1.--Among the speakers at the closing exercises of the State Colored Normal School here to-day were Gov. Fitzhugh Lee, Dr. John L. Buchanan, Superintendent of Public Instruction, and the Hon. ...
DETROIT, Mich., June 1.--Work on the proposed tunnel under the St. Clair River at Port Huron is, after a long period of waiting, again actively under way.

CHICAGO, June 1.--The lines in the Western and Northwestern Freight Bureau have made no move yet toward meeting the action of the Burlington and Northern in reducing rates between Chicago and St. Paul.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1.--Messrs. Hager, Phelps and Hallidie of the Board of the University of California Regents, and Trustees Plum and Mastick, representing the Lick Trust, met this afternoon and made the transfer of the Mount Hamilton property.

WINONA, Minn., June 1.--The steamer Evansville, a raft-boat, exploded her boilers a few miles below Winona this forenoon. Jack Scanlan, second engineer; Cornelius Scanlan, fireman, and Al Babbitt.
WASHINGTON, June 1.--The bond offerings today aggregated $1,012,200 as follows: Registered 4s, $200 at 127 1/8; $800,000 at 128. Registered ...

The Stock Exchange's dullness continues uninterrupted by even a single notable fluctuation, and that pet phrase of the Street, "the active stocks," has become a ghastly joke. The brokers' offices are empty. The "outside public" is wary and away. The grumbling contingent of brokers without incomes is about the only visible sign of life through the whole Stock Exchange district.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1.--A large coal oil tank at the barbed wire works in North Omaha exploded to-day, killing two men--William Kelley and James Crysty--who were repairing some leaky places in it. Both were blown through the root of the building and mangled most horribly. Kelley died instantly, but Crysty lin gered a few hours in great agony.

The second of Mr. Kennan's illustrated articles on Siberia, which appears in the Century for this month, gives new and excellent evidence of how rich a source of entertainment this series will be. With the help of the illustrations ...

The proceedings of the National Convention of Prohibitionists at Indianapolis showed more clearly than was ever shown before that the third party owes its growing strength mainly to dissatisfaction with the recent course of the Republican Party.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 1.--The brassworkers of the United States will hold a convention in this city on June 26.

BANGOR, Me., June 1.--In all human probability Stain and Cromwell must go to prison. The statute of Maine provides that in capital cases the prisoners can appeal for a new trial, which three of the eight Judges could grant.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 1.--Yesterday morning, off Thunder Cape, in Lake Superior, the schooner Maggie McCrae was sunk by running into a heavy field of ice.
The fuss about the Empress Maria Theresa which the Emperor of Austria has been making is due to the fact that the Crown Prince's only child is a daughter.

CHICAGO, June 1.--A bold attempt at kidnapping was made yesterday when three women, Julia Morris, Carrie Blackwell, and Louise Miller, lured Minnie Postle, a pretty girl of 14, into a saloon and induced her to drink a glass of drugged beer.
ALBANY, June 1.--The new calendar of the Court of Appeals directed to be made up at the session of the court held in New-York is now in the hands of the printer. It is the largest ...
The New-York Board of Fire Underwriters held a meeting, and passed resolutions calling the attention of the Mayor and Department of Public Works to the want of water for extinguishing ...

Count Arco, the newly-appointed German Minister at Washington, arrived from Europe yesterday and put up at the Albemarle Hotel, where he was visited by Consul-General August Feigel, Consul Frederick Meyer, and others. He will remain ...

OTTAWA, June 1.--The Government, it is believed will call for tenders shortly for the construction of the Sault Ste. Marie Canal, but whether the contract will ever be awarded is another question agitating the minds of the contractors.

Johannes Jacobsen, a young man who was employed in a wall paper factory in East Forty second-street, and who boarded at 216 East Forty-first street, disappeared May 23, on the evening of which day he was to have been married to Bertha, the daughter of Christian Meyerhoff, a tailor living at 77 Second-street. He is 25 years of age, a native of Holstein, and has been in this country for six years.

VIROQUA, Wis., June 1.--Late last night Andrew Grandstaff, aged 25, was arrested at Kickapoo Centre charged with the murder of the Drake family on the 24th ult. He was brought to this city this morning and lodged in jail.

RICHMOND, Va., June 1.--An unusually large crowd for that court assembled in the Chancery Court room this morning to hear argument in an injunction case in which Maurice B. Flynn's Union Passenger Electric Railway Company is the defendant.

As is well known, nearly $400,000 of the State debt will mature on July 1, 1888, and, in order to provide for redemption thereof, the General Assembly of the State at its last session authorized the issue of that amount of new bonds, to run 40 years and bearing interest at the rate of 4 per cent. per annum, payable in January and July of each year.

ST. Louis, Mo., June 1.--The sixth day of the St. Louis meeting was signalized by the breaking of a turf record. It was the performance of Wheeler T., who in the first race ran one mile and one-sixteenth in 1:47 , which is second less than that of Jim Douglass at Chicago in 1886.
Some men become bald quite early in life, while others die and have their wills offered for probate before their heirs fall out.--Yonkers statesman.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 1.--A. Fairbanks, a hardware merchant of Antwerp, Jefferson County, was found dead in the woods just outside of that village this evening. He had committed suicide.

ANNANDALE, N.Y., June 1.--St. Stephen's College here has got over its recent typhoid fever scare. The baccalaureate sermon will be preached June 17. Class Day will occur on the 19th and Commencement on the 21st.
RONDOUT, N.Y., June 1.--The New-York Ministerium of the Lutheran Church will meet in the Spring-Street Church here on June 7. Nearly 200 ministers and laymen will be in attendance as delegates.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1.--E. Hussong, editor of the Nelsonian at Nelson, this State, was fatally shot Wednesday while returning from a Grand Army camp fire. His assassin was concealed in the grass at the side of the road and made his escape in the darkness. No cause is known for the shooting.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 1.--The Western trade, and Pittsburgers in particular, sold immense quantities of oil to-day.
The legislative investigation into the manner in which the New-Jersey State Asylum is conducted was resumed at the asylum, at Morris Plains, yesterday morning.
ST. LOUIS, June 2.--The few delegates who are in town have very little to talk about except the movement in support of Thurman for the second place on the ticket.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 2.--Business has been quite lively here this week, and the hotel keepers and others were able to take in considerable money as an offset to the large losses sustained previously.

This volume contains the programmes of nearly all the musical entertainments given in this city in the course of last season.

WASHINGTON, June 2.--The Acting Secretary of the Treasury to-day received offers for the sale of bonds to the Government as follows: Four per cents. registered--$50,000 at 127, $100,000 at 128, $30,000 at 127 7/8. Four and a half per cents, coupon--$1,000 ...

RICHMOND, Va., June 1.--The announcement is made that Miss Amelie Rives will shortly be married to Mr. Archie Chandler, grandson of John Jacob Astor. Mr. Chandler lives in Paris. Miss Rives is at her home in Albemarle County, where she has been engaged in her literary work for the past 12 months.

LONDON, June 2.--John Bull is in quite a stew over his newspapers. There is a bill before Parliament allowing them more liberty in reporting public meetings than they have hitherto enjoyed.

The finals in the Spring tournament of the New-York Law Tennis Club were played yesterday afternoon at the club grounds, at One Hundred and Forty-seventh-street and St. Nicholas-avenue, Washington Heights.
Frank H. Damrosch continued yesterday morning his course of lectures on "The Best Methods of Instruction in Vocal Music in our Schools" at Association Hall, on Twenty-third-street.

Wall-street's current experiences are not inspiriting. When Stock Exchange business is not stagnant, keeping quotations at a standstill, the liveliness that comes is of an unwelcome sort. The slightest activity sends prices down.
WASHINGTON, June 2.--Gen. Sheridan is holding his own. If it were not for the cough, which the doctors have not been able to overcome, they would probably call his condition better than yesterday.
George G. Ward, the Secretary of the Commercial Cable Company, returned from England yesterday in the Etruria.

If the races at Jerome Park yesterday did nothing else they brought to the attention of every one of the 5,000 people present a possible candidate for Suburban honors in Linden.
CHICAGO, June 2.--Mrs. America L. Rawson was indicted to-day for the attempted murder of Attorney H.C. Whitney in Judge Jamieson's court room by the Grand Jury this morning.

The Seventy-first Regiment is to go to Creedmoor for rifle practice Thursday, June 14.

RED BANK, N.J., June 2.--Henry Little, a 12-year-old son of Henry Little of Fair Haven, narrowly escaped a horrible death this afternoon. For a day or two a large gasoline tank has been stored on the Fair Haven steamboat ....

PARIS, June 2.--The flower show is over, and with the exception of the magnificent exotics--the finest display ever seen here-- the only novel feature was a ceiling of white marguerites growing and thriving in their unusual position.

Edward F. Browning yesterday obtained an attachment from Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, against the Schlicht Field Company of Rochester, manufacturers of office files, cabinets, , who made an assignment a short time ago.
The second attempt to sail the muchtalked-of match between W.A. Wolff's sloop yacht Vivid and Ernest Staples's sloop yacht Wizard was successful yesterday.

ALBANY, June 2.--At its recent meeting the State Civil Service Commission appointed C. J. Kintner, Chairman of the examiners of employes of the Board of Electrical Control.
ITHACA, June 2.--For the first time in several years there has been trouble between town and gown at Ithaca.

The Union Pacific Railroad's official report of earnings for April came out yesterday, and gave much encourangemet to the company's friends. The gross earnings were $2,539,242, an increase of $197,487.
BOSTON, June 2.--The first of the June weddings occurring in Boston was a most charming affair and was witnessed by a large company of notable Boston and New-York people.
Early Saturday morning Benjamin Maginley, known to his friends as "Ben," died at the home of his son-in-law, Frank Buckle, in the village of West Chester, Westchester County.

CHICAGO, June 2.--When Andrew Pearce Game to America in 1880 he left his iron shipbuilding establishment in London in charge of his wife, Elizabeth Ann Pearce, and William R. Whent, a young man he had taken from the docks and educated.

Everybody who has any connection with Birmingham will be acquainted with the vast publishing establishment still known by the short title of "Meeson's," which is perhaps the most remarkable institution of the sort in Europe.
DECKERTOWN, N.J., June 2.--The pipe line of the Standard Oil Company broke yesterday a few miles from here, several thousand barrels of crude oil escaping.

DANBURY, Conn., June 2.--William Burns, whose son, Francis, was found murdered on May 14 near John McNiff's saloon in Turner-street, has brought suit for $5,000 damages against McNiff, the alleged murderer of his son. McNiff is now under bonds for trial.
Inquiries have been made of late as to what had become of the opium smuggling case in which the name of the firm of McKesson Robbins was mentioned.

The majority of the Kings County Republicans favor the selection of Judge Gresham to lead the party to victory or defeat next Fall, but Col. Andrew D. Baird, the party candidate for Mayor last November, looks with favor upon Chauncey M. Depew.

The New-Rochelle Rowing Club held its seventh annual regatta yesterday afternoon in the bay off its clubhouse. The water in the early part of the afternoon was somewhat choppy, and the races were deferred to as late an hour as possible.

Since the arrival of several New-England delegations and of politicians who are familiar with the opinions of the bodies of delegates now on the way the Thurman movement has gained so much in force and popularity that it can scarcely fail to overcome all opposition.

BERLIN, June 3.--The Cologne Gazette says that the Council, at a meeting on Friday, Prince Bismarck presiding, resolved to resign if the Emperor should insist upon the publication of his letter to accompany the promulgation of the quinquennial Parliament law.

CORK, June 3.--A monster meeting was held in City Park here to-day to take action with reference to the Papal rescript. The meeting indorsed the resolutions adopted by the Irish Bishops at their recent meeting in Dublin.

The annual reception of the religious school of the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun was held yesterday afternoon at the temple, on Madison-avenue, near Sixty-fifth-street. The exercises were entertaining, the singing being of a pleasing order.

WINDSOR, Mo., June 3.--A sensational poisoning tragedy was developed here to-day. Three days ago John Owsley was taken suddenly ill, and after medical attention was summoned it was found that he had been given rat poison.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 3.--The Horseshoe Falls on the Canadian side have been safely navigated. To-day a barrel shot through with a live chicken in it. NEWPORT, R.I., June 3.--Townsend Smith, a young New-Yorker, who has just come in possession of a large fortune, gave a dinner last evening in honor of the event. Young smith is the only son of Mrs. Henry Turnbull by her first husband.

Under the old law the number ran from 55 to 378 each Sunday.

RICHMOND, Va., June 3.--The Richmond Greys arrived home this evening after a week in NewYork of marching, counter-marching, banqueting, and comic opera.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 3.--The sale of the Fort Worth and Denver Telegraph Company to the Western Union was announced yesterday. The line extends from here to Denver and is the only telegraph line running northwest from the Pan Handle. The terms were private.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 3.--To-day at his home at Beauvoir, on the shore of the Gulf of Mexico, Jefferson Davis, the ex-President of the ex-Confederacy, celebrated his eightieth birthday. The house was filled with flowers sent by his neighbors.
BRENSWICK, Me., June 4.--E.P. Pomeroy of Rochester, N.Y., aged 60 years, while visiting his sister at Harpswell, hanged himself this morning. He was temporarily insane.
A new sect has been added to the already numerous religious communities in Germany. Its members call themselves the "Free Brethren in Christ."

CHICAGO, June 4.--George Bell, the man who out off George R. Murray's ear, was to-day bound over for trial on a charge of mayhem. He gave $2,000 bonds. No new testimony was introduced at the hearing, the Justice ruling out what purported to be a confession by Mrs. Bell of undue intimacy with Murray.
Leighton Foster, Bennie Evans, and Lewis Bishop spent Saturday in hunting for turtles, snakes, toads, butterflies, and bugs along the banks of West River and on the West River meadows.
CHICAGO, June 4.--Judge Benjamin D. Magruder was to-day re-elected to the Supreme bench of the State. There was no opposition.

CRESTON, Iowa, June 4.--Charles Schreeves, a hardware merchant of Murray, killed Lou Mears, a farmer, last night. Their quarrel grew out of Mears's objections to Schreeves paying attention to his sister.

Calvary Church, at Twenty-first-street and Fourth-avenue, was pleasantly crowded yesterday afternoon with friends and relatives of Miss Lucy Edwalyn Coffey, daughter of Edward Lees Coffey, and Charles de Kay, who were married by the Rev Dr. H.Y. Satterlee, Rector of the church.
"Under Cover" by Charles Foster was produced at the Windsor Theatre by George C. Boniface last evening. There was a large and well-pleased audience.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 4.--Upon reassembling at 9 o'clock this morning the Democratic State Convention adopted a platform and proceeded to the eighty-sixth ballot for Governor.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 4.--Ex-Gov. Porter will present the name of Gen. Harrison to the Republican National Convention. The Governor was the distinguished Indianian's law partner, and the intimacy between them has existed undisturbed for many years. It is understood that Gen. Harrison expressed a wish to have his old friend thus chosen by the Indiana delegation, and Gov. Porter has consented to make the nominating speech.

The work of the New Parks Commissioners is nearly finished. It will not be the fault of the Commissioners if the territory marked out by the Legislature in 1884 for new playgrounds for the people in the Twenty-third and Twentyfourth Wards shall be much longer withheld from the uses designed for it.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 4.--The Cornellian, the satirical annual of the university, will be issued tomorrow. It is published by the Junior Class, and is the book in which the cream of the jokes and "grinds" of the year is collected.

Railroad earnings for the month of May were reported in Wall-street yesterday for many of the lines of the country. These showed decreases: St. Paul, $100,212; Buffalo; Rochester and Pittsburg, $27,872; Milwaukee, Lake Shore and Western, $46,000.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--Assistant Surgeon James E. Pilcher has been detailed as a member of the Medidal Board to examine candidates for admission to the Military Academy, vice Surgeon Robert M. O'Reilly, relieved; Second Lieuts. John F. Morrison, Company A., and Marcus D. Cronin, Company B., Twentieth Infantry have been transferred.

Mrs. Potter has come back to New-York and hung out her sign at the Grand Opera House, on Eighth-avenue. She was greeted last evening by a vast assemblage of people, many of whom had gone three or four avenues westward to get another view of the American beauty.
It is an event in the career of a Columbia College Sophomore when he completes his mathematical course. The "Triumph over Legendre" was only celebrated last evening by the Sophomore Class.

ROCKDALE, Texas, June 4.--A fire occurred here this morning in which 11 lives were lost and 2 persons at least were seriously injured. The fire originated in the office of the Mundine Hotel, a three-story brick structure, and was discovered at 3 o'clock.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 4.--The local option election to-day in the township in which Raleigh is situated resulted in a majority of 141 for license. Last year the township went dry by a majority of 31.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4.--The old and the now in ships and sailors of the American Navy are now represented at Annapolis. BOSTON, Mass., June 4.--To-day the Ancient and Honorable Artillery of Boston, with its guests, a delegation from the Honourable Artillery of London and the Old Guard of NewYork, are celebrating the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the local organization.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 4.--David T. Disney, while on route with the Duckworth Club, of which he was a member, to the St. Louis Convention yesterday, met with a distressing accident at Seymour, Ind., from the effects of which he died at 2 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--The business of the House of Representatives got into a tangle early to-day, and there was no way out of the difficulty except to adjourn, unless one party or the other would yield the point in controversy.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 4.--New-Brunswick is suffering from a prevalence of diphtheria that has almost become an epidemic. There have been many deaths.

PITTSBURG, June 4.--The city is thronged to-day with iron and steel workers from every part of the country. Both of the labor organizations which control nearly all of the mills in the country are well represented.

RAHWAY, N.J., June 4.--This city has been discussing murder themes again to-day. This time it is the murder of Phoebe Pauline, the mystery of whose death on the Orange Mountains remains, with that of the Rahway murder, unsolved.
PORTLAND, Oregon, June 4.--The Republicans confidently claim the election of Harmann for Congress by not less than 1,500 majority.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 4.--Forest fires are doing great damage in Wisconsin, south of Ashland. At "Thirty-mile Siding." on the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railroad, the Post Office, 3 houses, 30 cars, 5,000 ties, and 3,000 posts were burned this afternoon. Trains are delayed and fears are entertained for other towns in the vicinity.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 4.--Aspecial to the Avalanche from Paris, Tenn., gives the details of two bloody encounters in the streets of that place to-day, growing out of the recent shooting of Kennedy Porter, a son of ex-Gov. Porter, by Will Edmunds.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 4.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following causes were argued:
TRENTON, N.J., June 4.--The State Board of Assessors filed in the office of the State Controller to-day their first return of taxes on the miscellaneous corporations of the State.

Chevalier Blondin, the hero of Niagara Falls, the delight of juvenile millions and the wonder of their elders all over the civilized world, the only man who ever crossed the chasm of Niagara on a tight rope, and who did that twice in the infancy of the present generation, is here again.

CHICAGO, June 4.--A case of more than ordinary importance was begun to-day before Judge Blodgett in the United States Court, involving the question of whether the Bell Telephone Company is entitled to the exclusive use of certain telephone patents.

The monthly investment circular of the banking house of John H. Davis Co. of 10 Wall-street contains a forcible presentation of the way the Half-Holiday bill and Gov. Hill's veto are looked at by the down-town business men.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia,, June 4.--It is stated that a number of Cape Breton collieries are to be consolidated under one management. Among the concerns selling out are said to be the Sydney and Louisburg Coal and Railway Company, the International Coal Company, and the Caledonia Company. It is believed that a New-York syndicate will become owners of the organization and invest a large amount of fresh capital in Cape Breton coal mines.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., June 4.--The Battlefield Memorial Association to-day elected all but one of the old Directors and in addition Col. Wheelock G. Veazey of Vermont, Col. George G. Briggs of Michigan, Gen. John P. Rea of Minnesota, and S. McSwope of Gettysburg. The State Monument Commission arrived this afternoon and will confer with committees from the various regiments to-morrow.

Gen. Phil Sheridan's hopeless illness, taken in connection with a recent visit to the Upper Cascades, recalls vividly an important episode in the early military history of that dashing and brilliant cavalry officer. Thirtytwo years ago, on the 26th day of last March.

HAMILTON, Ontario, June 4.--Prof. C.W. Williams; aeronaut, made an ascent in a balloon from the Dundern grounds this afternoon. When the balloon had gained an altitude of about three-quarters of a mile, Will iams, with the aid of a parachute, dropped from the basket.

There was no music from unseen orchestras, nor the sound of the sweeping of angels' skirts in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday. There was naught save an impassive magistrate, an empty jury box, a fat ...

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 4.--Mrs. Virginia Wilkinson Wilde, wife of Major William C. Wilde, died yesterday morning. She was born 61 years ago in Plaquemines Parish on Pointe Celeste plantation, the home of her fathe, Mr. J.B. Wilkinson.

The first International Congress of Anthropology ever held in this country began its sessions at Columbia College yesterday afternoon, under the auspices of the New-York Academy of Anthropology. Two sessions were held yesterday, morning and afternoon, and similar sessions will be held to-day, to-morrow, and Thursday.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 4.--A few weeks ago THE TIMES reported the prospective failure of the scup season. Prominent fishermen who had been engaged in the seining of fish all their lives were of opinion that the sea bass always followed scup, and that the latter always failed to "show up" after the former made their appearance.

When the Springtime wanes and the regular theatrical season has gone a little beyond that point it is the custom to bring out in playhouses that would otherwise be unoccupied new plays which cannot be exhibitied in the usual course of events.

Four children of the late Col. Dexter R. Wright, a prominent lawyer and politician of New-Haven, began a suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday to recover property valued at $100,000 and now held by Thomas R. Sexton of Merrick, Long Island, and Charles G. and ...

LONDON, June 4.--The dissident members of Parliament at a conference to-day decided to support the Government, on the licensing question if modified so as to limit the period of compensation and provide that the purchase money be obtained by an increased license tax.
The Albion Cricket Club will play a match with the Alma Club of Newark, N.J., in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, next Saturday.

ST. LOUIS, June 4.--With regard to the second place on the ticket the only question which remains to be decided is whether the Indiana delegates shall withdraw Gray or shall first give him their votes on one ballot.
Theatrical circles were, to say the least, surprised yesterday when it was announced that John A. Stevens, the play wright, actor, and manager, had instituted against his wife a suit ...

Judge Barrett gave the special Grand Jury which was impaneled in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday a charge which made them open their eyes and prick up their ears. The court room was crowded, for it had been rumored that Judge Barrett would have something pertinent and instructive to say upon election frauds and excise crimes.

ALBANY, June 4.--Four of the breweries which have been run with non-union hands since early in April took back the Knights of Labor who left their breweries in a body this morning and discharged the men who took the places of the strikers.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 4.--At the session of the Supreme Court this morning Chief-Justice Norton fixed the 13th of July as the day for the execu tion of Hugh M. Brooks, alias Maxwell, the murderer of C. Arthur Preller at the Southern Hotel.

ROSLYN, Long Island, June 4.--The Methodist parsonage at Port Washington was entered by burglars early this morning and $200 in cash and a large quantity of clothing, the property of the Rev. Mr. Russell, the Pastor, and father of Prof. Russell of the University of New-York, were carried off. The burglars are supposed to be the same who robbed the residence of Mrs. J. Small a few nights ago.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 4.--Edward A. Deacons, the convicted murderer of Mrs. Ada Stone, was this morning sentenced to be hanged July 10 between the hours of 10 A. M. and 3 P. M.
MONTREAL, June 4.--At the annual meeting of the Bank of Montreal this afternoon the statement showed that the balance of profit and loss last year was $605,740.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 4.--A special to the States from Baton Rouge says: "The Board of Liquidation to-day made arrangements with the Louisiana National and Canal Banks for the payment of all coupons of State bonds up to July, 1890, at 4 per cent. interest per annum."

BERLIN, June 4.--The Emperor will examine Minister von Puttkamer's reply to the letter concerning the freedom of elections before publishing the Quinquennial bill, and will then decide whether his letter to the Minister shall be published with the bill.
A fair in aid of the Grant fund was opened yesterday in one of the rooms on the Thirty-ninth-street side of the Metropolitan Opera House.

Mr. Richard Mansfield's engagement at the Madison-Square Theatre began last night, when a numerous and attentive audience watched his powerful acting in "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" with the customary interest and enthusiasm.
The final hearing in the Page will case was held yesterday afternoon at the Surrogate's Court, Stapleton, Staten Island.

The New-York State Executive Committee, J.N. Knapp, Chairman, has completed arrangements for transportation to the National Republican Convention at Chicago. The NewYork Central and Hudson River Road will ...

WASHINGTON, June 4.--In the words of his own physicians Gen. Sheridan is "on the verge of dissolution." At no time since the beginning of his illness has he been so love as now, with so little hope of improvement. Last evening's relapse was so severe...

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 4.--General Traffic Manager Hanley of the Kansas City Road is in receipt of numerous congratulatory telegrams from railway officials in the Northwest relating to the position he has assumed in the matter of rates from Chicago.
ALBANY, June 4.--The following bills, most of which relate to New-York City and vicinity, were signed by the Governor to-day:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4.--A true Bohemian and, to Providence people, a Wholly mysterious man died when the breath of Claude De Haven left his body lying on the bed in his lonely room in a small hotel Sunday night.

WHEELING, West Va., June 4.--One of the most terrible crimes ever committed in the vicinity of this city occurred at the well-known suburban roadhouse of Jerry Clemens, on the old national "pike" in Belmont County, three ...
NORWICH, Conn., June 4.--The funeral of Gen. H.W. Birge was held from the residence of Gen. William A. Alken, on Washington-street, at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

The New-York Turnverein Bloomingdale took formal possession last evening of its new hall, 305 West Fifty-fourth-street. The ceremonies of the evening began with the formation at the old hall on West Forty-fourthstreet of the 300 members of the society, together with other turner and singing organizations, into a long procession.

The suit of John A. Austen and William Flash against Mrs. Viola B. McLaurin came up before Judge McAdam yesterday in the City Court, on a motion to vacate as attachment in order to relieve a life insurance policy from attempts to levy upon it.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4.--When the roll of Shaler's brigade, the surviving members of which have a reunion at Gettysburg next Tuesday, is called, one of the regiments of the brigade, the Sixty-seventh New-York, will not respond.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 4.--The dispatch from Wilkesbarre, Penn., printed in Saturday's TIMES recounting a fresh escapade by "the notorious lawyer, Herbert S. Graham," is of special interest in this quarter, where the person referred to has been known from his early youth up as the scion of a respectable ...

MILTON, N.C., June 4.--One of the most terrific cyclones that has ever visited the South passed near this place at 4 o'clock Saturday afternoon. The length of the tract covered by the storm was about 25 miles and its width about 500 yards.

Mr. and Mrs. D.B. Tredwell of the Continental-Hotel were thrown from their carriage while riding in the Park last evening at 7 o'clock. Their horse took fright and suddenly dashed into the Terrace Bridge. The occupants of the carriage were not injured. The horse injured himself, and the carriage was somewhat broken up.
The lower house of the Prussian Diet to-day resumed the debate on the bill granting State assistance to the popular schools in Prussia.
A young man of swarthy complexion, with black hair banged over his forehead and wearing eyeglasses, was taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 4.--The Democratic National Convention is all in St. Louis, and to-morrow morning it will begin to work. It has been slower in getting together than it was in 1884, and has come together with less enthusiasm. The absence of contest accounts for the lack of demonstrations for particular men.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 4.--A large audience gathered in the Academy of Music here to-night to listen to addresses on imperial federation.

Senator Evarts went over to the Brooklyn Court House yesterday to appear as counsel for the defendant in the suit of Mrs. Annie F. Jarrett against William Ziegler to recover 265 shares of stock in the Royal Baking Powder Company, valued at $500,000. The case was adjourned.
The Alumni of the Bucknell University of Lewisburg, Penn., who reside in this city were entertained at dinner last night at the Hotel Vendome by Alfred Taylor, one of their number.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 4.--Patrick Morrissey was tried in the District Court at North Adams to-day for the murder of Sylvanus Morgan.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 4.--Gov. Hill to-day signed the bill abolishing hanging for all murders committed after Jan. 1, 1889, and substituting death by electricity therefor.
CHATHAM, Mass., June 4.--The schooner Rebecca J. Moulton, Capt. Sturgis, for Boston, went ashore on Pollock Rip Shoal, Sunday. She was floated off in the evening. she has a valuable cargo of sugar.
The war between the fruit dealers and the fruit importers, growing out of the differences of opinion as to how fruit should be offered for sale in the auction room, is still going on.

CHICAGO, June 4.--The new rates that went into effect to-day between Chicago and St. Paul were widely at variance. On the lines in the Western and Northwestern Freight Association the rate was 60 cents for first-class; on the Chicago, Burlington and Northern and ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 4.--At a meeting of Republicans to-night, speeches deprecating Blaine's withdrawal from the race were made, and when it was declared that with him was victory and without him defeat, great ...

Battery Park had on its real Summer day look yesterday for the first time this year. May usually begins the season at the Battery, but May this year brought nothing but rain and damp winds that crept in from the Bay and made sitting in the park far from pleasant.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--To-day's bond offerings amounted to $19,000, in lots as follows: Four per cents., registered. $1,000 at 128:4 per cents., coupon, $18,000 at 108. Neither of these offers was accepted.

BIDDEFORD, Me., June 4.--A warrant has been issued for the arrest of Mrs. Orrin Boothby for assault, with intent to kill, Mrs. Bean last week. Jealousy was the cause of the assault. The trial will be had Wednesday.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 4.--Araki Miyaki, Japanese, was ordained a Dutch Reformed minis ter this evening and will become a missionary in his native land.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 4.--The negro Richard Kearney, who was convicted of the murder of Miss Margaret Purcell, and who declared yesterday that he assaulted Miss Herbert at Eatontown, a crime for which "Mingo Jack" was lynched, tells several stories, all different.

BELFAST, June 4.--The Government has proclaimed Belfast under sections 3 and 4 of the Crimes act. This will enable the court to grant a change of venue in the trial of persons arrested for defrauding the Equitable Life Insurance Company of New-York.
Franzesko Grocolino, an Italian living at Second and Jackson streets, Hoboken, had a a wound in his head dressed by City Physician Simon in the police station in that city on the night of May 27.
The Jewish tailors of Leeds are making a decided stand against long hours and poor wages.

Now that Vice-Commodore Caldwell H. Colt of the New-York Yacht Club has satisfied himself with the performance of his old sloop, the Wizard, in her race with the Vivid last Saturday, he intends, it is rumored, to sail a match in the schooner Dauntless against the Ramouna, lately the Resolute.

New-York ball players are rapidly going to the front in the race for the first honors of the League. By defeating Indianapolis yesterday they advanced from third to second place in the race, and are now ahead of Boston by a small percentage.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 4.--Senator Fassett, Chairman of the Senate Committee to investigate abuses in New-York City departments, who has been ill at his home in this city since the adjournment of the Legislature, though not yet entirely recovered in health, has summoned the committee to reconvene on June 8. He will leave for New-York to-morrow morning.

BANGOR, Me., June 4.--The side-wheel teamer Bar Harbor, intended to run on a daily line to that place, was launched here to-day. Connecticut, New-York, and Philadelphia people are fast opening their cottages there, and already the famous seaside resort presents a lvely appearance. All Summer trains are on and all are well patronized.
The United Labor Party Association of the Second Assembly District met last evening at 475 Pearl-street. There were 13 persons present, including President Michael Foley.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 4.--Frank W. Gibbs, the night train dispatcher whose conflicting train orders caused the collision on the Air Line Divsiion of the New-Haven Road last night, has fled. As soon as he learned of the accident he notified the chief train dispatcher, and then left his office. The police have as yet been unable to find him.

BISMARCK, Dakota, June 4.--Bismarck and Burleigh County will indulge in a novel election contest about the middle of June. The office of County Superintendent of Schools is already sought for by three candidates. W.H. Winchester, the incumbent, will run for another term, and Mrs. E.H. Wilson and Miss Edith ...
HURON, Dakota, June 4.--The coming political conventions of the 10th, 11th, and 12th of July will exert a great influence on the future of Dakota.

Jeremiah Shay, 30 years of age, died at :30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at his home, .6 Batavia-street, from the effects of an assault made upon him about an hour previous, at Pier 19. East River, by Patrick Green, a laborer, formerly employed by him.
The second day of the examinations for admission to the College of the City of NewYork were held yesterday morning at the college building, in Lexington-avenue.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 4.--The Railroad Commissioners to-day completed their compilation of the earnings of the railroads in the State for the month of April as compared with the same period last year. Twenty-four roads show an increase and two a decrease.

LONDON, June 4.--Walsh, the man who was suspected by the police of being implicated in a plot similar to that which led to the murder of Lord Frederick Cavendish and Under Secretary Burke in Phoenix Park, Dublin, finding himself dogged at every footstep, accorded an interview in Paris to an agent from Scotland Yard.

PARIS, June 4.--Gen. Boulanger took his first step in the Chamber of Deputies to-day for the revision of the Constitution. His arrival at the Chamber was without incident. He gave notice to the Chamber that he would submit a proposal for a revision of the Constitution and would demand urgency therefor.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 4.--The Bailey gold medal, instituted by the late Rear-Admiral Thomas Bailey for the purpose of inciting the apprentiees of the United States Navy to greater effort in acquiring a knowledge of their profession, will be awarded to one naval apprentice under the following conditions:
The will of Fred Marsden, the play wright, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The original will was executed Feb. 8, 1882, and by it he left all his property to his wife.

The unveiling of the statue of Garibaldi, in Washington-square, yesterday, drew together a large crowd of spectators and participants. The Garibaldi Legion, the Regiment Alpine, and the Botenza Loggia Italiana, took positions immediately about the statue, with representatives of many other Italian societies massed behind them.
Isaac Billbarrow, aged 7 years, was run over by a beer wagon at Tenth-avenue and Sixty-third-street yesterday afternoon. The boy was conveyed to the Roosevelt Hospital where he soon afterward died.

BALTIMORE, June 4.--The Grand Jury for the United States District Court, in its report to the court submitted to-day, suggests practical means for correcting the cruelties inflicted on crews engaged in dredging oysters in the Chesapeake.

The election of officers for the ensuing year at the University Club last evening resulted as follows: President--Dr. George A. Peters; Vice President--James W. Alexander; Secretary--Allen W. Evarts; House Committee-- Willard P. Ward, W.H.L. Lee, John P. Kingsford. The council has decided to have the clubhouse lighted by electricity.

Thomas G. Shearman spoke to the Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club in Avon Hall, Bedford-avenue, last night on "How Wages Could be Raised on a High Tariff." It was expected that Henry George and Frederick Hinricks would speak, but they could not attend.

Notwithstanding the strenuous, efforts being made by the managers of the Trsascontinental Association to discover attempts on the part of any railroad companies to give cheaper freight rates than those authorized by the association, nearly all the freight agents feel that "something is going on," though no one seems ...
LONDON, May 26.--A committee of general officers met in Lord Wolseley's room at the Horse Guards yesterday afternoon for the purpose of further considering the question of the defense of London.

William F. Kern, the fourth member of the Jersey City Board of Works "combine," who failed to appear on Saturday to plead to the indictments found against them, was in Judge Lippincott's court yesterday morning.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 4.--The Commencement exercises of the Lawrenceville School began yesterday. Dr. Mackenzie, the head master, preached the baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class.

A fire occurred at the Grand Hotel last night about 11:30 o'clock which caused a flurry of excitement. A cigar or lighted match was dropped from some room above on the awning that shades one of the fourth-story rooms fronting on Broadway.

WHEELING, West Va., June 4.--A telegram from Charleston this evening says a serious affray occurred in McDowell County, near the Virginia State line, a day or two age, in which one man was killed, and his brother and stepmother wounded.

RICHMOND, VA., June 4.--The announcement of the betrothal of Archer Chandler and Miss Amelie Rives, the young Virginia authoress, whose recent works have attracted considerable attention in the literary world, was received here with some surprise.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 4.--The first day's shooting in the revolver match between Chevalier Ira A. Paine of Providence and Frederick E. Bennett of Boston for $1,000 a side and the championship of the world, came off in Hampden Park, in this city, this afternoon, and was won by Paine ...

ALBANY, June 4.--Bank Superintendent Paine recently asked the Attorney-General to answer a letter sent him by F. Hughson asking for his opinion as to what is meant by the term "accumulated surplus" in connection with investments by savings banks in bonds and ...
CONCORD, N. H., June 4.--The thirteenth annual Spring meeting of the Athletic Association will be hold in the afternoon to-morrow and continue Wednesday.

Mrs. Anna Knatz of 364 East Tenth-street appeared as complainant at Police Headquarters yesterday against Patrolman Lincoln E. Chaffee of the Thirteenth Precinct, whom she charged with cruelly injuring her son August, aged 10 ...

BUTTE, Montana, June 4.--There was a "cave-in" in the St. Lawrence Copper Mine yesterday when all the men but four had come to the surface. Men are now at work digging through the "cave-in" in the endeavor to rescue the entombed men, two of whom can be heard distinctly hammering on the wall.
At least 500 people who could not get their winning French mutual tickets cashed at Jerome Park on Saturday got to the track early yesterday afternoon and got cash for their bits of pasteboard.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4.--On board the steamship Oceanic, which arrived from Yokohama yesterday, was Munimitsu Matsn. Japanese Minister to the United States. He succeeds Minister Kuki, who recently left Washington for Japan.

A terrible forest fire is reported from Jenbach, near Innsbruck. In one day 600 acres of fir trees were burned to the ground. A telegram from Galicia also states that the town of Calbuszowa was completely burned on Friday, 400 wooden houses, a church, a Twon Hall, and a ...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 4.--A cable message from the United States Consul at St. John's, Newfoundland, to-night, to Consul-General Phelan says the Captain and crew of a Booth Bay schooner, Ambrose H. Knight, have been arrested there for selling bate obtained from Newfoundland waters to French fishermen at St. Pierre. Consul-General Phelan thinks the Newfoundland authorities have made an egregious blundor.

MONTREAL, June 4.--The petition for a writ of injunction against the Beaver Steamship Line, which, it was alleged, had formed a "combine" with the Allan and Dominion Lines against the cattle shippers, was to-day dismissed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 4.--A little girl named Addie Donohue, aged 5 years, whose father lives in New-York, was accidentally shot and instantly killed this morning at 70 Kingsley-street with a rifle by her uncle, Edward Weise, a boy 14 years of age. They were handling the weapon at the time, which had been loaded to shoot pigeons. The ball entered the child's head back of the ear.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 4.--The Princeton College Athletic Association to-day elected the following officers for next year: President--J.D. Denegre, '89, Minnesota; Secretary--F.S. Miller, '90, NewYork; Treasurer--F.W. Church, '91, New-York. The Springfield meeting will occur June 16.
There was a lively annual election at the New-York Produce Exchange yesterday. The contest was over some of the members of the Board of Managers.

Edward Mueller, alias A. Stokvis Vitrain, a teacher who was once employed at a school of languages in Philadelphia, was a prisoner yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court to answer to the charges of fraud and larceny.
The Republican Club of the city of NewYork held a meeting last night at its rooms, 450 Fifth-avenue, President Edward T. Bartlett presiding.
TROY, N.Y., June 4.--Miss Catharine Gormby, aged 67 years, deliberately walked in front of a train of cars at Saratoga to-day and was killed.

CHICAGO, June 4.--The annual election of the Chicago Stock Exchange was held to-day, and the regular ticket was elected. With the exception of four members of the Governing Committee, it was a re-election of the officers who served during the past year. The new members of the committee are C. Granville Hammond, S.G. Lynch, Joel D. Harvey, and M. M. Jamleson. The President of the Exchange is Edward Koch.
NORWALK, Conn., June 4.--Another gradecrossing accident occurred on the Danbury and Norwalk branch of the Housatonic Road at this station shortly after 2 o'clock to-day.
PROVINCETOWN, June 4.--The whaling steamer A. B. Nickerson killed a large right whale off Cape Cod to-day, which was successfully towed to the oil works at Herring Cove.

ST. LOUIS, June 4.--The glass manufacturers of the United States have been contemplating the advisability of closing down this Summer, and by agreement of the leading manufacturers it was thought advisable to close down on June 15 indefinitely. Messages have been flying around the country very freely to that effect, and a leading Ohio manufacturer says the close will occur as indicated.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 4.--William A. Homan, the ex-Suspension Bridge Water Works Commissioner, who has been indicted on four different counts for appropriating bonds of the company, while a Commissioner and holding the office of Treasurer, was brought to trial in the Court of Sessions here to-day.

NORWICH, Conn., June 4.--Coroner A.F. Park of this city was summoned to Willimantic to-day to hold an inquest over the body of Conductor Charles H. Stebbins, who was killed in the railroad accident at Leonard's Station this morning. He rendered the following verdict:

A good many people go down to Wallstreet every morning as a matter of habit. They find little to interest and nothing to excite them on the Stock Exchange, nor get anything to squeeze a profit out of. The speculative world seems to be having an "off year," as the politicians phrase it.
The woman's body that was left at the Grand Central Station has been identified as that of Mrs. William Enright of Pittsfield, Mass. She was the wife of a shoemaker of dissipated habits.

A rather curious episode in natural history occurred the other day on board the French steamboat Abd-el-Kader during the passage from Marseilles to Algiers. Just as the vessel was about two hours out the sky became quite black with swallows.

CONCORD, N.H., June 4.--The new chapel of St. Peter and St. Paul at St. Paul's School will be consecrated to-morrow. The Bishops of New-York, New-Hampshire and Massachusetts, with other noted clergy, will take part in the exercises.

TRINCOMALEE, Eastern Ceylon, April 6. --A smooth land-locked bay, bright with all the glory of a true equatorial sunrise; a narrow entrance between two bold wooded bluffs, from the crest of one of which the dark gray wall of an ancient Dutch fort scowis in sullen contempt of the smart, ...
BUENOS AYRES, June 5, via Galveston.--A heavy shock of earthquake was felt here at 12:14 this morning. It is not known whether any damage was done.

ANTWERP, N.Y., June 5.--Two men were killed in the Sterling Iron Ore Mine, about four miles from this place, this afternoon. A scale weighing several tons fell from the ceiling of a drift, in which three men were working, killing Joseph Duford instantly and injuring William Bishop so that he has since died.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 5.--Detective M. M. McElheney of Cleveland, Ohio, arrived here today with requisition papers from Gov. Beaver for Michael Hitel, who was arrested here a few days ago for the killing of Andrew Tandara, a puddler, at Cleveland, on the 11th of November, 1886.

Saloon keepers have commenced a war on the "growler." The pitcher-and-kettle trade has never been very profitable, and ward organizations are being formed for the purpose of raising the price of beer and porter to be carried out of the place.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5.--Upon proceedings brought by the Southern Development Company, owners of the steamship Eureka, which was struck and sunk by the British steamship Benison off the Cape of Virginia, ...

NEW-ORLEANS, June 5.--The annual regatta of the Southern Yacht Club was held this afternoon at West End. The wind was blowing 18 miles an hour. The distance was three times over a five-mile triangular course.
David B. Hill started afresh his boom for a renomination among Brooklyn Democrats when on Monday he signed the 14 bills affecting that city.

MONTREAL, June 5.--The last act in the judicial drama connected with the robbery of the vault at the Grand Trunk Railway station last October, took place to-day, when Constable Bureau, who was watchman at the station at the time, was found guilty of complicity in the robbery and sentenced to seven years in the penitentiary.

Mr. S.J. Patterson exhibited yesterday a petrified pignut, which was found in the Tom Corwin Coal Mine, near Wellston. It was taken from the slate which covered a coal seam. A mass of rock 60 feet in thickness rested upon the slate.
PITTSBURG, June 5.--The thirteeenth annual convention of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers convened here to-day. There were over 200 delegates present.
Something new in artificial light is produced, it is claimed, through the Bunsen principle. By this system ordinary illuminating gas is treated in such a manner as to produce perfect combustion.

BUENOS AYRES, June 5, via Galyeston.--The Governor of Santa Fe will arrive here to-day for the purpose of arranging the sale of the Colonial and Santa Fe Railway, the product of the sale to be devoted to increasing the metal currency of the Provincial Bank of Rosario to 15,000,000.

The American colony in Canada will probably lose one of its members. Judge Cowing yesterday, in General Sessions, dismissed an indictment which was found Dec. 21, 1886, against Louis S. Stelnitz, who was charged with having appropriated to his own use $9,914 68, the proceeds of a note sent to him to get discounted by Carstairs, McCall Co.

The Grand Hotel had very bad luck with its awning Monday night. As told in yesterday's TIMES the Fire Department was called out to extinguish one that blazed up and set fire to the interior of an apartment on the fourth floor. Not more than an hour later another ...
Ann O'Delia Salomon, alias Diss Debar, was apparently much more interested in her pair of yellow suede gloves yesterday than anything which occurred during her trial.
The Randall Club of Pennsylvania is in St. Louis parading the streets and visiting the hotels where delegates congregate with a banner with this "strange device," "Harmony and victory."

With the exception of the ticket sellers all the old employes at Jerome Park have, since Monday, been superseded by men appointed by the Pinkerton Detective Bureau. Some of them were offered the opportunity to stand up continuously and watch the fences at $2 a day to ...

ITHACA, N.Y., June 5.--The graduating class at Cornell University numbers 120. Of these the Faculty have selected nine who are to take part in the Commencement exercises on June 21. The speakers and the subjects are:

The steam yacht Nautilus, formerly the property of the Marquis of Lorne, now lies at the foot of Twenty-third-street, Brooklyn, awaiting the settlement of a dispute between her owner, John B. Healy of New-Haven, and the customs officers.

Mayor Hewitt sat down yesterday to write an interview with himself about the absence of local office holders from the city. He saw a few reporters around, and calling them over, began to give his sentiments to them on the subject.

We are glad to know that measures are being taken for the establishment in this State of an asylum for the orphans of the colored race. It is not proposed to establish at this time a State institution.

Gordon, it was decided that the veterans of Georgia, without distinction of which side they fought on, accept the invitation of the Army of the Potomac to participate in the Gettysburg reunion in July.

Fenton of Chicago, Thomas Morgan of this city was to-day enjoined by the United States Circuit Court from infringing on the complainant's patent for toe weights for horse shoes. The shoe in question is in general use for trotting horses. The same attorney obtained a final injunction in behalf ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 5.--St. Louis is threatened with a loss of its telephone facilities. A few months ago the Municipal Assembly passed an ordinance making it a misdemeanor for any telephone company to charge more than $50 a year for the use of an instrument.

ST. LOUIS, June 5.--The regular annual meeting of the bondholders and stockholders of the St. Louis, Alton and Terre Haute Railroad Company was held at that company's office in this city to-day. General Manager George W. Parker submitted the following report of the businees for the year 1887: Gross earnings, ...
BURLINGTON, Vt., June 5.--The Lake Champlain Yacht Club, which W.H.H. Murray was instrumental in instituting, has had remarkable growth, and it now has nearly 200 members.

DETROIT, Mich., June 5.--The Mineral Range Railroad has passed into a Receiver's hands for the non-payment of the first mortgage bonds, amounting to $200,000, which matured June 1, with interest for one year. This is a narrow gauge road running from Hancock to Calumet.

The charter election in Edgewater, Staten Island, to elect one Trustee in each of the five wards took place yesterday. It was the most exciting local election ever held in Richmond County. All the candidates were Democrats.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5.--The Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy were entertained this morn ing with a steam drill by the Naval Cadets in steam launches.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 5.--The probable nomination of ex-Senator Thurman as candidate for Vice-President on the Democratic ticket leads the friends of Senator Sherman to believe that his strength will be greatly increased, and that he will be nominated at Chicago without much of a contest. The Hon. Warner Miller of New-York is referred to as the probable choice for the second place in the event Mr. Sherman is nominated.

The funeral of Benjamin R. Maginley, the veteran actor, was held yesterday afternoon at St. Peter's Church in West Chester. The Rector, the Rev. F.N. Clendennin, read the burial service, after which the body was carried to the grave in the churcyard beside that of his wife, where a deputation of the Elks conducted the funeral rites of their order.

ST. LOUIS, June 5.--As soon as the New-York delegation could get out of the hall it was driven in carriages to the residence of Sir Charles Gibson for lunch. Sir Charles's home is on the outskirts of the city.

AUBURN, N.Y., June 5.--The June Fair of the County Agricultural Society is a great success. In the hose company contests to-day the Nestors of Geneva won the first prize, $200. The Waterloo Company took the second prize $100, while Hose No. 6 of Auburn took the third prize of $60, and Hose No. 7 of Auburn was awarded the fourth prize $40.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 5.--The annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company was held in this city to-day, Thomas D. Messler acting as Chairman.

QUEENSTOWN, June 5.--The British steamer British Princess, Capt. Freith, from Philadelphia May 23, for Liverpool, which arrived at this port this morning, met the French gunboat Crocodile, bound from the Azores for St. Pierre on the 29th of May in latitude 41 north, longitude 49 west. The Crocodile was destitute of coal and provisions. With great difficulty the British Princess supplied her with 35 tons of coal and a quantity of provisions.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 5.--A construction engine on the Cleveland and Mahoning Valley Railroad wad derailed near Niles, Ohio this morning and wrecked. Harry Schofield and John Rosenberg of Warren, Ohio, were killed. Both were married.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 5.--The Board of Pardons has made known its decision refusing to commute to life imprisonment the sentence of Philip Palladoni, the frarticide who is condemned to be hanged in, October next.
The amateur championship billiard tournament at the Racquet Club created a very pronounced revival of interest in the game among amateurs throughout the city.

BALTIMORE, June 5.--Elaborate arrangements are being made for, the National Saengerfest which is to be held here the last of this month. A large attendance of singing societies from different parts of the country is expected.

John B. Murray, the aged lawyer who was recently removed from his wife and home by his sister, Agnes Murray, has returned to his residence, 13 Washington-place, and is said to be suffering from nervous fright excited by fears that his sister will attempt another effort, to remove him from his home.

Miss Catherine T. Simonds Monday completed 50 years of most faithful service as teacher in the Franklin School of this city, having commenced her labors on the first Monday of June, 1838.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 5.--The steamtug Nellie left here this morning for Wood's Holl to lay a submarine cable from Wood's Holl to Naushon, which is to be part of the Government cable to be laid from Pasqua to Gay Head, the connection across Robinson's Hole to be laid later.

WASHINGTON, June 5.--The marriage of Miss Grace Matthews, youngest daughter of Justice Stanley Matthews, and Mr. John Harlan Cleveland, a nephew of Justice Harlan, took place at high noon to-day at the Matthews residence.

At the cigarette factory of W. Duke, Sons Co., at Twenty-ninth-street and First-avenue, some trouble arose yesterday which resulted in about 26 of the girls employed in the machine department going on strike.

James F. Porter of Gravesend, Long Island, was yesterday arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court for larceny. Dr. K.R. Taylor of 245 West Forty-third-street swore that on April 20 he loaned Porter $30 upon the latter representing to him that he would repay him at an early date with money that he would borrow of Edwin Rulon of 1,491 Broadway.
Inspector Tunbridge of Scotland Yard, London, enjoyed, as much as he could yesterday afternoon the experience of a live American examination in supplementary proceedings.

Brig.-Gen. A.W. Greely was present last night at Kane Lodge, No. 454 F. and A.M., of which he is an honorary member. He was introduced to the Master of the Lodge, Thomas E. Stewart, by Charles Appleby, and was given the "Grand Honors."

There was a collision in the North River off Thirty-fourth-street yesterday afternoon between Commodore Bateman's yacht Meteor and the Hudson River steamer City of Kingston. The Meteor had just got under way and was steaming across the river when the City of Kingston came to close water. The vessels met with considerable of a shock.

Edward P. Hatch of 1,033 Fifth-avenue, while playing polo at Orange, N.J., yesterday was thrown from his horse. His thigh was broken by the fall. He was brought on the cars to the Hoboken Ferry and then taken to his home in an ambulance. Mr. Hatch is a dry goods merchant at 901 Broadway and is a member of the Union League Club.

BOSTON, June 5.--The body of John Newman, a driver of one of the city teams in Chelsea, was found near the Chelsea Bridge on Sunday last. An autopsy held to-day showed that his skull had been fractured and the body bruised and cut. It is sup- posed that he was murdered. He was seen last on Friday, June 1.

ALBANY, June 5.--Messrs. E.R. Kennedy, J. Montgomery Hare, and Charles Sewall, constituting a committee from the Board of Fire Underwriters of New-York, with Julien T. Davies as counsel, appeared before the Governor this afternoon in opposition to Vedder's bill to equalize the taxation of corporations.
The attendance at yesterday's sessions of the International Congress of Anthropology at Columbia College was very much greater than on the preceding day.

The charges on which the Gloucester schooner Ambrose H. Knight has just been seized at St. John's, in Newfoundland, adds a novel element to the fishery dispute.

CONCORD, N.H., June 5.--The consecration of the Chapel of St. Peter and St. Paul at St. Paul's School took place to-day. Bishop H.C. Potter of New-York preached the sermon. There were 44 of the clergy present.

The most enthusiastic friends and supporters of the Metropolican Musical Society could not have hoped for a greater degree of approbation than was accorded by the audience at Chickering Hall last night at its rehearsal.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 5.--A general strike of masons, bricklayers, and plasterers to-day, insion of building operations in this city. The demand is for nine hours instead of ten for a day's work.
ST. LOUIS, June 5.--The attention of the New-Yorkers was diverted somewhat from the convention and its possibilities by a bit of news from home which created much excitement an discussion among them.

The members of the ninth company, Seventh Regiment, last night elected eight new members, making a membership of 125, only 103 of whom are allowed in the ranks by law. The Chaplain, the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, and George W. Fairchild were elected honorary members.
