William Sexton and Maurice Daly have stopped practicing for the Cincinnati billiard tournament, it having been decided not to hold it.
St. Paul and Reading were the weak sisters in yesterday's stock market. The former yielded and went down on sales by insiders, helped along by bad earning reports given out by the Granger roads.
The sea serpent, that deceptive monster, made his first appearance of the present season on Sunday last off Jones's Beach, near Fire Island.
Archdeacon Farrar certainly made a great mistake in his lecture in Westminster Abbey in describing the author of "The Complete Angler and Contemplative Man's Recreation" as a Nonconformist.

The Concord Summer School of Philosophy will hold one session, after all, this year. It will be a memorial of the man whose sole personal ambition it fulfilled, the Dean of its unsystemized but catholic and spiritual Faculty, the transcendentalist Alcott. This is excellent.

BALTIMORE, June 5.--The Board of Trade at its monthly meeting yesterday adopted a resolution requesting that Congress remove the duty on sugar altogether, or, it that is incompatible with the new tariff bill, that the lowest rate of duty be extended to embrace No. 18, Dutch standard. The resolution declares that the proposed duty on sugar, as indicated by the Mills bill, gives greater protection to the sugar trust than ever.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 5.--The annual convention of the Connecticut Diocese will be held at Christ Church in this city beginning Tuesday, June 12. Bishop Williams will preside during the two days' session.

CHICAGO, June 5.--The judicial election yesterday in Illinois brought out only a very light vote generally.
PARIS, May 20.--M. Richepin is a great favorite here, and deservedly so, for his work not only shows thought and a deep love for his art, but it gives the pleasanter, rarer quality of inspiration.

WASHINGTON, June 5.--The bond offerings today aggregated $151,000 as follows: Registered 4s, $50,000 at 127 7/8; registered 4 s, $1,000 at 108 and $100,000 at 107. None of the offers were accepted.

Roundsman Peasley and three policemen of the Thirty-seventh-street police station last night arrested a gang of 10 men who are in the habit of assaulting and robbing people on Eighth-avenue in the neighborhood of Twenty-seventh-street.
ST. LOUIS, June 5.--Convention day dawned with clouds of smoke and mist hanging low over the city and with the air hot and ominously oppressive.
The Larchmont Spring Regatta, which will occur Saturday, is promising to be a very large one. Members of most of the large yacht clubs will compete.
The plans for the new church edifice of the Tompkins-Avenue Congregational Society have been finished, and work has commenced at Tompkins-avenue and McDonough-street.

Mrs. Burnett's dramatic version of her story "Little Lord Fauntleroy," now playing at matinees in Terry's Theatre, London, has been secured for this country by T. Henry French.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 5.--Great interest is manifested here in the experiment that is about to be made in propelling vessels by electricity. A yacht built by the Messrs. Bigler for the Electric Light Company of Newark, N. J., is being fitted with machinery that will be run by electricity stored in batteries. The yacht is 38 feet long and 9 feet breadth of beam.

The world moves. Kentucky Bourbon prejudice gives way apace. James W. Schooler of Nicholasville, a colored man, has been admitted to practice in the Kentucky Court of Appeals. Republican opinion has some weight in Old Kentucky, and will be dominant ere many years pass away.
PORTLAND, Oregon, June 5.--As returns come in from remote counties the plurality for Hermann, Republican, for Congress, increases, and it is safe to put down his plurality at not less than 3,500.

Police Commissioner French presented "honorable mention" badges yesterday to the officers on the police force who were unable to be present at the police parade when the honors were generally distributed.

RICHMOND, Va., June 5.--G.B. George, manager of the Joseph Davis Shoe Company of Lynn, Mass., contractors for convict labor in the Virginia Penitentiary, committed suicide this morning in the penitentiary yard by shooting himself in the temple.

BOLTON, Lake George, June 5.--One of the prime movers in the project to build a new boulevard along the west shore of Lake George and otherwise beautify the neighborhood and make it attractive to Summer visitors is the Hon. John C. Adams of Newburg.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 5.--The unique case of Elia S. Brown against J.R. McCollum, at Clarion, has been decided in favor of the plaintiff by the jury. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 5.--The statistics for the Class of 1888, Yale University, have just made their appearance and develop some very striking features. Politically the class is divided into 70 Republicans, 13 Democrats, 17 Independents, 1 Prohibitionist, while 8 are undecided.

LONDON, June 5.--The prospectus--of the new Reading 4 per cents was circulated around the Stock Exchange to-day, and the bonds quickly rose to a premium.

There seems to be an epidemic of horticulture this June. Many of the cemeteries have been purloined of Decoration Day flowers as never before. In contrast Jerome Park has found that its patrons have no taste for blos soms. It spent $300 in sodding a large plot and cultivating slips, and the trampling of racegoers has been so effective that probably the whole plant could now be bought for a ten-dollar note.

CHICAGO, June 5.--The De Golyer Varnish Company, one of the oldest concerns in its line of business in the country, failed to-day. Attorney Frank S. Weigley in the Superior Court entering judgments aggregating nearly $122,000 against it.

CHARLESTON, West Va., June 5.--J. H. Clarborne, who shot and killed Nelson Lee at the Hotel Ruffner Sunday, had a preliminary examination to day and was remanded to jail to await the action of the Grand Jury. The excitement among the colored people continues, and military and private citizens are patroling the streets, the former having been called out by the Governor.

POTSDAM, June 5.--Emperor Frederick passed a good night. He arose at 10 o'clock and went out upon the terrace. He was without any headache. This morning he received reports from Gens. von Albedyll and von Rauch and Count von Radolin-Radolinski.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 5.--The Democratic State Convention completed its ticket and adjourned at 4 o'clock this afternoon. Following are the nominations: For Governor, John P. Eagle; Secretary of State, Ben B. Chism; Auditor, W.S. Dunlop; Commissioner of State Lands, Paul W. Cobbs; Superintendent of Public Schools, W.E. Thompson; Electors at Large, W. E. Heming way and W. Fishback.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 5.--At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Reform Club this evening committees were appointed and arrangements made for inaugurating the tariff reform movement throughout the State.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 5.--Two remarkable escapes from violent deaths occurred here to-day. A 3-year-old child of Joseph Scully fell from a four-story window on a brick walk and escaped with a fractured arm. Henry O'Grady, aged 17, jumped from a West Shore train running 25 miles an hour. He received simply a cut on the scalp and a few bruises.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 5.--A murder, of which a woman was the cause, has excited the usually quiet little town of Gaithersburg, Montgomery County, Md. Edward Watkins and Bud Trail were infatuated with a Mrs. Norwood, a comely widow who occupies a tenant house on the farm of L.L. Watkins.

Luther R. Marsh, the well-known lawyer, whose name has recently been prominently connected with the prosecution of the Diss Debars, was on his way to the General Sessions Court yesterday to testify in that case, when his progress was stopped by an accident at Twentysixth-street and Fourth-avenue.
Edmund C. Stanton's trip to Europe in behalf of the Metropolitan Opera House Company did him more good than any tonic he could have taken.

It was actors' day yesterday, and from their scattered homes in the city and the outposts of Brooklyn and Jersey all paths led to the Madison-Square Theatre, where exercises to celebrate the seventh anniversary of the Actors' Fund Association were held.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 5.--The American Home Missionary Society (Congregationalist) began its sixty-second anniversary at the WashingtonStreet Methodist Episcopal Church to-day. President Seelye of Amherst College, the President of the society, presided.

It is reported that the Hon. Hannibal Hamlin will attend the Republican State Convention in Portland as a delegate, holding the proxy of B.B. Thatcher, Esq., who was chosen a delegate from Ward Seven, Bangor. If he goes, Mr. Hamlin will have something to say and will say it.

The fair and festival in aid of the Grant monument fund, under the auspices of the Shakespeare Society, was continued yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House. The thing that awakened the most curiosity was Charles L. Marshall's stereoscopic incubator, a wooden box pierced with 12 peep holes.

Dow, agent for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, who arrived on the steamer Colon, from Aspinwall yesterday, stated last night that the steamer City of Para, before reported ashore at Old Providence, lies in an easy position, and that on the arrival of the wrecking tug I.J. Merritt the prospects of getting her off would be very good.

FREDERICTON, New-Brunswick, June 5.-- Duncan Good's house and barn at Howland Ridge have been burned by a series of mysterious fires. The first fire broke out on Thursday and did considerable damage. Fresh fires were discovered in different parts of the house on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, each doing some damage. Yesterday the final fire broke out, consuming all that remained of the house and barn.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 5.--Deputy United States Marshals Phil Bunn and Thomas B. Love came in to-day with four moonshiners from Clay County. The officers report a desperate state of affairs in Clay.

The Columbia College Freshman crew has gone to New-London. Such as could went Monday afternoon on the City of Boston, of the Norwich Line, taking the shells and other equipment for the training preparatory to the race with the Harvard Freshmen about July 1.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 5, via Galveston.--A railway accident occurred yesterday evening just outside of Tampico, in which many lives were lost. A construction train was derailed near a bridge by a cow and a donkey which were on the track. The train crashed through the bridge and went down an embankment. The dead and injured were brought in to-day. So far as known 18 were killed and 41, injured.

The Republicans from various parts of New-York State who remained in this city yesterday seemed to be surprised at the accounts in the evening newspapers of the enthusiasm displayed among the Democrats at St. Louis over the impending renomination of President Cleveland.

BOSTON, Mass., June 5.--Gov. Ames this evening gave a reception at his elegant Back Bay residence to the commissioned officers of the Massachusetts Militia, to which the Ancient and Honorables and their guests were also invited.

TRENTON, N.J., June 5.--Barclay W. Peak, the slayer of Katie Anderson, his cousin, will be sentenced on Wednesday, June 13. The Supreme Court fixed the date to-day, at the request of Prosecutor Hendrickson of Burlington County.

HAVANA, June 5.--Considerable damage has been done on some plantations in the districts of Baracoa and Guantanamo by a rainstorm.

HELENA, Montana, June 5.--The body of Samuel Blake, a young man from Butte, was today exhumed from the ruins of the Red Light Lodging House, which was burned Sunday night. Companions tried to save Blake, but he was in a drunken slumber and could not be roused.

These transcontinental excursions have now obtained a permanent hold on all the railroads. Every railroad is bidding for them. They are a source of so much profit that the temptation to "cut rates" is almost irresistible.

The alterations now being made in the granite building on the corner of Hamiltonplace and Tremont-street make it correspond in external appearance with the other buildings in this block, and for the first time give the five stores an air of having been originally designed for the purpose, instead of having been "made over" from dwellings.

Adam Rhinehart, a boss painter, left his home at 23 Whipple-street, Brooklyn, on Saturday last to take his two children, aged 3 and 6 years old, respectively, to the theatre at Reid avenue and Broadway, and has not since returned.

The will of the late Hannah C. Flickwir, who was famous for her benovolence, was admitted to probate yesterday. The estate is valued at $150,000, while the private bequests and various trusts created by the testarix dispose of an estate amounting to $370,000.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 5.--This afternoon a fire swept over Wards Nos. 4 and 5 of the city of Hull, opposite Ottawa, destroying between 300 and 450 houses, and rendering over 2,500 persons homeless. Six or seven blocks are now a smoldering mass of ruins.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 5.--Dudley Porter, son-of ex-Gov. Porter of Tennessee, who was shot and killed at Paris, Tenn., on Monday evening, attended Eastman College, in this city, a number of years ago. While here he shot A.M. Doty, a prominent druggist of this place. Mr. Doty narrowly escaped with his life.

Deputy Coroner O'Meagher went to the late residence of Jaremiah Shea yesterday afternoon for the purpose of holding an autopsy on Shea's body. Shea's family protested and the Coroner left the house. He will make another visit this morning under police protection and will hold the autopsy despite the objections. In the opinion of the Coroner death was due to a rupture of the stomach.

The Mahhattan Athletic Club is in boiling water again. With the approval of the Board of Governors, Harry Pike, Chairman of the Athletic Committee, has written to a number of Manhatten Athletes who have entered in next Saturday's games of the Pastime Athletic Club that they must not compete.

ST. LOUIS, June 5.--The Committee on Resolutions met in the large parlor of the Southern Hotel at 5 o'clock, and it soon treated the crowd that waited outside to a surprise.

Joseph J. O'Donohue's resignation as Vice-President of the Coffee Exchange was accepted yesterday at a special meeting of the Board of Managers, 11 members of which were present, including George W. Crossman, President of the Exchange.

The new way of playing whist--duplicate whist as they call it--is already causing the most intense excitement in whist-playing circles, and wherever I go, in my whist-playing capacity I mean, I find the pros and cons of the new method of playing the game being vigorously--nay, in some cases, almost fiercely-- discussed.

One of the most notable weddings of the season was that of Miss Josefa Howard Neilson and Robert Arthur Osborn, who were married yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock by the Rev. Dr. Rainsford of St. George's at the residence of the bride's parents, in Gramercy Park.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 5.--The second day's shooting in the match between Chevalier Ira A. Paine of Providence and Frederick E. Bennett of Boston, at Hampden Park, in this city, this afternoon, resulted in a victory for Bennett, who scored 887 points to his opponent's 879, thus ...

At the meeting of the New-York Historical Society last evening it was announced that $105,000 had already been subscribed toward the fund of $150,000, which must be raised by Nov. 1 in order to secure the $100,000 offered conditionally by an unknown patron for the purpose of crecting new and more ample quarters for the society.
In the years gone by the Philadelphia Bar was eminent for its learning, ability, and eloquence.
LONDON, June 5.--The Hanover Cotton Mills, containing 15,000 spindles, were burned to-day. Three hundred persons are thrown out of work.

The memorial window to President Arthur that will be placed by his friends is Trinity Church, Lenox, Mass., has just been completed by the Tiffany Glass Company. It is 9 feet high and 5 feet wide, and contains several thousand pieces of glass, put together so as to give the desired effect without painting.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 5.--Neither the general reduction in rates announced by the Burlington and Northern nor the particular reduction of the St. Paul and Kansas City was met by the other St. Paul roads yesterday.

Royal S. Crane, counsel for Barton B. Higgins of 52 West Twenty-second-street, is making an active search for E. Berry Wall to serve papers on him and insure his presence in the City Court on supplementary proceedings.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 5.--A curious mix-up occurred in Quarter Sessions yesterday. Adaline and Sarah Bolier, mother and daughter, colored residents of the Welsh Mountain, were tried for receiving stolen chickens, and the evidence against the mother was conclusive.

PARIS, June 5.--The majority of the morning newspapers regard Gen. Boulanger's statement of the policy which he outlined in his speech before the Chamber of Deputies yesterday as confused, contradictory, and absurd.

PETERSBURG, Va., June 5.--Martha White colored, aged 19 years, was struck and instantly killed to-day in Chesterfield County by the engine of the passenger train coming to this city from Richmond. She was seen to run upon the track just ahead of the engine, and was knocked dead into the ditch. The supposition is that he intention was suicidal.
CONCORD, N.H., June 5.--The first day's events of the thirteenth annual Spring meeting of the St. Paul's school Athletic Association took place to-day. Three records were broken.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5.--The wife of the Rev. Olof Schroeder, Pastor of St. John's German Church of the Missouri Synod at Wharton and Barlow streets, who threw her little baby out of the second-story window of the parsonage, 524 Wharton-street, adjoining the church, on Sunday, jumped out of the same ...

The war of rates which has been going on between the railroads that run from Chicago to St. Paul is likely to bring at least one of the companies into conflict with the "long and short haul" provision of the inter-State commerce law.

We have already called attention to the straits to which the leaders of the Knights of Labor have been reduced in their crusade against "pool beer." The power of the leaders, who appear to be Knights "for revenue only," rests upon their ability to force their followers to abstain from boycotted products.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 6.--The Western cut nail manufacturers, at their meeting here to-day, adopted a new card, making the base from 12 to 40-penny. The change advances 10penny nails 10 cents, and 50 to 60-penny 25 cents. The trade is very dull.

Samuel C. Smith, an ex-policeman, died Tuesday night at his home, 145 Monticelloavenue, Jersey City, of hydrophobia.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--"Another 24 hours like this and the General will be on the road to recovery," was the cheering comment on Gen. Sheridan's condition made by one of his official attendants late this afternoon.

It is expected that the special committee of the State Senate of which Mr. FASSETT is Chairman will to-morrow resume its investigation of municipal affairs in this city. Precisely what the course of its inquiries will be has not been announced.

The fun which began with Dr. Landis's appearance at Industrial Hall on Monday night came near having a serious ending before the close of the performance last night. The audience had been pelting the "actor" with oranges, paper balls, and ham sandwiches.

There was an affecting scene in the Diss Debar trial yesterday, which took the audience by surprise and settled a long-disputed relationship. George Francis Train, clad in an avowedly five-dollar suit, appeared in court after a hasty trip from Canada.

PANAMA, May 28.--The news that the Pacific Mail steamer City of Para had been lost at sea was brought here by the New-Orleans and Colombian steamer Madrid, which was on her way from Colon to New-Orleans when hailed by the City of Para, stranded on Old Providence Island.
LONDON, June 6.--A semi-panic occurred in the market for diamond mine shares to-day owing to the bank's refusing to make advances with the shares as security. Some shares fell 5 per cent.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., June 6.--The wife of George Herkimer of this city, proprietor of a knit goods factory, left her husband last Wednesday and went to Fairchild, a village 30 miles from Eau Claire, taking her baby with her.

Henry Vincent, a dapper-looking Englishman, applied to Justice Smith, at the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, for advice regarding his legal rights in an alleged dispute between himself and Mayor Hewitt.

Charles and Albert Skinner, while driving across the tracks of the Culver Road just beyond Gravesend station, at 12:23 yesterday afternoon, were struck by a down-bound train and instantly killed. They were brothers, aged 26 and 22 years respectively, and in conjunction with John J. O'Brien's son, owned the ponies on...

PANAMA, May 28.--The Star and Herald says: "The locks which are being constructed on the Panama Canal are not designed to be a permanent feature of the canal, but have been adopted through the necessities of completing the work and opening up the canal within the required time.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 6.--The news that the Co-operative Life and Accident Association of 171 Broadway, New-York, has been placed under ban by the State Insurance Department causes no little stir and anxiety among its thousands of policy holders in this quarter.

One of the new conductors on the Jersey Central Road met a "spotter" on his first trip. He pretended, of course, to be an ordinary passenger, and not having a ticket attempted to suborn the conductor.

Peter McDermott, aged 32 years, a blacksmith, residing at 484 East Seventy-fourthstreet, was arrested yesterday evening on suspicion of having killed his father, Patrick McDermott, aged 65 years, at his residence yesterday afternoon.
DOVER, Del., June 6.--Dr. Leighton Coleman of Sayre, Penn., was elected Bishop by the Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of Delaware to-night, to succeed Bishop Alfred H. Lee, deceased.
Treasurer Bleckwein of Long Island City yesterday refused to pay Excise Commissioners Reilly, Murray, and Slattery the $25 claimed by each as salary for May.

CHICAGO, June 6.--The annual meeting of stockholders of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company was held to-day. Five Directors whose term of service had expired were re-elected, leaving the personnel of the board unchanged. The Directors subsequently re-elected are old officers.

MOUTH OF THE IRRAWADDY, Lower Burmah, April 4.--My last letter ended with our arrival at Madras, and the coming on board of the Maharajah of Vizianagram as a passenger up the coast. His Highness went with us as far as Calcutta, and his presence gave to the humdrum European ...

The St. Louis Convention presents to the people a candidate and a principle. Of the candidate they have already once recorded a favorable judgment. The principle is now first put before them as the dominant issue of a national contest.
June 17, 1775, a British man-of-war lying in the Mystic River threw a cannon ball at the little American army intrenched on Bunker Hill.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 6.--It is made public to-day that the accounts of M.L. Lichtenstein, lately Secretary and Treasurer of the Perpetual Building and Loan Association, show a shortage of $33,250.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 6.--News was received in this city this afternoon that the schooner Blanche of Colbourne, Ontario, is supposed to be lost with all on board.
DENVER, Col., June 6.--Jay Gould and party are still at the Iron Springs Hotel, Manitou. Mr. Gould said to-day that he had enjoyed a thorough night's rest and this morning was feeling quite well.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 6.--The City Council last night paid the first installment of the debt due the colored voters of the city. It will be remembered that at the last municipal election the Republicans refrained from putting up a municipal ticket, but while they cast their ...
NEW-ORLEANS, June 6.--The Signal Service reports a rainfall from 12:30 to 2:10 this afternoon of 2.84 inches, of which two inches fell in one hour, from 12:30 to 1:30.
Policemen Ryerson and Dougherty of Jersey City were tried yesterday in the Hudson County Court of General Sessions of assault and battery on John Boyd and false imprisonment.

In about one month's time six of the family of William Miller, at Stony Run, Berks County, have died. Mrs. Miller first died. Since then five of his children have been carried away by malignant diphtheria.

Since the last report made by the St. John's Guild the following contributions for building and furnishing the new wing at the Seaside Nursery and making necessary repairs and alterations to the Floating Hospital have been received:

DETROIT, Mich., June 6.--G.A. Sheley Co., dealers in gas fixtures and imported novelties in this city, made an assignment this morning. Mr. Sheley went into that business about eight years ...

Manager Frohman has finally decided to close the first season of the Lyceum with the performance of Saturday, June 16, which will be the two hundred and thirty-ninth representation of "The Wife." The season has been extended seven weeks beyond the time originally fixed for its close, which is a remarkable record for...

HAVANNA, June 6.--The troops pursuing the banditti twice came up with the fugitives in the Province of Santa Clara and killed six of them. It is not thought that there can be now an organized band in existence.

At an auction sale of stocks and bonds on the Real Estate Exchange yesterday five shares of the Chemical National Bank were sold at 3,400, 58 shares of Mechanics' National Bank at 167 , and 13 shares of Merchants' National Bank at 140 .

AUBURN, N.Y., June 6.--The First Presbyterian Church in this city was this afternoon the scene of two weddings, the contracting parties in each being very prominent in the leading social circles of Auburn.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Tooker, daughter of Commodore Joseph H. Tooker, to Victor A. Seggerman, took place at noon yesterday in a parlor of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. The Rev. R. Heber Newton was the officiating clergyman and J.H. Tooker, Jr., was the best man.

A trade sale of 15,000 dozens of silk handkerchiefs and mufflers by order of the Phoenix Manufacturing Company, which has mills at Allentown and Pottsville, Penn., and Paterson, N.J., was held yesterday morning at the auction...

AUBURN, N.Y., June 6.--Seven thousand persons to-day attended the June fair. The chief attraction was a balloon ascension and a parachute descent by Prof. Hogan of Jackson, Mich., who dropped 5,000 feet and landed safe two miles from the place of starting.

WEST POINT, June 6.--This has been a great day for the big guns. This does not refer to Prof. Lummis and the other big guns of the Board of Visitors, for every day is a great one for them. The entire post is at their disposal, and in the classic language of the day, they own the earth.

ST. LOUIS, June 6.--Grover Cleveland is the candidate of the Democratic Party for President--renominated with a degree of enthusiasm remarkable in a period that has seen some of the most remarkable demonstrations of the popularity of public men.

LOWELL, Mass., June 6.--The Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston with their English guests arrived at Tyng's Island in the Merrimack River this morning by special train.

It is true that Lord WOLSELEY did not present a particularly edifying spectacle in virtually retracting in the House of Lords the indiscreet but accurate criticisms of the British Army that he had permitted himself to make at a public dinner.

LONDON, June 6.--Advices from Zanzibar state that the Italian Consul at that place has hauled down the Italian flag and suspended relations with the Sultan. An Italian man-of-war is expected to arrive shortly.

Application for a warrant for the arrest of ex-Senator John J. Kiernan for contempt of court was made to Judge Van Wyck, in the City Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, by Lawyer H.E. Yonge, as counsel for Eugene G. Blackford.

BREWSTER'S, N.Y., June 6.--A general convention of the various societies for the detection of horse thieves in Eastern New-York and Western Connecticut was held here this afternoon. A large number of delegates attended, and after a prolonged session the object ...
ALBANY, June 6.--Gov. Hill did very little official work to-day. He had the bulletins from the St. Louis Convention taken at the telegraph office in the Capitol for him.

SUPERIOR, Wis., June 6.--The walls of the hotel being constructed by the Land and River Improvement Company here fell in at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon. Five men were buried in the debris and five others were injured.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 6.--A terrific cyclone passed over the city this afternoon, creating great damage. It came from the southwest, and swept everything in its path. Dwellings were blown down, and the streets are filled with debris.

The Hamburg-American steamship Wieland, which sails for Hamburg to-day, has among her passengers Consul Emil Peters, Dr. L. Straus, Capt. Carl Seemann, Baron Leon von Ossko, Dr. and Mrs. Hugo F. Mayer, the Rev. L. Louis Gambosville, Dr. V. McCabe, the Rev. and Mrs. Theodore Lingby, and Richard Brandt.
CHICAGO, June 6.--W.J. Spicer of the firm of Spicer Dunham, sign painters, shot himself to-night in front of the house in which his wife is living.

The new Methodist church at Hackettstown, N.J., was dedicated yesterday. It cost $50,000 and is free of debt. Bishop Force preached the dedicatroy sermon. There was a great outpouring of people to attend the services.
ST. LOUIS, June 6.--There was a flurry in the Democratic camp to-night when it was discovered that the New York delegation showed a strong disposition to drop Thurman overboard and take up Gray.
Charles Bolderman, a walking delegate of Hod Carriers' Union No. 3 of Brooklyn, went to 85 Johnson-avenue, in the Eastern District, where a building is being erected, on Tuesday...

BATON ROUGE, La., June 6.--The Legislature to-day adopted a concurrent resolution praying for the passage of the Blair Educational bill by Congress.

Arthur Thomas and Joseph Hall, first and second officers of the steamer Llandaff City, were held in $1,500 bail each by United States Commissioner Shields yesterday for examination for assaulting Customs Officers Charles A. Reilly and ...

It was frightfully hot at Jerome Park yesterday afternoon. Every one knew it would be, yet a fairly good crowd went up to the park to see the day's racing, of which the run for the Ladies' Stakes between a good lot of 3-year-old fillies was the chief feature.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--In both the Senate and the House of Representatives much more interest was felt to-day in the news from St. Louis than in the legislative matters before the two houses. Bulletins were received every two or three minutes while the convention was in session.

Frank R. Newell, aged 18, who was indicted under the name of Thomas Jones for robbery in the first degree, second offense, was acquitted in Part III, of the General Sessions Court yesterday, apparently because the jury did not have faith in the methods of identification made use of at Police Headquarters.

There has just been finished by a wood carver in this city a group representing the baptism of the Saviour, which is intended for the baptistry of St. Vincent's Church at Vallejo. The carving is of California redwood and was executed at a cost of $1,000.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 6.--The Citizens' Committee who have the celebration and military review in honor of the opening of the Queen Victoria Niagara Falls Park on the Cana dian side in hand completed final arrangements last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6.--Judge Arnold granted an injunction for James R. Taylor, a broker, against the Philadelphia Local Telegraph Company, restraining them from taking their tickers out of Taylor's office at 29 South Third-street. Taylor was a member of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 6.--The jury in the case of William A. Homan, the ex-Suspension Bridge Water Works Commissioner, on trial for embezzlement of bonds, after being out four hours, came in this afternoon and failed to agree.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6.--The British bark Balaklava arrived yesterday from London after a remarkably long voyage of one year and seventy-four days.

CHICAGO, June 6.--The stockholders of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad held their annual meeting to-day, re-electing the old Board of Directors and the following officers: President--H.H. Porter; Vice-Presidents--O.S. ...

CATSKILL, N.Y., June 6.--The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America began its eighty-second regular annual session in the Reformed Church here this afternoon. The Rev. C.F. Shepard of Newtown, Long Island, ...

The striking cigarette makers of the factory of W. Duke, Sons Co. were out all day yesterday, and declared that they would not return to work until the two girls who were transferred from the machine department to the handmaking department were reinstated in their old places.

George Atkinson, 21 years of age, of 293 Adams-street, Brooklyn, and employed as a collector by the Shea Brothers' Towing and Transportation Company, was given a check on Tuesday drawn on the Bank of North America for $350, the amount to be handed over to his employers.

UTICA, N.Y., June 6.--Prof. Charles A. Borst, assistant astronomer in the Litchfield Observatory, Hamilton College, who was elected a Fellow in the Department of Mathematics and Astronomy in Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore has accepted.

SARATOGA, N.J., June 6.--The sixty-sec ond annual session of the American Home Missionary Society opened here to-day. The President, J.H. Seelye, D.D., LL. D., addressed the society on "The Gospel, the Great Need for Social Regeneration."

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 6.--A terrific windstorm struck this city about 8 o'clock this morning and has raged with more or less intensity since. Branches of trees, shrubs, and plants have been broken off and strew the streets and gardens of the city.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Vermont and Massachusetts Railroad Company was held at Boston yesterday. The old Board of Directors were re-elected with the exception of W.H. Hill, whose place was filled by Charles A. Welsh.

There is a sensation in the town of Dartmouth, Mass., over printed notices posted in public places, signed by the Selectmen, forbid ding all persons doing work on the Sabbath unless it is necessary or for charitable purposes.

The New-York Baptist Ministers' Conference the other day had a rather suggestive experience. Some gentleman had been invited to speak on "Social Problems," who is Vice-President of the Nineteenth Century Club, and avowed himself an agnostic.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 6.--The ninety-fourth Commencement of Williams Collego will begin next Monday with the Senior examination. On Sunday, June 24, at 10:30 A.M., the Rev. Phillips Brooks, D.D., of Boston, will deliver an address to the Mills Young ...
All the brick yards at Verplanck's Point were at work yesterday except two, and they are trying to make up for the lost time occasioned by the strike of the Knights of Labor.

There was another large attendance at the sessions of the Anthropological Congress, at Columbia College, yesterday. The President, Dr. E.C. Mann, occupied the chair, and Prince Roland Bonaparte sat at his right on the platform.
ST. LOUIS, June 6.--The St. Louis Republic will publish the following double-loaded editorial in the morning:

CHICAGO, June 6.--For some time the Eastern railroads have been putting on lines of big lake steamers, and so successful have they been that they now carry a big proportion of the lake freight. Private vessel men here say that these steamers will eventually monopolize all the trade, and they are much worried over the prospect.

The application of Procter Turner, theatrical managers, to erect an entirely new building for theatrical purposes on the site of the old Tabernacle at Twenty-third-street between Sixth and Seventh avenues, has been granted, and the plans have been approved.

The Grant Monument Fair, conducted by the Shakesperean Society, which has been in progress in the Metropolitan Opera House since Monday, has been so successful that it has been decided to continue it for the rest of the week.

The New-Yorks played in poor form yesterday, and allowed the Indianapolis men to win a game from them. Crane, who pitched, filled his position acceptably, not a run being earned off his delivery, but the support given him was of the worst character.

A.J. Miller, District Attorney of Putnam County, and Annie P., daughter of William G. Ganung, one of the oldest merchants of Brewster's, were married at the residence of the bride's parents in Brewster's yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Eli D. Sutcliffe of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church.

ST. LOUIS, June 6.--Most of the Tammany men here were in bed when the news of the fire in their wigwam reached this city this morning, but they gathered at their headquarters in a short time and talked the matter over. The pecuniary loss affected them much less than the sentimental features.

DETROIT, Mich., June 6.--The output of the Lake Superior Copper mines for May was: Calumet and Hecla, 2,600 tons; Tamarack, 600 tons; Atlantic, 230 tons; Oceola, 210 tons; Franklin, 185 tons, and Quincy, 183 tons, the small yield of the latter being due to the fact that the stamp mill was run only half the time during the month.

CHICAGO, June 6.--Mrs. E.H. Waldron to-day began suit for $100,000 against Mrs. E. H. Waldron. The plaintiff was divorced from Mr. Waldron about a year ago and the defendant married him about six months later.
The Manhattan and Staten Island Cricket Clubs played an interesting match at Prospect Park yesterday, on what a veteran cricketer said was the best wicket he ever played on in any country.

The Widow Blaudville, who kept a stationery store at Perth Amboy, died a few days ago rather suddenly. A few hours before her death she seemed to be in excellent health. She complained of feeling badly and Dr. Wilson was summoned, but could do nothing for her.

Mr. George Lewis of Richwood is 82 years of age, and yet this octogenarian walked from Richwood to his son's, Mr. G.D. Lewis's house, Galt, on Tuesday. The distance is said to be 20 miles, which the sturdy old veteran covered in exactly six hours, including stoppages on the way to chat with old acquaintances.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 6.--The Bell Telephone Company to-day took 12 telephones out of the city buildings, including the Mayor's office. Mayor Francis soon after issued an order to Street Commissioner Turner to notify the company that if their poles and wires were not ...

It was semi-officially stated yesterday afternoon that subscriptions to the Reading Railroad's new 4 per cent. loan had been received here and in London for more than twice as many bonds as are held by the syndicate for distribution.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 6.--The students of Drake University last night, in their mock national convention, nominated Gresham and Allison, adopted a moderate tariff and restricted foreign immigration platfrom.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--Col. James M. Whittemore, Ordnance Department, has been ordered to inspect certain clothing and equipage at the Watervliet Arsenal, for which Capt. Charles Shaler, Ordnance Department, is reponsible.

For several years William P. Pridgeon has kept a large restaurant and bakery at 1,142 and 1,144 Third-avenue, and to all appearances conducted a very flourishing business. His old customers are now compelled to go hungry or go elsewhere. Pridgeon has gone to Canada.
CITY OF MEXICO, June 6, via Galveston.-- The frightful accident on the Mexican Central Railroad on Monday last occurred 40 kilometers from Tampice, at a railroad bridge 45 feet long and 12 feet high.
NEWBURG, N.Y., June 6.--Frederick Boyger, assistant editor in the Jeweler's Publishing Company, New-York, was married to-day to Miss Gertrude Kidd, second daughter of Dr. Willett Kidd of Newburg.
TORONTO, Ontario, June 6.--Judgment was given to-day in the extradition proceedings against Adam Morse, the Savannah negro charged with the attempted murder of Bourbee, a street railway conductor.

OMAHA, Neb., June 6.--Three children of Ferdinand Mathias and James Mark, all between 10 and 16 years of age, were drowned at Wisner yesterday while crossing the river in a boat. There were eight in the boat when it capsized, but the others were saved. They were returning from a wedding.
BOSTON, Mass., June 6.--The Commencement exercises of the Class of '88 of Boston University were held this afternoon in Tremont Temple.
Three handsome examples of art work in stained glass were privately exhibited at the studies of the Tiffany Glass Company yesterday.

LONDON, June 6.--The steamship Tower Hill, (Br.,) Capt. Archer, from New-York May 27 for London, passed the Lizard to-day. The Cunard Line steamship Seythia, Capt. Roberts, from Liverpool, sid. from Queenstown for New-York to-day.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 6.--The Republican plurality on the State ticket continually increases as the returns come in. Herrmann's majority now stands at nearly 4,000, and will be increased rather than reduced. The Republicans will have 70 members on joint ballot in the Legislature and the Democrats 20.

The American Bell Telephone Company yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Wallace, applied for a decree ordering the destruction of telephone apparatus owned by William T. Kitsell, besides an injunction and damages ago and defaulted.
Like the "old woman who lived in a shoe" and other people who choose outlandish places for their abodes, Mrs. Jane Brigham is an afflicted woman.

The action of the Board of Governors of the Manhattan Athletic Club in promulgating an edict that members of the organization would not be allowed to compete in the games of the Pastime Athletic Club, to be held next Saturday, has caused a decided sensation among athletes generally throughout the city.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 6.--The strawberry crop along the Hudson is ripening rapidly, and in its entirety it is probably the finest on record. The copious rains all through May caused all kinds of vegetation to grow luxuriantly.

BOSTON, Mass., June 6.--The Globe will to-morrow publish a letter written by Mrs. Cleveland to a lady in Worcester who had forwarded to Mrs. Cleveland a copy of the alleged statements of a Worcester clergyman against the character of the President. The letter is as follows:

Through somebody's carelessness the taxes on eight pieces of property owned by the Brooklyn Board of Education were left unpaid and the property in arrears which included the headquarters at Red Hook-lane, was advertised for sale yesterday. The entire amount of un paid taxes does not exceed $700. The matter is under investigation.

PRINCETON, June 6.--The Faculty has awarded appointments for the Commencement Class of '88 as follows: Hugh T. Dobbins of California, Latin salutatory; Edwin M. Hopkins of New-York, English salutatory, and Winthrop M. Daniels of Ohio, valedictory.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 6.--The centennial of negro Baptists of Georgia began in Savannah to-day and will continue two weeks. Five thousand negro Baptists are present. At the opening of the celebration over 300 preachers were in attendance. It is expected that 50,000 negro visitors will be here during the celebration. Excursion trains will run from all parts of the South.

CINCINNATI, June 6.--It was hot and sultry at Latonia to-day. The racing was fine and the time made was excellent. Bonita in the last race made the fastest mile time ever made at Latonia--1:41 --and won a great race from Valuable right under the wire.

Adam G. Faist, a German beer bottler, committed suicide early yesterday morning by inhaling illuminating gas by means of a rubber tube which he had attached to a gas pipe in his cellar. He was found with one end of the rubber tube resting on his body.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6.--The gunnery exercise to-day in the Chesapeake by the naval cadets on the Wyoming was marked by skill and proficiency. At a range from 900 to 1,300 yards the target was struck several times.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, June 7.--Destructive forest fires are raging on the south shore of Conception Bay. PORTLAND, Oregon, June 7.--Returns up to 6 o'clock this evening serve only to increase the Republican pluralities on the State ticket. Three small Republican counties are still to hear from. The Republican plurality will be more than 7,000, which is larger by 4,000 than during the war.

ALBANY, June 7.--Deputy State Controller Westbrook to-day gave an opinion that parsonages, when upon church sites, are exempt from taxation. He says the statute exempts from taxation every building erected for public worship, and the lots whereon such buildings are situated and furniture belonging to each.

At a meeting of the flour and provision exporters at the Produce Exchange to consider the new clause lately introduced in the bills of lading by the London steamship lines of this port, a committee was appointed to protest against the clause to the managers of the steamship lines. The obnoxious clause is now inserted in all the bills of lading, and by it an extra quay charge of 1s. 2d. per ton is exacted.

ZANZIBAR, June 7.--Later explanations of the difference between Italy and Zanzibar show that the Sultan has refused to ratify the cession of the islands, Kismayne and Sala, demanded by Italy as a compensation for the alleged insult of the late Sultan to King Humbert. The Hoboken Turtle Club held an enthusiastic meeting at its rooms in the Sinclair House last evening, Vice-President William H. Townley presiding. Thirteen new members were elected, swelling the number of active membership to over 500. It was decided to hold the annual repast on Thursday, June 21, at Gabe Case's. After the meeting those present enjoyed an evening lunch of turtle soup, chowder, and other Turtle Club delicacies.

BANGOR, Me., June 7.--The Democrats here fired 100 guns in honor of the St. Louis ticket to-day, and specials from all parts of the State to-night indicate the delight of the party in the selection of Thurman for Vice-President.

Hannibal Hamlin, the first Republican Vice-President, who sailed to be elected as a delegate from his own ward to the Republican State Convention, will go there through the back door, having received the proxy of a delegate. DENVER, Col., June 7.--Jay Gould and party left Manitou to-day for the East. It is now pretty generally conceded that Mr. Gould came West on railroad business.

AIX-LES-BAINS, June 8.--The Emperor of Brazil is rapidly recovering. CAIRO, June 8.--In Upper Egypt the cotton crop is forward and in an excellent condition. In some of the Delta provinces, however, it is backward, but healthy. The season is cold. Water is abundant.

There was a lively time yesterday morning in Edgewater Town Hall. Staten Island, just before the meeting of the village Board of Trustees. The hall was crowded with interested spectators when the meeting convened at 10 o'clock.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 8.--The result of the election of Fellows last evening by the Faculty of Cornell University was a great triumph for co-education. The fellowships are worth $400 a year plus free tuition. Scholarship and ability determine the candidate's success.

CATSKILL, N.Y., June 8.--The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America resumed work this morning. The committee on the state of religion reported 34 classes, 546 churches, 47,518 families, and a total membership of 86,932.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8.--Mr. Clans Sprekels said to-day, in the course of a conversation with a reporter regarding the sugar industry, that the work on the big refinery in this city will be vigorously prosecuted, and that the establishment will probably be in full operation in a year.

WASHINGTON, June 8.--The convention of the Machinery Constructors of North America, which has been in session here for several days, adjourned sine die this evening. One hundred and forty delegates, representing nearly every state in the Union, were present.

QUEBEC, June 8.--Difficulty has arisen between the Rector of the Laval University and a number of students as to extra charge for gas. Twenty-three students, who refused to pay for extra gas which they had burned, were expelled to-day. The police were called upon to see that the students departed quietly, as a violent demonstration was feared.

CHICAGO, June 8.--A meeting of the General Freight Agents of lines interested in Iowa traffic was held to-day to decide what should be done in regard to the new distance tariffs prepared by the Iowa Railroad Commissioners to govern freight business in that State.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 8.--It seems that there are two sides to the Indian difficulty on the Tuscarora Reservation. Chief Thomas Williams and his brother Daniel Williams of the Tuscaroras, also Enos Johnson, have been arrested, charged with assault, and taken before Justice Robinson at Lewiston.

Maturin, Rector of St. Clement's Church, Philadelphia, was about to sever his connection with the Episcopal Church and be received into the Church of Rome, the Rev. Father Grafton of this city said to-day that there was no truth in the statement.

DEVIL'S LAKE, Dakota, June 8.--Lightning struck the house of Julius Becker, a prosperous German farmer, wrecking the building and killing his daughter, and seriously injuring both him and his wife. The latter may not recover.

LOUISVILLE, KY., June 8.--Charles Murphy, a fisherman, aged 33, was drowned in the falls this morning in a singular manner. He went out with his net, and making two or three unsuccessful hauls, passed over to a point called the Backbone.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 8.--For a week Annapolis has had the air of a military post; the Naval Academy the atmosphere of a naval depot. BALTIMORE, June 8.--The select committee of the United States Senate, appointed to investigate the operations of the civil service, met to-day at the Hotel Rennert. The subcommittee present consisted of Senators Hale, Chairman, Chase, and Blackburn.

BALTIMORE, June 8.--The steam yacht Gleam, belonging to T. Harrison Garrett, the millionaire banker of Baltimore, and a brother of Robert Garrett, ex-President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, was run down last night in the Chesapeake Bay by the steamer Joppa, and Mr. Garrett was crushed to death in the wreck and drowned.

CENTRAL CITY, Neb., June 8.--A committee appointed by the County Commissioners to examine the books of Treasurer Col. W.H. Webster has reported a shortage of about $35,000 in his accounts. Col. Webster's deputy, Otto Foster, was also found to be short $1,000. Webster has property worth $20,000, which it is said he will turn over to the county.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., June 8.--The dedication of the new Methodist Episcopal church was today brought to a close after carrying out a lengthy programme covering three days. The Rev. D.W. Couch preached the opening sermon, followed by sermons by Bishop Foss, the Rev. John A. Monroe, and the Rev. F.C. Iglehart.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 8.--A farmer named O. Reasoner, residing northeast of this city, had a narrow escape from death this afternoon. His team of horses, which he was driving, ran away in the city and dashed over an embankment 30 feet high into the canal, carrying carriage and man with them. Mr. Reasoner was rescued alive and uninjured from the water. Both horses were drowned.

READING, Penn., June 8.--The boiler of an engine on the farm of Edwin Mickley, at Maple Grove, Lehigh County, exploded this morning and was immediately followed by the explosion of 125 pounds of dynamite and a quantity of powder, which was stored in the engine house. Mr. Mickley's barn, erected at a cost of $5,000, was completely wrecked. Win dow panes a half mile distant were broken.

Queen Olga of Greece has passed incognita through the Bosphorus on her way to Odessa in her steam yacht. QUEBEC, June 9.--Lord Stanley of Preston, the new Governor-General of Canada, arrived to-night under most unfavorable auspices, the night being dark and stormy and a keen northeast wind blowing, accompanied by occasional drenching showers of rain.

The Seventy-first Regiment will parade for rifle practice at Creedmoor next Thursday. The Fourteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, will open the State camp at Peekskill next Saturday. Col. Michell expects to take 450 men and officers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 9.--District Attorney John R. Fellows of New-York is at the Ryan. In an interview to-day he said: "Gray is a good man, and had he been nominated we should have given him a very cordial party support.

When the special train from St. Louis bearing the Tammany Hall delegation to the Democratic National Convention arrived at the Grand Central Station at 10:30 A.M. yesterday the first news which the wearied pilgrims heard was that Gev. Hill had consented to address the Tammany ratification meeting, which will be held Tuesday evening next in the Academy of Music in behalf of Cleveland and Thurman.

VIENNA, June 9.--Herr Smolka was elected President of the Austrian Delegation to-day. In an address to the members Herr Smolka referred feelingly to the death of Emperor William of Germany, and eulogized the present German Emperor, who, he said, was inspired by the same noble and peaceful spirit that had inspired his father. The Hungarian Delegation elected Herr Ludwig Tisza President and Herr Haynald Vice-President.
LONDON, June 9.--The court has ordered the winding up of the American Exchange in Europe, (limited,) which recently suspended.

CHICAGO, June 9.--The Alger ship, which its friends think may find a safe harbor in the Republican National Convention, anchored in the port of Chicago to-day with F.S. Hecker, Gen. Alger's business partner, in command and Major George H. Hopkins as the crew. A.B. Hall, the resident agent of the Alger line, took the crew and the Captain to the Grand Pacific.

CHICAGO, June 9.--The Andrew Jackson League of Chicago has arranged for a special train, which will leave the city next Tuesday, carrying all who desire to attend the State Convention of Democratic Clubs at Springfield. It will return Wednesday evening. Credentials entitling to seats in the convention will be allotted to the first 150 members who apply for them.
There was a strong dash of spice in the testimony elicited yesterday by the Senate investigating committee which is just now engaged in discovering the weak spots in the new Croton Aqueduct.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 9.--There is great excitement at Greenfield, the county seat of Dade County, over a supposed suicide which turns out to be a murder.

FRANKLINVILLE, N.Y., June 9.--The Prohibitionists of the First Assembly District of Cattaraugus County met in convention here today. Messrs. F. Findlay, E.L. Jones, J.H. Day, A.S. Holland, and W.W. Harris were chosen as delegates to the State Convention, to be held at Syracuse, June 26 and 27. Neither the national ticket nor the platform was indorsed.

In response to invitations which were sent to a hundred or so representative people, some seventy-five attended a meeting yesterday afternoon at the residence of Dr. William B. Wood, 17 East Thirty-eighth-street, far the purpose of organizing a society to reform abuses in the public schools of New-York City.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9.--During a fire at Rhinebeck last evening a village rough named Peter Wetzeler entered a saloon and asked for a drink, which was denied him.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 9.--Stuart Robson and William H. Crane, whose names during the past 10 years have been inseparably associated in the theatrical world, have resolved to dissolve partnership and each to pursue his own way.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9.--The cheers of 2,000 people, mingled with the shrieking of whistles and mingling of bells, saluted the City of Birmingham as she gracefully slid down the ways in Roach's shipyard and glided out on the Delaware, opposite Chester, to-day.
Three statues of Roman art were discovered and seized yesterday; one of the Emperor Hadrian, another of Antoninus, and the third a small Bacchus.

There was quite a lively time among the brokers on the Produce Exchange who carried on their business after the regular closing hour yesterday. A synopsis of the Government crop report arrived and the first impression gained from it was that the showing was much worse than last month.

MILWAUKEE, June 9.--The old superstition that a cat will suck the breath of a sleeping child and thus cause its death has been revived in this vicinity recently by the circulation of a story that the 3-days-old babe of Mrs. Henry Crocker had met his death in this way.

The challenge of George Slosson, the billiard expert, who has taken a room at Saratoga for the Summer, in which he offers to play matches in his own rooms against Sexton, Daly, or Schaefer at balk line for $250 a side has not been productive of favorable responses from the other experts named.

BOSTON, June 9.--The Grand Jury for Middlesex County in its report found no bill against Mrs. Abble H. Corner, the Christian scientist, of West Medford, charged with manslaughter in causing the death of her daughter, Mrs. Lottie A. James. Mrs. Corner had neglected to provide proper medical assistance at the time of her daughter's confinement on the 18th of March.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 9.--The rural and farming districts of the State continue to furnish instances of remarkable longevity in the human family.
Charles H. Haskess, a lineman in the employ of the United States Electric Illuminating Company, was arrested yesterday while fixing a carbon in an electric lamp on Broadway in front of Parsell's.

The annual Summer games and picnic of the Pastime Athletic Club were held yesterday at Jones's Wood. There was a large number of entries for the races which made up the athletic part of the entertainment.

The Larchmont yachtsmen gazed very anxiously out from the plazza of their clubhouse yesterday morning toward the place where they knew the waters of the Sound must be, in spite of the dense fog which hid them entirely from sight.

BELVIDERE, N.J., June 9.--George Naylor, the oldest conductor on the Belvidere Branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died at his home here to-day after a week's illness. He will be buried on Tuesday, when a large delegation of railroad men will be present.

The exercises of the graduation week for the Seniors of Colombia College begin this evening with the baccalaureate sermon, which will be preached by the Rev. Morgan Dix, S.T.D., a graduate of '48, at St. Thomas's Church, Fifthavenue and Fifty-third-street.
The principal event in the convention of the State Medical Association yesterday occurred in the afternoon. It was the discussion over the existence of hydrophobia.

MACON, Ga., June 9.--If the bloodhounds do their duty there will be a lynching in Schley County soon. Wednesday night Charles Blackman, a notorious colored desperado, effected his escape from the American Jail by means of a false key furnished him by confederates.
BESSEMER, Mich., June 9.--There was a narrow escape from a terrible disaster to the limited passenger train on the Lake Shore Railroad this morning.

There died on Tuesday at Fort Hill, Dover, in his ninety-first year, Thomas B. Rutley, who, before the days of railways, conducted the bullion wagons between Dover and London. His books show that he had had over 20,000,000 of specie under his care. His last consignment was two and a half tons of silver, which he brought from London and shipped in the Downs for the East India Company.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 9.--On a lonely back road which runs from the town of Redding to that part of Newtown known as Hattertown, is located the residence and farm of Andrew J. Peck. Peck has been for years a notorious character, being in fact regarded by his country acquaintances as a sort of a moral outlaw.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 9.--Judge Thurman, much to the surprise of his friends, stood yesterday's fatigue wonderfully well, and was about his home and grounds to-day looking hale and hearty.
KINGSTON, N.Y., June 9.--The tide of travel to the Catskills this afternoon was heavy for so early a date in the season.
Joseph Clarke is lying at the point of death in St. Francis Hospital, Jersey City, from injuries inflicted upon him in a street row early yesterday morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9.--The following were elected to-day to the Students' Conference Committee for the next year: From the Class of '89--W.S. Chase, Ohio; W.J. George, Ohio; R.V. Speer, Pennsylvania; J.C. Norris, Jr., Louisiana; H.C. Warren, New-Jersey; David Bovaird, Jr., Pennsylvania. From the Class of '91--Donald McColl, New-York; Edgar Allen Poe, Maryland.

Frank H. Damrosch continued yesterday at Association Hall, on Twenty-third-street, the course of Saturday morning lectures which he has been giving for the past month on "The Best Methods of Instruction in Vocal Music in Our Schools."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 9.--The Rev. C. H. Pendleton of Worcester, Mass., whose characteristic slander of the President's domestic life has thrust him into a national notoriety which is increased by his abject apology after Mrs. Cleveland's stinging rebuke, was formerly settled in this city.
GREAT HEAD, Mass., June 9.--The open subscription and sweepstake regatta of the Great Head Yacht Club was sailed to-day, 24 yachts participating. Following are the winners, with the corrected time:
The weights for the Westchester Handicap, to be run at Jerome Park on Tuesday, have been fixed as follows:

Among the distinguished Michiganders at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday was ex-Congressman Roswell G. Horr of East Saginaw, one of Gen. Alger's closest friends. He is a delegate to the Republican National Convention. He says that wherever he has been, especially since Mr. Blaine's last letter, he has found the Republicans having friendly feelings for Alger.

LIVINGSTON, Montana, June 9.--J.J. McBride, Postmaster here, left suddenly Sunday morning. It is now learned that he is a defaulter to the Government to the amount of several Hundred dollars, besides owing private indebtedness to a large amount.

BELVIDERE, N.J., June 9.--Edward Beers, a well-to-do farmer residing here, committed suicide by hanging this forenoon. He had taken a bridle rein and throwing it over the limb of a tree two feet from the ground, sat down and strangled himself.
Two movements with much the same purpose, but in quite different quarters, have recently been set on foot for the improvement of the public schools of New-York.

PARIS, June 9.--To-morrow is the Grand Prix Day and the last public fashion gathering of the season. A few grand dinners are to be given next week, but the social event is the dinner and fete champetre of the Princess, de Sagan, which takes place this evening.
E. Berry Wall is becoming an adept at dodging the officers of the law. All yesterday morning the janitor of the City Hall was kept busy directing people to Judge McAdam's court, where it was ...

The cause of the attempted suicide of Mrs. George S. Jones, who jumped from the ferryboat Hoboken in midstream while crossing the North River at 9:30 Friday night, and whose life was saved by Pilot Thomas McMullin, was the subject of much discussion in the Oranges yesterday.
SANDWICH, Mass., June 9.--During a game of baseball at Sandwich this afternoon John McLaney, shortstop of the Athletics, dropped dead of heart disease. He leaves a widow and one child.
Joseph Bindel, a butcher, 30 years old, who with his wife and three small children lived on the first floor of the big tenement 851 First-avenue, ...

For three days and three nights of last week the front of the Office Boy was lowering and wrinkled. His shoulders were stooped as if they bore two worlds instead of their usual burden--one--and dumbly protested against the imposition.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., June 9.--An application for a Receiver for the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad was filed in the United States District Court last evening before Judge Brewer, but was laid over until Gen. B.H. Waggener of Atchison, General Solicitor of the Missouri Pacific, could reach here.

A petition was in circulation on the Cotton Exchange yesterday which is attracting very much attention in down-town business circles. It is a request to the Board of Managers of the Exchange "to so amend rule 2, page 104, that the minimum fluctuation shall be threehundredths of a cent per pound, instead of one-hundredth as at present."
PHILADELPHIA, June 9.--The Pennsylvania Club, an important semi-political organization comprising leading Republicans, indorsed Gresham unanimously to-night.
PITTSBURG, June 9.--The National Convention of Knights of Labor iron workers, which has been in session here for a week past, adjourned at noon to meet in Chicago on the first Monday in April, 1889.

BOSTON, Mass., June 9.--The Record has interviews with a large number of prominent Republicans of Massachusetts regarding their preferences for candidate for the Presidential nomination. The following are some of the expressions of choice:

NEWPORT, R.I., June 9.--The sessions of the New-England Meeting of Friends opened this morning with a meeting on ministry and oversight, followed by a joint business session of men and women. The following requests were referred to the representatives:

"The Lady or the Tiger?" closed its fifth week at Wallack's last night, leaving behind it the best record ever made by Col. McCaull for the same period at the begining of his Summer season in this city. This is the fourth Summer that the Colonel has occupied Wallack's Theatre ...
It is a difficult thing to describe the notions of etiquette and of social propriety existing in any community, for the reason that different people have such very different ideas upon the subject.

The Ladies' Association of the Manhattan Dispensary and Hospital gave a garden party in aid of that institution yesterday afternoon in the grounds of J. Hood Wright on the King's Bridge road at One Hundred and Seventyfourth-street.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 9.--The schooner Minnesota sailed to-day for Greenland to engage in the halibut fishery, and others are expected to follow the coming week.
WASHINGTON, JUNE 9.--The bond offerings today aggregated $400,600, as follows: Registered 4s--$600 at 128, $140,000 at 127 7/8, $100,000 at 127, registered 4 s--$160,000 at 107 .

The latest dodge of the elevated roads to avoid reimbursing property holders whom they have injured shows, more plainly perhaps than any of their previous proceedings, how irresponsible the corporation is to public opinion and how inaccesible to considerations of decency.
DANBURY, Conn., June 9.--Mrs. James Halpin, the wife of a prosperous farmer living at Stony Hill; lies in a very critical condition to-day and is liable to die at any moment.
Special study will call several of Columbia's Professors abroad during the present Summer. Prof. C. Sprague Smith of the modern language department has gone to Iceland for purposes of study.
There is every prospect that the political campaign of the present year will be the most salutary through which the country has passed since the great civil war.

To the intense surprise of 13,000 persons who gathered in the Polo Grounds yesterday Capt. Anson and his band of ball plapers won a game from the Giants. The latter were unable to bat the delivery of Krock, and they fell easy victims.
DEADWOOD, Dakota, June 9.--A new scheme of gigantic proportions has been born. Deadwood is on an air line between Chicago and Portland, Oregon.

The period of Summer dullness of which real estate men have been apprehensive for several weeks past seems at last to have settled fully upon the market. Last week's sales were not numerous, and hardly one of them would have been classed as important at a busy time.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 9.--Ohio is the source of Senator John Sherman's greatest Presidential strength, and also of his chief danger and weakness. The power that attaches the State support to him at present is that merely of gravity, and not of chemical cohesion or natural affinity, and can be far too easily overcome.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9.--Mrs. Dorette Schroeder, wife the Rev. Olof Schroeder of the German Lutheran Church at Sixth and Wharton streets, died in the Pennsylvania Hospital today from injuries received by jumping from the second story of her residence a few days ago while insane.
LOUSVILLE, Ky., June 9.--The first case of sunstroke for the season was reported here yesterday. The afternoon was very sultry, though the thermometer marked only 88.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9.--The Assignees of William T. Coleman Co. have completed the revision of the statement made by Mr. Coleman several weeks ago, but will not make it public unless the creditors desire to have it so.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., June 9.--The town of Norway, Mich., was almost destroyed by fire to-day. Thirty buildings were wiped away, including the main business section. Among the buildings destroyed were the Town Hall, Masonic Hall, Post Office, and principal hotel.

Medicine in the market is Riker's Compound Sarsaparilla, because it costs only 75 cents large bottle. It contains nearly double quantity of any other. It is only taken twice a day (so handy.) It only requires one or two bottles to cure. It very seldom fails to cure.

CHICAGO, June 9.--The Gas Trust weakened to-day, and made a proposition to the Aldermen to furnish gas to west side consumers for $1.25 a thousand feet, the city paying $1 a thousand for its lamps in that section.
BERLIN, May 20.--Never probably were so many American students in Berlin as during the semester which closed a few weeks ago. About 160 Americans have been registered in the university; and as ...
William Werking, brother of the ex-champion swimmer of America, hanged himself yesterday evening at 2 Garden-street, Hoboken. Despondency was the cause.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 9.--A remarkable woman has just died in Lancaster County. She was Mrs. Catherine Crowell, the great-greatgreat-grandmother of Mrs. A.J. Bennett of Lancaster. She was 99 years old.
There will be a meeting of the Brotherhood of Professional Baseball Players in this city to-day. Tiernan will be able to join the New-Yorks in a few days.

St. John's Guild is actively making preparations for largely increased work on behalf of the sick children by more trips per week of the "Floating Hospital" and by doubling the capacity of the Seaside Nursery.

BALTIMORE, June 9.--The celebrated Crise will case ended to-day, the jury returning a verdict probably sooner than they would have done, owing to the instructions given them by Judge Duffy, which compelled them to bring in a verdict or sit for a month or more.

Victor Markopf, who was charged with embezzlement by the Superintendent of the Union Benefit League and after a hearing was held in $500, has since been charged by the company with which he was formerly connected with swindling and forgery.
There were reportoted during the past week at the Bureau of Vital Statistics 720 deaths, 672 births, and 349 marriages. The number of deaths was 19 more than the preceding week.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES published on Sunday last the opening chapters of a story by H. Rider Haggard entitled "Mr. Meeson's Will." These opening chapters give promise of a story in the true Rider Haggard vein. "Mr. Meeson's Will" is to appear in four successive issues of the Sunday TIMES, when it will be complete.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9.--The members of the Board of Visitors who have been present here during the graduating exercises at the Naval Academy have taken their departure, and the cadets are all astir to-night making preparations for a Summer's cruise on board the Constellation, Commander Harrington, which ...
The Statistical Bureau of the Municipality of Paris has just issued the returns as to the population of the city and of the department of the Seine at the end of 1886.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 9.--The exciting attack on the railroad train at Delhi last night is discussed in all quarters this morning. Chief Hazen of the police force is disposed to regard it as the work of tramps, and the facts show that if done by professionals they made a poor choice of booty.

CHICAGO, June 9.--Col. Abner Taylor to-day captured a majority of the primaries held by the Republicans in the First Congressional District and has a good lead for the nomination for Congressman Dunham's place.
WEST POINT, June 10.--This has been the first unpleasant day in the course of the graduation exercises at the Military Academy.
SALEM, N.J., June 10.--The Post Office here was broken into last night and about $800 in money and stamps were taken from the safe.

The question of the importation of laborers into this country under contract took up some of the time of the Central Labor Union yesterday. The committee that had been appointed to look after James Pain, who is said to have imported workmen as well as fire works...

"About this time look out for warm weather," is printed in trustworthy almanace opposite the table of days for the week ending June 9, 1888. Perhaps that is why people were out in such numbers Saturday night.

The recent discussion in the Sorosis Club on the subject of woman in her relation to the drama has brought Miss Georgia Cayvan, the leading lady of the Lyceum Theatre, somewhat prominently before the public as an alleged advocate of female theatrical managers.

Among the numerous data furnished by the State Commissioner of Agriculture in his official report to the General Assembly there is nothing more interesting than the detailed showing of the acreage and yield of the various Louisiana crops.
The Council of the Brotherhood of Baseball Players held its annual meeting yesterday. Seven clubs were represented. The delegates were Ruffinton of Philadelphia, Morris of...
The attendance at the Brooklyn-Cleveland game at Ridgewood Park yesterday afternoon numbered a little over 2,000 people. The contest was not a brilliant one by any means.
Gen. Boulanger is just moving into his new house, 11 bis--not 13, that number being held to be of ill-omen--in the Rue Dumont d'Urville, near the Place des Etats-Unis, and not...

Among the most interesting of the Children's Day services yesterday was that of the little ones in the Five Points House of Industry. In place of the usual service during the afternoon the children sang of flowers and the early Summer's beauties.

A year or so before the breaking out of the war of the rebellion Alexander Barnes, a plasterer, came from Boston to this city and started in business at 203 West Seventeenthstreet. His wife and child, a boy 8 years old, remained in Boston.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 10.-Stephen Gleason, the oldest resident of this city, died this afternoon at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. Desmond, on Bedford-street, in the one hundred and third year of his age.
It took Dr. McGlynn just one hour and three-quarters last night to remind his AntiPoverty hearers of the alleged principles of their alleged organization.
A match will be played at 2 o'clock to morrow afternoon at Livingston, Staten Island, between the New-York Cricket Club and the Staten Island Cricket Club.
LONDON, June 10.--The rate of discount during the present week was 1 @1. It is expected that there will be a further decline during June and July if the superabundance of money continues.

The sight of 300 little colored boys, all dressed alike, and all busy at something, is a novel one, and worth driving from Kingston out to Stony Hill to see. At Stony Hill is the Jamaica Reform School for boys, where they are kept out of harm's way till they are 16 years old, educated to some extent, and taught useful trades.
CHICAGO, June 10.--The Times has received another carrier pigeon dispatch from Capt. Jones's buffalo hunters, who three days ago were at Mount Blaneo, Texas.

The fog that hangs over the city of Chicago is still so dense as to be altogether impenetrable, but some faint signs of clearing weather have been noted by the politically weatherwise.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 10.-Prof. Edward Danforth of this city, known throughout the State in connection with Sunday-school work, is dangerously ill with Bright's disease, having been for two days in a semi-conscious condition. For several years he has been Secretary of the State Sunday-School Association and was at one time Deputy State Superintendent of Public Instruction.

The leaders of the County Democracy met in the New-Amsterdam Club yesterday and agreed to hold a meeting of the County Committee at Cooper Institute Tuesday night. The organization will then decide the date and place for their big Cleveland and Thurman ratification.

Concerning the suit against Mrs. James Brown Potter by Manager Harry Miner for $3,000 he claims to have advanced her after she contracted to play under his management, Mr. Hummel, of counsel for the plaintiff, said yesterday that about $2,200 was paid to the actress in Europe last summer and the balance while she was traveling about the United States.

The news that the famous comedians, Robson and Crane, are to dissolve partnership after one season more with "The Henrietta" furnished food for talk and speculation among people inside and outside of the theatrical profession yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10.--Walt Whitman is seriously ill at his home in Camden, and grave fears that his strength will not be sufficient for his recovery are expressed by his friends. The old poet's general health has not been robust...

NEWPORT, R.I, June 10.--Chaplain Robert Hudson and Dr. Kindleberger of the navy, Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont, Miss Mary Neilson, Alexander J. Leith, Julian T. Davies, J.N.A. Griswold, Mrs. Henry Ledyard, and Amos T. French of New-York, and W.H. Dunbar and Gordon McKay of Boston have arrived at their cottages.

READING, Penn., June 10.-The bodies of Miss Sue Wixson, aged 18 years, and her 3-months-old babe were found drowned in the Schuylkill River here to-day. Miss Wixson disappeared from home in Muhlenburg Township, on the outskirts of the city, two weeks ago. She had tied her child about her body with a rope before plunging into the river.
Contagious diseases have been very prevalent among the Italians who occupy the tumble-down shanties in the lower part of Adams-street, Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, June 10.-Jay Gould and his private car "Atlanta" paid a surreptitious visit to St. Louis to-night, and immediately departed over the Iron Mountain Railway. Mr. Gould is inspecting his roads, and a physician is constantly inspecting him. General Manager S.H. H. Clark is with him.

The marriage of Danforth Geer, son of Mr. and Mrs. A.C. Geer, to Miss Amy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Gay, all of Hoosick Falls, Mass., took place at St. Mark's Church, in that village, Wednesday evening.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 10.--William A. Seelay, agent for W.A. Swift Co. at the Kansas City Stock Yards, and for several years a wellknown resident of the west side, has filed in the Circuit Court a suit for divorce. He and his wife were married 29 years ago and have lived together ever since.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 10.--Yesterday was formally given to the city a large and handsome bronze fountain, the finest in the South.
