Everything was booming at Coney Island yesterday, even the breakers. There was that something about the genial, but tepid, atmosphere which suggested to the most chronic lover of his own fireside that it was time to bank the ashes of Winter memories and seek the Mecca of New-York, old Coney Island.
Since the Queen met with a slight accident at Windsor and sprained her knee she has not been able to stand comfortably for any long period, and at drawing rooms, although appearing...

The shower early yesterday afternoon looked like a dampner on driving, but it quit before the usual hour for the roadgoers to turn out, and Seventh and Jerome avenues were as black as usual with conveyances during the afternoon. Frank Fox, looking as well as ever.

The Archbishop of Paris has refused to allow Verdi's "Requiem" to be given in Notre Dame, on the ground that ladies of the opera were to sing in it. The "Requiem" has been given under similar conditions at all the principal cathedrals in Italy, so that the Archbishop's scruples seem rather ridiculous.

Vice-Chancellor McCracken of the University of the City of New-York preached the baccalaureate sermon last night to the graduating class of that institution in the UniversityPlace Presbyterian Church.

The withdrawal of Mr. Blaine has united and greatly encouraged the Republicans of New-Hampshire. The Plumed Knight has as ardent admirers here as anywhere, but if this was ever a Blaine State in the sense that a majority of its Republicans thought it wise to nominate him it certainly has not been since 1884.

Twelve members of the detachment of the Honorable Artillery Company of London reached here last evening from Boston. Whether or not the others of the detachment had fallen victims to Boston hospitality they did not say, but they are understood to be still enjoying themselves somewhere between that city and this. The 12 went to the Victoria Hotel. They will probably sail Wednesday on the North German Lloyd steamship Aller.

BANGOR, Me., June 10.-The night mail between here and Boston is cared for by three men, and last night the postal car going west was under the charge of A.G. Sellen, with S. Lyman Hayes, second clerk, and Jeremiah Sinclair of Ossipee, N.H., as third clerk.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10.-The Rev. Waldo Messaros startled his congregation in the Northwestern Independent Church this morning when he said he could no longer be their Pastor if the church remained independent.

Central Presbyterian Church, 220 West Fifty-seventh-street, was filled to overflowing last evening, the occasion being the memorial services of the Pastor of the church, the Rev. James D. Wilson, D.D. Scripture selections were read by the Rev. C.H. Everest, D.D.,...

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 10.-The story of how C.D. O'Brien's resolution relative to the extradition treaty failed to come before the Democratic Convention is quite interesting, and has been fully detailed by that gentleman.

RICHMOND, Va., June 10.-Capt. C. Gray Bossleux, Commander of the Richmond Grays, whose presence in New-York on Decoration Day attracted attention, yesterday received a letter from Col. Fred Grant. In this the Colonel on his own behalf, as well as for his mother, thanks Capt. Bossieux and through him his company for placing flowers on the grave of Gen. Grant on Decoration Day.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 10.--The annual convention of the International Typographical Union will open here in the Board of Trade Hall to-morrow morning and will continue in session for over a week.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 10.--The season, according to the principal real estate dealers, those having charge of the rental of the splendid private establishments here, is somewhat backward, but the majority of the most expensive residences will soon be occupied by their owners on tenants.

John Pope, 46 years old, took a dose of rat poison near his home on Bloomfield-street, Hoboken, last night. He will probably die. He has a wife and five children and has been out of work for some time. About a year ago he made a similar attempt upon his life.

About 11:30 last night a man rushed out of the hallway at 31 Union-square and darted across the park, closely followed by Officer Lang of the Nineteenth Precinct. The officer soon overtook and marched him off to the station...

PHILADELPHIA, June 10.--There were two large banquets in Chinatown to-night, given in honor of 16 Chinamen who were initiated on Thursday night into the mysteries of Chinese Freemasonry by Yang Yin of New-York, Supreme Grand Master of the Chinese Freemasons of the United States.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 10.-A narrow escape from a destructive fire occurred in the Yale-Kent laboratory last night. The laboratory has just been built and the university is just preparing to utilize it.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 10.-In Novem ber, 1886, J.H. Yarborough, a clerk in the Santa Fe material yards at Emporia, shot and killed L.D. Collier, son of the famous preacher, the Rev. Robert Laird Collier, and agent of the railroad company at that city.

Few, if any, of the New-York clubs have such a pleasant country home as that which the New-York Athletic Club took possession of yesterday. Travers Island, on the Sound, is the future Summer domicile of the Athletics, and at 10:30 A.M. yesterday a special train of seven cars drew out of the Grand Central Station carrying thither about 300 members of the club.

It will be the wisest politics of his career if he does it.

Yesterday's stock market was flavored with the spice of a new activity, but it was activity at the expense of good prices. Nearly every stock on the Stock Exchange list suffered a decline in quotations, and some of the more conspicuous shares ran off materially.

ALBANY, June 11.--When the Legislature adjourned Gov. Hill had in his hands 414 acts. Within the 30 days allowed him by law he has signed 298 of these, vetoed 2, and returned 1 to the clerks of the two houses.

PORTLAND, Me., June 11.--There was a larger crowd in town to-night than was ever seen here on the evening before a State Convention. Every hotel was full before the evening trains arrived, and every delegate came with his mind made up.

OSWEGO, N.Y., June 11.--The body of Simon Hale, aged 25, was found horribly mangled on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdansburg Railroad track between Pulaski and Richland yesterday. When last seen alive Hale was intoxicated, and started from Pulaski for home, about three miles distant. It is supposed that about three miles distant. RACINE, Wis., June 11.--John Zacher, Jr., son of a wealthy Bohemian farmer, living in Mount Pleasant Township, five miles north, has not tasted food for 23 days. During the greater portion of that time he has done arduous farm work, but has now grown so weak that anything more laborious than light chores exhausts him.

At yesterday's session of the Senate investigating committee it was developed that there was a system of signals on the aqueduct by which the inspectors and workmen were warned of the coming of an engineer.

For some months past Special Treasury Agents Finley and Simmons have been at work on an interesting and peculiar smuggling case, and it has now so far developed that about $10,000 worth of smuggled goods has been seized, and the end has not yet come.
The regular ticket of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange was elected yesterday with the exception of S.B. Hard, who was defeated by J.A. McPherson.

The last monthly meeting of the Ladies' Health Protective Association, at the parlors of the Misses Thomas, 32 West Twenty-sixthstreet, was very well attended. Several subjects pertaining to the public health were discussed.

The Commencement exercises of the Packer Collegiate Institute, Brooklyn, took place last evening. The platform in the chapel was a bank of handsome flowers; the front seats were filled with white-robed maidens, and the remaining space was more than filled with admiring friends.

There is prospect of a sensational session by the Board of Aldermen to-day. It will be the first regular meeting in two weeks, as many of the Aldermen attended the National Democratic Convention in St. Louis.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., June 11.--Kansas will be represented at the Chicago Convention by 18 orphans--they have no mother, and they lost their father when Blaine's second letter appeared.

BALTIMORE, June 11.--The ill-fated yacht Gleam, by the wrecking of which T. Harrison Garrett lost his life, and which was raised yesterday and towed to this city, was placed on the railway this afternoon.

The class of '88 of the University of the City of New-York celebrated class day last evening at Association Hall. The members of the class were in a merry mood, and frequently applauded with tin horns.

The Directors of the Consolidated Railroad decided at their meeting Saturday to have hourly express service from New-York between 8 A.M. and 5 P.M., with the exception of Sunday.
John Walsh arrived Sunday night on the steamship La Normandie from Havre. He bought his ticket and was registered in the list of passengers as M. Walters.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11.--The Daily Evening Post, the only evening paper in San Francisco receiving the Associated Press dispatches, to-day reduced its street price from 5 to 2 cents. This is the first attempt of an evening or morning paper on the Pacific coast to break the five-cent rate for single copies.
Gov. Hill set up his political fences in Kings County yesterday by vetoing the Electric Light and the County Farm bills, and allowing the Bridge bill to die a natural death, but he made many enemies.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 11.--The committee appointed by the Board of Trade to visit Washington and tender an invitation to President and Mrs. Cleveland to visit Columbus on the occasion of the opening of the Centennial Exhibition have postponed their visit at the suggestion of the chairman, Judge Thurman.
PITTSBURG, June 11.--A lively rate war is threatened on all the roads running out of Pittsburg to the National Convention at Chicago.

Miss Jennie Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Mayer, was married to Dr. Max Y. Breitenbach, the well-known druggist, at Delmenico's last night. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. K. Koehlor, rabbi of the Temple Beth-El.

HAVANA, June 11.--The two murderers of Senor Corujos, the well-known merchant who was stabbed to death in Tejadilla-street on Friday night, were run down. One of them while resisting arrest, was shot dead.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 11.--At a meeting of the Harrison Home Club to-night final arrangements were made for going to the Chicago Convention in the interest of Gen. Harrison's candidacy.

The driver escaped with a sprained ankle, but his friend John J. Dwyer of 15 Sixteenth-street, struck on his head and was instantly killed.

The United Brooklyn Conclaves, Ancient Order of Foresters, thoroughly enjoyed their picnic and festival yesterdy at Euler's Park, East New-York. The games were exciting, particularly the tug of war, which created more hubbub than a political caucus.

OMAHA, Neb., June 11.--One of the worst blows the Republican Party of Nebraska has received in years was the one which the Bee, which is considered the most influential Republican paper west of Chicago, gave it to-day.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 11.--The Democrats had a torchlight parade to-night in honor of the nomination of Cleveland and Thurman. The paraders were white hats and dusters, with the bandana conspicuously displayed.

TRENTON, N.J., June 11.--Secretary of State Kelsey has sent out a circular letter to savings banks informing them that the act passed Feb. 22, 1888, authorizing savings banks to invest their funds in first mortgage bonds of any railroad company which has paid dividends of 4 per cent. per annum is null and void.

Charles Collins, 9 years old, of 35 Hancock-place, while crossing the street last night in front of his home, was run over by one of Timman's furniture vans, and was crushed to death. Patrick Coughlin, of 241 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street, the driver of the van, was arrested.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11.--Gen. Alexander Shaler and his staff of what was known as Shaler's Brigade during the war arrived from New-York to-night and registered at the Continental Hotel.
Another death will probably be placed on the list of steeplechase victims. Cross, who trained Bob Miles, and was thrown and rolled on by him at the first hurdle, on Saturday, died yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, June 11.--The 75 yearling thoroughbreds shipped by J.B. Haggin from Sacramento to New-York on June 3 arrived at Washington Park yesterday. They came through in a special train from Sacramento.

WASHINGTON, June 11.--The bond offerings today aggregated $307,200, as follows: Four per cents, coupon--$500 at 127 and interest. Four per cents, registered--$400 at 127 and $140,000 at 127 7/8. Four and one-half per cents. registered--$160,000 at 107 , $1,200 at 107 net, and $5,000 at 108.

CHICAGO, June 11.--Abner Taylor was nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the First Illinois District to-day on the second ballot.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 11.--A Canadian Pacific freight train was thrown from the track near Claremont last night by cattle. The engine, tender, and 14 cars were badly wrecked.

WASHINGTON, June 11.--Gen. Sheridan continues to hold his own. He has passed one more day without a relapse, and if there has been any change in his condition it has been for the better.

Having nine vacancies to fill, the Electric Subway Commission yesterday held a supplementary examination of applicants who had been certified as available by the State Board of Civil Service Examiners.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 11.--Members of the Executive Committee of the Irish-National League are gathering here for a meeting tomorrow to determine upon the time and place of the next convention of the League. Affairs in Ireland will be discussed, but the impression that this conference is to consider the Papal rescript is erroneous, though that may be incidentally discussed.

The dedication of monuments to the soldiers who fell at the battle of Gettysburg in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of that great battle will begin to-day by veterans of the regiments of Gen. Sharler's brigade.

Yesterday was the regular meeting day of the Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge, but only 6 out of 20 answered to their names at roll call, thus failing to produce a quorum.

Although politics are not recognized in the Ancient Order of Foresters, 300 Knights of Sherwood Forest paraded through the streets of Brooklyn yesterday carrying red bandanas. Italian Consul Giovanni B. Raffo was called upon yesterday by E.N. Rich and J. Tolley Worthington of Baltimore to enlist his services in behalf of Leonetto Cipriani, who is supposed to be imprisoned at Bastia, on the island of Corsica.

CHICAGO, June 11.--David Henderson, manager of the Chicago Opera House, to-day bought out the interest held by W.S. Eden in that theatre, and now holds a controlling interset. Mr. Eden's connection with the management has lasted for about a year. He has been a silent partner here, but at the close of the Chicago season of the "Arabian Nights," the summer piece produced at the theatre last year, he took the play on the road.

ELLAVILLE, Fla., June 11.--Dennis Williams, a negro desperado of this place, was lynched yesterday and his body afterward thrown into the Suwannee River where it was found this morning.

LONDON, June 11.--In the House of Commons to-day Lord George Hamilton, First Lord of the Admiralty, stated that the calculation made in regard to the number of transports necessary to enable 100,000 men to land in England and to seize London by surprise took into ...

FORT SMITH, Ark., June 11.--Saturday evening in Equojat district, not far from Webber's Falls, Cherokee Nation, James Seven and William Drew became involved in a difficulty, when the latter drew a pistol and shot Seven through the stomach. He died in a few hours. The murdered man was a great-grandson of John Seven, or, as the Cherokees called him, "Nola Chucke Jack," the first Governor of the nation.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 11.--The Lutheran Ministerium received reports to-day from churches in the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, and Massachusetts which stated that the Lutheran Church is gaining in membership and that its church property is steadily enhancing in value. The Rev. G.C.F. Haas and G.A. Leicht were elected Directors of the Lutheran Theological Seminary at Philadelphia.

An elaborate speech was made in the House yesterday by Mr. GROSVENOR, Republican, of Ohio in favor of the Arrears of Pensions bill and in bitter criticism of the Democratic Party for its indifference to the claims of the soldiers.

LONDON, June 11.--The Berlin correspondent of the St. James Gazette telegraphs that the Emperor is distinctly worse, and has lately suffered severe pains.
To Recorder Smyth and other Judges of the Court of General Sessions who are disgusted with Col. Fellows's administration of the District Attorney's offfice Judge Barrett is now to be added.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 11.--Lord Stanley of Preston, the new Governor-General, was sworn in by Chief-Justice Sir William Ritchie at 3 o'clock to-day. The ceremony took place in the Senate Chamber in the presence of a brilliant assemblage.

Denman Thompson opened at Baldwin's Theatre, San Francisco, last night, for a four weeks' season of "The Old Homestead," after which he and his company will come to NewYork to prepare for the grand revival of the play at the Academy of Music in August.

NEWPORT, R.I, June 11.--Commedore Schley of the United States Navy arrived at the United States training station this morning to inspect the ships and was recieved with the usual salute. He will award the Bailey medal to-morrow morning.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11.--A meeting of Americans who sympathize with the Irish patriots in their struggle to obtain home rule was held this afternoon in Common Council chamber.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11.--After lying dormant for nearly a year the suit of the Pennsylvania Company in New-York against the stockholders of the South Pennsylvania, is about to show some animation.

Charles Cross, the well-known colored jockey, died at the Manhattan Hospital yesterday morning from the injuries he received on Saturday at Jerome Park, when Bob Miles, the horse he was riding in the steeplechase, stumbled at the first hurdle and fell upon him.

The body that was found in the Bay off Bedlow's Island yesterday was identified at the Morgue last night as John McLaren, aged 50 years, a machinist, who lived with his wife and family at 230 East Thirty-fifth-street. He was last seen alive on Nov. 12, when he went fishing.

PRINCETON, June 11.--The new biological laboratory presented by the Alumni of the Class of '77 is now completed and is being fitted out. It will probably be formally handed over to the Trustees at the coming meeting next week.

The Palette Club, a pleasant organization of artists and literary men, which has led for the past few years a somewhat fitful existence, has been resuscitated, and has taken up its abode at 21 West Twenty-fourth-street.
The room occupied by Part II. of the Court of General Sessions has become the rendezvous of Spiritualists, both amateur and professional.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 11.--Mrs. Sarah Leech of New-Milford, Penn., who has been under treatment in the City Hospital here for a few weeks past, committed suicide last night by drowning in the Susquehanna River. The body was recovered this morning. The patient had been suffering from the effects of cancer and was temporarily deranged.

WEST POINT, June 11.--They are cadets no longer. They are "going out in the wide, wide world to see what they can see." The Class of '88 has left the "old gray prison" and is now prepared to "don the army blue."

The probability of a fleet of English ironclads coming over here, anchering off Sandy Hook, and bowling over the Goddess of Liberty was fortunately dispelled yesterday morning in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions by Judge Gildersleeve discharging Alice Woodhall from the custody of the country authorities.

One of the trusts investigated by a committee of the United States Senate during the Spring was the Oil Cloth Trust. Under the name of the "Table and Stair Oil Cloth Association," this trust has just issued a circular to the trade imposing conditions of so peculiar and oppressive ...

BANGOR, Me., June 11.--Hayes, one of the postal clerks, has confessed that Sinclair, the victim of the postal car tragedy, came to his death at the hands of Sellen, the chief clerk, and the latter has admitted the same to his counsel, and has told something of the deed to the jury.

Morris Jacobs, tailor, at 114 Fultonstreet, made an assignment yesterday to Lewis H. Ryder, giving four preferences for $1,964. He has been in business over 20 years. It is said be failed in 1879, and then his wife carried on the business until June, 1886, when she made an assignment. Mr. Jacobs then used his own name again and continued until now.

It is not improbable that the Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Surface Railway Company may before long replace the present system of horse power with electricity. Thomas F. Ryan, Secretary and Treasurer of the Broadway Company, said yesterday that it would like to get rid of horses and substitute electricity if it were proved a cheaper ...
SAN FRANCISCO, June 11.--Drafts--Sight, 17 ; telegraphic, 22 .

The explanation given yesterday in the Italian Chamber of Deputies of the origin of the recent trouble with Zanzibar throws little new light on the subject, but, so far as it goes, confirms the impression that Italy is resorting to a grasping policy.

The New-York County Democracy Committee of the Eleventh Assembly District met last evening at its headquarters, 472 Sixth-avenue, to ratify the nomination of Cleveland and Thurman. The resolutions passed stated that for the first time in the Nation's history the Chief Magistrate was placed in nomination without a ballot.

CHICAGO, June 11.--All the delegations to the National Republican Convention have secured their hotel accommodations, with the exception of those from Mississippi, North Carolina, Texas, Utah, and the District of Columbia.
LONDON, June 11.--The Inman Line steamship City of Richmond, Capt. Redford, from New-York June 2 for Liverpool, was signaled off Kinsale at 6:30 P.M. to-day.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 11.--The Second District Dental Society of the State of NewYork, made up of dentists from all points between Brooklyn and New-York and Albany, assembled here in semi-annual session to-day. Dr. J.J. Pitts of New-York presided.

ALGIERS, June 11.--The locusts are advancing in a compact mass over 12 miles long by 6 in breadth. A panic prevails in the province of Constantine. The valley of Guelma has been devastated by the locusts.

BURLINGTON, N.J., June 12.--Henry C. Ladmaster, a well-known lumber dealer of this place, has made an assignment without any preferences to Nathan Haines, Cashier of the Mechanics' National Bank, for the benefit of his creditors. Gov. Hill's veto of the Electoral Reform bill, while disappointing to the friends of the measure, did not strike any one with surprise. Members of the Legislature who had been interested in the measure were assured by their Democratic colleagues that it would never become a law.
MONTPELIER, Vt., June 12.--The Prohibition State Convention for Vermont, consisting of about 100 members, met here this morning to nominate a State ticket.

DANVILLE, Va., June 12.--At an early hour this morning C.F. King, editor of the Watchman, a weekly journal, was publicly caned ou Main-street near the Post Office by two young men named Ed and Granville Ashlin.
KANSAS CITY, June 12.--The largest crowd ever at a Kansas City race track was at Waldo Park to-day to see the great Derby. The race was a mile and a half, and had $3,000 added money.

Without Ewing the New-York Club is incomplete. On Monday his coaching was sadly missed, and yesterday his batting and work behind the bat would have won a game for the Giants.

BRIDGEPORT, June 12.--A brilliant assemblage witnessed the marriage of Miss Julia Billings to Mr. Wilbur Brooks Smith of Auburn, N.Y., this evening, at the residence of the bride's mother, Soney, at Park-place.

The village of Edgewater, on the bank of the Hudson in Bergen County, N.J, is very much exercised over the summary disposal of the drowned body of an unknown woman which floated ashore there last Friday and an hour after its discovery was placed in the shallow grave prepared for it.
LONDON, June 12.--The first indication here to-day of the alarming condition of the German Emperor was at Ascot.
Pilot Rolfe of the pilot boat Lillie, No. 8, who brought up the steamship State of Nebraska yesterday, brought news that his boat is returning to port in a much disabled condition.

Mayor Cleveland of Jersey City is anxious for the good of the city that the Board of Public Works should organize. The board, which is composed of six members, has been dead-locked since April.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 12.--In the General Assembly this morning Jonathan Chace was reelected United States Senator by a majority of both houses. The vote was: Senate--J. Chsee, 29; J.W. Davis, 4; Charles H. Page 1, House-- Chace, 59; Davis, 8; Page, 1. A joint resolution of adjournment from Wednesday, June 13, to the third Tuesday in January, 1888, was passed.

The annual "washing" of the lambs of the Lambs, Club was held last Sunday at Wallack's Island, the property of Lester Wallack, adjoining his home at Stamford.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 12.--On Feb. 1 last the mammoth iron dry goods stores of Barnes, Hengerer Co. were totally destroyed by fire, entailing a loss of $1,250,000 and damaging about a dozen adjacent stores.

The smuggling case exposed yesterday, in which Miss Bessie Montour, who passed herself off as an actress, Mrs. Ludvigh of 7 East Thirteenth-street, and several valuable dresses from Worth of Paris figured, had an interesting sequel yesterday in the arrival of Miss Bessie on the North German Lloyd steamer Eider.

When Gov. Hill signed his name to the McEvoy Elevator bill, he put about every man who is interested in floating elevators, and many of those who are interested in the grain trade, in a state of high indignation.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 12.--After having been in session for a week the Lutheran Ministerium concluded its business sessions to-night. The Committee on Discipline stated that the Rev. J. Keerl, formerly of Bergholz, had been expelled on charges of a serious nature. Tomorrow the delegates will spend the day in the Catskill Mountains, as the guests of the Hon. Thomas Cornell, and on Thursday they will return to their respective homes.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--The bond offerings today aggregated $2,678,600, as follows: Four per cent. coupons--$4,000 at 127 5/8, $7,600 at 127 5/8; 4 per cent. registered--$1,000 at 127, $13,000 at 126 5/8. flat; $2,000,000 at 127 5/8, $140,000 at 127 7/8; 4 per cent. registered--$160,000 at 107 1-9. $550,000 at 107 1/8, $3,000 at 107 .
CHICAGO, June 12.--Dispatches from points in Northern Iowa and Western Illinois report the appearance of swarms of 17-year locusts.

The Board of Electrical Control yesterday took its first step in the offensive in its war upon the electrical companies which continue to defy its authority by refusing to make use of the subways already completed.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 12.--There was a large and brilliant attendance at Ciass Day observance at Vassar College this afternoon, the exercises lasting over three hours.

Christopher Krauss and his family were breakfasting in their apartment on the second floor of 217 Greene-street at 6:30 yesterday morning, when they were startled by a woman's scream in an adjoining room, the bedchamber of Mr. and Mrs. Emilio Marri.

BALTIMORE, June 12.--Willie Alt, only 15 years of age, killed his father last night because, as the boy says, he could not stand seeing his father beating his poor mother to death. Peter Alt was the proprietor of the Arlington House, near the Pimlice race course, and leaves a large estate.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 12.--Jay Gould, his son, and Vice-President Hopkins of the Missouri Pacific Railroad arrived here by special train from Memphis this afternoon, on their way to New-York, for which city they will leave in the morning via the East Tennessee route.

In a few months Mr. Potter can sit on the top of his big building on Park-row, and be in the shade. There is going up alongside of that lofty structure another that will be 20 feet higher. It will be the old TIMES Building with a new stone overcoat on, a mansard roof for a high hat, and a practically new interior.
PITTSBURG, June 12.--Chairman B.F. Jones of the National Republican Committee will leave for Chicago to-morrow evening.

Rumors of a conference of Republican leaders at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last night for the purpose of arriving at an agreement for concert of action in the New-York delegation at Chicago next week were in circulation and found general acceptance among the politicians who were present.

Col. Fellows is undoubtedly on his way home, and Mr. Semple hopes that he will reach here this morning. By a great piece of good luck Mr. Semple's urgent telegram, which he sent after his conversation with Judge Barrett, was delivered to Col. Fellows at St. Paul.

KANSAS CITY, June 12.--The State Prohibition Convention was called to order at 10 o'clock to-day. About 400 delegates were present. When Dr. Brooks appeared upon the stage he was greeted with applause.
The great hall of Cooper Union was last evening well filled with enthusiastic Democrats, who attended the regular monthly meeting of the County Democracy's County and Assembly District Committees.
CHICAGO, June 12--"The Crystal Slipper" was given for the first time to-night at the Chicago Opera House, where it is to be presented for the Summer season.
PORTLAND, Me., June 12.--The Republican State Convention met at 11 o'clock. The convention hall was packed, fully 3,000 persons being present.

The Spring meeting of the American Jockey Club came to an end yesterday, and was ushered out with excitement enough to satisfy the cravings of the most worn of the men of the world who were present.
GALESBURG, Ill., June 12.--Dr. Newton Bateman, for 13 years President of Knox College, to-day presented his resignation to the Board of Trustees to take effect July 1. His health has been failing.
The Presidents of the railroads that form the Trunk Line Association held a meeting at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday afternoon, and all were present except Chauncey. M. Depew.
CHICAGO, June 12.--For some inexplicable reason the mercury in the Harrison thermometer has risen during the day, while that in the Sherman and Gresham tubes has taken a little tumble.

Tammany Hail's ratification of the nomination of Cleveland and Thurman at the Academy of Music last evening was a grand success in numbers, in enthusiasm, and especially in the hearty and multitudinous cheers which were shouted whenever the name of the President was mentioned.

The sole reason given by Gov. HILL for refusing to approve the bill authorizing the Edison Company to furnish electric light in Brooklyn is that it would violate the principle of home rule to which he is "irrevocably committed."

The Republicans of Maine seem bound to keep up the gait at which the State, as reported in song and story, "went for Gov. KENT." But it might be as well for them to remember that that was the last occasion on which the party then winning was on the victorious side in a national contest for a good many years.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 12.--The St. Louis River, in Northern Minnesota, is racing to-day and is said to be higher by far than for 20 years, and at the Duluth end has spread itself over fields until it has become a great lake.

Justice Solon B. Smith rendered his decision yesterday in the case of Henry Friedman of 402 East One Hundred and Fourth-street, who was arrested last February at the instance of Charles H. Reilly, credit clerk in the employ of F. Vietor ...

Several gentlemen interested in navigation went to the swimming bath at the Battery yesterday to inspect the working model of a new kind of propeller for steam vessels. It is called the "Bender" propeller.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 12.--Over 500 delegates were present at the opening session of the State Sunday School Convention this morning in the Brick Church. Ira D. Sankey is in attendance and led in the song, "Bringing in the Sheaves."

Robert Hilliard, the actor, was examined before Judge Nehrbas in the City Court yesterday in supplementary proceedings on the judgment obtained in November, 1887, by his cousin, F.R. Smith, for $448.83 borrowed money.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 12.--Rumor is again busy with the name of Superintendent Manvel of the Manitoba Road, and it is asserted that, despite denials, the resignation of Mr. Manvel is in the hands of President Hill, who has delayed taking any action thus far.

At 12:45 this morning fire was discovered in the three-story tenement on Second-street and Second-avenue. Three families occupied each floor of the building and the greatest excitement occurred when they woke up and discovered the flames rising from the cellar in which they originated.
LONDON, June 12.--Steamship Croma (Br.,) Lord, from New-York May 27, arr. at Leith to-day.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 12.--The new armory of Company C, New-Jersey National Guard, was formally opened to-night. The town was gayly decorated with bunting and Chinese lanterns.
CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, June 12.--The talk Elvira arrived at Altata, Sinaloa, on the 11th inst., with materials from England for the construction of the Sinaloa and Durango Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12.--Mrs. Sarah J. Whiteling, a short, stout, rather coarse-featured woman, 40 years of age, was committed to prison by Coroner Ashbridge this afternoon after she had confessed to deliberately murdering her husband and two children.

OMAHA, Neb., June 12.--Gen. John C. Fremont has accepted an invitation of the Republicans of Omaha to accompany them to Chicago and be their guest during the convention week.
An interesting day was spent yesterday at Garden City by the parents and friends of the scholars attending the two cathedral schools there, St. Paul's and St. Mary's.
AUX-LES-BAINS, June 12.--The Emperor of Brazil went for a drive in the park this morning.

Bury Irwin Dasent of the staff of the NewYork Herald was married yesterday at noon in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square, to Miss Eleanor Barry of the Rosina Vokes comedy com pany. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Rainsford, Mrs. Dasent has no intention of retiring fron the stage, but will in all probability be connected with one of the stock companies in this city next season.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 12.--A license was issued to-day by the County Clerk for the marriage of Miss Amelia Rives, the authoress, to John A. Chandler of New-York.

Henry Johnson, alias Herman G. Clark, and John H. Williams, alias Henry H. Williams, two of the most notorious "boarding house" thieves in this city, were yesterday sent where their field of operations will be limited.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 12.--The Rev. William H. Moore of this city, Statistical Secretary of the General Conference of Congregational churches in this State, has just completed the compilation of statistics for 1887.

Miss Minnie Terry, the Spiritualist, who sued Mrs. Perine, another Spiritualist, for libeling her, got 12 cents damages yesterday morning.

To any one who had never heard the story of the defalcation in the Wall-street bank of the Manhattan Company, the second day's proceedings in the trial of John R. Dunn in the Supreme Court, before Judge Barrett, yesterday would have possessed strong interest.

On Monday the Children's Aid Society opened for the season its beautiful Summer home for poor children at Bath, Long Island, and 242 children from the various schools went to the home to spend the week.

Miss Augusta Ohling, a young German woman living at 345 West Fortieth-street, NewYork, was in Jersey City yesterday looking for William D. Robinson, who was formerly the Station Agent of the Erie Railroad at Arlington.

LONDON, June 12.--The race for the Ascot Stakes was won by J. Jameson's 4-year-old ch. c. Dan Dancer by three lengths, Lord Cholmondeley's Chippeway second, and Willyams third. Ten started. Seven to one each was laid against Dan Dancer and Chippeway. Banter was the favorite.

PANAMA, June 4.--Yesterday morning about 1 o'clock a fire started in a wooden house owned by a Chinaman adjoining the Hotel Roma, another structure of wood, and before the firemen could reach the scene the fire had communicated with the hotel.

BALTIMORE, June 12.--The body of T. Harrison Garrett, the banker who was drowned last Thursday night in the collision of his yacht with a steamer, was found this morning floating on the bay not a great distance from where he went down. Every effort had been made to recover the dead.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., June 12.--The survivers of the Twenty-third and Eighty-second Pennsylvania and the Sixty-fifth and One Hundred and Twenty-second New-York Regiments, comprising Shaler's Brigade Association, arrived here this afternoon by special train.
WATERVILLE, Me., June 12.--The Union Labor State Convention was held here to-day. F.A. Howard of Belfast was President and A. F. Wooster of Rockland Secretary.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--Senator Cullom called up in the Senate to-day the bill prepared by his committee some time ago to amend the inter-State commerce law, and made a long and careful explanation of the effect and bearing of the proposed amendments.

Messrs. Drexel Morgan announced yesterday that, through the mediation of their houses here and in London, all differences between the Erie Railroad and James McHenry, including Erie's Judgment of $2,000,000 against Mr. McHenry, had been amicably adjusted.
READING, Penn., June 12.--The large puddle mill at Naomi, this county, is idle. The price of puddling was reduced to $3.35 per ton, a reduction of 10 per cent., and the puddlers refused to work.

The Twenty-second Regiment is complaining that although the ground for its new armory at Sixty-seventh-street and the Boulevard has been purchased and $300,000 has been appropriated for the erection of the armory matters are in such shape that there is a delay in the building.
Every one of the 5,000 people who went down to Manhattan Beach Tuesday night to see the initial performance of Pain's latest pyrotechnic spectacle, "The Fire of London," came home well pleased.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 13.--Haik Garribed, a youthful Turk, who came to the theological seminary in this city two years ago, has, it appears, a most unenviable record. It seems that Garribed has recently obtained money by presenting himself to members of the churches as a student at the seminary.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13.--Lawyer George B. Carr yesterday issued a writ of foreign attachment in Common Pleas Court No. 4 for James S. Martin Co., dyers, against the L.B. Smith Rubber Company of New-York.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 13, via Galveston.-- There was a heavy rainfall, which lasted three hours, at Fresnillo, State of Zacatecas, last night. Eleven houses were washed away and three persons were drowned. Many houses were badly damaged. Immense hailstones caused much damage. There is one metre of water in the streets. The Governor is giving aid to the sufferers.
The Governing Committee of the NewYork Stock Exchange held a meeting yesterday which is expected to have exceedingly important results.
BALTIMORE, June 13.--Congressman Rayner stated last night that he would introduce a bill in Congress in reference to the case of Leonetto Cipriani, the Baltimorean now under arrest in Italy.

One hundred and forty-six young lawyers were turned loose upon a cold and heartless world last night, although that portion of the world which found its way into the interior of the Metropolitan Opera House last evening gave the newly-fledged L.L.B.'s a sympathetic and enthusiastic welcome.

ST. LOUIS, June 13.--Nine thousand people assembled in the north nave of the Exposition Building to-night to listen to the welcoming concert given by the people of St. Louis to the Saenger societies from all parts of the country.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 13.--A large delegation to the New-York State Sunday School Association Convention arrived on the Falls Road train this morning, and it is now estimated that there are at least 800 delegates at the convention.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13.--A.R. McHenry Co., commission merchants at 113 Walnutstreet, yesterday issued an attachment under the Fraudulent Debtors act against John S. Pennock, Joseph Pennock, and C.E. Pennock, who traded as C.E. Pennock Co., of the Valley Iron Works at Coatesville.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 13.--Among the passengers from Washington who passed through the Union Station this morning was Fred Douglass, whose towering frame showed but little signs of old age, except for the snowy mass of lion-like locks that crowned his head and fell in waves upon his massive shoulders.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13.--In the House of Representatives this afternoon the advocates of the Kansas injunction law, seeing that the law could not be passed at the present session except in an emasculated form, if at all, secured its recommitment to the committee, to hold public hearings and report at the January session.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 13.--The Executive Committee of the Irish National League met yesterday. There were present John Fitzgerald of Lincoln, Neb., the President; John P. Sutton, Secretary; the Rev. Charles O'Reilly, ...

Whether the plot that is unquestionably on foot to force the nomination of BLAINE at the last moment be successful or not-- and for the credit of the Republican Party it is to be hoped that it cannot be successful--the various steps by which the Blaine managers are proceeding throw a good deal of light upon the condition of the party.
At last the Lick Trustees have transferred the great observatory to the Regents of the Univesity, and the splendid institution is a part of the educational system of the State.

BERLIN,June 13.--The people of this city appear to have made up their minds that the death of Emperor Frederick is a mere matter of a short time, and the quiet born of suspense which is affecting all classes of the community strongly reminds one of the last days of the old Emperor.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 13.--A joint resolution was unanimously passed to-day memorializing Congress to provide for the completion of the Chalmette monument, and ceding to the United States jurisdiction over the Chalmette monument and plain.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 13.--The Presbyterians of Georgia are celebrating in this city the formation of the General Assembly of the church. Gov. Gordon presided at to-night's session. Among the speakers taking part in the exercises are the leading ministers of the church in Georgia.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 13.--Over 100 Columbia County people--including editors and reporters of the various newspapers, members of the Bar, business men, and farmers--are here in attendance as witnesses in the quo warranto proceedings now in progress in the Circuit Court, marked on the calendar as "The People of the State of New-York against John P. Mickle and others."

Mrs. James Brown Potter's answer to the charges made against her by her former manager, H. C. Miner, has been filed in the City Supreme Court. Through her counsel, ex-Judge A.J. Dittenhoefer and Franklin Bartlett, the defendant denies each allegation in the complaint, except the allegation that no part of the amount claimed in the complaint has been paid.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 13.--The chapel at Vassar College was crowded at Commencement this morning. There were no decorations, except a single bouquet of flowers on the platform in front of the organ.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 13.--Two serious wash-outs have occurred on the St. Paul and Duluth Road, which renders the line from Duluth to the Northern Pacific junction impassable until the high water in the St. Louis River subsides.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--From the Committee on Ventilation and Acoustics, Representative Landes of Illinois to-day reported to the House, with favorable recommendations, the bill making an appropriation of $150,000 to enable Mr. A. de Bausset to build an air ship.

The debate on Monday night in the House of Commons upon the question whether Great Britain could be successfully invaded at the present time brought up the usually neglected but fundamental inquiry how a foreign army is to get there.

Miss Bessie Montour, the young lady who has been creating a sensation in Custom House circles for the past few days, had a chance to explain her position in Mrs. Ludvigh's enterprise of smuggling Worth dresses into this country to Collector Magone yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 13.--Drafts--Sight, 17 ; telegraphic,25 .
The "Official Turf Guide," published by Goodwin Brothers to-day, contains in addition to the usual complete records the list of winning jockeys so far this season.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 13.--One Andrew Jackson Brown, colored, is creating a decided sensation in Soddy, a mining village near this city.

James S. Cowlin and Francis J.C. Ferris, the lace importers at 273 Church-street, whose fraudulent transactions have occupied the courts during the past year, seem to have given up the contest for good now, and yesterday they gave themselves up to Order of Arrest Clerk Bernard F. Martin and are now in LudlowStreet Jail.

As the propeller Captain John from Portland was rounding Corlear's Hook, in front of Coe's stores, at the foot of Corlear's-slip, East River, yesterday morning, she was caught by the strong ebb tide and carried with much force ...
Mr. Hiram Maxim's mitrailleuse gun has been accepted by the Austro-Hungarian War Ministry, and orders have been given for 30 of these weapons to be delivered before the end of 1888.
The funeral services of John Otto Hundt, the former President of the Arion Singing Society, were held in accordance with his preferences at Arion Hall yesterday morning.
TORONTO, Ontario, June 13.--The American schooner John Bird, from Jonesport, Me., for Hillsborough, went ashore near Mispec, New-Brunswick, and will be a total wreck. No insurance.
BALTIMORE,June 13.--Mr. McLane, United States Minister to France, leaves Baltimore today for New-York, and will sail from that cityon Saturday for Havre on the steamer La Normandle.

The New-York Schuetzen Corps, the oldest German sharpshooting association in this city, yesterday began their annual Schuetzenfest at Schuetzen Park, Union Hill, N.J. Several of the old-time members have disappeared, some having died and others having left this part of the country.

The June meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will be inaugurated to-day at the beautiful grounds at Sheepshead Bay. Superintendent Frank T. Clarke has made use of every means at his disposal to add to the natural beauties of the place, and the eyes of the onlookers will be refreshed by broad stretches of green and beautiful beds of flowers.
ELMIRA, N.Y., June 13.--The Rev. A.W. Cowles, D.D., has been President of the Elmira Female College for 33 years. Next June he will be 70 years of age.

MADISON, Ind., June 13.--Miss Viola Johnson (colored) of the Stewart Concert Company, being ordered to a separate table from the white passengers on the steamer City of Madison, has given notice of a suit for damages against the Louisville and Cincinnati Mail Line Company.

ROCHESTER, June 13.--The first of the suits for damages growing out of the great naphtha explosion in this city last December resulted to-day in the Circuit Court in a verdict against the Vacuum Oil Company of this city in favor of Mrs. Ann Lee for $5,000.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 13.--The Board of Trustees of Franklin and Marshall College this morning refused to accept Thomas G. Apple's resignation of the Presidency, and he agreed to serve another year, being relieved of the discipline of the college.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 13.--The report comes from Marion that the old yellow house on the point, opposite the old landing in Marion Harbor, is refitting for the occupancy of Mrs. Cleveland this Summer.

The action of the Union Club at its meeting on Tuesday evening, postponing the taking of any steps in regard to acquiring the Stewart mansion as a clubhouse until November next, was yesterday regarded with great equanimity by the members of the Manhattan Club, it giving them the first chance to obtain the property.

Much excitement has been caused at Montlery by the murder of an old lady of 70, Mme. Saintin. Although worth upward of 200,000 she lived in the most simple manner, employing only a charwoman and a lad named Charron to do the work of the house and garden, Mme. Saintin herself acted as cook, and took her meals with the two servants.

Frederick H. Galt, employed in the Treasurer's office of the Standard Oil Company, was run over by a Manhattan Beach train on Atlantic-avenue, near Ralph-avenue, Brooklyn, at about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and had ...
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 13.--Prof. Otto Lugger, the entomologist of the State University, has been up in the Otter Tail locust region and has brought back interesting reports of his observations there.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 13.--Shotwell, Clerihew Hothman, the Minneapolis wholesale dry goods firm, are financially embarrassed. They suspended payment to-day and a meeting of the creditors has been called.
A movement is on foot among a number of business men in this city to have Thomas F. Gilroy, the present Deputy County Clerk, nominated for Sheriff to succeed Hugh J. Grant.
The ceremony of laying the cornerstone of the S.R. Smith Infirmary's new administration building on Castleton-avenue, NewBrighton, Staten Island, was performed yesterday.

LUCKNOW, Ontario, June 13.--Stephen Martin, living on the lake shore near Kingsbridge, found a bottle on the beach on Sunday last. Inside was a piece of paper signed by Capt. McDunn, and saying that the schooner Tiffen of Bay City, Mich., went down with all hands 15 miles from Goderich. There was no date on the paper.

At the meeting of the grain and elevator men held yesterday in the call room at the Produce Exchange, A.E. Orr presided, and it was determined to appoint a committee from the grain trade to confer with the committee of the elevator men already appointed upon the best way to undo the harm done or claimed to have been done by the McEvoy Elevator bill's passage into a law.

PITTSBURG, June 13.--Senator Farwell of Illinois passed through the city to-night en route to Chicago. In an interview he stated that Blaine's name would probably be presented at the Chicago Convention, and if nominated he would accept.
TORONTO, June 13.--On the night of Aug. 25 last year Joseph Priestman, an insurance agent, living in Parkdale, a suburb of this city, died from a bullet wound in the head, and was ...

By the midnight fire in the tenement house at Second-avenue and Second-street, yesterday morning, one man, Gustav Berkel, lost his life from inhalation of smoke and flame, and two persons lie at the point of death in Bellevue Hospital. One of these is Mrs. Christiana Weiss, a woman about 30 years old.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission is at present in this city investigating the complaint of the Produce Exchange that the railroads which bring grain and other commodities from the West to the seaboard discriminate against the local trade of NewYork for the benefit of foreign customers.

The Park Commissioners yesterday decided that no more drawbridges should be built over the Harlem River. The report of Gen. John Newton, Edgar B. Van Winkle, Thomas C. Clarks, and George W. McNulty, the engineers appointed to consider the relative advantages of drawbridges, high-span bridges, or tunnels as a means of communication across the Harlem River, made their report.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--The sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee, which is gathering material out of which to shape the course of the Senate in opposition to any tariff reduction bill which may come to it from the House of Representatives, ...
The information which comes from Colombia in regard to fraudulent applications for pensions under the State law is not pleasant reading.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 13.--It has been learned that Judge Buckingham of the Licking County Court of Common Pleas has set the trial of the Hocking Valley case for July 9 and ordered the plaintiffs to furnish an additional bond of $100,000.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 13.--In conversation with an officer of the Yale Navy today some facts were learned with regard to the Yale University crew which have not yet been made public.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 13.--The Connecticut delegates to the National Republican Convention will leave here for Chicago on Friday night, and will be among the first of the New-England delegates on the ground.
From London to St. Petersburg, even before the Summer acceleration of service between on the Russian capital and the German frontier has taken place, can be easily performed in three days.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 13.--Green Mountain Maid, the dam and granddam of more fast trotters than any other mare that ever lived, died a day or two ago at Mr. Charles Backman's Stony Ford Stock Farm, in this county, of old age and paralysis.
CORYMANS, N.Y., June 13.--Many experiments in burning brick with oil in place of wood are being made by manufacturers of brick along the Hudson River.

Bang! went the signal gun of the Columbia Yacht Club at 10:55 yesterday morning, and before the pretty girls on board the steamer Cygnus had recovered from the start it gave them, the White Wing with every bit of sail set and drawing, dashed across the line before a ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 13.--The railway managers appeared before the Iowa Commissioners yesterday to make final remonstrance against the new freight schedules which are to be announced probably this week.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 13.--The Amalgamated Association placed itself on record today on the tariff question. The Tariff Committee appointed several days ago has been carefully weighing the matter before drawing up any resolutions, and at the forenoon session of the convention they were presented.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 13.--The threemile race between Kennedy of Quincy, Ill., and Plaisted of Portland, Me., on Lake Quinsigamond this afternoon, was easily won by the former, who took the lead at the start and finished 30 lengths ahead in 22:07 . Kennedy stopped rowing once. He pulled the last mile very lazily. Plaisted made bad work steering.

ROCHESTER, June 13.--The defalcation of ex-Sheriff Van Camp of Orleans County is still the sensation of the hour in this vicinity. New creditors of the once trusted and honored citizen are constantly appearing, mostly the holders of notes of from $10 to $50 each for indorsers of Van Camp's notes for like amounts.
CINCINNATI, June 13.--The procession of the Knights of Pythias this afternoon was a very brilliant affair,though it did not contain the promised 30,000 people.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 13.--Solomon G. Comstock was to-day nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the Fifth District of Minnesota, and if elected will succeed Knute Nelson.
FREDERICKSBURG, Va., June 13.--At Chancellorsville the monument that marks the spot where Stonewall Jackson received the wound from which he died was dedicated to-day with imposing ceremonies.

Miss Dora Wheeler, an artist at 124 East Twenty-seventh-street, went to England in 1885 and painted portraits of Austin Dobson, Walter Besant, and Mrs. Thackeray Ritchie, (Thackeray's daughter,) the novelists, and of others.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 13.--The trial of a remarkable homicide case commonly known as the "melon patch murder," has just been finished in the Otsego County Circuit Court and Oyer and Terminer.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 13.--Henry Boswick of Ludlow Centre was murdered in a cowardly and brutal manner by an employe of Forepaugh's circus this afternoon named Harry Taylor.
Contrary to expectation fewer politicians are around the hotels this week than last. Neither the corridor of the Fifth-Avenue nor of the Hoffman was crowded last evening.

In compliance with the resolution passed by the Brooklyn Central Labor Union last Sunday, representatives of the different district assemblies of the Knights of Labor in this neighborhood met Tuesday evening in Canalstreet.

DETROIT, Mich., June 13.--A wealthy citizen of Worcester, Mass., named Maculler, with his wife and a lady friend, have been visiting of late the mineral springs at Mount Clemens, about 30 miles from Detroit, and creating quite a sensation by their lavish display of fine clothes and costly jewelry.

L. Laflin Kellogg, as counsel for Andrew J. Kimball, obtained from Judge Van Hoesen, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, a temporary injunction restraining the Gas Commission from awarding contracts for the lighting of the streets of the city for the year ending May 1, 1889.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 13.--Commander-in-Chief J.P. Rea of the National Grand Army of the Republic to-day issued general orders No. 8 in substance as follows:

"Boodle" Alderman Henry W. Jaehne, who is serving a term of nine years and ten months in the State prison at Sing Sing for bribery, two years of which have expired, has had his last hope of relief dissipated.

ALBANY, June 13.--A daring daylight robbery in the Albany Post Office came to light today. It occurred on April 26, between 1 and 2 o'clock in the afternoon, when Deputy Postmaster Isaac McMurdy was alone in the main office of the Postmaster in the southeast corner of the building.

EL PASO, Texas, June 8.--Col. Jesse R. Grant, the son of Gen. U.S. Grant, arrived in El Paso this morning, after a trip of several months' duration through various portions of Mexico, partly for pleasure and health and partly on business.
CHICAGAO, June 13.--The officials of eastbound roads have been unable to check the unprecedented drift of all kinds of freight to the lake lines this year, and the in- ...
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 13.--Nineteen persons were poisoned at Kasola, Minn., from eating cheese which was found to have been manufactured in Wisconsin.

Col. D.W.C. Ward of the Seventy-first Regiment Veterans says that the trip to-day of delegations of various regiments of this city and Brooklyn to Brooklyn, Conn., to participate in the dedication of the equestrian statue to Gen. Israel Putnam is only made to carry out the scheme lately commenced of paying more attention than heretofore to patriotic events.

CHICAGO, June 13.--Timothy Sullivan, the eighth victim of the Haymarket bomb among the Chicago police, died to-day. He was one of the best men on the force, and was connected with the Police Department for six years.
CATSKILL, N. Y., June 13.--The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America devoted the forenoon to the report on domestic missions, which was read by the Rev. Dr. Wesley A. Davis.
Some of my readers may have noticed in public print that the original pass given by Arnold to Andre has been offered for sale by a descendant of Paulding, who was one of the captors of the latter.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 13.--Col. Frank W. Cheney of South Manchester entertained a notable gathering of Hartford gentlemen at his residence in that place to-night.
The Alumni Association of the Stevens Institute of Technology held its twelfth annual meeting last evening at the institute, Hoboken.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 13.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 1,275--In re McGraw-Fiske.-- Argument resumed and concluded. No. 1,291--The People, respondents, vs. Andrew E. Merwin, appellant.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 13.--Jay Gould spent severel hours in this city to-day. His health has improved greatly in the past day or two, and he seemed to enjoy the reception and luncheon given him by the leading citizens of Knoxville.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 13.--It is now pretty well understood here that a big effort has been made in certain quarters during the past few days to place Gov. Foraker in a false position ...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June. 13.--A very pleasant reception was held aboard the flagship Richmond Tuesdap afternoon. It was given to the officers attached to the Naval Academy and their families by Admiral Luce, Capt. Boyd, and tha officers of the flagship, in return for the numerous hospitalities extended to the officers of the squadron during their stay in this place.
BUENOS-AYRES, June 13, via Galveston.--Yesterday the agent of the steamer Nile delivered 150,000 brought from England to the Nacional Bank.

BALTIMORE, June 13.--The funeral of Mr. T. Harrison Garrett this afternoon was largely attended. The remains were brought from "Evergreen," the beautiful country residence of the deceased, and interred in the family plot in Green Mount Cemetery.

CHICAGO, June 13.--Five portraits decorate the front of a safe behind the counter in the office of the Grand Pacific Hotel. They are the portraits of Alger, Allison, Gresham in one row, and those of Sherman and Harrison in another.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 13.--The Western Association of Coal Dealers is in annual session here. Twenty-five of the members have quit the business during the year because they were unable to compete in their localities with natural gas.

The Crise will case was given to the jury yesterday at 2:20 o'clock, after ex-Gov. William Pinkney Whyte had concluded the closing address on the part of the plaintiff, which occupied the entire day up to that time.

The annual tournament of St. George's Cricket Club for singles only for the championship of the Middle States commenced yesterday at Hoboken. Some excellent work was done, Messrs. Campbell and Paton seeming to be the favorites. The following score shows up well for each winner:

GAINESVILLE, Texas, June 13.--The negroes in the Chickasaw Nation are making preparations for a general exodus to Oklahoma, where they contemplate farming. Numerous colonies are entering lands and making permanent plans. Several thousand of them assembled at Wynnewood, Indian Territory, yesterday for organization. Sam Paul, a full-blood Chickasaw tribal Senator, is assisting the colored people in this move.

TRENTON, N. J., June 13.--Barclay W. Peak, the slayer of Katie Anderson, his sweetheart, was taken to the Supreme Court for sentence to-day. He was neatly dressed in a suit of brown cassimere, and there was nothing about his appearance to indicate that he had spent many months in jail.

Frank Burke, 1,762 Third-avenue, who has recently applied for appointment as a policeman, was committed in the Harlem Police Court yesterday to await the result of injuries which he inflicted upon Joseph Burke, a coachman of 218 East Eightiethstreet, and which may result in the latter's death.
BRISBANE, Queensland, June 13.--A match race for 500 a side between Hanlan and Trickett was rowed on the Fitzroy River to-day. Hanlan beat his opponent by six lengths.

Col. John R. Fellows has returned from the West in an apparently defiant mood. On his arrival home last evening he found a number of reporters waiting for him, and in the course of a long explanation to them about his singular neglect of his duties he summed up his position with the remark: "If the public don't like it they'll have to get along without liking it."

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 13.--The opening of the Peoples' Theatre Monday with a stock company under the management of C.J. Wilson and L.W. Walker was made memorable by the presence of the State and city officials, the regular army officers from Fort Snelling, and a ...
Manager E. G. Gilmore told a TIMES representative last evening all about the newlyorganized Metropolitan Opera-Glass Company, in which he is a Director.
GAINESVILLE, Ga., June 13.--Gov. Gordon has pardoned John M. Cheatham, who was under a life sentence in the penitentiary for the killing of William Etheridge. The parties were at a corn shucking.
The stock market has developed a measureable activity lately, but yesterday, as on the preceding days when trading was liveliest, quotations were weakest.

A case of a somewhat exceptional nature was tried before Judge Cowing in Part III. of General Sessions yesterday. The defendant, Ellen Hoar, was accused of unlawfully marrying one James J. Plunkett, on April 26 last, in that before the marriage she knew Plunkett ...

Richard S. Scott, the self-confessed defaulting Paying Teller of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, who turned State's evidence against his alleged partner in crime, John R. Dunn, the lawyer on trial for grand larceny before Judge Barrett and jury in the Court of ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 13.--The Grand Lodge of Orangemen heard annual reports yesterday. Fifteen new lodges were instituted last year and the net increase in membership was 5,000. Committees were appointed and some amendments to the constitution submitted to be voted on next year.

Wong Ke Li, a Hartford (Conn.) laundryman, visited this city a week or two ago to "buck" Sam, the Chinese tiger, in Mott-street. Fan-tan relieved him of his savings in short order, and Wong, deciding upon the uselessness of a further struggle with adverse fate, bought 25 cents' worth of opium and a one dollar lottery slip, resolving if the latter failed him he would fall back upon the former.
OSWEGO, N. Y., June 13.--A terrific thunderstorm passed over this region Monday night. Reports from various parts of the country show that quite a number of buildings were struck by lightning.
BERGEN POINT, N.J., June 13.--Fire broke out at 11 o'clock last night in a two-story frame building owned by George Taylor in East Eighth-street, near Avenue D. Less than $5,000 damage was done.

NEWBURG, N. Y., June 13.--Frank V. Leeds, at 11:20 o'clock yesterday morning, released three carrier pigeons from the Brooklyn Bridge. They belonged to George F. Anderson, agent of the Wallkill Valley Railroad at Walden, an arrived home at 2:11 o'clock in the afternoon, making the 70 miles in two hours and fifty-one minutes over a route never traveled by them before.
CHICAGO, June 13.--The Wisconsin Central Railroad has met the rates of the Chicago, Burlington and Northern on St. Paul and Minneapolis business.
WASHINGTON, June 13.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Postmasters.--John W. Spaight, Fishkill-on-the- Hudson, N.Y.; Philo H. Stevens, Fredonia, N.Y.; ...
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 13.--Gov. Beaver presided this afternoon at the Music Festival, and at his request the 5,000 people present sang the "Resurrection Morning," a sacred hymn.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., June 13.--The utter demoralization into which the public school system of this bankrupt city is now plunged is lamentable in the extreme. Owing to the continued plundering of the City Treasurer's vault no school houses have been built for a great many years.

James Jay Brady, who has been the efficient business manager of J.M. Hill for a number of years, and who acted as assistant manager of the Union-Square Theatre until that house was burned, has severed his connection with Mr. Hill.

The new ferryboat Robert Garrett, which has just been built by the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company for use between St. George and this city, arrived at the dock at Staten Island shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Less than a year ago Senator Thurman made an address in Ohio, a portion of which the Register at the time took pleasure in laying before its readers. To-day those words have a new meaning and weight. Said Senator Thurman:
With reference to an interview with John I. Davenport in THE TIMES of yesterday that gentleman writes to the editor saying: "The ...

Educational reform started out under rather stormy skies last evening. The meeting which had been called at the Church of the Holy Communion attracted a much larger assemblage than was anticipated by the most enthusiastic friends of the proposed society.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 13.--The latest manifestation of generosity by ex-President Andrew D. White toward Cornell University is his offer to contribute $10,000 for an Alumni hall, on condition that Cornell's 5,000 Alumni subscribe a large enough fund to erect a handsome and suitable structure.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 13.--A special train on the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railway, carrying Jay Gould and party, made the fastest run on record in the South this morning.

The Board of Electrical Control yesterday gave the Western Union Telegraph Company leave to repair its lines in Sixth-avenue and Broadway pending the placing of the wires under ground on these streets upon the assurance that the work of putting the wires in the subways would be immediately undertaken and carried on as rapidly as possible. ...

MENOMINEE, Wis., June 13.--A clay bank in a brick yard here caved in about 10 o'clock this morning. Seven men were buried beneath it. Two brothers named Jansen were taken out dead and terribly mangled. Ole A. Holte and Ole Hecker cannot live.

WHEELING, West Va., June 13.--Active negotiations have been in progress in this city during the past week between the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railroad Company, by Vice-President and General Manager W. M. Woodford, on the one hand, and the South Pennsylvania and ...

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 13.--A convention of delegates from the State organizations, municipalities, and people interested in the establishment of a deep-water port on the coast of Texas has been called by the Fort Worth Board of Trade to meet at Fort Worth July 10 for the purpose of memorializing Representatives in Congress and devising means ...

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 13.--At Georges today lightning struck the house of Prof. M.C. Connert and instantly killed Miss Annie Brown, aged 22. The lightning entered the window, passed over an instant in a cradle without injuring it and struck Miss Brown, who was sitting in a chair in the middle of the room.

QUEBEC, June 13.--Several thousand persons were present at the reception to GovernorGeneral Lord Stanley this afternoon. The City Council attended in a body and many members of the clergy were present.
BURLINGTON, Vt., June 13.--Henry Doubleday of South Royalton was swindled out of $5,000 by the gold brick game last week. The swindlers gave their names as Stewart and Ellison.

ALBANY, June 13.--The second day of the trotting meeting at Island Park was very exciting and the races were witnessed by about 4,000 people. The programme for the day included the Clay Stakes for trotters in the 3:00 class, a 2:22 class, and a 2:23 pacing race.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., June 13.--Farmers in the town of Hardenburg have become quite desperate recently at the number of sheep and calves that have been carried off by bears. Traps have been set in vain for wary Bruin, ...
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 13.--Yesterday morning three cases came up for argument in the Supreme Court of Errors growing out of the E.S. Wheeler failure.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 13.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad which was called for today, to be held in this city, was postponed for a week owing to the absence of the proxies of some of the foreign stockholders.

A fire yesterday morning at 17 Myrtleavenue, Brooklyn, did over $30,000 damage, and destroyed the property of two unfriendly neighbors. The buildings burned were old three-story frame structures through which the fire ran rapidly.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June. 13.--One hundred and twenty of the leading citizens of Springfield, Hartford, Winsted, and other places in Massachusetts and Connecticut came here today by special train to inspect the Poughkeepsie bridge, now approaching completion.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 13.--Dr. John P. Pemberton, the Long Branch physician who assulted Clifton W. Taylure, the editor of the Long Branch News, was convicted this morning. The jury was out only a few minutes. Sentence was deferred at the request of Dr. Pemborton's control.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 13.--A convention of the Democratic clubs of the State of Illinois was held in this city to-day, with about 1,000 delegates in attendance.
The summary disposal of the body of the young woman which floated into the dock at Edgewater, N.J., Friday, and was buried after a careless examination by Squire Fitzgerald, ...

BUFFALO, June 13.--A madder set of elevator men cannot be found anywhere in the State than right here in Buffalo. Gov. Hill on Monday signed the bill regulating terminal charges, and thereby earned the enmity of all men engaged in the grain trade.

BANGOR, Me., June 13.--Since the beginning of operations along the Canadian Pacific line in Maine there has been a constant stream of Italians going and coming between New-York and this city and as many as 600 have arrived in one week.

The cornerstone of the new TIMES Building on Park-row, New-York City, was laid on Thursday last. This structure will be 13 stories in height, and when completed will be one of the best equipped newspaper establishments in the world.
The Hudson County Board of Health is "after" the Jersey City Board of Public Works. The latter board is still dead-locked, and in consequence the sewers are in a filthy condition.
It is difficult to imagine anything more horrible or revolting than the spectacle of a woman hanging by her teeth to the car of a balloon until the machine has risen out of sight.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 13.--At Brooklyn, Conn., to-morrow will be dedicated Gerhardt's equestrian statue of Israel Putnam. President Dwight of Yale College will offer prayer.

A dispatch from Wamsutter, Wyoming, states that the California delegates to the Chicago Convention held a meeting there to-day and agreed to act as a unit upon Blaine as the first choice, and to cast their first vote for him unless they decide upon a more available man after their arrival at Chicago.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 13.--Traffic Manager Hanley of the Kansas City Railroad has received a letter from Chairman Cooley of the Inter-State Commerce Commission in reply to his letter of a week ago, addressed to that body announcing the intention of his road to put its own construction on the inter-State law and abide the courts.
LONDON, June 13.--Prince Soltykoff's b. c. Sheen won the Ascot Derby by five lengths, Zama second, and Strouvar third. Hazelhatch won the Fern Hill Stakes from l'Abesse.

ROCHESTER, N.Y. June 13.--The Eighth NewYork Cavalry are holding their reunion in this city to-day, and a number of veterans from all parts of the country are among those present. This afternoon they are enjoying an excursion to the bay.

CHICAGO, June 13.--To the trouble in transcontinental rates is likely to be added another in Colorado tariffs. In fact the Fort Worth and Denver has already announced a further reduction between the Atlantic coast and common Colorado points, and the reason given for the movement is the low rates by lake and rail.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., June 13.--Members of Shaler's Brigade Association to-day dedicated four monuments to their fallen comrades. At 9 o'clock the regiments marched to Culp's Hill, and, after music by the band, the ceremonies by the brigade began. William J. Wray introduced Gen. Alexander J. Shaler as the orator of the occasion.

There was a very lively debate on the tariff question at Grand Union Hall, on Courtstreet, Brooklyn, last evening, under the auspices of the Federal Republican Club.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 13.--Roy McClain, Cashier of Wells, Fargo Co.'s express at this point, was horribly mangled in a railroad accident at the Union Station to-night.

There was a little tinge of sadness among the Trustees, Faculty, and students of Columbia College at their Commencement exercises yesterday in the Academy of Music. It was caused by the vacant chair in which President Barnard was accustomed to sit and bid the graduating class good-bye in friendly words.
About 5,700 men were killed and wounded during the Mexican war and many died from disease. How many sleep under the soil of Mexico is probably not known, but they amount to thousands.

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, June 13.--The Santa Fe passenger train had an unusual experience a few miles from Dorsey station Monday night. The train suddenly stopppd and eight masked men boarded the platform of the baggage car.

On Saturday the members of the Authors' Club of this city will be the guests of E.P. Roe at Cornwall-on-Hudson. The party will go up the river on the day line boat Albany, which will make a special landing at Cornwall.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 13.--The second day of the Millers' National Convention in this city was opened to-day in Music Hall by President Seybt.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--The bond offerings today aggregated $3,383,600, in lots as follows: Four per cents, coupon--$20,100 at 127 7/8, $2,300 at 127 7/8. Four per cents. registered--$500 at 127 and accrued interest, $3,000 at 127 5/8, $1,000,000 at 128, $1,700 at 126 7/8.

ROCHESTER, N.Y. June 13.--The Eighth NewYork Cavalry are holding their reunion in this city to-day, and a number of veterans from all parts of the country are among those present. This afternoon they are enjoying an excursion to the bay.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 13.--Passenger rates to the Chicago Convention were quoted today at $5 over the Wisconsin Central, Kansas City, and Burlington lines.

The present demoralized condition of freight traffic from the West to seaboard and to foreign ports gave particular interest to the meeting of the Inter-State Commerce Commission in this city yesterday for the purpose of hearing the charges of discrimination preferred by the New-York Produce Exchange against various trunk line railways and their connections.

William F. Kitsell, who keeps a boarding house at 207 West Fourteenth-street, was complainant in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday against Ellen Maxwell, Nellie Devine, and Delia Ryan, charging them with stealing clothing from Mrs. Louise Ludington, one of his boarders.

One more defeat was charged against the Giants yesterday, when the Detroits won a game by figures of 8 to 6. Poor batting, weak fielding, and unsteady pitching were the causes of the defeat. Ewing and Ward were still on the sick list.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 13. The Grand Lodge of the Loyal Orange Institution of the United States elected Grand Officers to-day as follows: Worshipful Master--Thomas Milligan of Massachusetts; Deputy, Henry Robinson of Pennsylvania.

The National Educational Association, which aims to elevate the character and advance the interests of the profession of teaching and to promote the cause of popular education in the United States, will hold its annual meeting at San Francisco July 17 to 20.

MADISON, Ind., June 13.--Hanover College confers the degree of Doctor of Laws on the Rev. John Dewitt, D.D., of Chicago, and the Hon. John M. Butler of Indianapolis; Doctor of Divinity on the Rev. J. A. Rondthaler of Indianapolis, J.W. Clokey of New-Albany, and R.H. Leonard of Cincinnati; Master of Arts on the Rev. Clarence E. Brandt and Dr. John S. Hunt of Chicago and the Rev. W. H. McCaughey of Philadelphia.
