The stock market scored a marked gain of strength yesterday. The Vanderbilt stocks were conspicuous in the advances of the day, and Wall-street was full of tales representing that William K. Vanderbilt was a big buyer of Lake Shore and Canada Southern.
One of the most interesting weddings of the month was held yesterday at the residence of Cornelius Van Santvoord, 10 West Eleventh-street.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 21.--A NewLondon special to the Morning News says that the building of the bridge over the Thames River has necessitated changes in the course over which the college boat races are rowed. The start is placed 15 feet further in the middle of the stream and the finish is 100 feet nearer...
Miss Ida Cohen's suit for breach of promise against Joseph Sandler, a grocer, came up for hearing on a motion before Judge O'Gorman...

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., June 21.--An extra freight train on the New-York Central Railroad, drawn by Engine 676, was wrecked here to-day. The accident was caused by the breaking of the air-brake connections. Six empty cattle cars were demolished. All the tracks were blocked for two hours. The less is $35,000.
CHICAGO, June 21.--The greatest burst of enthusiasm seen thus far in this convention came this afternoon at the end of Foraker's speech for John Sherman.

Sydney Rosenfeld is fulfilling his promise to Col. McCaull in regard to furnishing new verses for De Wolf Hopper's topical song in "The Lady or the Tiger?" to the letter, and there are very few matters of public interest which have not been touched upon in the song.

CHICAGO, June 21.--There was the biggest kind of a row this afternoon over the sequestration of most of the season passes heretofore issued, and the general cussedness of the gatekeepers who explained their conduct by saying they were "acting under instructions."

The Ninth Assembly District County Democrats met last night at 3 Abingdon-square, and raised a banner on which were placed the names and portraits of Grover Cleveland and Allen G. Thurman. Police Commissioner John R. Voorhis made a speech.

The partial paralysis sustained by a lady passenger a week ago in a Brooklyn street car run by electric motors of the Van De Poele system has called attention anew to the application for permission to run cars on the Fourth and Madison-avenue street line to be propelled by electric motors of the storage battery system.
Some of the Grand Army men in Brooklyn are indignant over the admission of John U. Shorter as a "subscribing" member of George Ricard Post and some are amused.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 21.--Intense interest centred in the Woodford oratorial contest held last evening at Cornell University. It is the only exhibition of oratory held at the university.

A man walked into Johnson's New-York Pavilion at Rockaway Beach Wednesday night, and after taking a few drinks went to bed. Yesterday morning he was discovered dead on the beach by Joe Wilkinson, Captain of the watchmen of the big Rockaway Beach Hotel.

The days of Lessing and of Goethe as educators in art appear to be numbered, yet neither can be profitably overlooked by any one who wishes to understand the position of the artist in modern life.

The most important cricket match likely to take place in the United States this season was begun on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston, Staten Island, yesterday morning and will be brought to a close to-day.

AUBURN, N.Y., June 21.--Another Old World fortune has fallen to two fortunate Auburnians, and this time the story is no myth, It reads like a romance, and contains the necessary runaway youth and marriage and a happy termination of the escapade.
JAMES G. BLAINE is three thousand miles away, upon the old stamping ground of the Picts and Scots, but his "boom" at Chicago has more vitality than all the others combined.

The Bard did it again yesterday. He won the Coney Island Cup and placed the sixth race of the year to his credit. Two of the races have been actual walk-overs, and he hasn't really had to race in but one of the others, that being his first, when he won the Brooklyn Handicap after a hard run against Hanover.

A large audience crowded the Academy of Music last evening to witness the thirtysixth annual Commencement of the College of the city of New-York. The class which was graduated last evening was the largest which that college has sent out for the past 20 years, and, in spite of the warmth of the weather, the building was filled.

The Kings County Wheelmen held their seventh annual parade last night, each wheel carrying a lantern, and making one of the prettiest processions of the year.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 21.--The Commencement dinner at Brown University was served in Sayles's Memorial Hall.
The schooner Alice Hodges, Capt. John Beauchamp, arrived yesterday from Governor's Harbor, Eleuthera, with a cargo of pineapples and a sea-serpent story for the susceptible and indulgent public.

While Isaac Hirshwitz, a newsboy, was selling papers yesterday at Broadway and Canalstreet, he had his right foot run over by a truck and severely injured. Patrick Harris, the driver of the truck, was arrested.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 21.--The Connecticut State Normal School at New-Britain will graduate a class of 49 members on Friday.

LONDON, June 21.--Mrs. Boucicault, wife of the well-known playwright and actor, Dion Boucicault, has obtained a divorce from him Mrs. Boucicault was also awarded costs.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 21.--Michael Roach, his wife, and four children reside at Staatsburg, 10 miles north of the city. Roach has been a farm laborer on the Dinsmore farm there for 10 years.

CHICAGO, June 21.--When the conventionhall was opened this morning the streets in the neighborhood of the Auditorium were not so crowded as on yesterday by the throngs moving toward the convention.

The sale of unclaimed and seized dutiable articles which began Wednesday at the Barge Office was concluded yesterday. The sale was well attended, the goods bringing better prices than on the preceding day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 21.--Another effort was made to-day to agree upon the iron workers' scale of wages. The conference between the committees began at 10 o'clock and was prolonged till 1:30.
Paul Witte, an unusually bright lad of 11 years, committed suicide At hiS home, 1,320 Second-avenue, Wednesday night by taking poison.
The Prohibitionists are to hold a grand rally at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening.

CHICAGO, June 21.--A cheer from 8,000 throats makes a mighty volume of sound. Since the convention was called to order on Tuesday many cheers have been given in the great building. Some of them have been hearty and some perfunctory.

When the Twenty-third and Twentyfourth Wards, composing the so-called annexed district, were taken in out of the wilds of Westchester and incorporated in the city and county of New-York their population, grouped in little country places in various parts of the district, was about 35,000.

The semi-annual reports of the Vanderbilt railway system beyond Buffalo were made yesterday, meetings being held of the Directors of the Lake Shore, the Canada Southern, and the Michigan Central. Upon Lake Shore a dividend of 2 per cent. was declared, with 1 per cent. upon Canada Southern and 2 per cent. upon Michigan Central.

The steamer Artison, which runs between Wilson's Point, Conn., and this city, went ashore on Flood Rock, Hell Gate, yesterday morning, and remained two hours. It was necessary to employ eight powerful tugs to haul her into the channel. Her injuries were not sufficiently serious to prevent her from proceeding to her deck in this city.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 21.--Track laying on the Red River Valley Road began today at West Lynne. The Northern Pacific engineers returned to St. Paul in their car to-day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 21.--Shotwell, Clerihew Lothman have been forced to make as assignment to protect their creditors. The papers were filed late last night, and the Assignee is A.H. Lindeke of the firm of Lindeke, Warner Schurmier, the St. Paul wholesale dry goods dealers.

The Hoboken Turtle Club auspiciously opened its ninety-second season yesterday with a breakfast and dinner at the clubhouse in Jerome-avenue adjoining Gabe Case's hotel. All the old turtles and many young ones attended.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 21.--Reports have been received from New-Mexico to the effect that one of the most gigantic land and cattle deals ever consummated in the United States is now about to be closed.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 21.--The Democratic Party of Alabama is preparing to make an active canvass of the State for the success of the ticket, State and National. At a meeting of the State Executive Committee to-day a resolution was passed instructing Col. H.C. Thompson, Chairman, to appoint speakers in all sections of the State.

Lascelles's colt, Nunthorpe, second, a head in front of J. Lowther's colt. Workington. There were 12 starters. FORTRESS MONROE, Va., June 21.--The Swatara went up to the navy yard this morning, where she will finish the few needed repairs and fill up her crew.

Charles Giblin, who killed Mrs. Madeline Goelz, was yesterday convicted of murder in the first degree, the jury deliberating about 15 minutes. The prisoner was apparently unmoved when the verdict was announced, a scarcely perceptible smile being the only change upon his blanched countenance.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 21.--The sixtyeighth Commencement at Madison University occurred to-day. Nineteen young men were graduated.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 21.--On and after the night of the 23d inst. the rear light of Pumpkin Hill Range will be discontinued and the front beacon will be moved to the southward, to form, with the Charleston main light, a range to lead through the south Channel. The lights which form the new range will retain their present color and characteristics.
HYAMUS, Mass., June 21.--The steamer Henry Russell Chase, New-Bedford for Bar Harber, Maine, was sunk near the railroad where at the place to-day.
The feature of the racing at Sheepshead Bay to-day will be the Coney Island Derby, for 3-year-olds, for which all the best horses of that age hereabout are eligible.

NEWTON, N.J., June 21.--While William Hooey and family were driving a team of colts yesterday the animals became restive and ran away. The wagon was upset and the occupants thrown over a steep bank, instantly killing their 2-year old child and severely injuring both Mr. and Mrs. Hooey. The horses ran over a bridge and, falling into a deep stream, were only rescued with much difficulty.
BERLIN, June 21.--The text ordered by the Emperor for the Sunday sermons of the German preachers is; "Selig ist der Mann der die Anfechtung erduldet." (Blessed is the man that endureth temptation.)
OTTAWA, Ontario, June 22.--The Post Office Department has received advices that mail matter posted in London on May 27 was distributed in Vancouver, 6,500 miles distant, 12 days later.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, June 22.--The Hon. William H. Crain was renominated by the Democratic Convention for Congress from the Seventh District by acclamation. Resolutions indorsing the St. Louis platform were adopted.

A resident of Adams, Jefferson County, asked the Assessors of that village to raise his assessment on personal property $1,000. They compiled with his request, of course, though it almost took their breath away. Requests of this kind are not common.

CHICAGO, June 22.--Miss Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Isabella Beecher Hooker, upon reading the Republican platform as adopted, issued an address to the Republican Party asking its immediate and serious consideration of the arguments set forth why women should not be granted the right of voting.

Among the passengers of the steamship Fulda, on her outward passage, to-day, are included some of the principal members of a little band of scientists who are bound on an expedition full of the most fascinating interest to every lover of ancient lore.

A very determined effort to make George Francis Train shake hands was made Thursday night by a man who was very fat and forcible. He announced himself as a gentleman from Tipperary, but talked more like a cockney.
BERLIN, June 22.--The National Zeituna announces that the coronation of the Emperor and Empress as King and Queen of Prussia will take place at Konigsberg in the Autumn.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 22.--During the past few days there has been some complaint of too much heat along the James' River Valley, though no injury is reported yet. From Otter Tail County some reports of increasing numbers of locusts or grasshoppers and in the southern part of the State chinch bugs are creating some alarm in limited sections.

PARIS, June 22.--M. de Lesseps is well and was out walking to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, June. 22.--An expert is at work going through the books of Edwin Louderback Co., wire screen makers, whose office is at 413 and 415 South Fifth-street. Their factory runs from 428 to 434 Tenor-street. It is on of the biggest window screen concerns in the country.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 22.--The striking ring spinners in one of the Wamsutta Mills have settled their dispute with the corporation. The ring spinners in the Grinnel Mill struck to-day. They want an advance of 66 cents a week in wages of spinners capable of tending six sides, which would make $6 a week. They say the corporation offered 50 cents advance.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 22.--The Second Regiment Alabama state troops, went into camp here yesterday for the annual encampment. CoL Thomas C. Jones is in command and Lieut.

TROY, N.Y., June 22.--This morning Frank Brown of Melrose was arrested on the charge of bigamy. One woman, supposed to be his wife, died at Melrose Monday night under suspicious circumstances. Mrs. Brown, the complainant, resided in this city and is the mother at three children. Two children were left by the woman who died at Melrose.

Miss Colburn, only daughter of James Colpurn, late of Franklin, has kindly shown us an old account book of her father's, the entries in which begin March 23, 1829. Mr. Colburn was for many years a merchant in Franklin.
The annual meeting of the Associate Alumni of the College of the City of New-York was held last evening at the college, and about 400 members were in attendance.

Samuel Harrison, 16 years old, who said his family lived at 101 Harrison street, Syracuse, was brought from Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon and arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court, by Agent Grant of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children under the Vagrant act.
William Brown, aged 23, giving his residence as 315 East Thirty-second-street, made a bold and sucessful dash for liberty yesterday from the Court of Special Sessions.

Three of the persons supposed to be implleated in the murder of John Baugh, who was found lying dead in the surf in front of Johnson's Pavilion, at Rockaway Beach, on Thursday morn ing, with three stab wounds in the abdomen, were arrested yesterday by Capt. Cavanagh and looked up in the Kings County Jail.

The Troy Lacrosse team lost a game yesterday at Washington Park to the Nassau team of Brooklyn. The Troy reached but one goal, the fifth, the time 9 minutes. Nassau made first goal in 6, second in 9, third in 6, and fourth in 10 minutes. The play was good throughput. Skerry put in some creditable work.

LAKE MEGANTIC, Quebec, June 22.--Depius f. Warren, a United States Deputy Marshal. was shot dead here this afternoon by a desperado named Donald Morrison, whom he was trying to arrest on a charge of poisoning. The people of the village are greatly excited, as Morrison threatens to do more harm. A force to coming from Shorbrooke to arrest him.
A report was in circulation late last night, in the Sixteenth Precinct, to the effect that the New-York Savings Bank, at Eigth-avenue and Fourteenth-street, had been robbed.

Glovanni Campara of 231 East One Hundred and Eighth-street was held in the Harlem Court yesterday for trial for swindling his fellow-countrymen, Gaetano Pazzatti caused his arrest and testified that the accused had taken $1 from each of 31 Italians as commission for securing them work, and that he did not get the work for them.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 22.--The Transcontinental Association, at its meeting yesterday and to-day, could not be said to have accomplished anything, although a large amount of work was done.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 22.--The wholesale grocers of the United States meet in national convention in New-York to-morrow.
EASTON, Penn., June 22.--The congregation of the American Reformed Church of this place have unanimously voted to sever their connection with the Dutch Church and enter the Presbyterian denomination.

The first gun of the Prohibitionists' campaign was fired last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, and the report was of no uncertain sound. The Opera House was crowded even to the furthest recesses of the family circle, the boxes being filled with members of substantial city families. Many remained standing through the entire ratification.

BALTIMORE, June 22.--Mrs. Sidney Smith Swann, the wealthiest lady in Maryland with the exception of Miss Garrett, has filed a bill in the Circuit Court of this city praying for an absolute divorce from her husband, Donald Swan, on the ground of unfaithfulness.

BALTIMORE, June 22.--Prof. Williams, the aeronaut, fell from the balloon yesterday at Tolchester, and in falling struck Mr. Henry Scales, 729 Franklin-street, severely injuring him about the back. Williams escaped injury, but was badly dazed when picked up.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22.--Bishop Whitaker to-day announced his decision in the case of the Rev. Heward T. Widdemer, the Pastor of the church of the Beloved Diseiple, charged with violating the church canon of marriage and divorce.

BOSTON, June, 22.--The Post has the following: "It is now just about a year since there appeared before the public in Washington a company styling itself the American Telephone Company, and claiming that it had received and was about to operate an exclusive telephone concesson granted by the Government of Venezuela.

DETROIT, Mich., June 22.--A bulky document has been filed in the United States Circuit Court in this city setting forth the complaint of the Commissioners of Mary Irene Hoyt of NewYork against William L. Webber of East Saginaw.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 22.--James M. Morris, Prothonotary of Luzerne County, has mysteriously disappeared from his home here. His friends are greatly alarmed, as it is feared he has met with foul play.

CHICAGO, June 22.--Frederick Layman of Des Moines, the young Iowan who made such a vigorous fight for a genuine tariff reform plank in the St. Louis platform, was in the city to-day. "It seems to me," he said, "that the Republican platform is too smart. It's tone is not good.
ERIE, Penn., June 22.--A first mortgage bond was recorded here yesterday against the Pittsburg, shenango and Lake Erie Road for $2,500,000 in favor of the Central Trust Company of New-York.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 22.--The trotting meeting at Chartar Oak Park continued on Thursday, and, favored by fair weather and a Good track, very fast time and brilliant races delighted the large crowd that was present.
The Republican Party is in the throes of dissolution at Chicago. One strong hand, one wise head might check the disease that besets it and keep its soul and body together yet for a few years.

It has been inferred from some statements recently made in a House discussion that the Appropriations Committee will bring in a bill providing that the heavy guns needed for harbor defense shall be supplied complete by contract instead of being finished in Government works.
WASHINGTON, June 22.--The following bulletin was issued to-night:

Mayor Hewitt yesterday wrote another letter on street obstructions, the letter being this time directed to President French of the Police Board. In the letter the Mayor called attention to the efforts being made to rid the streets of peanut and fruit stands, and said that it was strange that the police force did not cooperate in such good work.

A dispatch from Montreal reports that Alexander Grant, who published the Bankers and Brokers' Atlas at 300 Broadway, was arrested yesterday on a charge of embezzlement made by the Guarantee Company of North America, and that he was remanded without bail.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 22.--Some stir has been caused recently by the sale of Minnesota flour in Montreal at prices below those at which Manitoba millers find themselves able to sell. Most of the flour finds its way to Montreal. over the "Soo" route.

Enthusiasm for Cleveland and Thurman on the New-York Produce Exchange is constantly on the increase, and a number of brokers are now at work preparing for the organization of a campaign club which is expected to number over 1,000 members at the outset.
ERIE, Penn., June 22.--John Rush, a fireman on the propeller Bessemer, was set upon at an early hour this morning by his helper, George Connelly, and stabbed to the point of death.

Political guesses and political bets are taking up Wall-street attention just new a good deal more than stock speculation does. Prices on the Stock Exchange, however, were strong yesterday despite inactivity. The Granger stocks were firmest, and dealings in them were more general than in the other groups.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 22.--The third day of the New-Haven Lawn Tennis Club's tournament was characterized by some of the prettiest tennis ever seen in New-Haven.

Carrie B. Kilgore, Esq., yesterday argued her first case in the Orphans' Court. The event his a special interest as occuring on the same day that the doctors of the County Medical Society made up their minds to admit a female member.

WASHINGTON, June 22.--The Republican platform seems to be quite as acceptable to the Democrats in Congress as to the Republicans. The most interest was felt in the plank on protection, and almost without exception that plank was read with an expression of hearty approval by the Democratic revenue reformers.

VIENNA, June 22.--The remains of Beethoven were transferred to the Central Cemetery to-day. Twenty-four carriages conveying Professors, musicians, and others followed the remains. Two carriages bore wreaths from all parts of the country. The actor Lewinski, funeral oration written by ven Weiler.

It was a glorious day yesterday in Grammar School No. 25, in East Fitth-street, where a combination of graduating exercises and patriotism hold away. It would be hard to find a more beautiful sight than that presented by the 300 schoolgirls, nearly all attired in white, as they sang the "Star-Spangled Banner," each waving aloft an American flag.

An accurate portrait, bust of President Cleveland in plaster, colored to represent terra cotta, has been modeled and will be offered for sale during the campaign by the Bau-Relief Manufacturing Company, 1,218 and 1,220 Second-avenue. The bust is a little more than two feet high, and represents the President in his habitual double-breasted frock coat and formal cravat.

CHICAGO, June 22.--Eager and excited beyond repression was the crowd that poured into the convention hall this morning. The test of the ballot was to be applied to the booms about which so much boasting had been heard for a week.

The great show peak mountain of St. Helena, in Lewis County, Washington Territory, is smoking, Grayish smoke or steam can be plainly seen issuing from the south side near the summit of the lofty mountain, and observa tions through strong glasses are convincing that the smoke comes from the lofty peak. These Volvanic indications cause much comment and a feeling of general uneasiness at Winlock and neighborhood.
The Hotel Kaaterskill, Catskill Mountains, is ready for the accommodation of seekers after Summer rest and pleasure. A number of improvemants have been made in and around the hotel.
CINCINNATI, June 22.--The Trustees of Miami University at Oxford, Ohio, have elected Ethelbert D. Warfield of Lexington, Ky., President of the university.

The friends of the early-closing movement in Harlem are taking emphatic measures to show their displeasure toward the storekeepers that decline to obey their mandamus to close their places of business every evening at 7 o' clock.

CHICAGO, June 22.--Al day long droves of people were leaving town and droves coming, but the number of departures exceededthe arrivals. The weather has turned cooler and it threatens rain.

CHICAGO, June 22.--The withdrawal of Mr. Depew's name this evening, together with a rumor that nearly all of New-York's votes would be cast on the next ballot for Harrison, caused an adjournment until tomorrow morning.
Moses G. MeLain, while County Clerk, on June 18, 1885, issued a marriage license to 'David C. Rankin and Olive S. Lowe. No return was ever made any the license until yesterday.

London, June 22.--Porter and Buck, the American burglars who were arrested in this city on the charge of having committed a burglary in Zurich, were arraigned in the Bow-Street Police Court to-day. Both prisoners were dressed in the extreme of fashion.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 22.--The Young Men's Democratic League of Atlanta held a ratification meeting to-night, which was largely attended. Among the speakers were Henry W. Grady, Judge Womach, the Hon. J.J. Spalding, and others. Delegates were elected to the Baltimore convention of Democratic clubs.

Another of the big Spring handicaps, the Sheepshead Bay, at a mile and an eighth, will be the event of to-day at the Coney Island Jockey Club course. With a good field of horses named as probable starters the race promises to be a good one.

The Trunk Line Association Passenger Agents held a meeting yesterday and discussed the vexed question of emigrant rates.

PITTSBURG, June 22.--W.F. King was convicted at the United States Court at Williamsport on Wednesday of robbing the Post Office at Milwaukee, Lackawanna County, and was sentenced to three years' imprisonment at Riverside Penitentiary.

WICHITA, Kan., June 22.--A severe windstorm swept over the northern part of Sedgwick County Wednesday night, doing considerable damage and, it is though, fatally injuring Mr. and Mrs. Frank Watt. The track of the storm was 300 yards wide and extended over about three miles of territory.

George Heyward Carpenter, the enterprising scheme promoter who left creditors and others in the lurch last Fall, and whose exploits were then fully narrated, has at last been captured, and, unless well-laid plans failed, he was landed last night in Police Headquarters.

Obder M. Hartt is in a fair way to be righted. The Court of Appeals has affirmed the order of the General Term, dismissing the habeas corpus and certiorari brought on behalf of John E. Gill, John Foster, George Worley.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22.--The steamer Bertha, which has arrived from Kurluk, Alaska, brought three of the sailors of the cod fishing schooner Isabel, which encountered a gale May 1, and on the 3d had to be abandoned.
The German element of the Twenty-third Ward is gleeful over the opening this week of Public Bath No. 7, moored at the foot of One Hundred and Thirty-eight-street, East River.

Reports of the death of Melvin Foster were in circulation yesterday. Inquiry elicits that though he is still confined to his house, his condition is scarcely worse than it has been during the past six weeks.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 22.--William Patterson was hanged this morning at 6:10 o'clock in the yard of the Jefferson County Jail. He was a colored man and was convicted with another colored man, Albert Turner, for assaulting and fatally beating Miss Jennie Bowman on April 23, 1887.

The rapid and wonderful series of succeases which attended the German Army in the Franco-Prussian war is well remembered. ST. PAUL, Minn., June 23.--The general officers of the transcontinental roads have been in session in St. Paul since Monday last. The meetings were held with closed doors and it was difficult to obtain from the members satisfactory particulars of what has been done.

OLEAN, N.Y., June 23.--Train 5, the lightning express going west, consisting of a baggage and express car, smoker, day car, and three Pullman sleepers, ran into an open switch between Hinsdale and Cuba, nine miles from Olean, early this morning, and was badly wrecked. The train ran full length into the switch, and every car left the track.

CHICAGO, June 23.--Some of Blaine's representatives, who have been keen at work here behind the scenes, came to the conclusion to-day that the time was ripe for securing his nomination and brought over a part of the New-York delegation to their way of thinking.

NORWALK, Conn., June 23.--Trinity Home, on Roton Hill, South Norwalk, is now open for the season. The come is conducted by Holy Trinity Church of New-York City, and to it are brought the poor women and children of the parish for a stay of about two weeks.
ALBANY, June 23.--Temporary relief came to well-nigh exhausted humanity this afternoon when one of the heaviest thunderstorms of the season prevailed.

It is understood in St. Petersburg that the Czar, in abandoning his projected visit to Samarcand this Summer, was moved in the first place by considerations of economy and next by a desire not to give rise to the comment which such a journey on his Majesty's part would excite in England.

PARIS, June 23.--Had the weather been half as propitious as the season of the year should promise, the fair sex would be more amiable and Paris would be a wilderness. Trunks have been packed, locked, and then unlocked at least a dozen times since the Grand Prize day.

LONDON, June 4.--In a former letter I have spoken of the great awakening which English society is experiencing, and have ventured the suggestion, though with some doubt, that it is due to political causes.

There were reported at the Bureau of vital Statistics during last week 801 deaths, 679 births, and 280 marriages. There was an increase of 121 deaths over the preceding week, and the death rate jumped to 27.31 per 1,000.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 23.--Mrs. Helen Althouse, the well-known musterious Attica sleeper has had a narrow escape from death from poisoning this week. Two men visited Mrs. Althouse Thursday evening, and it is said one of them while in the sick room, was seen to handle a cup containing coffee and milk from which the patient drank occasionally.
WASHINGTON, June 23.--Senator Sherman is credited with a very even temper, and he has shown an admirable degree of unconcern most of the time since the opening of the Chicago Convention.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 23.--The fashionable season of 1888 is slowly but surely coming to hand, and it won't be long before the social features of a Newport season will be duly inaugurated.

Lord and Lady Tennyson, who have been residing in the Isle of Wightfor several months, are about to leave Farringford for Aidworth, their place on the Hampshire Downs, near Haslemere. They intend to pass next Winter on the Rivera, probably at Cannes.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 23.--The first change in this weekly-changing camp has taken place, and to-night the Thirty-second Regiment, consisting of the Elmira, Walton, Oneonta, and Schenectady companies and the Second Provisional Battalion, sleeps in the tents for a week occupied by the Fourteenth Regiment and the First Provisional Battalion.

The strength developed in the market at the close of the previous week has continued through the past week, but the volume of business done has been small, for dullness next to strength has been the prevailing feature.

The cornerstone of the new building of the Harlem Turnverein, 211 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street, will be laid at 2 o'clock on Monday afternoon. The near building, which will be called the Harlem Turnverein Hall, will be 38 by 100 feet and 28 feet high from floor to ceiling.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23.--It rained here to-day, but the New-Yorks and Philadelphias decided to play their game. Only a small crowd was in attendance,but the spectators witnessed one of the most interesting contests of the season.

BOSTON, June 23.--The case of Capt. Marcus L. Howes of the bark Freeman of Boston ended to-day in a verdict of guilty of manslaughter in shooting a Japanese sailor on the high seas, between Cuba and Batavia.

FERNANDINA, Fla., June 23.--George Prichett, who murdered Henry Fushee, near Fort Clinch, in February last, was hanged to-day. He died professing his innocence.

There are living within a few miles of this place two colored men who have gradually changed from the cable hue of the African race to that of the white. The younger negro first cast off his dusky skin, and when the transmogrification was complete became as white as any one.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 23.-- The Yale and Harvard crews are at swords' points over the change in the course upon the Thames River. Capt. R.J. Cook talked to-day to THE TIMES'S correspondent about the trouble.
It is not often that one has a chance of watching a man who looks like a peer of France astride of a hippogriff flying through Staten Island air in the costume of a Roman centurion.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 23.--"At this time last year," said the manager of one of the largest hotels here to THE TIMES'S corresspondent this morning,. "we had over a hundred guests, and this year we are not yet open." As the above remark shows, the season here is very late. Most of the hotels have opened during the week.

ALBANY, June 24.--Steve Brodie has entered upon his swim to New-York, incased in a patent rubber suit, and expects to reach Hudson, a distance of 30 miles, by sunrise. He is attended by two New-Yorkers in a small boat.

Sir George Alexander Macfarren enjoyed, during the latter part of his life, the esteem due to a sage. The Insular School of Music, which is shut up within the borders of England, Scotland, and Wales, looked up to him as one of its shining lights, and when he spoke it was with the voice of an oracle.
The Claremont Cricket Club of Jersey City will visit Prospect Park next Saturday to play against the Manhattan Cricket Club.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 24.--Tony Hart, the well-known comedian, who was for many years associated with Edward Harrigan in the Theatre Comique and Park Theatre, New-York, has been committed to the State Lunatic Hospital in this city incurably ill of paresis, or softening of the brain.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 24.-- Clothing is not at a premium here to-day. The sentries pace wearily back and forth, hugging hot guns and with coats tight buttoned, as they would do until their guns or themselves melted, but the rest of the camp is in strictly undress uniform.
We print this morning a letter from Secretary FAIRCHILD to Mr. CURTIS, the President of the New-York Civil Service Reform Association, with reference to certain removals in the Custom House.

Maine will send large delegations, especially from Lewiston and Biddeford, to the National Convention of the French Canadians of the United States, to be held in Nashua, N.H., next week.

The Central Labor Union yesterday gave another example of its unreasonable vindictiveness. It had refused to listen to the journeymen brewers who had begged it to remove the boycott from pool beer, as the continuance of the boycott was hurting them infinitely more than it did the master brewers.

CHICAGO, June 24.--The Blaine undercurrent has a sluggish and uncertain movement to-day. The ill-concealed impatience of Blaine's Territorial politicians has caused some disgust and a free expression of opinion, which might have been withheld if these leaders had been content to remain behind the scenes.

PANAMA, June 16.--The construction by the canal company of the large iron wharf at Greytown has been begun. The local newspapers say that three dredges have been received from Panama for this and kindred works.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 24.--A fatal accident occurred here to-day growing out of a dispute as to the relative heights of the steeples of St. Mary's and St. Michael's Catholic Churches.

BOSTON, Mass., June 24.--Last night's storm overturned the sloop yacht Millie, in the cabin of which were John J. Gamon, Mrs. Catherine T. Tripp, aged 65, and her little niece, Katle T. Tripp. Gamon when taken from the water was alive.

BERLIN, June 24.--The Emperor and Empress made their formal entry into Berlin tonight. They came from Potsdam to Charlottenburg by steamer. They were then driven to the Berlin Palace, escorted by a squadron of cavalry. Unter den Linden was crowded, and the royal couple were given a hearty reception.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 24.--Three explosions of fireworks occurred in the variety store of Aaron Rice on Union-avenue, the main thoroughfare here, this afternoon, and a few minutes later the store and the building were in flames.

Herd No. 1 of the Benevolent Order of Buffaloes held a most enjoyable ladies' session at its new corral in Koster Bial's building last night. The magnificent bison's head given them by Buffalo Bill looked its approval at the many excellent songs sung and funny stories told by the jovial Buffaloes.

Bolossy Kiralfy, sunburned and looking remarkably well, arrived in the city yesterday morning on the steamer Alaska after a quick and pleasant trip of less than seven days.

LONDON, June 24.--Discount was extremely inactive during the past week at 1@ . On the Stock Exchange a fair amount of business was done, every department showing an improvement. The lead was taken by foreigners, which were freely bought by operators for a rise.

WILLIAMSTOWN, June 24.--President Carter preached the baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class of Williams College to-day in the Congregational church in this city.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 24.--A drunken bather caused considerable excitement here this afternoon by climbing up a stanchion at the sea end of the Ocean Pier and diving off. He would have been drowned but for a rescuing party of four men who swam out and brought him ashore.

ROME, June 24.--The municipal elections in Genoa and Venice to-day resulted in a victory for the Liberals over the Clericals.
Joseph Hessong, who scarcely two months ago wedded Della High, the daughter of a wealthy Morrow County farmer, has already deserted his young wife.

Air was what the pleasure seekers of New-York needed most yesterday, and they sought it in all the nooks and corners of the island. Where there was shade of foliage or awning there they went, and ate and drank and strove to be merry.

TARA, Ontario, June 24.--Contagious pleuro-pneumonia has been in existence in Grey County for some time and has carried off many animals, but the nature of the disease was not discovered until yesterday. when the last cattle to die were examined by veterinary surgeons. Stringent measures will be taken to prevent the disease from spreading.

AUBURN, N.Y., June 25.--Jacob Merker, a convict from Rochester, committed suicide during the night by hanging himself to a hook with a strap and handkerchief. The latter broke, and he was found on the floor of his cell this morning. He had been in prison only since last April.

CHICAGO, June 25.--The pot which was beginning to bubble when Commissioner Fink went to Europe boiled over to-day. Cut rates on dressed beef and live stock from Chicago to the seaboard are no longer made secretly.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 25.--Reports are coming in hourly from all parts of the city showing the damages done by last night's storm. The Florence-Street Church was struck and considerably damaged; a big elm tree on Waterstreet was shivered.

With three stake events to be decided the programme of the Coney Island Jockey Club is a good one, although not possessing any strongly attractive features. It is one that is calculated to make close racing, and the fields are not so large as to be cumbersome.

WASHINGTON, June 25.--First Lieut. J.H. Slocum, Seventh cavalry, has been granted leave of absence for six months. First Lieut. C.M. Gandy, Assistant surgeon, has been granted three months' leave of absence.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 25.--A double tragedy occurred here last evening at 6 o'clock. Henry Baker is a farmer 43 years old living north of this city.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 25.--The trial of Frank Patterson of Asbury Park for forgery opened today. The court refused to postpone the case until to-morrow to enable Patterson's counsel to carry it before Justice Bradley of the United States Supreme Court at Trenton.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, June 25.-- Henry Peterson of California and William Payne of this place rowed here, single scull, yesterday for $1,000 and the championship of the Pacific slope. The race was three miles with a turn, and Peterson won, coming in 12 lengths ahead of his rival.

CHICAGO, June 27.--Bartholomew V. Moffett, clerk of the Lasalle-Avenue Baptist Church and President of the church debating society, went into Lincoln Park last night to think out a speech he is to make on "Protection versus Free Trade" before the society.
Although the great contest over the will of Samuel J. Tilden wus argued before Judge Lawrence last March he did not receive any brief from any of the counsel until yesterday morning.

The storekeepers along the Harlem end of Third-avenue have been in great tribulation for nearly six weeks, owing to the number of their windows which have been broken by a gang of miscreants as yet undiscovered.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday it was decided that, owing to the excessive heat that prevails in New-York during the latter part of June and the early part of July, the question of the propriety of so amending the by-laws as to close the schools the third week in June instead of July 3 should be referred to the By-Laws Committee.

CANTON, N.Y., June 27.--At the twentyninth annual Commencement of St. Lawrence University, held to-day, there were 19 graduates. Honorary degrees were conferred as follows: M.A.--The Rev. Moses Henry Harris, ...

MINNEAPOLIS, June 27.--The Northwestern Miller says: "With all the mills idle Saturday for the millers' picnic, the average daily output of flour for last week was brought down to a pretty low figure.

CHICAGO, June 27.--A bold attempt to throw a passenger from a train for the purpose of robbing, if not killing, him was perpetrated last niglit almost within the very walls of the main station of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad in this city.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 27.--The following honorary degrees have bean conferred at Amherst College: D.D.--The Rev. W.J. Holland ...

The cornerstone of the new United States Trust Company's building, which promises to be one of the finest of the down-town business edifices, was laid yesterday in the massive foundations at 43 and 45 Wall-street under the auspices of the Building Committee of the company. A large leaden box, containing coins and newspapers of current date, was plastered in the stone with appropriate ceremonies.

When the veteran Judge KELLEY proposed to drop the Tariff bill until after election, and in the meantime repeal the whole of the internal tobacco tax, his proposition was greeted with laughter from the Democratic side, and with a prompt and not too courteous repudiation from Mr. REED, as the Republican leader.

HANOVER, N.H., June 27.--Yesterday's heavy rain crowded the Class Day exercises at Dartmouth into to-day, and they were interspersed with the regular features of the day, in accordance with the programme already published in THE TIMES.

HINSDALE, N.H., June 27.--The statement sent from here some days ago announcing the removal of the Rev. Father Holahan, late Pastor of the Catholic church here, on account of charges of immorality made against him, was incorrect, and did injustice to the priest.
FALL RIVER, Mass., June 27.--The spinners at the Merchants' Mills are on strike on account of dissatisfaction with their pay, which, they say, has fallen off considerably since the hot weather began.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 27.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following causes ware argued: No. 1,288--The People. c., respondents, vs. Kate Brandt, appellant.
The refining influence of civilization has not lessened the strong taste that Buffalo Bill's Wild West Indians have for dog flesh, and the canine population of Staten Island is rapidly diminishing.

MONTPELIER, Vt., June 27.--The Vermont Republican Convention in the Blanchard Opera House here to-day was attended by fully 500 delegates. It was opened with prayer by the Rev. J.P. Booth of Northfield. The Hon. J.K. Batchelder of Arlington was elected Chairman, ...

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 27.--The ninety-first Commencement of "Old Union" was the most successful held in years. The attendance was unusually large. The Chancellor's oration was delivered by the Hon. Charles J. Noyes, Class of '64, of Boston, Mass., ...

The difference in the attitudes of the two parties before the country is singularly significant. The President's little speech in informally accepting the nomination was a striking illustration of the power he has so often shown of rising to occasions.

PROVIDENCE, June 27.--The third annual 25mile bicycle race for the championship of the Rhode Island division of the League of American Wheelmen and medals was ridden to-night on the halfmile oval at Roger Williams Park.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 27.--George Wilson was hanged in Albion (Orleans County) Jail this morning for the murder of his wife on the night of Jan. 17. last year.

D.J. McCarthy, the diminutive sportsman who gained fame and dollars by purchasing the runner C.H. Todd, was about the Hoffman House corridors yesterday offering to bet $10,000 to $6,000 that Cleveland would carry New York and Indiana and be elected.

LONDON, June 27.--The owners of the establishment at Munich from which Billy Porter and Frank Buck, the American eracksmen, made a large haul of jewelry, have arrived in London and have identified nearly every article of plunder sound in Porter's and Buck's residences.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 27.--A throng of people conspicuous in business and social circles witnessed this evening the nuptials of Miss Charlotte, yonngest daughter of Senator Henry R. Low, and Mr. James C. Anderson, General Passenger Agent of the Ontario and Western Railroad.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 27.--A severe storm raged in Southwest Georgia to-day, in which several houses were blown down and a number of dwellings twisted about and ruined by the fury of the storm. Fences were laid flat on the ground, and cornfields locked as though a heavy roller had passed over them.
Mr. James W. Ham, who lives on the shores of Moosehead, has recently enjoyed a great day's hunting. It was on Saturday of last week in the morning, and he was working in his field with his dog.

It was reported yesterday that the Retail Grocers' Association of Newark, N.J., had decided to establish a Peach Exchange, and not to purchase any more peaches from the commission merchants of Newark and of New-York because they refused to allow the dealers to have the baskets without payment of 10 cents each.

Employes of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company, Brooklyn, who have been discharged on reports received from the detectives by President Richardson from time to time since the discovery of that systematic robbery on June 13, belong to Knights of Labor Assembly No. 75.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 27.--The first of a series of races for the Tappan Cup, under the management of the Cape Ann Yacht Club, open to all yachts enrolled in the club, was sailed this afternoon off Gloucester Harbor.

LONDON, June 27.--At the Stockbridge meeting to-day the race for the Stockbridge Cup was won by Sir George Chetwynd's Fallerton, with Red Anchor second and A Life's Mistake third. The last betting was 4 to 1 on Fullerton, 12 to 1 against Red Anchor, and 20 to 1 against A Life's Mistake.

William Henning, a prominent and wealthy citizen of Hoboken and Superintendent of Clark's thread stores, 400 Broadway, this city, committed suicide with a revolver at his home, 341 Parkavenue, Hoboken, yesterday morning.
OMAHA, Neb., June 27.--John M. Thurston returned home from the Chicago Convention to-day, and this evening the Republicans, in addition to ratifying the nominations, are giving him a grand ovation.
WHEELING, West Va., June 27.--For some time there has been trouble brewing in the congregation of Latter-Day Saints near Glenn Easton, 25 miles east of this city.

CHICAGO, June 27.--Chicago will claim for itself and its immediate suburbs an even millin of inhabitants, according to the new Directory which will be issued early in July. This Directory will contain in the neighborhood of 214,000 names.

BRADFORD, Penn., June 27.--An explosion of dynamite occurred at the new park, Wellsville, N.Y., at 4 o'clock this afternoon, instantly killing Thomas Prentice and Patrick Rocney, and seriously injuring Henry Milback.
There is but one stake race on the card at Sheepshead Bap to-day, but as that one is the rich Emporium, in which the crack 3-year-olds meet at a mile and a half, it is naturally a great attraction.

The Aqueduct Commissioners were yesterday notified by Clark O'Brien that the city would be held responsible for all expenses incurred on completed aqueduct work which has not been accepted by the city and paid for in full.

The Governors of the Stock Exchange ended their Summer labors yesterday by listing some millions of new railroad securities. The next meeting of the Governing Committee takes place three months hence. The securities just listed are:
NOGALES, Arizona, June 27.--Much excitement has been created by two outrages re cently committed by a small band of Apache Indians in the Ariope district, Sonara, Mexico.

Chief-Justice Larremore's part of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday was occupied with the trial of the application of Charles Kruse for a license to sell liquor at the Spingler House. Fourteenth-street and University-place.

Corporation Counsel Beekman filed yesterday in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court the return of Commissioner Newton to the alternative writ of mandamus obtained by the New-York Underground Railway Company requiring the granting of a permit to opon the streets where the company proposes to build its road.
CHICAGO, June 27.--Owing to rain the races here to-day were declared off. The Oakwood Handicap will be run to-morrow in addition to the regular programme.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jnne 27.--A big fire broke out in the lumber district to-night involving a loss of $100,000.
WASHINGTON, June 27.--The bond offerings to-day aggregated $488,450, in lots as follows: Four per cents, coupon--$10,000 atg 128 , $25,000 at 128 1/8, $5,000 at best price paid to-day.
The heirs to three thrones--those of Italy, Russia, and Brazil--are weaklings, and there is danger of el Roy Nino of Spain being another.

The trotting meeting of the Jersey City Driving Park Association opened yesterday. Several hundred people were present, and there were two good races, though interest in the results was killed by the evident superiority of the winners. The favorites were beaten in each race.
DETROIT, Mich., June 27.--A drizzling rain fell from the start to the finish of the game to-day, but it apparently had no affect upon the champions, who fielded perfectly and hit the ball hard.
Anton Ehlers, driving a truck, tried to pass a florist's wagon driven by Nicholas Rother, at the corner of Cortlandt-street and Broadway yesterday morning, each claiming the right of way.

OTTAWA, June 27.--Chief-Justice Ritchie this morning delivered judgment in the famous case, involving nearly $400,000, of the Crown against Messrs. J.C. Ayer Co. of Lowell, Mass., dismissing the action, with costs, and ...
DETROIT, Mich., June 27.--The Prohibition State Convention reassembled this morning and spent the first hour and more in listening to peeches, quartet singing, and other camp-meeting performances.

The tariff of the Harlem Railroad is not without peculiarities. It perhaps gives the people of Melrose more reason to be elusive than any other along the route. The schedule the company issues for popular use puts the distance of Melrose at five miles from the Grand Central Station, and that of Morrisania at six.

The Rev. Edward Walpole Warren, the English clergyman whose landing here some weeks ago was opposed on the ground that he had been brought here on contract, sailed yesterday for Liverpool on the White Star steamship Adriatic.
WASHINGTON, June 27.--Gen. Sheridan's physicians announced last night that their patient would possibly leave Washington to-morrow for his cottage at Nonquitt, Mass.

SEATTLE, Washington Territory, June 27.-- The steam schooner Leo arrived yesterday from Alaska. Among hot passengers were 22 miners and prospectors, who report a fatal conflict between two tribes of Alaska Indians, the Chilcats and Sitkas.

LONDON, June 27.--The Morning Post says: "President Cleveland's conduct in his high office has fully justified those who placed him there. If re-elected, he will hold power such as no President has held since the great war."

HOLBROOK, Arizona Territory, June 27.--Fire at Fort Apache, Monday, destroyed the entire, Quartermaster and commissary supplies. The estimated loss to the Government, including the building, is $100,000.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 27.--This was the final day of the Commencement exercises of the University of Virginia. Diplomas were delivered, degrees conferred, and the usual exercises of closing day gone through with.

BOSTON, June 27.--At Mystic Park to-day the race postponed from yesterday on account of rain was trotted. In the 2:23 class Burt Stetson, the driver of El Monarch, finished fourth in the first two heats, when he was taken off, fined $100 for pulling his horse, and Jack Bowen substituted. El Monarch the won three straight heats. Following are the summaries:
Just before 11 o'clock Tuesday night a man was discovered rolling in the ditch and over the street-car tracks at Seventy-third-street and First-avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27.--Frank Thomson was to-day elected First Vice-President of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company at a meeting of the Board of Directors.

The cool wave for which New-Yorkers have so fervently wished of late dropped down upon the city early yesterday morning and gave a new lease of life to every one.
A letter received in this city yesterday makes known that G.F. Slosson had the day before secured a lease of the room in the Grand Union Hotel, Saratoga.
RALEIGH, N.C., June 27.--Mrs. Julia Moore, an aged lady, was run over and killed by a material train at Henderson this morning.

BOSTON, June 27.--The Senators made only one hit off Radbourn to-day, and this, combined with numerous errors on their part and free hitting by Boston in the seventh inning, resulted in a disastrous defeat for the visitors.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 27.--Williams College Commencement was held to-day. The attendance was smaller than usual.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 27.--The third day's proceedings of the American Institute of Homeopathy was well attended. Much interest is taken in the work of the convention.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 27.--The family of W.J. Waite of Philadelphia, this county, have been poisoned by eating canned beef. All are out of danger except Mr. Waite's aged father, but he is expected to recover.

CHICAGO, June 27.--The west end of the Northwestern Railroad freight station just north of the river and west of State-street bridge is divided from the great freight room by a very high, fierce-looking picket fence.
CHICAGO, June 27.--The General Managers of the lines in the Western and Northwestern Freight Association met to-day to consider the rate situation in their territory.
SYRACUSE, Kan., June 27.--Wallace Mitchell had his preliminary trial before Justice Waggoner yesterday. He pleaded guilty to the murder of Oscar Johnson and the attempted murder of August Johnson.

MONTREAL, June 27.--Pitcher, the absconding bank Teller of Providence, has been remanded until to-morrow, pending the arrival of the bank Directors. It is expected that his trial for extradition will be proceeded with tomorrow afternoon.

LAUREL, Del., June 27.--Having run the gantlet of frosts, rose bugs, hailstones, and the "June drop," the peach crop of the DelawareMaryland peninsula can safely be considered a big one. Whether it will amount in round numbers to the highest estimate made upon it, 11,000,000 baskets, or will fall below the most ...

BOSTON, June 27.--June never vouchsafed a brighter, fairer day for Harvard's Commencent than that ushered in with the blue sky and cool breezes of this morning. It was welcome and made doubly pleasurable the visit of the Alumnus to the scenes of his youth.
The Jersey City Club administered a "whitewash" to the Elmira nine at Jersey City yesterday. Pyle pitched a strong game for the the winning club, and he was ably supported.

Mexico's Presidential election this year has been such a foregone conclusion that the choice of Diaz Electors a few days ago was deemed, even by the victors, hardly worth a formal demonstration of joy.
LEWISTON, Me., June 27.--A meeting of the corporation of Bates College was held this morning. President Cheney reported that from $50,000 to $55,000 of the $100,000 subscribed had been raised.
THOMASVILLE, Ga.,--June 27.--A terrible train wreck occurred this morning on the Savannah, Florida and Western Railroad at the trestles over the Ochlochree River.

The Hon. Sheridan Shook, who went to Chicago with the firm belief that either McKinley or Harrison would be nominated for President by the Republican National Convention, returned to this city last night.

EASTON, Penn., June 27.--Commencement exercises of Lafayette College closed to-day. The degree of D.D. was conferred upon the Rev. Joseph H. Barnard of the Second Presby terian Church, Madison, Ind., and the Rev. Oliver ...

WASHINGTON, June 27.--First Lieut. M.P. Maus, First Infantry, and First Lieut. Richard R. Stedman, Sixteenth Infantry, have been ordered to recruiting service duty at David's Island, N.Y. Leave of absence for three months has been granted Capt. George F. Barston, Third Artillery.

The new schedule of the New-Haven Railroad, with its trains following fast upon one another's heels, is still casuing blockades at the Grand Central Station. Trains are often late in getting in, and sometimes slow in starting out. An extra signal station has been located across the track at Fiftiethstreet, and is being hurried toward completion. This will help matters materially.

The Republican Pioneers' Club of the Ninth Ward opened the campaign last evening with a grand parade. Fifty-four of the pioneers were dressed in blue uniform, with white bearskin helmets and shouldered axes, and about 100 other members marched in citizens' clothes, with white badges pinned to their breats.

BOSTON, June 27.--The second day's session of the National Association of Master Plumbers was held in the Mechanics' Building, the banquet hall at the Vendome proving too small to comfortably hold the large number of delegates.

EL PASO, Texas, June 27.--The General Passenger Agent of the Mexican Central Railroad received a telegram here yesterday from the Mexican Central Agent at Silao, saying that in two days the track would be so that passengers could be taken through the flooded area with one transfer.
A constable of Queensbury, Warren County, walked into the Yorkville Court yesterday morning with a warrant for the arrest of Elsworth Elliot, a surgeon in the New-York Hospital.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 27.--The report that the Duke of Marlborough was to be married to Mrs. Hammersley of New-York originally appeared in the Boston Globe's evening edition of Tuesday in a Newport dispatch, and it is supposed that it was forwarded from there to New-York.

WOBURN, Mass., June 27.--The morning train from Boston ran on a side track on account of a misplaced switch and damaged the locomotive besides destroying several freight cars. Robert McGuire and James Larkin were badly injured. The damage will reach several thousand dollars.

Joseph Derrigan, Parmlee Jones, and Nathaniel M. Jones, the three green goods men arrested in Jersey City for operating through the mails, were arraigned for examination yesterday before Justice of the Peace Crossman.

LEWISBURG, Penn., June 27.--Bucknell University, at Lewisburg, Penn., yesterday conferred the following honorary degrees: Chauncey B. Ripley of New-York City, LL.D.; the Rev. A.P. Coulston of Frankford, Penn., and the Rev. George E. Reese of Philadelphia, D.D., and A.J. Davis of Clarion, Penn., A.M. President Hill will probably accept the Presidency of the University of Rochester.
RICHMOND, Va., June 27.--The capitalists who have invested money in the projected road from here to Wicomico, in Westmoreland County, Va., seem to feel confident that the scheme will be a success.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27.--Connor's miss of Delehanty's grounder, three singles and a triple, and the Phillies' spryness between the bases gave the home club 4 unearned runs and the game this afternoon. Buffinton gave a superb exhibition of pitching in the eighth inning, when with no one out and three men on bases the struck out Slattery and Hatfield.
ALBANY, June 27.--Miss Mary McPherson, an eccentric maiden lady, left in her will a provision that $25,000 be expended for a statue to Robert Burns, to be placed in Washington Park.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--The House to-day passed the Public Land bill. The first section classifies all of the public lands as agricultural, timber, mineral, desert, and reserved. Section 2 authorizes mineral lands to be disposed of under existing law.

"I have been many years in Wall-street, but never before have I seen the financial centre of the country in such a stupor. The men down here have become absolutely spiritless. All courage has oozed out of them." This is the comment of a financier and railroad man whose standing is of the highest.

There is some trouble in Company I of the Seventy-first Regiment about the election of a Captain. Capt. Berry was re-elected, but declined to serve. First Lieut. A pair of silk flags was presented yesterday by the Hon. F.G. Gedney to Grammar School No. 44. The exercises consisted principally of addresses and the singing of patriotic songs.
Any person desirous of committing a quiet little murder, with good chances of getting off scot-free, should choose Rockaway as the scene of his crime.
NORWALK, Conn., June 27.--The twenty-second annual dinner of the Fat Men's Association will be eaten at Dorlon'a Poinf on Wednesday, Aug. 15.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 27.--As a general iron strike seems probable this is of importance. The Labor Tribune this week has an exhaustive table of figures on the amount of stocks on hand in the different mills in the city.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 27.--Among to-day's features of Commencement Week at Wesleyan University were reunions of Classes of '38, '78, '81, and '85.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., June 27.--Great preparations are being made for the coming reunion. One thousand tents are being put up at Spring's Hotel for the Army of the Potomac; 900 on East Cemetery Hill for Pennsylvania Grand Army men. Gov. Beaver will encamp in the college campus, and about 1,000 tents stand in the wheatfield to be occupied by the New-Jersey Veterans and National ...

One night stands are regarded, with contempt by McCaull, and he has marked out a route for next season's tour which will practically be a simple pleasure trip to Chicago and return. The season will open on Oct. 8 in Philadelphia, where six weeks will be consumed.
Arrangements were complted last night for to-night's big demonstration in behalf of Cleveland and Thurman in the Academy of Music and Nilsson Hall under the auspices of the New-York County Democracy.

If the testimony of the father of little James R. Bourne, who was run over by an Avenue D car June 15, is correct, Frank Seibert, a butcher doing business at 44 Lewis-street, is to blame for the child's death.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 27.--Steve Brodie, who is trying to surpass Paul Boyton's record in floating down the Hudson River in a rubber suit, arrived here at noon to-day, having been in the water over six hours coming from Poughkeepsie.

RICHMOND, Va., June 27.--The Hon. John S. Wise returned home this afternoon from the Chicago Convention. He is in excellent spirits and says that he is confident the ticket nominated at Chicago will carry Virginia.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--Mr. William D. Kelley made a funny proposition in the House to-day. He gravely proposed to postpone further consideration of the Tariff bill until the next session of Congress, with the understanding that the House should then stand by the decision of the people at the November election.

Another great crowd was at the Coney Island race track yesterday to witness what proved to be a remarkably good day's sport. Eolian opened the day's racing by defeating the Western crack, Terra Cotta, as THE TIMES predicted he would do, in a mile dash, and in the remarkably fast time of 1:40 , which is within a quarter of a second of the race record...

ALBANY, June 27.--For the purpose of manu facturing and selling oils and fertilizers from menhaden and other fish the Barren Island Oil and Quano Company of New-York City was incorporated to-day, with a capital of $40,000. The Trustees are Philip J. Goodhart, Octavins D. Baldwin, Frederick Lewis, Leon Rheinstrom, and Max Fleischman.
The Republican State Committee will begin active work this morning. There were only a few persons present at their rooms--the old Carleton Club--last night.
MOBILE, Ala., June 27.--The accident on the Mobile and Montgomery Division of the Louisville and Nashville Road this morning was a terribly mixed-up wreck.
A circular has been issued by the National Dispatch lake and rail route announcing that the tariff of through rates from New-York, Boston, Providence, and other Eastern points to Duluth.

Mrs. Folson and Mrs. Cleveland remained indoors at the Victoria Hotel most of the day yesterday, and received a few friends. Among these were Mrs. Nelson and Miss Nelson, Richard Watson Gilder, and Charles De Kay.

PARIS, June 27.--The Journal des Debats says the exact result of the subscriptions to the Panama Lottery loan is not yet known, but it is believed that the amount of applications will equal only about one-half the sum asked for.
Canvassers have been at work for some time soliciting subscriptions for the sale of the book which gen. Sheridan has prepared.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 27.--The third day of the Commencement at Bowdoin College was clear and cool At 9 o'clock the graduating exercises of the Maine Medical School were held in Memorial Hall. The Hon. W.H. Clifford of Portland delivered the address, which was a brilliant one.

The Tammany Committee on Organization met last evening in Tammany Hall, and directed the several Assembly District Committees to organize Cleveland and Thurman campaign clubs in all the election districts of the city.
George Francis Train sat in one of the upper boxes of the Casino last night attired in his white salt and making notes on the performance.
LOUISVILLE, June 27.--The Catholic Knights of St. John adjourned their tenth annual convention late last night. They will meet next year on St. John's Day in Washington.

George Reich, a stalwart, good-looking young man, recently succeeded his father in the business of raising, buying, and selling birds at 98 Fourth-avenue, and the business has prospered. Young Mr. Reich had been engaged to marry pretty Ida Rorke of 57 Wyckoff-street, ...

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 27.--Whether or not the flags on the course marked out for the 'Varsity race were changed so as to give Yale an advantage in the coming race may be open to question, but the Harvards, through Mr. Watson of the Governing Committee, have evidently determined not to row as the course is now laid out.

Judge Van Hoesen, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday morning was the recipient of more interesting information about the con tracts of building the new aqueduct than has been elicited by four Legislatures and half a dozon hotly-contested lawsuits, which have been in existence since the first aqueduct law was passed.

A decision of considerable importance to importers was rendered yesterday by Judge Lacombe. Meyerheim Co., importers, sued ex-Collector Robertson to recover duties which they claimed were exacted in excess of the lawful rate in 1882.
CHICAGO, June 27.--The Democrats of Illinois will open their campaign on Saturday. They are determined to be early in the field and to make an agressive fight from the start.
The Democratic State Committee rooms will be opened to-day, next door to the NewAmsterdam Club, in West Twenty-fourth-street.

CARLISLE, Penn., June 27.--At a secret meeting of the Board of Trustees of Dickinson College to-day Dr. John A. McCanby, President of the college, tendered his resignation alter the board had requested him to do so.

Joel B. Erhardt, having been granted a discharge from the Receivership of the New-York and Northern Railroad Company, the property has been turned over to the new Board of Directors, Mr. Erhardt withdrawing from the management by a letter of resignation made public yesterday.

Mr. W. Fearing Gill and Miss Edith Olive Gwynne, a younger sister of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, were married on Tuesday evening at the bride's residence, 80 Madison avenue. The couple will pass their wedding tour at Narragansett Pier and at Salter's Island, on the coast of Maine.

Four years ago Mr. SETH LOW was Mayor of Brooklyn. He had been elected by the votes of Republicans and Democrats. Of the former he received the ordinary party vote less that of a considerable number of "heelers" and their dupes, who thought he was too good a man for them.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 28.--President William J. Smith of the Flint-Glass Workers' Union gives some interesting information regarding that trade. "One remarkable thing," said he, "is the fact that next year there will be a scarcity of tableware workers, and because during the past season and at present so many new factories have been established, and so many will be improved and enlarged."

CHICAGO, June 28.--E.B. Bradley, the Teller of the Union National Bank of this city, who disappeared some months ago on the discovery of a shortage in his accounts, returned to Chicago this afternoon from Canada.
NASHUA, N.H., June 28.--To-day's celebration of the French Canadian societies brought to the town crowds of people. Fully 10,000 persons thronged the streets.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., June 28.--Theodore Castor, a farmer, was attacked on his way home from Kingston last night by three brothers named Drost, who demanded his money. He shot one dead and fatally wounded another, and thinks he hit the third, who escaped.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 28.--An Italian, name unknown, was shot and killed at Forest of Dean mines, town of Monroe, last night. Constable McCollum of Highland Falls attempted to arrest him on a warrant for stealing $400 from an Italian employed at Tarrytown on the aqueduct, when he resisted, and some person in the crowd that had assembled drew a revolver and fired two shots with fatal effect.

The Republican National and State Committees will take formal possession of the building in a few days.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 28.--D.W. Glass, stationer and printer of Baltimore, Md., who failed recently, has submitted a statement to his creditors, including a number of New-York firms, offering, if allowed to continue, 40 cents on the dollar in three, six, nine, and twelve months. He puts his liabilities at $73,616; assets, $41,416. The Baltimore creditors have accepted, but the New-York parties have not yet decided.

The permanent fund of the Teachers' Mutual Benefit Association of this city was increased yesterday by a contribution of $2,000 from an unknown friend. This fund is now $35,500. There is a membership of 1,987, and there are 12 annuitants.

Two hundred and ninety-one young ladies were graduates at the Normal College, Sixtyeighth-street and Fourth-avenue, yesterday. They received double honors in the form of a diploma and license to teach in the public schools.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 28.--A heavy gale yesterday did considerable damage to the lobster and salmon fishery in the neighborhood of Ingonish, Cape Breton. The schooner Mary Jane was driven ashore at New-Haven last night and is a total wreck. The crew had a narrow escape. The vessel is partially insured. A large timber raft belonging to the Victoria Lumber Mills, at Black Brook, was partially destroyed, causing a great loss.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 28.--News was received to-day of the destruction of Wilson's mill near Jasper, Ark. The engineer, Houston James, not knowing the boiler had run dry, started a fire, when the boiler exploded, tearing the mill to pieces. James himself was blown 100 yards and killed instantly. Horace Ratcliff, an employe, was fatally wounded, dying in two hours. Other employes escaped serious injury.

Every citizen of New-York ought to take shame to himself at the showing made by the special Grand Jury touching the excise cases. The jury sets forth that at the beginning of this year there were 5,000 complaints for violations of the excise law, which had accumulated since 1882, or at about the rate of a thousand a year.

BOSTON, June 28.--The Master Plumbers' Convention to-day elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President--John Trainer of Baltimore; Vice-President--E.J.
