It is a curious fact about the election figures from Oregon that they show an increase of nearly 6,000 Republican votes in two years without any corresponding loss elsewhere, the Democratic vote being about 200 more than in 1886 and the Prohibition vote only a few hundred less. This indicates that the Republican gain in Oregon has been mainly by immigration.

Phillip White, a student at the University of Heidelberg, fell in love in that college town. He came of a good family in Bavaria. The girl was of lowly station. Opposition to his attachment from his family only fired the young man's purpose.
The $2 sent to THE TIMES office yesterday by "Belle and Florence" will be handed over to the Children's Aid Society.

With the exception of Ward and Whitney the New-Yorks played an excellent game of ball, and won by a score of 8 to 3. It was the first opportunity the admirers of the New-Yorks had to witness the exhibition of the new third baseman, and to say that his display was a disappointment is putting it mild.
LOCK HAVEN, Penn., June 29.--G.J. Weaver and Lewis Hochholzer are neighbors and reside near Hyner, this county, and are bear hunters of no mean reputation.
BOSTON, Mass., June 29.--Billy Conley of South Boston rowed his first professional race this afternoon on the Charles River course with J.J. Buckley of Salem.

CHICAGO, June 29.--The legal fight over the Iowa rates promises to be interesting. The railroad companies concerned in the application for an injunction to prevent the Commissioners from putting their reduced tariffs into effect are incorporated in other States than Iowa, and consequently had a right to go into the United States Circuit Court in opposing the restrictions put upon them by the Iowa law.

Margaret Mather, the actress, said yesterday, when asked concerning the report that Manager J.M. Hill's cross-examination, on the trial of her suit against him, was practically a vindication of his claims and corroborative of his direct testimony, that any such conclusion...
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 29.--There has been a good deal of gossip for several days on account of the appearance on the streets of a novel machine for collecting bad debts.

The thirty-fifth Commencement of Manhattan College at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon drew out the largest audience of any Catholic event of the kind this season, fully 2,500 people being in the house.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 29--Matters have apparently reached a climax in regard to the construction of the Portage link.

Bradstreet's reports the total number of mercantile failures in the United States during the first six months of 1888 as 5,254, the estimated assets of which amount to $34,834,746, with liabilities aggregating $64,987,622.

The Health Commissioners yesterday appointed 41 Summer visiting physicians, who will commence work July 5, visiting the tenement houses in this city, looking after their sanitary condition, caring for such of the inmates as may be found to be in need of medical attendance, and reporting such contagious and other diseases as they may find prevailing in the houses visited.
The Denver and Rio Grande Western earned $103,544 in May, a gain of $28,000; operating expenses increased $11,400. Further railroad earnings for the third week of June reported yesterday were:...
The American Yacht Club was granted permission by Judge Andrews in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday to mortgage its property at Milton Point, Rye, Westchester County, for $35,000...
CINCINNATI, June 29.--Gen. Samuel F. Carey remarked to-day: "There is one fact in connection with Ben Harrison which I have not seen stated.

HELENA, Montana, June 29.--The death of Miss Forrest of consumption at Oakland, Cal., a few days ago was the end of a sad romance. Miss Forrest was a beautiful girl and belonged to a wealthy family in Plainfield, N.J. Traveling in Europe a few years ago she met Count Draike, a Frenchman of the old nobility.
CHICAGO, June 29.--A fair-sized crowd witnessed the races at Washington Park to-day. The track was slow and the card anything but a good one:
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 29.--VicePresident Greenleaf called the Minneapolis Chamber of Commerce to order to-day and read the following, submitted by a member:

The Brooklyn Board of Estimate's budget of expenses for 1889 shows appropriations for next year aggregating $8,282,330 25--an increase of $223,031 84 over the amount allowed for the present year. In addition $1,732,686 was appropriated for county expenses, as against $1,441,270 last year.
CHICAGO, June 29.--A gentleman just returned from Colorado, speaking of crop prospects, said that corn in Eastern Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, and Illinois could not look better.
There were two sessions of the Republican National Convention on Monday last. At the first Gen. HARRISON was nominated to stand at the head of the ticket.
Steamship Breakwater, Dale, West Point, Va., with mdse. and passengers to the Old Dominion Steamship Co.

The parents of 4-year-old Ellen Maria Wahlberg, the pretty child who disappeared last Wednesday from her home, 157 East Eighty-seventh-street, rejoiced last evening at the return of their little one by Sergt. Thompson of the One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-Street Station.
CHICAGO, June 29.--The Rosedale, the first British steamship to make a voyage from England to Chicago, arrived here this morning with a cargo of 1,100 tons of cement.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 29.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following decisions were handed down: The People vs. Merwin.-- Judgment affirmed.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 29.--Laurens County, this State, furnishes the latest case of remarkable longevity in the person of John Fielder, a white man, familiarly known in his neighborhood as "Uncle Johnny Fielder."
Albert E. Krahe, the cashier for Hirsh Co., importers of buttons at 427 and 429 Broad way, on June 16 made out and the head of the firm signed a check for $900 to pay off the employes.
RACINE, Wis., June 29.--Zachar, the faster, is keeping up his intention of beating the world's record. He has now been 41 days without food.

LONDON, June 29.--A dispatch from Paris says: "The Temps states that M. de Lesseps convoked the members of the Panama Canal Board to-day in order to submit to them resolutions relating to the issue of the lottery bonds.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., June 29.--The scene of the great battle of the rebellion wears an unusually martial air, though only a small number of the men who fought for and against the Union on the field of Gettysburg have arrived.
NASSAU, New-Providence, June 29.--Sir Ambrose Shea, Governor of the Bahamas, sailed for England via New-York on the steamer Cienfuegos, which left here to-day.
LONDON, June 29.--The race for the Electric Stakes at the Sandown Park meeting to-day for 3-year-olds was won by Bullion, Hazelhatch second, and Juggler third.
CHICAGO, June 29.--Mrs. Naomi Babcock, the woman who yesterday presented a claim that she was the widow of Col. W.S. Babcock, who was killed last August, told her story in the Probate Court to-day.
BALTIMORE, June 29.--The 3,000 representatives from Democratic clubs all over the country to the meeting of the National League will meet in Baltimore on the Fourth of July.
The Spring meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will terminate to-day, and with good weather the close should be a brilliant one.

A particularly contemptible swindle was exposed recently, and Post Office inspectors are now on the track of the swindler. For some time advertisements have appeared in many country papers, declaring that the "London Ribbon Agency of New-Jersay, N.J.," would furnish, upon the receipt of 25 cents in stamps, a large package of assorted ribbons.

MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, June 29.--The State Convention of the Union Labor Party met in this city yesterday. There were about 75 delegates present, representing about onefourth of the counties of the State.
At their ratification meeting last evening the Republicans filled the Metropolitan Opera House with a shouting, laughing, and cheering crowd of men and women, and had an overflow meeting outside.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 29.--Wetmore Baker, dry goods dealers of St. Paul, made an assignment yesterday. Shotwell, Clerihew Lothman of Minneapolis held some $19,000 of Wetmore Baker's paper, and their failure was the indirect occasion of the assignment of the St. Paul firm.

Trombone-player Innes appeared yesterday morning in Essex Market Police Court to answer to the charge of assault preferred by Mr. and Mrs. Beard. Innes's counsel, Joseph Steiner, asked for an examination, which Justice White granted, and set down for July 18 in Yorkville Police Court.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 29.--Bishop Rademacher of Nashville to-day laid and blessed the foundation stone of a new Roman Catholic church here. It will take the place of the one in which Gen. Rosecrans the day after the battle of Chickamauga heard mass. It will cost $90,000.

DETROIT, Mich., June 29.--The exercises of Commencement week at the State University closed yesterday with the formal exercises of the graduating classes of the different departmants of this great institution.

One gratifying thing about the Presidential contest of the present year is the fact that the character of the candidates on both sides is such that it must be conducted on the merits of the policies and of the parties which they represent.
The Hoboken ferryboat Misconotcong and the Newburg of the West Shore Ferry Company came into collision in the North River at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning just outside the Christopher-street slip.
NYACK, N.Y., June 29.--A new feature added to the political parades and meetings of all parties in this place promises to land additional interest to them during the campaign.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 29.--Three thousand persons attended the Driving Club races at Cold Spring Park to-day. The 2:30 class trot was won by Geneva S. in three straight heats, Maggie Wilkes second, Genevra third. Best time, 2:23 . It took four heats to decide the 2:21 class trot: purse $1,000. White Stocking took first money, Williams second, James G. third. Rest time, 2:24.

After Dr. Abbott had closed last evening's prayer meeting in Plymouth Church, Clerk Manuel arose and read a letter signed by the committee of the church and the committee of the society notifying Dr. Abbott of his selection as permanent Pastor.

WASHINGTON, June 29.--It was stated at Gen. Sheridan's house this morning that he slept well during the night and was resting quietly this morning. There was a heavy fall of rain during the morning, and the weather is cold and damp. The removal of Gen. Sheridan will, it is stated, be postponed until it clears up and the conditions are more favorable than at present.

The new Chair of English Language and Literature in the University of the City of NewYork was filled yesterday by the appointment of Richard H. Stoddard of the University of California. William A. Houghton will continue to serve as acting Professor of Rhetorie and History.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 29.--Twentyfour boat lengths--one-sixth of a mile or thereabouts. That is the size of the whopping administered by Yale to Harvard to-day.

Edward Goodenough and H. Frank Woglom, comprising the firm of Goodenough Woglom, dealers in books and Sunday-school supplies, at 122 Nassau-street, yesterday made an assignment to William A. Jones, Jr., giving two preferences for $3,457. Mr. Goodenough has been in the business 30 years.
WASHINGTON, June 29.--The President has nominated to the Senate Thomas Parker to be Postmaster at Albion N.Y.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 29,--Hiland C. Rose, the young man who did so much toward saving the lives of the party on the ill-fated yacht Enid at the time of the collision on Wednessday night, to-day offers $200 reward for the recovery of the bodies of Mrs. Odell and Miss Miller. Joseph Rose, to whom Miss Miller was betrothed, is still violently insane whenever the effect of the opiates works off.

Fine weather and good play marked the second day of the Staten Island Athletic Club's tennis tournament yesterday. Larkin and Carroll distinguished themselves, although the latter was suffering from a sprained ankle. Larkin is also looked on as the probable winner in the singles. The score is as follows:
DETROIT, Mich., June 29.--A local Jesse James gang was broken up Wednesday night in Grand Traverse County with quite sensational accompaniments.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 29.--During the past week there have been some marked changes is the condition of the wheat crop of the Northwest, and the changes have not been altogether for the better.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass.--June. 29.--The steam tug Nellie arrived at this port this morning from Gay Head, having been engaged in laying the Vineyard cable. It was laid in three parts, and the work was completed at 8 o'clock last night, but connection with the cable has not yet been made.
The thermometer commenced to rise at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, when it registered 52 .
At Jersey City yesterday over the track of the Driving Park Association there was one good trotting race--that for the 2:45 class--and a very stupid sweepstakes.

Coroner Eidman was requested yesterday to take the ante-mortem deposition of Frederick Bock, the janitor of 9 Sheriff-street, who was lying in a precarious condition at his home from injuries caused by having been struck on the head by a cart rung by Luke Walsh, a truckman, and also janitor at 636 Water-street.

The Third-Avenue Theatre is becoming quite a bone of contention in theatrical circles. Yesterday, Judge Andrews, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, appointed John M. Drysdale a Receiver of the leasehold property and the present tenant, Manager Jacobs, is required...
The main school room of the male department of Grammar School No. 2, 116 Henrystreet, presented a gay appearance yesterday morning, being draped with American flags and brightened with flowers.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., June .29.--The rain of the past two days came just a week too late to help the strawberry crops along the garden of the Hudson, and the result of the previous fortnight's draught is that the crops have been cut off short, and the strawberry season may be said to be practically ended.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 29.--A colored woman 110 years old and scarcely able to walk is missing from her cabin, near Mossy Creek, in East Tennessee. During the temporary absence of other members of her family she was spirited away and no trace of her has been found. Foul play is suspected, and a thorough search for her is being made by her neighbors and friends.

A ratification meeting under the auspices of the Tammany Hall General Committee of the Sixth Assembly District was held last evening at the Columbian Clubrooms, 518 Grandstreet, and a Cleveland and Thurman banner was raised in the street outside the clubhouse.
About 6 o'clock yesterday morning Mrs. Neil Wetherspoon of Richmond Hill, Long Island, left her kitchen to go to the pump, a few rods back of the house.

ROCKLAND, Mo., June 29.--C.A. Russ Co., granite contractors at Greene Island have shut down their works rather than accede to the demands of the workmen for a monthly pay day and a new scale of wages.
INDIANAPOLIS, JUne 29--Among the callers at Gen. Harrison's residence to-day were Susan B. Anthony, who was in Indianapolis visiting friends, and Gen. Lew Wallace.
J.C. Patrykosky, the proprietor of a beerbottling establishment at Islip, Long Island, was fined $260 by a jury before Justice Smith for selling liquor without a license.

Travel to Long Branch and other popular resorts on the upper coast of New-Jersey has started in so briskly that a multiplied service will be put into operation to-day on the Pennsylvania Road. New express trains will have here daily for Long Branch and Point Pleasant at 2:30, 3:40, and 7 P.M.

LONDON, June 29.--If the White Pasha in the Bahr-el-Ghazel province is Henry M. Stanley, and he intends to relieve the white slaves at Khartoum, the Government will actively assist him; but if he intends to hold Khartoum and to send from that place a force to Emin Bey it is not probable that the Government will support him.
George Charles Spencer-Churchill, seventh Duke of Marlborough, of England, was married yesterday to Mrs. Lilian Warren Hamersley, widow of Louis C. Hamersley, who resides at...

OMAHA, Neb., June 29.--Three laborers, John Hurley, James Dowley, and John Brady, were prisoners in a caisson of Pier 4 of the new bridge being constructed between Council Bluffs and Omaha from 7 o'clock yesterday morning until 6:30 last night.

BROOKHAVEN, Miss., June 29.--The Rev. Andrew Jackson, a colored preacher, who was arrested near Martin Station and placed in the jail here last week, charged with murdering his own child near Brookhaven about three weeks ago, was arraigned for preliminary trial before Justice McMillan to-day.

LONDON, June 29.--The trial of the libel suit of Jockey Wood against the Licensed Victuallers' Gazette, which accused him of pulling horses, ended today, a verdict being returned awarding 1 farthing to the plaintiff.

The death of Capt. William L. Payne on the steamship Athos of the Atlas Line seems to have attracted the attention of the passengers on board to the fact that his life could have been saved had there been medical assistance on board.

Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild addressed an open letter June 20 to George William Curtis in which he discussed at some length the investigation by the Hale committee of the sugar frauds existing in the customs offices in this port.

An array of excellent reading matter will be found in the Century for July. Edward L. Wilson's account of Sinai and the wilderness carries the reader over the ground in a delightfully confidential way, and the papers on the career of the Confederate ram Albemarle, one of them being from the pen of her builder, are very far from the least in interest of the war papers.
CHICAGO, June 29.--The scramble for business continues with unabated vigor among the roads east of Chicago.

Gov. Hill left this city for Albany yesterday. Before going he told several prominent gentlemen that he would probably call an extra session of the Legislature to consider the question of providing for the support of the State prisons and several other public questions. If the Governor does call an extra session his course will be approved by both Tammany Hall and the County Democracy.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 29.--All ecclesiastical council at Plymouth Church this afternoon declined to dismiss the Pastor, the Rev. Charles Wadsworth, Jr., who has accepted a call to a Presbyterian church in San Francisco, as more than 90 per cent. of the church members object to the change.
ALBANY, June 29.--In his recent report on oyster shell fish Commissioner Eugene Blackford said: Our oyster supply in the future must depend on artificial beds.

BERLIN, June 29,--The National Zeilung says that the coming interview between Emperor William and the Czar will take place between the 10th and 15th of July. The place of meeting, it says, has not yet been decided upon.

MINNEAPOLIS, Kan., June 29.--At 2 o'clock this morning a party of 40 or 50 masked men from Fountain Township in this (Ottawa) county, neighbors of Mike Dorsey, who was murdered in his bed a few days ago by ChubbMcCarthy, came into this city and with sledges and a bar of railroad iron proceeded to break down the outside doors of the jail.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., June 29.--Peter Hronek was hanged to-day for the murder of his wife on April 17, 1887. He denied any intent to commit the crime.
The veterans will leave the city to-day in large numbers for Gettysburg. Among those who will go are the Second New-York Fire Zouaves' Association.

The storm Thursday night played havoc with the yachts of the Williamsburg Yacht Club anchored off the clubhouse at Steinway Village. At Bowery Bay Beach over 50 rowboats broke loose from their moorings, and yesterday were found strewn along the beach.

The General Passenger Agents of the Central Passenger Association and the Trunk Line Passenger Agents met at Long Branch on Thursday, but on account of the small attendance an adjournment was had until July 10 at Cresson, Penn.
Henry Eldred, living at 8 East Fortysecond-street, was run over at Madison-avenue and Forty-second-street last evening by a coupe which was being driven to the Grand Central Station.

The announcement that Francis Henry Temple Bellow died yesterday at the home of hiS daughter, on Long Island, will appeal to the generation that is thinning out, rather than to those who are now most active in city life.
LOUISVILLE, June 29.--The Louisville team, to the delight of a big crowd, held Brooklyn down to a single run to-day. Brooklyn's fielding as a rule was good, but they could not hit Chamberlain.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 29.--Polly, the 8-year-old daughter of Mr. Hockingberg, dry goods dealer at Worthington-street, was abducted by a stranger this afternoon, and for whom the police of Holyoke, this city, and Chicopee have been searching all evening, returned home at 10 o'clock to-night.

CHICAGO, June 29.--Grace Waring Roberts to-day was granted a divorce by Judge Shepard from Louis Roberts, Jr. She is a daughter of John T. Waring, a wealthy resident of Yonkers, N.Y., and at the time of her marriage, in 1875, was a favored member of society in New-York.

CANADAIGUA, N.Y., June 29.--Elizia Lennehan, domestic in the family of J.W. Barnes of this village, was killed in the freight yard here this afternoon. She was very deaf and while walking on the track was overtaken by a freight train. The body was frightfully mangled. She was about 30 years old.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 29.--The will ofWilliam H. Chandler of Thompson, the wealthiest man in Eastern Connecticut at the time of his death, has been admitted to probate. The estate will considerably exceed $1,000,000 in amount.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 29.--The United States Circuit Court for the Eastern District of New-York, Judge Blatchford presiding, is holding another session at the State House.
ABSURY PARK, N.J., June 29.--One of the fiercest storms that have visited this coast in many years raged along here last evening, doing much damage.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 29.--The Connecticut Summer school for teachers, which will be held under the direction of the State Board of Education, will begin at Niantie on Tuesday, July 3, and continue for two weeks.
There was a rise in June coffee yesterday, and the members of the Coffee Exchange had more excitement to attend to than they have had in many months.

Grimaldi, Satisfaction, Jay F. Dee. and Bradford furnished surprises of a most agreeable nature to their backers at the Sheepshead Bay races yesterday. Mona, Eolian, Blazon, Inverwick, Charley Dreux, and Golden Reel...
BOSTON, June 29.--Members of Boston's Common Council are feeling very uneasy over the threatened exposure of their junketing devices.

WASHINGTON, June 29.--Col. Jedediah H. Bax ter, Chief Medical Purveyor, has been ordered to New-York on temporary duty; Second Lieut. George H. Cameron, Seventh Cavalry, has been granted 16 days' extension of leave of absence;

The conduct of representative Republicans in the press and in Congress since the adjournment of the Chicago Convention recalls that famous cartoon of Punch in which Lord JOHN RUSSEL was represented as running violently away from a door on which he had just inscribed "No Popery."
The engagement has just been announced of Miss Belle Wilson, a daughter of R.T. Wilson and a sister of Mrs. Ogden Goelet of this city, to the Hon. Michael Herbert, a brother of the Earl of Pembroke.

The Indian troubles reported in Alaska spring from a novel cause. The Chilcat tribe, it appears, has a monopoly of the freight business from the coast to the mines in the interior; and, like some other monopolists, they have been in the habit of regulating their prices for transportation according to their covetousness.

Virtue was triumphant in the great ball match plaped yesterday afternoon in the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, between the married and single men's nines of the Seventh Assembly District Tammany Hall Association.
WASHINGTON, June 29.--The Hawley amendment to the Army Appropriation bill came up in the House to-day.
CLEAR WATER, Minn., June 29.--Charles Pinkerton of the town of Corins, 12 miles from here, in digging for a cellar came across the remains of seven persons in a good state of preservation.

Mr. Mansfield's afternoon performance of "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" at the Madison-Square Theatre yesterday was attended by a large and demonstrative audience. Many actors who had never seen Mansfield's wonderful portrayal of the man of two lives appalauded the performance with enthusiasm.
A wild spurt on the Coffee Exchange yesterday in expiring June options served for a sensation in Wall-street, though the total amount of money involved in the transactions was insignificant.
TACOMA, Washington Territory, June 29.-- The court room has been crowded all day during the progress of the Gardner trial, and intense interest, is manifested in the proceedings.
The trial of ex-Transfer Agent Du Bois of the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad for swindling the company by means of an overissue of transfer tickets, was held in Justice Massey's court, Brooklyn, yesterday.
John Schlamp of Peterson, N.J. visited the Academy of Music Thursday night. In the hallway his watch, valued at $250, was stolen.

WASHINGTON, June 29.--A Republican ratification meeting was held at the headquarters of the Republican National League to-night. Notwithstanding a drizzling rain about 500 people gathered on the lawn in front of the clubhouse, while several hundred more assembled within doors.
CALAIS, Mo., June 29.--Reuben Essensa, aged 20 years, ettempted to swim across the Magaguadavic River, at Lee Settlement, NewBrunswick, this morning, with a child named Willie Beney on his back.

MONTREAL, June 29.--The Post to-night has a story to the effect that A.M. Du Hamel has absconded from Longueuil. He had charge in that town of the collection of water rents, the supervision or auction sales, and was also corporation bailiff.
Coroner Nugent yesterday finished the inquest in the case of Thomas Fagan, who died May 25 at St. Vincent's Hospital from injuries alleged to have been received at the hands of Henry Cairnes.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 29.--Today's session of the American Institute of Homeopathy was devoted to the reading of the final reports of sevaral bureaus, appointment of new committees, assignment of subjects for bureau work, delivery of eulogies on deceased members, and adoption and formulation of the recommendations of the Committee on Medical Legislation.
Grammar School No. 22, that is situated at Sheriff and Stanton streets, had its annual Commencement yesterday afternoon.
A pretty little wedding was celebrated on Wednesday last in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rector, the Rev. Dr. Houghton.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., June 30.--The Methodists of this village have been engaged this week celebrating the semi-centennial of the establishment of the Methodist Episcopal church here.

The Philadelphia oarsmen are going to have a great time of it on July 3 and 4. There will be a succession of races over the national course, from Fall's Bridge to Rockland Landing, on the Sehuylkill, that will call out the best scullers from most of the important rowing clubs in the East.
MOULMEIN, Lower Burmah, May 9.--This will probably be my last letter from Burmah, and our visit to the "Golden Kingdom" has certainly been filled with adventures up to the very end.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30.--Drafts-Sight, 17 cents, telegraphic, 22 cents.

CHICAGO, June 30.--Articles for a match race between Johnston, the famous pacer, record 2:06 , and Oliver K., trotting record 2:16 , were signed here to-day. It is to be a go-as-you-please contest, and will take place in St. Paul July 4 at the State Fair grounds. The race will be for $1,000 a side, with $2,000 added by the Twin City Driving Club.

A prisoner who gave his name as T.E. Hart of 125 West Sixty-fourth-street, and also as J.F. Crandall of 4 and 6 Liberty-place, escaped from the Second Police Precinct Station House early yesterday morning.

Get-away Day at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday proved to be one of the best day's racing of the most brilliant and successful meeting ever held at the pretty track of the Coney Island Jockey Club.

CHICAGO, June 30.--The rate war on eastbound freights goes merrily on. The week closes with the rate on dressed beef 30 cents to New-York and Beston and 28 cents to Philadelphia, or less than half the tariff rate that was in force up to last Monday.

SUSPENSION BRIDGE, N.Y., June 30.--The Collector of Customs here has been instructed by the Secretary of the Treasury to refuse the entry and importation of neat cattle from Tara Grey County and vicinity, in Ontario Province, on account of the reported existence of disease.
The New-York Central Railroad Company issued yesterday a statement of the business of that company and its leased lines for the quarter and for the nine months ending yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. George W. Abell of Baltimore, Md., together with their children, Miss Jennie M. Abell and Master Charles S. Abell, accompanied by Miss Bertie Le Brou and Horace A. Brooks, sailed on the Cunard steamer Aurania yesterday for an extended tour through Europe.

The people of Far Rockaway are anxiously inquiring for a builder named Robert E. Mills, who until about six months ago lived at 240 East Twenty-eighth-street, this city, and had his shop at 146 East Twenty-sixth-street. It is said he suddenly disappeared a week ago last Friday, leaving behind him a number of creditors, among them about 20 workmen.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 30.--A remarkable test of the flying powers of the homing pigeon was made to-day. The local agent of the Wells-Farge Express Company at sunrise released three birds, whose destination is East Liverpeol, Ohio, a distance of 700 miles. The birds were sent from Philadelphia, and are expected to make the flight in 14 hours.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 30.--Grasshoppers have recently appeared by the million in this vicinity and seriously threaten the total annihilation of crops. A vigorous warfare is being waged against them. BOSTON, June 30.--About 8:30 o'clock last evening a canoe containing J.R. Codwise of Wellesley Hills, and a young lady, capsized in Charles River, near Riverside. The body of Codwise was recovered an hour later.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 30.--Seven hundred thousand dollars was placed in bank here yesterday to be used in the erection of three new blast furnaces in this vicinity. The furneces are to be 17 feet each. The projectors of the enterprise are H.F. De Berdeleben of Bir mingham and parties from Charleston and Savannah. Work is to be begun immediately. When these furnaces are completed there will be 24 blast furnaces in operation in Alabama.

PITTSBURG, June 30.--The Summer shutdown of the flint-glass factories commenced today. All the factories in the country have banked their fires and the 6,600 employes will take a rest for six weeks. The annual wage conferences of the flint-glass and chimney blowers will begin on Monday. No important changes in the scale are probable.

MONTREAL, June 30.--It now turns out that Albert Krahe, the New-York forger, was not arrested yesterday as reported. Detective Creed arrived from New-York this morning, but he has no warrant for extradition, but simply for forgery. After an interview Krahe agreed to go back, and the detective will leave with him for New-York this afternoon. Krahe has given up $1,200 in money and $400 in diamonds.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, June 30.--News reached here this morning that United States Marshal Hector Thomas was shot yesterday at Redford, Creek Nation, Indian Territory, by a desperado he was trying to arrest. Two years ago he killed the notorious Lee boys in this (Cook) county.

Mr. Amberg was asked yesterday whether he was going to bring the Saxe-Meiningen theatrical company to this country, and replied that he did not think he would. As far as he could see the expenses would be too great. Mr. Amberg will become Pauline Lucca's manager next Fall. She will appear in his new theatre, in Irving-place, next November.

DID HE TELL LIES?--If Sir John Mandeville lied, he lied with Herodotus and Pliny. He merely repeated marvels more or less generally received by everybody in Europe. When there is a sound reason for doubt, who can be more persuasively candid and cautions? ...

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 30.--Typhus fever is prevalent among cattle in portions or Sullivan County. Nicholas Dauch, a farmer near Mountaindale, has lost five animals within 24 hours from the disease. Sylvester Crossman, a neighbor of Dauch, has lost four cows. The symptoms resemble bloody murrain. There is a loss of appetite, great thirst and diarrhea, followed quickly by spasms and paralysis.

From the notes of the British Vice-Consul at Denver on the agricultural condition of the State of Colorado it appears that the increase of the area of land under cultivation throughout the district is very remarkable, especially in the more Western States and Territories.

There has been only a nominal market in Wall-street the past week. The Stock Exchange has been open every day, and the brokers have been there, but business has not. On Friday transactions dwindled down to about 80,000 shares.
A committee of residents of the lower east side, friends of Dr. William Dwyer, have arranged for a testimonial for the benefit of the family of the dead physician.

Chevalier Blondin, the well-known acrobat of Niagara fame, will leave for Europe next Wednesday on a Guion steamer unless his agent, S.A. de Parravicini, can come to some definite arrangements with Manager Imre Kiralfy before that time.
A sentiment much appealed to in our politics is loyalty to party, but it must be considered that a political organization is a means for the attainment of certain ends and not an end in itself.

Steve Brodie arrived at the Battery at 9:30 A.M. yesterday, accomplishing his task of swimming from Albany to that point and beating the record of Capt. Paul Boyton. He made the journey in six days and one hour.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., June 30.--Mrs. Eva Harsch, 62 years of age, fell from a box on which she was standing while looking through a hole in the loft of a barn this morning, and her head was caught in such a way that she was suspended. When found she was dead.

The First Brigade, New-Jersey National Guard, is to go into camp at Sea Girt, N.J., on Monday, July 16, to remain until Saturday, Aug. 4. On Monday, Aug. 6, the Second Brigade will take the vacant tents and remain under canvas until Saturday, Aug. 18.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30.--Very thin dannel suits were found almost uncomfortable at this place during the early part of the week, but on Thursday a decidedly cool wave struck the town, and no white or dark flannel suits were visible.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 30.--The new rates announced by the "Soo" line show a reduction of 31 cents on first-class freight and, as the rates are all rail, the possibility of the Chicago lines meeting the figures is precluded.

LONDON, June 30.--The election in the Isle of Thanet Division of Kent to fill the vacancy in the House of Commons caused by the death of Col. E.R. King-Harman was held yesterday, and resulted in the return of the Conservative candidate, Mr. James Lowther, by a ...

The greatest racing meeting ever held in this country will begin on Wednesday next at Monmouth Park, and there during the coming two months the great racers of the East, West, and South will meet to contest for purses and stakes which are the most valuable ever ...

CHICAGO, July 1.--A heavy eight-wheel cable car of the north side line played havoc with some of the company's rolling stock tonight on Lasalle-street. Its grip caught in a strand of the cable, and the car, which could not be stopped, dashed into the train ahead of it.
HAVANA, July 1.--Alfonso Bernal, a kidnapper, was executed at Matanzas on Friday.
CHICAGO, July 1.--The following crop summary will appear in this week's issue of the Farmers' Review:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 1.--Senator Cullom, who has been sick at his home here ever since his return from the Chicago Convention, expected to start for Washington to-night, but under the advice of his physicians he did not go. He will be able to go to-morrow. It is probable Mrs. Cullom will accompany him.

In the month of June next year it will be 350 years since the introduction of the Reformation in the Province of Bradenburg. It is the intention in Government circles and of the municipalities of all the larger cities and towns in the Mark to celebrate the great event with appropriate ceremonies.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 1.--The Republican will print in the morning reports from over 100 correspondents on crop prospects in Western New-England, including Western Massachusetts, Northern Connecticut, and southern districts in New-Hampshire and Vermont.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 1.--A State Convention of Prohibitionists will meet here July 4. Delegates to the convention were chosen yesterday from Pulaski and a number of other counties in the State.

Robert Hargreaves, a salesman, hailing from Buffalo, N.Y., was arrested in this city on Saturday night by Detective McCarty, on a warrant issued by Police Justice Thomas S. King of Buffalo, in which the prisoner stands charged with having passed two worthless checks for $70 on John Warner, a saloon keeper of that city.

CHICAGO, July 1.--None of the iron and steel works in and about Chicago shut down last night, but may do so at any time. The North Chicago Rolling Mill and the Rolling Steel Works--the principal ones--discussed the matter of wages with their employes last January and signed a scale then. The managers, however, refuse to say what action they will take now.

Special services in celebration of Independence Day were held last night in the Reformed Episcopal Church of the Atonement, at Mercy-avenue and Keap-street, Brooklyn. A programme selected in part from the Fourth of July service of the church was prepared, including several patriotic songs and addresses.

With the close of the racing at Sheepshead Bay last Saturday the Spring meetings came to an end, and for the next two months the scene of action will be transferred to Monmouth Park where the Summer meeting of the association will begin on Wednesday next.

The social success of Mr. Daly's company of players in London, as described by letters received by friends of some of the members of the company in this city, is something to recall pleasant memories of the season abroad for many years to come.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 1.--A grizzled old farmer named William P. Brown was in town the other day, and fell to giving reminiscences of Paterson as he remembered the place 60 years ago.

Russian romances and Russian sketches have a fast hold on American taste. It might be easy in some respects, difficult in others, to account for the favor in which Turgenieff, Tolstoi, Gogol are held.

DUBLIN, July 1.--The New-York and Manhattan Athletic teams met with a cordial reception on their arrival at Kingstown to-day. They were escorted by prominent Irish athletes and sportsmen to Dublin. Here a band of music awaited them and they were heartily cheered.
BALTIMORE, July 1.--The Rev. Joseph Haid of the Benedictine Monastery in North Carolina was consecrated a Bishop this morning at the cathedral.
NEW-BEDFORD, July 1.--The strikes of ring spinners at the Wamsutta and Grinnell Mills have been settled, and the girls get nearly all the advance they asked for.

Dr. McGlynn addressed the usual large assemblage at the Anti-Poverty meeting in Cooper Union last night. He said he thought a deathblow could be administered to the landlords of New-York through the medium of the United Labor Party; whom he urged to contribute money for the purposes of sheltering those who might be turned from their homes upon their refusal to pay rent.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 1.--The bodies of Mrs. B.B. Odell, Jr., and Miss Annie Miller, who were drowned at the Enid's collision with the steamer Baldwin in Newburg Bay Wednesday night, were recovered this morning.

The numerous friends and admirers of Dr. William Dwyer tendered his family a benefit at the Windsor Theatre last night. The programme consisted of vocal and instrumental performances, recitations, and readings. The Hon, S.S. Cox, in his introductory address, spoke in growing terms of Dr. Dwyer, calling special attention to his sympathy with oppressed Ireland and his many acts of charity toward the Irish people.

About 200 veterans of the Irish Brigade gathered at the foot of Desbrosses-street early yesterday morning to take the 9:20 special train awaiting them at the Pennsylvania Railroad station for Gettysburg.

Gov. Robert S. Green of New-Jersey has gone to the Gettysburg reunion, and in the absence of the Governor and also of President Large of the State Senate City Controller Dickinson, who was Speaker of the last House, is Acting Governor.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 1.--Robert William Flack of Syracuse will make a trip through the Rapids of Niagara River next Wednesday as late celebration of the Fourth. He will start from the old Maid of the Mist landing, go through the Whirlpool Rapids and the Whirlpool, the Devil's Caldron, and finish at Lewiston.

The Republican organs, especially in the Central Western States and in others where the temperance vote is strong, are trying to explain away the plank in their platform that prefers free liquor to the surrender of any protective tax whatever.
The closing exercises of St. Gabriel's Grammar School, held yesterday afternoon in St. Gabriel's Hall, East Thirty-sixth-street, consisted of a long programme of very well rendered ...

HAWLAY, Penn., July 1.--When the Blooming Grove Park Association, or what afterward became such, composed of many prominent New-Yorkers, was casting about for a spot suitable for forming its game and fish preserve, the prospectors for such a spot were led into Western Pike County, where they found a sheet of water 2,000 feet above tidewater, surrounded by mountains, and covering about 600 acres.

GETTYSBURG, Penn,. July 1.--The Louisiana "Tigers" have arrived, and Gen. Longstreet, in making a speech before the Association of the First Army Corps on the spot where Reynolds was killed, almost broke down, and for several moments seemed upon the point of crying.
The Brighton Beach Pacing Association will continue its meeting to-day with a programme of six races. The entries and weights are as follows:

President-elect Antonio Flores of Ecuador, South America, was one of the passengers arriving from Europe yesterday by the steamer La Gascogne of the French Line. He was met down the Bay by Consul-General Dominigo L. Ruiz of Ecuador, who had previously secured apartments for him at the Albemarle, to which he retired as soon as the vessel reached her wharf.

DULUTH, Minn., July 1.--Superintendent Jarvis, Division Superintendent Watson, Mr. Orr, and other officials of the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Road, arrived here this evening to look over terminal matters for their company.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 1.--The Government has ordered an investigation into the complaints made by Chinese merchants at Victoria, British Columbia, that the Chinese interpreter there was interfering with the immigration of Chinese. The interpreter says he merely sought to prevent the importation of Chinese women for immoral purposes.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 1.--The regular monthly meeting of the Board of Commissioners of the Niagara Reservation was held at Niagara Falls yesterday.
There was an installation of Elders and Deacons yesterday afternoon at the Third Reformed Presbyterian Church, on Twenty-thirdstreet, between Seventh and Eighth avenues.

LONDON, July 2.--The Berlin correspondent of the Daily News says: "Prince Bismarck, in a conversation with several members of the upper house of the Prussian Diet, expressed his conviction that peace would not be disturbed unless other powers provoked a war.
CHICAGO, July 1.--J. Aldrich Brown proves to be the real name of the man looked up yesterday on a charge of bigamy, who is said to have 23 wives.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., July 1.--Mrs. Gonys, aged about 70 years, living on the shore, near St. Albans Bay, was left alone last evening with her two grandchildren, 5 and 8 years old respectively. She took the children into a flat-bottomed boat, with nothing but a paddle with which to control the craft.

Detective Sergeant Creed returned to this city yesterday from Montreal, having in his custody Albert E. Krahe, the dishonest cashier of Hersh Co. of 427 and 428 Broadway, who fled recently with $3,000 belonging to his employers.

The Casino will be the only home of comic opera in this city during the next two weeks, and "Nadjy," with Fanny Rice in the title role, will be given there nightly without reference to the temperature outside.

NYACK, N.J., July 1.--"Hallelujah!" shouted Convert Thompson of the Salvation Army last night, when a heavy windstorm temporarily wrecked the immense tent under which a spirited meeting was being held and the canvas closed in upon the large audience present.

TACOMA, Washington Territory, July 1. --Yesterday morning Col. Haines entered on the defense in the Gardner case, and in his address before the jury made a total denial of every allegation in the indictment.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 1.--The Eleventh Regiment and that able body of men forming, While in camp, the Third Provisional Battalion, on their first night here incurred the displeasure of the assertive hobgoblin of Dunderberg.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the delegates from the building trades section asked that the metal section should be reinstated to membership pending an investigation to be made by an impartial committee.

RED WING, Minn., July 1.--In speaking of the late decision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the case of the Business Men's Association of the State of Minnesota, petitioner, against the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company, President Pope of the association says:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 1.--Through the Collector of the Port, Walter Goddard, the city authorities addressed a letter to United States Treasurer James W. Hyatt, setting forth the intention of the citizens to celebrate on a grand scale the coming Fourth of July.
Policemen were hastily summoned from the Grove-street station, in Jersey City, at 6 o'clock last evening, to a little grocery store on the corner of Henderson and Grove streets.

CINCINNATI, July 1.--The Cincinnatis won to-day's game by their superior all-round playing. Viau was a puzzle to the Brooklyns, and Mays also pitched a very good game. The feature of the game was the fielding of Corkhill. Attendance, about 6,000. Score:

HEMPSTEAD, Long Island, July 1.--The inhabitants of this village will pass another night of anxiety, as William Kane, leader of a band of boy incendiaries, who broke jail last night, is still at large.
NEW ORLEANS, July 1.--While drilling an artesian well for an ice manufacturing company at Shreveport on Friday, a vein of natural gas was struck at a depth of 970 feet.

Mrs. Louise Stanbury, who lives in West Houston-street, was standing at the corner of that street and Hudson-street Saturday evening when she saw two men beating a third on the opposite side of the street.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., July 1.--The United States steamer Swatara, Capt. McGowan, with Gen. Sheridan and party on board, arrived here at 8 o'clock this morning. A boat came ashore at 10 o'clock with the following bulletin:

After the immigrants who arrived on the steamships Etruria, City of Richmond, and Polaris had passed through Castle Garden yesterday a very pretty little girl, apparently a little over a year old, was found seated quietly on the floor near the railway ticket counter.
DETROIT, Mich., July 1.--There are few who have the slightest idea of the work involved in "unwatering" the great Calumet and Hecla Copper Mine, which is now going on.

As the sloop Thorn was beating up North River against the ebb tide yesterday morning she was capsized, but, as she went over gradually and for some time lay on her side, her crew and passengers, 15 in number, were enabled to crawl up, and, perching themselves on her bottom, held on until relief reached them.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 1.--The great iron lock-out which began yesterday presented no new features to-day further than the report of the signing of the Amalgamated scale by another firm.

Yesterday was the twentieth anniversary of the connection of the Rev. Dr. Anthony Schuyler with Grace Church, Orange, N.J., as its Rector. His morning sermon was devoted to a review of the history of the parish during this period.
WASHINGTON, July 1.--The following is the weather crop bulletin for the week ended Saturday, June 30, 1888, issued by the Signal Officer:

TARA, Ontario, July 1.--The experts sent here by the Dominion and Ontario Governments to investigate the disease which has been killing cattle in Grey County have pronounced it a blood disease due to local causes. It was reported to be contagious pleuro-pneumonia.
Walter Callahan, who was injured by the explosion or a bomb found on the dump at the navy yard Saturday, will probably die. His arms were amputated yesterday at the Homeopathic Hospital.

DUBLIN, July 1.--The Irish Bishops have published a series of resolutions explaining in detail the present position of the land question and expressing the opinion that unless Parliament immediately applies a really effective measure to protect tenants from oppressive exactions and arbitrary eviction the most disastrous consequences to public order and the safety of the people must almost inevitably ensue.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--Jacob Baltz, a member of the Malta Boat Club and son of Jacob Baltz, the millionaire brewer, was drowned in the Schuylkill River shortly after midnight this morning.

The Attorney-General of this State heard arguments on May 14 in support of petitions in which he was urged to bring suit against the Sugar Refineries Company, commonly called the Sugar Trust, and against one of the corporations absorbed by that organization.

CHICAGO, July 1.--The Chicago Times to-morrow reduces the price of its weekday issue from 3 to 2 cents a copy, the Sunday edition remaining at 5 cents. This is the second reduction made in the price of the daily within a month, the first being from 5 to 3 cents.
The Mormon Church has a firm clutch on the Territory of Utah, which has an area of 84,970 square miles. There are many hundreds of thousands of acres of arable land in the Territory.

LONDON, June 23.--A few days ago in Berlin I received some information about the new English ammunition. The old proverb about going from home to learn home news once more justified, and Lord Wolseley's assertion that the secrets of the British Goverment are well known to foreign officers receives an apt illustration.
BUFFALO, July 1.--The Niagara Reservation Commissioners have a great plan in mind for the furtherance of a free Niagara scheme.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 1.--No liquor was sold at the big social clubs to-day. The members who have been in the habit of drinking whisky cockrails and champagne on Sunday were amazed this morning when they were informed by the waiters at the clubs that they could not be served with liquors.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The legislative Committee of the Line of the Navy is doing some effective work in the way of securing a new pay table. An argument favoring an increase of pay has just come from the printer, and will be widely circulated among the Senators and Representatives.

William J. Le Moyne, the comedian, and Miss Sarah Cowell, a public reader, were married on June 26, and the first intimation many of the friends of the actor had of the event was obtained from the formal announcement of it which was made public in yesterday's TIMES.
LONG BRANCH, July 1.--The programme arranged by the liquor dealers of this place at their recent meeting, to keep their saloons open on Sundays, was not carried out to-day.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 1.--On Saturday night bad feeling between cousins in Tangipahoa Parish, at Spring Creek Church, near the Illinois Central Railroad, about 100 miles above this city, culminated in the killing of one and the fatal wounding of another.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 1.--The schedule of assets and liabilities of Shotwell, Clerihew Lothmann, the Minneapolis dry goods jobbers who recently made an assignment, has been filed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 1.--"The advocates of a protective tariff will find in Ohio this year a great change in the attitude of the people from that of eight years ago when they were making the same fight." This declaration, made by a loading citizen in the hearing of the writer to-day, is fully borne out by the facts.

ALBANY, July 1.--The cornerstone of the statue to Robert Burns, the gift of the late Mary McPherson to the city, was laid by the Grand Lodge Free and Accepted Masons of this State in Washington Park yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--Dr. George M. Wells, Chief Resident Physician of the Philadelphia Hospital, telephoned to the Coroner's office at 9:30 o'clock this morning that a man had committed suicide at the almshouse.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 1.--The present week promises to be an eventful one in Cincinnati. It will witness the opening of the Centennial Exposition and at the same time the celebration of the Fourth of July.
NEWPORT, July 1.--The congregation worshipping at the Hanson-Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, will visit Newport July 6, and will stop at the Ocean House on the way back from Martha's Vineyard.

Coney Island was not as thickly populated yesterday as is usual on Sunday at this time of year, but there were several thousand people scattered along from democratic West Brighton to the more aristocratic precinct surrounding the Oriental Hotel.

CHICAGO, July 1.--But one of the theatrical novelties promised for last week materialized. D'Ennery's "Cavalier" was given its first presentation in this country, but the date of the introduction of Steele Mackaye's now play, "A Noble Rogue," was carried over to the coming week.
The orders rogarding the contemplated embarkation of the troops aboard the Ossipee and Galena to-day were issued Saturday by Major-Gen. Schofield.

Secularly speaking, there was stunning good time at the old Jane-Street Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday. It was an occasion filled with red letters. Everybody was in good humor. Sisters in the church greeted brethren with an effusiveness that bespoke unmeasured rejoicing.
BRAINERD, Minn., July 1.--The most disastrous fire which over visited this city broke out last night, and, after three hours of tremendous efforts to stay it, the flames were checked.

The murder of Thomas Wood, the Mount Vernon Constable, by Frank Brouty, a notorious ruffian of that village, Saturday afternoon has created a good deal of feeling against the murderer, and of sympathy with Wood's widow and family.

The Chicago limited express, Lake Shore line, due at the Grand Central Station at 7:30 o'clock last night, was delayed for about half an hour by an accident to its locomotive when about 35 miles from New-York.

The excise year expired at 12 o'clock Saturday night, and with it nearly 1,200 saloon licenses. Only about 50 saloon keepers have applied for new licenses, and the others are all liable for selling without a license.

Soon after midnight last night Alfred E. Dutcher of 318 West Fourteenth-street and an inspector of linen in the Custom House was found unconscious upon the walk in front of the St. James Hotel. Blood was flowing from an ugly wound on his head.

MACON, Mo., July 1.--A valuable historical relic was shown in this city to-day by its owner, Elias McNeal of Vienna, Macon County. It was the compass owned by William Penn, and used by him in surveying his domain and laying out the city of Philadelphia in 1682.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Local packers have a new phase of the rate situation to bother then in the extending of the war on dressed beet rates to Kansas City, from which place to NewYork the rate has been reduced to 56 cents by

The Rev. Hugh O. Pentecost delivered a sermon to Unity Congregation at the Masonic Temple, yesterday morning, on "The Presidential Nominations." He had a large congregation, which, from the enthusiastic applause elicited from it by Mr. Pentecost's disparaging references to political leaders of whatever party, was evidently a strictly non-partisan gathering.
The Newark and Albion Cricket Clubs will play a match next Saturday at Prospect Park.

BALTIMORE, July 1.--The city was a little too dry for the German singers to-day, so they went to Bay Ridge, a delightful resort on the Chesapeake, where they had water all around them, and several thousand kegs of lager with which to clear their throats and make merry.

James Adams, a laborer, 24 years old, of 605 First-avenue, while endeavoring to stop his horse, which was running away, at One Hundred and Seventh-street and First-avenue, last evening, was knocked down and received a compound fracture of the nose.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 1.--One probable result of to-day's meeting of the Trade and Labor Assembly will be the withdrawal of those Knigts of Labor who still remain friendly to it, and the unfriendly feeling of the Knights toward the Assembly will be intensified.

It was a very, very cold day yesterday compared with the indications on the corresponding day last year. Hudnut's thermometer ought to have blushed with shame to think it could average only 66 3-6 up to 6 o'clock, when last year the sun boiled ...

In his address before the Harvard chapter of the Phi Beta Kappa last week on "The Working of the American Democracy," President ELIOT of Harvard University furnished at least one good theme for the reflection of the whole American people, especially at this time, when the Republic is approaching what is to be one of the most important elections in its history.

Most freight agents on Broadway are of the opinion that the newly-adopted tariff sheet of the "Soo" line, cutting the former rates to St. Paul and other Minnesota points, via all rail, down to 60 cents per 100 on first-class freights and 20 cents on sixth-class, has been ...

The Republicans of Newark and Essex County had a large celebration of the nomination of Harrison and Morton last evening under the auspices of the Republican Union League of Newark. The hall of the league in Halseystreet was adorned inside and outside with flags and banners.

WASHINGTON, July 2.--The President has sent the following nominations to the Senate: Peter F. Knight of Florida to be Marshal for the Southern District of Florida, vice Fernando J. Moreno, resigned; Charles De Blanc of Louisiana to be Consul at Puerto Cabello.
Several League and Association clubs are trying to buy the release of pitcher Burkett of Scranton.

The Committee on Public Works of the Board of Aldermen yesterday reported in favor of giving permission to the owners of property on both sides of West End-avenue to inclose with an iron railing a space of 10 feet extending outwardly from the house line, to be used exclusively as courtyards.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian squadron, which was to have assembled at Oyster Bay, Long Island, yesterday, was much delayed on account of the flat calm which fell upon the waters of the Sound early in the afternoon. Among the first vessels to arrive at Oyster Bay were the Ruth, Capt. Marfuand; Iola, Capt. ...

ALBANY, July 2.--The water in the upper Hudson is extremely low, and the larger river craft have difficulty in passing troublesome places. It is estimated that at dead low water the tide is nearly a foot below the average Summer low water.

Mr. Goldstein, who represents the American Tract Society in Castle Garden, received a letter yesterday from a Swedish immigrant now in Trenton Prison, named Gustav Jensen, who claims that he is innocent of the crime of which he was convicted.

VALPARAISO, Ind., July 2.--A serious accident occurred on the Grand Trunk Road near here yesterday morning, resulting in the wrecking of an engine and 10 freight cars, and the killing of Stephen Buel, a brakeman, of Scotts, Mich., and the maiming of a fireman. The accident was caused by the freight engine striking some horses on the track, three of which were killed.

William Holzhauer, who says he is the owner of the steam launch Olivette which was overturned in Newark Bay a week ago Saturday night, has sent in a report to the Steamboat Inspectors. La Cuenca, a young and comely Spanish lady, was the special attraction at Koster Bial's concert hall last evening. She appeared in two acts.

The Union Pacific Railroad's report for May was issued yesterday. It showed $2,312,191 in gross earnings, an increase of $123,913. Net earnings were $792,257, an increase of $34,432. From Jan. 1 to May 30 gross earnings have increased $495,247, and net earnings have increased $389,263.

COEYMANS, July 2.--Fruit growers along the Upper Hudson are now estimating their crops. Peaches will be in abundance, apples an ordinary crop, and plums a very scant yield. Plum trees blossomed full this year, but before the setting period came heavy frosts ensued and destroyed the greater part of the blossoms.

WASHINGTON, July 2.--Commander Louis Kempff has been ordered to duty at the Mare Island Navy Yard, California; Assistant Paymaster M.B. Calvert, assistant to the general storekeeper, Portsmouth, N.H. The orders of Ensign Harold X. Hines to the coast survey have been revoked, and he has been granted leave of absence until Aug. 1; ...
Coroner Cronin of Queen's County had to proceed with the inquest upon the murdered body of John E. Baugh at Rockaway Beach yesterday with a short jury.

The argument in the contest over the will of William Page, the well-known artist, which has been going on for the past two years before Surrogate Stephens of Richmond County, was made yesterday before the Surrogate at Stapleton, Staten Island.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 2.--Edward C. Fox, convicted of manslaughter in the second degree for killing John Slavin at Brockhart in July, 1886, was this morning sentenced to pay a fine of $350, and to stand committed until paid, not to exceed 350 days.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 2.--The cruising of yachts has opened in season, and since late Saturday afternoon quite a number of yachts have arrived here and many will tarry until after the national holiday.

CHICAGO, July 2.--The cost of the Republican National Convention will amount to about $30,600, which is nearly $700 more than has been subscribed. It is not anticipated that there will be any difficulty in raising the deficit.

TROY, N.Y., July 2.--When the steambeat Saratoga on its way up from New-York entered Haverstraw Bay cries for help were heard from the water. The engines were stopped. It was difficult to discern any objects in the water on account of the waves caused by the high wind prevailing.

BALTIMORE, July 2.--Perfect weather and unlimited hospitality are making the National Saengerfest a great success. The thousands of visitors have thoroughly enjoyed themselves. It has been a busy day all around.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., July 2.--Ralph Wallace, a young sailor of Millbridge, returned from sea on Saturday to find that a young woman, to whom he was attached, had been receiving attentions from another young man. He became intensely jealous, and this afternoon sought an interview with her and asked her to marry him. She refused, and he drew a revolver and shot himself through the heart, dying instantly.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2.--To-day's game was essentially a pitcher's contest, in which Casey got a little the best of Clarkson. No runs were scored by either side until the ninth inning. For the Phillies Farrar led off with a twobase hit to right.

BOSTON, July 2.--Gov. Ames is very ill, and his condition this morning was such as to cause considerable anxiety as to the final outcome. He has been suffering for the past week from acute bronchitis, and recently this has been attended by dangerous symptoms, with some grounds to fear apoplexy. To-night, however, his physician states that no serious complications have developed to-day, and his family anticipate his ultimate recovery.
WHEELING, West Va., July 2.--Robert Burt, the business man charged with arson, was honorably acquitted to-day on motion of the State. He received an ovation.

RACINE, Wis., July 2.--John Zachar, the young farmer who has lived 44 days without food, is dying. Up to to-day Zachar has continued at work. This morning, however, he was attacked with cramps, and is now very low.

HAVANA, July 2.--A laboratory belonging to a dentist named Villarraza has been totally destroyed by fire. The flames spread to the Grand Pasaje Hotel and other buildings, but were extinguished before much damage was done. Many firemen were seriously injured.

BUTTE, Montana, July 2.--A frightful accident occurred yesterday at Meaderville, Montana. While some boys were riding from Centreville to Mcaderville on some flat cars the cars jumped the track, rolling down the mountain side, instantly killing James Henry Burns, aged 13, and Joseph Green, aged 14. Three other boys escaped injury. Two brakemen had their arms broken. The remains of the boys were literally cut to pieces.

AMESBURY, Mass., July 3.--This town is beautifully decorated, arches have been erected in the main streets, and the principal buildings are fairly covered with bunting in honor of the great event of to-morrow, the unveiling of the statue of Josiah Bartlett, the first signer of the Declaration of Independence, who was a native of Amesbury.

ITHACA, July 3.--Mr. H.W. Sage has agreed to pay for the new Cornell University library building, in the event of the university being defeated in the Fisk will case. The late Emperor Frederick III. reigned just 99 days. He was the first ruler of the hones of Hohenzollern who has occupied the throne for so short a space of time, that family belonging more particularly to the long-lived ones. Of German Emperers before him, Albrecht II. ruled from 1438 to 1439, and Leopoid II. from 1790 to 1792.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 4.--Fourth of July as it is, the town of Gettysburg is as quiet as a cemetery. It appears to be one of the very few communities in the United States that participate in patriotic celebrations from mercenary motives. It glories in military reunions, and the larger they are the more it glories, for the more they inure to the benefit of Gettysburg.

RACINE, Wis., July 4.--John Zachar, the factor, has now passed 47 days without food, but is still able to be about the farm on which he is employed. For two weeks he has taken no medicine, but he still drinks a great deal of water. The doctors expect him to live about two weeks longer Zachar says he is not hungry and will net eat until he becomes so.

BERLIN, July 5.--The Politische Nachrichten, referring to reports that the passage in the Emperor's speech in the Reichstag concerning the welfare of the working classes was exclusively the work of Prince Bismarck, says it is authorized to declare that the passage was introduced by the Emperor's special command, given before the speech was drawn up.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 5.--Two thunderstorms met over the eastern part of the city this afternoon, and as a result much damage was done. One storm came from the northeast and one from the west. PORTLAND, Me., July 5.--The yacht Dauntless of New-York ran on Spring Point Ledge yesterday and stove a hole in her bottom. She was pulled off by a tug. The damage was not sufficient to cause much delay and she proceeded to Bar Harbor.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 6.--Edward B. Reynolds, builder and foundryman, while passing through the Crescent Brewery to-day, was struck on the head by a falling slate and instantly killed.
