BOSTON, Mass., July 6.--The rumor was freely circulated about town this afternoon that Gov. Ames's condition was so much worse as to alarm his physicians. It is denied to-night, and the statement is officially made that he is no worse. His physicians think he will be able to be removed to North Easton next week.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 6.--The list of firms that have signed the Amalgated Association scale of wages was increased to-day by the name of another firm. The Amalgamated Association officials received a telegram from Ironton, Ohio, stating that the scale had been signed ...

DETROIT, Mich., July 6.--Tidings have reached this city of the death in Bloomfield, N. J., to-day of the Rev. George Duffield, D.D., eldest son of the famous Rev. Dr. George Durfield, for so many years Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Detroit, and one of the ...

BOSTON, July 6.--This afternoon Judge Parmenter gave a decision in the case of J. Ben jamin Palmer, a broker, who is charged with having embezzled shares of the New-York and New-England, Western Union, and West End Land stock belonging to Thomas N. Flynn.

LONDON, July 7.--The British steamer Durham City sailed from Hamburg July 6 for Boston. She has been in collision with the German steamer Gellert, from Hamburg for NewYork. Both vessels were damaged above the water line. The Gellert returned to port, but the Durham City proceeded.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 6.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Nicollet National Bank the principal subject of the discussion was the Shotwell, Clerihew Latham failure.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--The President will probably nominate a successor to Gen. Duane as Chief of Engineers on Monday next, and persons in a position to know assert that Col. Thomas L. Casey has been selected for the office.

A party of about 80 teachers, mostly ladies, left last night at 6 o'clock on a special train over the New-York Central Road to attend the annual meeting of the National Educational Association to be held in San Francisco July 17 to 20. Dr. Jerome Allen, the Director of the association for New-York, has charge of the ...

NEWBURG, July 6.--But one church of the Associated Reform faith now remains north of the Mason and Dixon line, that at Mongaup, Sullivan County. The church in this city last night voted to join the Presbyterian Church of North America, and will take steps at once to join the Presbytery of North River.

BALTIMORE, July 6.--Col. John R. Fellows, in his speech at the Democratic mass meeting last night, made a rather amusing break. The presiding officer was Gov. Jackson of this State. Col. Fellows, in speaking on the tariff, attacked the lumber kings with particular ...

TROY, N.Y., July 6.--Oliver N. Benson, proprietor of a fancy goods store, has made a confession of judgment in favor of Mary J. Benson. The store was closed by the Sheriff. Mr. Benson states that there is about $10,000 worth of goods in stock, and that the assets exceed the liabilities.

PITTSBURG, July 6.--At 4:30 o'clock this afternoon a battery of three double flue boilers exploded in the tannery of A. J. Groetzinger, River-avenue, Allegheny, near Herr's Island, with the following terrible result: William Wetzel, engineer, leg out off and terribly scalded about the body; will die. Christ Neidt, a laborer, scalded about the body and face; will die.

Although the hearing before Judge Van Hoesen in the suit of John Keenan against Heman Clark has been postponed by mutual consent until Monday, Col. George Bliss is not idle by any means. Yesterday afternoon he went before Judge O'Brien in the Supreme Court, Chambers, and obtained from him an order to examine the bookkeeper and books of Mr. Clark in regard to the transactions pertaining to Sections A and B of the new aqueduct.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6.--At yesterday's session of the American Party delegates at large to the National Convention were elected as follows: P.D. Wigginton. Frank M. Pixley, Victor J. Robertson, and Alfred Daggett. District delegates were also elected. P.D. Wigginton and Frank M. Pixley, the latter the editor ...
The New-Yorks will play in Pittsburg to-day. Knell, Pittsburg's new pitcher, made his first appearance yesterday and created a good impression.

There were some very close contests in the third rounds in singles yesterday at the tennis tournament of the Englewood (N.J.) Field Club. To-day it is expected that the winners of the prizes in both singles and doubles will be known. The first prize in singles is a turquois pin set with diamonds. The first prize in doubles is a silver shaving set. The scores yesterday were: ...

At 12:30 o'clock this morning an automatic fire alarm was set off in a building in the rear of the Century Building in Union-square. A few minutes later Henry Wilson, the janitor, who lives on the seventh story of the building, was aroused from his sleep by smoke.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 6.--Sandford Gaylord, an engineer on the Tioga Railroad, pulled his train up to the Erie station at 9 o'clock this morning as usual. He entered the train dispatcher's office for a moment, and left to return to his engine, when he fell dead.

The City of Rome arrived at the Anchor Line dock Thursday evening minus her bowsprit and with her lookout bridge in a damaged condition, but with crew, passengers, and cargo safe. During a gale which she encountered July 1 a heavy sea struck the bowsprit and snapped it off.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--"Mr. Harrison's nomination is a respectable one, but the selection of Mr. Morton for the Vice-Presidency is unfortunate for the Republican Party," said Mr. Belmont to-day. "While it is quite true that this campaign ought to be conducted ...

Thomas J. McCahill, whom the Building Bureau require to repair the north wall and more strongly support the galleries of the Third-Avenue Theatre, appeared before Judge Van Hoesen, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, and submitted that the wall was all right, and that the galleries would be if they should not be filled with people. Unless he immediately obeys the Building Bureau a precept will be asked for a three days' notice.

While the members of the New-York delegation to the National Democratic Club Convention in Baltimore were attanding the sessions of that body this week they improved their opportunity by organizing the New-York State League of Democratic Clubs. James E. Graybill of the Harlem Democratic Club was chosen Chairman, Assemblyman ...

Further railroad earnings reported in Wallstreet for the month of June showed as follows: Increases--St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas, $36,600; Pittsburg and Western, $21,000; Texas Pacific, $81,000; New-York, Ontario and Western, $22,772; Chicago and West Michigan, $7,400, Chicago and Eastern Illinois, $2,060: Hocking Valley, $67,000; Northern Pacific. $438,326. Decreases--Wabash Western, $21,000; Louisville, Evansville and St. Louis, $9,446.

John J. Mahoney, a retired bookmaker, has bet $20,000 to $10,000 that Grover Cleveland will be re-elected President of the United States. The bet was made with Proprietor Huntoon of the Hoffman Club on Twenty-fifth-street. The stakeholder is Lucien Appleby of Appleby Johnson. If Mr. Huntoon does not put up the whole amount of his wager he will forfeit $2,500.

Nearly 50 members of the Reform Club held the first of their proposed tariff reform discussions at their house, 12 East Thirtythird-street, last night, and sat at the feet of R. R. Bowker, receiving from him instructions how best to convince their hearers of a needed reduction.
The following cases of prostration by the heat were reported by the police yesterday:
ALBANY, July 6.--After much delay Gov. Hill this afternoon named Henry Burden of Troy, as Commissioner of Fisheries in place of Robert B. Roosevelt of New-York, resigned by request.

The Staten Island Prohibitionists held a Counts Convention at Prohibition Park, Port Richmond, Staten Island, last night, and nominated the following county ticket: Member of Assembly--A.F. Merrill of Mariner's Harbor; Sheriff--J.C Smith of Stapleton; County Treasurer--John D. Ward of Tompkinsville; Coroner--W.F. Walters of Concord; Superintendent of the Poor--Daniel Butcher of Castleton Corner.

CHICAGO, July 6.--An extra day's racing was held at Washington Park to day, the events being mostly selling races. The attendance was moderate. Large fields and fast time marked most of the events. Details are as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, July 6.--The Philadelphia Times will say to-morrow, that ever since the memorable strikes on the Reading and the Chicago Burlington and Quincy Railroad systems, in which the Knights of Labor, ...

CHICAGO, July 6.--A greater surprise to the public than the arrest of three men yesterday on a charge of conspiring to blow up the buildings and trains of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Road has not occurred in the West for many a day.

BOSTON, July 6.--The Sutton Mill at North Andover, which shut down last Friday on account of the weavers' refusal to accept a cut-sown in wages, will make an effort to resume operations on Monday morning next.

There was a good day's sport at the Brighton track yesterday, although in five of the six races the favorite came to grief. But the weather was pleasant, the track fast, and the events, as a rule, well contested.

ST. LOUIS, July 6.--W.C. Mitchell, proprietor of the People's Theatre and one of the most widely-known theatrical managers in the West, was killed on Franklin-avenue to-night while attempting to jump off a cable car. Mr. Mitchell was about 50 years of age and was for years manager of the old Theatre Comique.

Perhaps no final judgment can fairly be given on any phase of the aqueduct inquiry until all the evidence is in affecting that phase. It will be necessary to hear both sides and know what explanation is to be given in regard to what appear to be damaging disclosures.

LONG BRANCH, July 6.--The Hon. William L. Scott of the National Democratic Committee and member of Congress from Erie Penn., engaged a suite of rooms at the West End Hotel to-day and will arrive here to-morrow.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 6.--A tripartite alliance has been formed between the Central of Georgia, the Richmond Terminal, and the Plant Investment Company. The Terminal Company embraces the Richmond and Danville and the East Tennessee, Virginia ana Georgia Roads.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 6.--The Pennsylvania Road has a branch line from Sunbury to Wilkesbarre, a distance of 55 miles. This morning Telegraph Operator Beidleman at South Wilkesbarre was given orders from the dispatcher's office at Mocanaqua to hold the passenger train leaving Wilkesbarre at 8:30 until the arrival of the train from Hazleton.

The salesmen on the fourth floor at Cowperth wait's furniture store on upper Parkrow were startled yesterday morning at about 9 o'clock by a crash overhead and the sudden appearance of a man's body dangling from the ceiling. There were agonizing cries and groans from the floor above.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--The Republican Senators have lost any doubt they may have had about the passage of the Tariff bill by the House of Representatives, and they have decided that they must prepare a substitute for adoption by the Senate.

PITTSBURG, July 6.--The home team won to-day's game by sheer good luck. The Senators had men on second and third with no one out several times, but they were unable to get them home, Knell, the young Californian, pitched his first game for the Pittsburgs and his work was decidedly promising, although his delivery was wild. The attendance was 1,500. Score:
The Gammontown section of Jersey City was the scene last evening of an exciting shooting affair, resulting in the wounding of three persons.
The cry was raised yesterday that the Sugar Trust is about to increase the price of sugar 1 cent per pound, ostensibly because of heavy demand and poor crop of raw material.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark," July 6.--Articles of incorporation of the Memphis, Little Rock and Indian Territory Railroad Company were filed in the State Department to-day. The road is to run from Little Rock to Hot Springs, thence in a westerly direction to Indian. Territory at a point in the county of Polk, and also branch from Hot Springs to another point on the State line between the State of Arkansas and ...
The decomposed body which was washed ashore at Oak Point, Thursday, and removed to the Morgue has been identified. Pinned to the clothing was Volunteer Firemen's badge 1,540.

What was undoubtedly a contemplated petty swindle has been brought to light in an East Twenty-third-street cafe, and the proprietors of the place, Metz Bunten, are awaiting the development of a flower seed planted by each of them, which, the giver claimed, would develop into wonderful and beautiful plants.

The unaccountable disappearance May 26 from 639 Jersey-avenue, Jersey City, of Catharine J. Buckham, a lady 66 years old, who was dying of Bright's disease, was disclosed yesterday at Police Headquarters by Inspector Williams, Sergts.
ST. PETERSBURG, July 6.--Russia has signed the convention for the abolition of sugar bounties.

With the rich Lorillard Stakes for 3-yearolds, the Hopeful for 2-year-olds, and the Long Branch Handicap for all ages, together with four other events, the programme announced for to-day by the Monmouth Park Association, is certainly a grand one, and as the list of probable starters in the stakes and entries to the over-night events are all rich in quality, a great day's sport is certain to result.

KEY EAST, N.J., July 6.--An unknown man of middle age, apparently a tramp, was struck by a south-bound Pennsylvania train on the New-York and Long Branch Railroad at this place about 6:15 o'clock this evening and almost instanly killed. He was intoxicated and was sitting on the track at the time. The body was carried on to Ocean Beach and Coroner Vanderveer notified.

Freight rates from New-York to Chicago via rail and lake took another drop yesterday. The Gentral Vermont line reduced the rates adopted by the New-York Central, Erie, Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, and some of the other trunk lines on the previous day 3 cents on first-class and 1 cent on second and third, making their rates on the six classes 27, 24, 19, 15, 15, 15.

PARIS, July 6.--The police have seized, at the house of M. Dufeuille, the Director of the Orleanist press, copies of letter written by the Count of Paris to the Conservative Mayors of France, in which he says:
ST. PAUL, July 6.--In the southern part of the Spring wheat belt the weather for the past week has been hot, though not exceedingly so, and all grains have been showing a very rapid growth.

ST. PAUL, July 6.--The bodies of Harry Tucker and Mrs. Dysinger, who with Mr. Tucker's father, were drowned at Lake Johanna yesterday, were recovered to-day. Mr. Tucker was a good swimmer, and if he had not attempted to help the others of the party he himself could have swam to the shore.

The Summer corps of physicians who are employed by the Board of Health to visit the tenements in the city and prescribe for such sick as may be found without medical attendance, as well as report upon the condition of the crowded houses, started out on their tours yesterday morning and found warm work awaiting them.

LONDON, July 6.--At the Pan Presbyterian Council to-day Mr. Murkland of Baltimore presided. The proposal that the next meeting be held in Toronto was supported by Messrs. Cavan and Cochrane and was unanimously agreed to. Mr. Murkland observed that owing to the strong, loyal, and ardent Presbyterian sentiment existing in Toronto, work would be carried on in the midst of congenial surroundings. [Cheers.]
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 6.--William Gray, a farmer of Hampton County, suspected that improper relations existed between his wife, an attractive woman 30 years of age, and Cradock Mew, a neighbor.

ST. PAUL, July 6.--The recent failures in this city and in Minneapolis, combined with the fact that collectians have been slow, owing to the backward Spring, have given rise to rumors of dull trade and a stringent money market.

JOLIET, July 6.--The Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railroad is building a branch from this city and has met with opposition from some of the people living along the line. To-day a construction train on the track. Three Italian planks placed on the track. Three Italian laborers were killed and the engineer, Thomas Knight, was fatally scalded.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 6.--The storm which swept portions of Middlesex County yesterday afternoon proves by reports received horn to-day to have done damage beyond immediate estimates. Hugh Garragan, one of the young men who were crushed beneath the ruins of the roundhouse, which was blown down at Millstone Junction, will die of his injuries. Roots of barns at Four Mile Bridge were blown a mile.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 6.--The committee appointed to inspect the condition of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway is arriving in sections. The Gould faction, represented by Messrs. Sibley Rand, O.G. Murray, Freight Traffic Manager, and A.W. Dickinson, General Superintendent of the Missouri Pacific, returned yesterday, leaving the rest of the committee, Messrs. Gardner, Atkins, and Robinson at Sedalia.

NEWSBURG, July 6.--Detective Robert J. Vail of New-York, assisted by Roundsman Lezier of this city, to-day arrested Joseph Henry O'Neil, alias Joe Johnson, who is charged with being an accessory in the murder of Cornelius Lenahan of 20 Rector-street, which occurred at Pier 6 on the night of June 25.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--The President today returned to the House without his approval four bills to place the names of as many persons on the ponsion rolls. In returning the bill to pension Nathaniel D. Chase, who enlisted in September, 1863, the President says that the ...

President Flores of Ecuador paid Mayor Hewitt a visit of courtesy yesterday afternoon, interrupting for a brief space the meeting of the Board of Street Openings and Improvement. The Mayor was so captivated by the courtly style and engaging manners of his Excellency of Ecuador that, upon resuming his seat in the council, he ejaculated in his happiness: "It's Dukes and Duchesses one day and Presidents the next."

LONDON, July 6.--Mr. Parnell's denial of the London Times's charges, in the House of Commons this afternoon, was very impressive. All the Opposition members were in their seats and most of the other side were also present. Mr. Parnell rose at 3:05 o'clock, Mr. Thomas Sexton, Lord Mayor of ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 6.--Mrs. John Wells this afternoon sent a communication to the Hospital Association signifying her intention of building a handsome Queen Anne structure on Albany-street to be used as a hospital. The offer was accepted and a deed was immediately obtained for the lots. In honor of her husband, now deceased, the hospital will be known as the John Wells Memorial Hospital.

CINCINNATI, July 6.--The strike of the Brewers' Union because a member was discharged by his employer for disobedience of rules was formally declared off to-day after a continuance of three months. It had caused no inconvenience to the boss brewers after the first few days, and now all the breweries are non-union, while the workmen have lost about $150,000 in wages.

CHICAGO, July 6.--The Eastern roads continued to cut rates industriously to-day. Dressed beef, as usual, was the contre of the fight, the Erie leading off with another reduction to maintain its differential allowance. It made the rate 17 cents per 100 pounds, Chicago to New-York, and all the other roads promptly cut their charges to the same figure.
FORT SMITH, Ark., July 6.--A number of persons were holding a prayer meeting at the house of William Randall on Sunday, near Childers, Cherokee Nation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 6.--James M. Ripley, counsel for the Union Bank, has returned from Montreal. He says the bank's loss by Pitcher's defalcation will not exceed $5,000. He says that Pitcher will be convicted and punished in Canada.

PITTSBURG, July 6.--The trial of H.O. Price and his partners, the pool sellers, proceeded this morning. J.S. Ferguson held that a horse race was not a game of chance and was not forbidden by law, and betting on a horse race was not, therefore, prohibited by law.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 6.--About 100 members of the Hanson-Place Methodist Episcopal Church of Brooklyn arrived here this afternoon, and were driven to the Ocean House, where dinner was served. The party was accompanied by the Pastor, the Rev. A.B. Kendig. All enjoyed the drives about the city, took tea at the hotel, and left to-night on the Sound steamer for New-York.

The United States steamer Swatara, with Lieut.-Gen. Phil Sheridan on board, arrived in the harbor early last evening and anchored off Bedlow's Island. Judging from the statements of the General's wife and friends on the steamer and the bulletin issued by Drs. O'Reilly and Yarrow, Gen. Sheridan has greatly improved in the last day or so, and decided hopes of his ultimate recovery are now entertained.

At 4:20 yesterday morning a horse attached to a butcher's truck owned by M. Meyer, Washington Market, and driven by Thomas McDonald, was frightened by some loosened harness and ran away when about midway on the south roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge.

ERIE, Penn., July 6.--The froliesome firecracker was the nucleus for the conflagration that took out the heart of the little oil town of Gladerun, in Warren County, on the Allegheny River, last night.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y., July 6.--For two or three years Mr. William R. Sheffield of this village, who is also one of the leading manufacturers in the Hudson River Valley, has been inviting Senator Warner Miller to pay him a visit and with him make a tour of the Catskills. Mr. Miller has not been able until to-day to accept the invitation.
At the last election of the Maritime Exchange the two tickets in the field were dubbed by some of the members the American and the English.

More than 15 years ago Mrs. Phoebe Copeland died, leaving a family of eight, of which Police Captain Copeland of the Ninth Precinct is one. Mrs. Copeland left no will, but it was known after her death that she had several thousand dollars doposited in city savings banks, the names of which were not obtained until within the past few days.

PITTSBURG, July 6.--A man attired in the picturesque blue uniform and jaunty cap of the sailors of the United States Navy, was among the passengers who strolled along the platform at the Union station this morning. He was to meet his mother in Washington to-night.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., July 6.--The yacht Coronet arrived in the harbor here this morning, 106 days from New-York. Capt. Crosby reports light winds since crossing the equator. The Coronet will remain here about two weeks before sailing with the owner, Mr. Bush, on a pleasure trip around the world.

LONG BRANCH, July 6.--Mrs. Lillie Langtry has rented Mayor Brown's cottage, on Batl and Sears avenues, until Aug. 1. She will take possession with a retinue of servants next Monday. Steps have already been taken with the view of having her appear in one of her new plays in Amusement Hall, connected with the hotel. She netted $2,000 from a performance she gave here last Summer.

CHICAGO, July 6.--Threatening clouds and falling raindrops had no effect in dampening the ardor of the people who are in attendance upon the National Convention of the Society of Christian Endeavor, and Battery D hall held at least 1,000 more persons at 9 o'clock this morning than were present at the opening of the convention yesterday morning.
The regular monthly business meeting of the Seventeenth Assembly District, Tammany Hall, was held last night at Washington Hall, on Eighth-avenue, between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth streets.

BOSTON, July 6.--A party of about 250 school teachers from all parts of New-England, but mainly from Massachusetts, left this city this afternoon to attend the Teachers' Convention in San Francisco, The party left the Fitchburg station in a special train at 4:30 P.M.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 6.--The Mount Hood illuminating party returned here this afternoon very much used up on account of their exertions in reaching the summit and the extreme cold. One man, J.M. Keene, suffered from frozen feet.

The active work for the Summer of St. John's Guild has begun, and arrangements have been made for improving the facilities of the Guild so that even more efficient work than has been done in the past may be accomplished in the preservation of the lives of infant children of poor families during the present heated term.

Robert Gilchrist, once Attorney-General of the State of New Jersey, died at his home, on Wayne-street, Jersey City, last evening, after a long illness. He had been for some months in a perceptible decline. Two months ago he was obliged to take to his bed with heart troubles, and his death since that time has not been unexpected.

Creditors are looking for Ephraim M. Kantrowitz, dealer in furniture at 1 Fourthavenue, who is reported to have left the city. He was for six years a partner in the firm of Epstein, Kantrowitz Co., but withdrew a year ...

SARATOGA, July 6.--George F. Slosson laughed this morning when he read Jacob Schaefer's letter from Chicago in THE TIMES. He said that the young, wild Western champion was considorably off the track, and that it was not true that at a banquet in St. Louis he admitted that Mr. Schaefer could defeat him at 14inch balk line. He did, in consequence of illness, ...

CHICAGO, Ill., July 6.--The Chicago, St. Louis, Kansas City and Galveston Railway Company is the name under which articles of incorporation have been filed at Springfield. The incorporators are Chicago men, Francis E. Hinckley being the prime mover in the enterprise.

Hereafter those Wall-street men who live in Brooklyn and who are "detained at the office" after 9 o'clock at night will be compelled to present their excuses to their families by way of the bridge. The Wall-Street Ferry has stopped work after that hour during the week' and on Sundays will run no boats.

We notice that the Rev. Dr. CUYLER, in a letter protesting against the high-tariff and free-whisky Republican platform, points out that it is still in the power of the Republicans in Congress to avert the defeat which that platform invites.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 6.--The sale of the main lines and branches of the Florida Railway and Navigation Company having been confirmed by the United States court the articles of incorporation of its successor were filed with the Secretary of State to-day.
LONDON, July 7.--The Steamship Glenshiel, (Br.,) Capt. Robinson, sld. from Singapore for New-York July 5.

In the New-York Evangelist of this week the Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler of Brooklyn, President of the American Temperance Association, publishes "A Free Talk on Free Trade and Free Whisky," in which he gives his opinions of the Republican platform. Dr. Cuyler's letter is as follows:

There is pending in the Senate a bill to define the routes of steam railroads in the District of Columbia. It relates to the continued occupation of one of the public parks by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.

BOSTON, Mass., July 6.--Commodore W. F. Weed of the Eastern Yacht Club has resigned. It is rumored that the Commodore takes exception to the ruling of the Regatta Committee awarding the Adrienne the prize over the Gitana in the last race. A strong effort is being made to induce the Commodore to withdrawn his resignation.

Nothing in our recent history is more curious than the transfer of the moral weight and influence of the country from the Republican to the Democratic Party in national politics. Of the fact of the transfer there can be no doubt.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 6.--The Executive Committee of the State Agricultural Society to-day formally adopted a site at Syracuse as a permanent location for the State fair.

Arrangements are in active progress for the fourth annual regatta of the American Yacht Club, in which nearly all the steam yachts in this section whose owners seek a reputation for speed are expected to enter.

CHICAGO, July 7.--The three men first arrested for complicity in the plot to blow up property of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad had few visitors at the jail to-day. A brother of Bowles, one of the prisoners, arrived here from Ohio, but up to a late hour none of the three had succeeded in securing the ...

CHICAGO, July 7.--A great crowd witnessed the Washington Park races to-day, the attraction being the Great Western Handicap. Montrose was the favorite and won easily.

Calling Independent Republicans "Mugwumps" don't seem either to have killed them off or seared them away. They appear to be as independent as ever, and, as far as the unassisted vision can discern, quite as numerous.

NEWBURG, JULY 7.--John Ayres of Summit Lake, Central Valley, is missing and it is thought he is drowned. Ayres is well known to all New-Yorkers who have spent the Summer at the Lake House, having had charge of the boats and boathouse for years. Parties were dragging for his body to-day.

On and after July 9 a new line of sleeping cars will be established between New-York and Ottawa, the capital of the Dominion of Canada. The sleeping car will be attached to the Montreal express leaving the Grand Central Station of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad an 6:30 P.M. daily ...

The finals at the tennis tournament of the Englewood Field Club were played yesterday. As it was intended to close the play yesterday some future time must decide who is to be the recipient of the second prize in singles. HAVERHILL, Mass., July 7.--The Academy of Music building, a four-story brick structure on Merrimac-street, was found to be on fire about 5:30 to-night, and so threatening became the outlook for surrounding property that aid was summoned from neighboring cities.

LAKE GEORGE, July 7.--Visitors have been coming to Lake George at quite a rapid rate during the past week and the various hotels are rapidly filling up.

PARIS, July 7.--The glorious Fourth was singularly tame in Paris this year. There was no official representation and no patriotic benefactor inclined to swing the Stars and Stripes for the benefit of his friends.

So strong was the sentiment against it in the Middle Ages that one of the chroniclers denounces it as "a burning brand of infidelity."

Capt. Muller of the steamship Sorrento, which arrived yesterday from Hamburg, reports that on July 1 August Blowatnelz, an Austrian immigrant, walked to the ralling and jumped overboard. The engines were stopped and a boat was lowered, but he traces of the man were found. He was 31 years of age and was traveling alone. No reason for his suicide was known to any of his follow-passengers.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 7.--The property holders of East St. Louis will apply next week to have the municipality turned over to a Receiver. The taxation is eating up the wealth of the city, and the people are combining for the purpose of relief.

CANONICUT ISLAND, July 7.--The season at this charming Summer resort is "booming" in earnest. The hotels, private boarding houses, and cottages are actually crowded. Already arrangements are boing made to increase the hotel accommodations for another season, and no less than a dozen new cottages are to be erected.

SARATOGA, July 7.--The Saratoga special Saturday express over the New-York Central and Delaware Railroads, which arrived at 6:35 this evening, brought a large number of people from New-York, and they met with a warm reception.

EDDYVILLE, N.Y., July 7.--The body of a well-dressed unknown man was found floating in the Rondout creek at Greenville, near here, to-day. Coroner Hasbrouck of Rosendale will make a searching examination as several unverified stories of foul play are afloat.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 7.--William S. Davis, a flagman at Wickford Junction, on the Stonington and Providence Railroad, attempted to stop Charles Doane, who was about to drive his horse across the track in front of a nearapproaching train. Doane struck the horse with his whip, the animal knocked the flagman down, and the train ran over him, killing him instantly.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 7.--Robert Bridges of the Century Magazine is spending a short vacation in the Park.

XENIA, July 3.--The 5-months boy baby of John B. Mason, who lives in Xenia, was badly bitten by a black spider on Wednesday last while lying in its crib. Its limbs began to swell and turn black immediately, and the poison penetrated all parts of the little fellow's system. It is being treated by physicians, but with little hopes of success.

CHICAGO, July 7.--A.J. Clark, a traveling salesman for a New-York fur house, tried to kill himself to-day with a penknife. He went to the Grand Pacific Hotel, tried to cash a check, and failing to do so ran into a bedroom and stabbed himself several times in the abdomen. He was taken to the hospital, where his chances to recover are called good. He has been drinking heavily.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 7.--The east side is welcome to its Eleventh Regiment. The State Camp has seen it start back for its favorite haunts this afternoon without a sigh of regret. It is safe to say that there is not a person here not glad to see the last of that portion of the State militia.

The Rockaway Steeplechase Association announces that its Fall meeting will be run on Aug. 24, 25, 27, 29, 30, and 31. With the exception of the opening day, upon which there will be racing at Monmouth Park, the association will not run counter to racing upon any of the big tracks, so far as announced up to now. The programme will consist of three flat races and three events over the jumps each day.

EDINBURGH, July 8.--Dr. Mackenzie, in an interview with a correspondent of the Scotsman at Venice, totally denied the accuracy of the interview published in the Dutch Dagblad, in which he was represented as admitting that he had concealed the cancerous nature of Emperor Frederick's malady in order to prevent a regency.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 8.--Late last night the water in this level of the Erie Canal fell rapidly, and it at once became evident that a serious break had occurred above this city. This morning all boats were stranded high and dry.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., July 8.--Word was received to-day that Arbitrator Midgely of Chicago, Chairman of the Southwestern Statistical Bureau, has rendered a decision restoring the obnoxious 6 cent lumber freight differential from Chippewa Valley points to the Missouri River, which was cut last Winter by the Milwaukee and St. Paul. Rose Coghlan is enjoying the Summer preparatory to her coming season as a star as an actress of good sense might be expected to pass it. She has a lovely place on the Hudson, nearly opposite Greystone, the country seat of the late Samuel J. Tilden, between Yonkers and Hastings.

MERIDEN, Conn., July 8.--Fred Baskin, a prominent German, living on South First-street, committed suicide to-day by taking "Rough on Rats." He committed the act about 7 o'clock in the morning and lingered all day in horrible agony. He died at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The cause of the suicide was despondency. The deceased was 50 years old and leaves a widow and five children.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 8.--Commodore Elbridge Gerry's steam yacht Electra passed this harbor at noon to-day and anchored at Cottage City. It is expected that she will remain in this vicinity a few days.

According to late statistics, there are more pensioners in Canada than in any other British colony. When the Imperial forces were here a large number of men took their discharge, either purchasing out of the service or completing their 21 years and leaving with a pension.

A defective flue in Edward Cullen's house, 433 Montgomery-street, Jersey City, set fire to the house at 3:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the flames spread to the adjoining house, 435, owned by Thomas Murtha. The houses are three-story frame, and each contained six families. The tenants were all driven out by the fire and water and the houses were badly damaged. The total loss is $4,200; insured for $5,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 8.--The Legislature of Louisiana meets only once in two years and the Constitution limits its sessions to 60 days. WINCHESTER, Va., July 8.--Judge Clark has decided that T.A. Ridenour, who has been twice convicted of the murder of his friend, William Andrew Broy, twice and sentenced to be hanged, shall be tried again in August before a Rockingham County jury. MOBILE, Ala., July 8.--During the past five years Mobile has been plagued by incendiaries. At divers times accused parties have been arrested and most convincing evidence produced, but through technicalities and a weakness of juries they have escaped.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8.--John P. Roth, C.W. Roth, George Ware, and William Cummings, the four-oared crew of the Queen City Rowing Club, are out in a challenge to any fouroared crew in the United States for a three-mile race, with or without turn, for the championship and $1,000, or for any amount not less than $150 nor more than $500 a side.

WHEELING, West Va., July 8.--Thomas Leggett was killed near Weston yesterday by John West. West was hunting ground hogs; Leggett was gathering ginseng. While Leggett was in a gully West saw his head, and, taking him for a ground hog, blew his brains out.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8.--Prof. Albert Le Grande come to town last week, hired Music Hall, gave some apparently wonderful exhibitions of his powers as a magnetic healer, seemingly affording the lame, blind, and deaf relief.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--Fully 1,000 persons were present this afternoon at the funeral of Walter McAllister, who was murdered with a hatchet by Thomas Cole last Thursday at his boarding house, 708 Salterstreet, while he was asleep in bed.

CHICAGO, July 8.--The Times of this city has been collecting many interviews with men of all parties in the Northwestern States, and the opinions collected seem to show that in most States party lines are not yet as closely drawn as they will be later in the campaign.

On Monday, June 30, the United States Fish Commission steamer Albatross was preparing to leave San Francisco on or about the 4th of this month for her Northern cruise. Yesterday's dawn brought ideal weather. No New-Yorker had the hardihood to complain. Those who had made up their minds over night to spend Sunday out of town gathered their wraps and luncheon baskets and went, but they had no reason to be envied by the stay-at-homes.

On a replevin suit brought by Dr. C.H. F. Peters, Director of Litchfield Observatory, Hamilton College, Sheriff Batchelor yesterday took possession of a star catalogue which had been held by Charles A. Borst.

The library of the late Mrs. Procter, the widow of Barry Cornwall, will be sold in London at an early date. She is said to have possessed an extraordinary collection of first editions, the value of which is enhanced by the fact that the most of them were presentation copies and have the autographs of their authors.

Such excitement as exists at present among the Hebrew population in the east side of town has never been equaled. For a long period the orthodox down-town Jews have been made sad because the rich congregations in the upper part of the city secured all the learned rabbis.

Mr. Bright's illness has been more serious than has been supposed. His friends insist that he must resign his seat in order to avoid all excitement and to secure entire rest. This, I believe he will very shortly do.

One of the very best anecdotes of Daniel Webster, as illustrative of that exalted and exalting character which his mind pre-eminently possessed, was told by the late St. George Tucker Campbell of Philadelphia, himself a lawyer of great and deserved distinction.

HARRISBURG, July 7.--"In Virginia they call the fish known in the North as pickerel the jackfish," said an old-time Virginian, now a resident of the Juniata Valley. "At least they did before the war, and it isn't likely, that the changes wrought by the result of the war, great as they are, have been so all-sweeping as to give the jackfish a new name.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 8.--The settlement by compromise of a contested will filed yesterday in the Hamilton County Probate Court revealed an old story that had been covered for a half century.

John Gilmartin, the young convict who attempted to escape from the Kings County Penitentiary Friday by walking out in citizen's clothing, but who was caught through the carefulness of a keeper, had prepared an ingenious plan for freeing himself.

The price of sugar is advancing. Immediately after it became known that Attorney-General TABOR had undertaken to prosecute the Sugar Trust and one of the corporations which were absorbed by it, the Trust decided that the people must pay a little more for sugar.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 8.--Local organizations are making arrangements for a celebration of the centennial of New-York's adoption of the Constitution. An invitation sent to Gov. Hill some time ago to make an address on the occasion remains unanswered.

Cornelius Walsh, one of the two victims of the shooting which occurred in Tireney's saloon at Dutch Kills, Long Island City, Friday night, died Saturday at midnight. The nine men arrested after the riot are in jail awaiting the action of the Coroner. The inquests will take place on next Wednesday and on Tuesday, July 17.

I see that Miss Amelia B. Edwards is advertising for funds to bring to England certain colossal sculptures discovered in the ruins of the Great Temple of Bubastes. I sincerely trust that her appeal will fail.

Crawford, which was lying at the foot of East Ninety-fourth-street, saw a man walk down Hencken Co.'s coal dock, get into a rowboat, and begin to divest himself of his clothing. Believing that the man was about to take an early morning bath, ...

The police arrested 113 persons yesterday for violating the excise law. Fifteen small outbreaks of fire in various parts of the city were quelled by the firemen yesterday. In several instances prompt response to the fire call averted serious disaster.

ST. LOUIS, July 8.--The terrible cyclone that swept away John W. Norton's vine and fig tree, and left him minus a friend, a wife, and a fortune, was the prominent feature of Sunday talk to-day. Norton idolized his wife. There was no trust too sacred for her.
WASHINGTON, July 8.--The following is the weather crop bulletin for the week ended Saturday, July 7, issued by the Signal Office Washington City:

The Rev. Father Sully, S.J., has been appointed President of St. John's College, Fordham, in place of the Rev. Thomas Campbell, promoted to be Provincial of the Society of Jesus. The new incumbent preached his first sermon yesterday in the Church of Our Lady of Mercy.

The Republican Party has control of the United States Senate. Its majority there is not large, but it is large enough to carry out any measure that the party may really agree upon.
WASHINGTON, July 8.--There is some uncertainty as to the officer who is to be appointed Chief Engineer of the army, although the indications are favorable to Gen. Parke.

LONDON, July 8.--The Post in an editorial this morning expresses the opinion that President Cleveland will be returned to office. It anticipates that his term of office will be signalized by a revolution of the fiscal system, which may have an important effect on European as well as American trade.
John C. New of Indianapolis is at the Gilsey House.

NONQUITT, Mass., July 8.--After nine days of travel and such rest as can be obtained on board a United States ship of war, Gen. Philip H. Sheridan arrived at this place this afternoon and is now resting comfortably in his new and handsome cottage on the shore of Buzzard's Bay.

CHICAGO, July 9.--The Baptist Church as a body has undertaken to put the Chicago University on its feet again and to re-establish it at Morgan Park, where an offer has been made of property and money to the amount of $80,000. At a meeting of the Provisional Committee to-day an anonymous donation of $20,000 was announced, and there seems to be an excellent chance of reviving the university.

Within an hour and a half on Sunday afternoon the entire system of running trains into and from the Grand Central Station was revolutionized. It Was a transformation involving the services of more than 1,000 men and the expenditure of many thousands of dollars, to say nothing of the time spent in devising the means by which so radical a change could be made without delaying traffic.

For full particulars regarding this generous offer see TIMES of July 8, fifth page.--Exchange.

Racing will be resumed at the Monmouth Park track to-day, and the programme promises some rarely good sport. There are three stake events, the July, for 2-year olds, at three-quarters of a mile, the Shrewsbury Handicap at a mile and a half, and the Monmouth Oaks, for 3-year-old ...

Mayor Hewitt sent a dozen veto messages to the Board of Aldermen yesterday. Most of them related to stands in the streets. In one message the Mayor said that there was no need of an ordinance reguiring tight board covers to be put on ash and dirt carts, as the law already ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 9.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day D.H. Chamberlain of New-York and J.W. Patterson of Troy, N.Y., representing $3,000,000 of the minority of the Wabash indebtedness, filed two petitions asking ...

DETROIT, Mich., July 9.--Gen. Clinton B. Fisk is in the city on business connected with the Swain estate, of which he is one of the Executors. In the course of an interview to-day he said he should make no speeches until September.

TRENTON, N.J., July 9.--In a dispatch from Pittsburg it is stated that an engagement which has recently been announced to the friends of the young couple has created quite a pleas urable stir of excitement in army and social circles.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 9.--The Board of Inspectors at Albany have investigated the recent collision in Newburg by which two ladies lost their lives, and have fully exonerated the officers of the steamer James W. Baldwin from all blame.

BOSTON, July 9.--It is rumored this afternoon that Inspectors Houghton, Gerroughty, Burke, and Watts, who have been friendly to ex-Chief Inspector Hanscom of the Boston police force, will be reduced to positions of patrolmen by the Board of Police. Prominent bank officials on State-street will, in the event of such a reduction being attempted, appeal to to Government to use his authority and prevent it.

Caesar Zella, an urchin of but 8 years, was early yesterday morning caught entering a cigar store at 15 Bowery, and was arrested. He had in his possession when searched a quantity of cigars and cigarettes and $1 46 in money, the proceeds of his haul.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 9.--A convention of the temperance people of the county was held here to-day. It was decided to present petitions to the court on Sept. 10 for an election under the local option law. The work of obtaining these petitions will be commenced immediately.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--After discussing the tariff on sugar for three days, the House finished consideration of that subject to-day and left the sugar paragraphs in the Ways and Means Committee's bill just as they were proposed.

At the regular monthly meeting of the New-York City branch of the National Travelers' Protective Association held at the Morten House last evening, George F. Corbierre, VicePresident of the State division, who was a delegate to the National Convention held at Minneapolis in June.

Buffalo Bill is becoming despondent, and he says life is a burden to him. As his popularity increases, so does the number of applicants from the rising generation for position as cowboys, Indian scalpers, marksmen, and similar offices increase.
The Board of Aldermen will not meet again until July 31.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., July 9.--A boiler of the Adelaide Silk Mill exploded at 7 O'clock this morning with terrific effect, killing three men and wrecking the boilerhouse. The disaster will probably cause a suspension of operations for at least six weeks.

SIOUX CITY, July 9.--A strange case is revealed by sheriff Magee, who returned from Fort Madison this morning. On Friday he left here with Charles Miller, who on the 5th of April was sentenced for horse stealing.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 9.--Carlton J. Stannard, age 28, committed suicide at the City Hotel this morning by swallowing two ounces of laudanum. Ha registered are from Cleveland, Ohio, but from a bank book found in his possession. It is thought he balenged in Southington, Conn.
Superintendent Bates of the free delivery system, who came to confer with Postmaster Pearson about putting into effect reduced hours of labor for the carriers, has returned to Washington.

CANTON, Ohio, July 9.--Three bootblacks named Frank Dorsey, William Entrekin, and George Johnson, aged about 20 years, and claiming Pittsburg as their home, crawled under a box car on the Valley Railroad switch in the west part of the city this afternoon to escape the rain.

Nelson H. Coykendall, the father-in-law of John H. Van Loan, the defaulting clerk of the Second National Bank of Jersey City, had an examination yesterday before Police Justice Stilsing, in Jersey City. Coykendall is charged with conspiring with Van Loan to rob the bank.

LONDON, July 9.--The death of John Mandeville has created a profound impression. He was a prisoner along with William O'Brien in Tullamore Jail, where they served a term of five months, each ending his imprisonment last December.
The meeting on the half-mile track at Yonkers will be continued to-day with the following programme:
KINGSTON, Ontario, July 9.--A slight shock of earthquake, lasting nearly one minute, was felt at Belleville, Madoc, Tweed, and Wordsworth about 11 o'clock last night.

FENWICK, Conn., July 9.--Gov. Hill of New-York, accompanied by the Hon. Henry Watterson of Kentucky, Col. R.G. Ingersoll and family, Col. and Mrs. J.A. Cockerill, Joseph Howard, Jr., Judge W.D. Shipman, and the Hon. Myron Bangs, arrived here in the yacht Fra Diavolo yesterday.

The first work over done by Sydney Rosenfeld, author of "The Lady or the Tiger?" for Col. John A. MaCaull was the English version of "Prince Methusalem," which will be presented at Wallack's on the reopening of that house on Monday evening next.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 9.--West Point is filled with visitors, and yesterday among those present at sunset parade were Gov. Gordon of Georgia and wife, Gen. Daniel Butterfield, Col. and Mrs. Fred Grant. Col. O'Beirne, Major Ulrich, Gen. J. Grant Wilson, and Mrs. Wilson.
RED BANK, N.J., July 9.--Frank Russak of New-York is living with his family in the Throckmorton cottage in East Red Bank for the season.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--Joe Acton, the wrestler, accompanied by Arthur Chambers, left here to day for San Francisco, all the details for the match between Acton and James H. Faulkner, which is to take place in that city on the 31st inst., having been satisfactorily arranged. The match is to be for $500 a side and $1,500 added by the San Francisco Olympic Club.
Representatives of the American Party called on Mayor Hewitt yesterday after noon to formally notify him of action by the Provisional Committee in this State concerning his patriotic sentiments.

NEWPORT, R.I:, July 9.--The fifty-ninth annual convention of the American Institute of Instruction was called to order in the audience room of the Music Hall of this city at 8 this evening, President J. Milton Hall of Providence in the chair. There was a large attendance of teachers from all parts of New-England.

John Keenan's claim that he is a partner of Heman Clark in the contracts for Sections A and B of the new aqueduct was not tried yesterday. When Judge Van Hoesen called the ease in the Court of Common Pleas it was announced that a postponement until to-morrow had been agreed upon.
YAZOO CITY, Miss., July 9.--Relative to the bloody affray at Rising Sun, Leflore County, on Saturday night, the latest information places R.H. Ivey and Sam Austin as dead.

Aug. 1 is the date fixed by law for the commencement of woodcock shooting on Long Island, and it is confidently asserted that the sport will be at least as good as usual this year, and better than it was last season.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--Mr. Walter Stilson Hutchins retires from the editorship of the Washington Post with to-morrow's issue, and the management will assume immediate control.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 9.--It is now stated that Gov. Hill has answered the letter from the committee inviting him to make a speech here on the day of the coming centenary, stating that other duties will prevent him from doing so. A special committee went to Albany to-day to see him about the matter, but he was not in the city.
LONDON, July 9.--A marriage has been arranged between Dr. Stewart, a practicing physician of London, and the eldest sister of the Duke of Norfolk.

JACKSON, Miss., July 9.--The renomination of Congressman Morgan in the Second District, heretofore in grave doubt, is now assured. Lafayette County has pronounced in his favor, which gives him a majority of the District Convention. He will be opposed by Gen. Chalmers, whom he easily defeated two years ago.

The 9th of July is the Independence Day of the Argentine Republic, and in its observance Adolfo G. Calvo, the Argentine Consul, gave a lunch at the Lawyers' Club yesterday to a number of his friends, including the consular representatives of all of the South American States in this city.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 9.--The Southern League matter is settled at last by the death of the organization for this season at least.
EL PASO, Texas, July 9.--Myer's Opera House in this city, one of the most beautiful buildings in the Southwest, is in ruins.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 9.--The annual tournament of the Hartford Wheel Club will take place at Charter Oak Park, beginning Sept. 12 and lasting two days.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 9.--The case of Judge A.M. Pulliam, who on Friday killed James Miller, a wealthy farmer at Hardinsburg, Ky., came up before a county magistrate this morning at that place. Pulliam waived an examination and went to jail without bail.

BERLIN, July 9.--At the meeting of the two Emperors, the Czar, on board the yacht Derjava, escorted by two men-of-war, will meet the German squadron. The Emperor William will then go on board the yacht Derjava and the two squdrons will sail for Kronstadt, where the sovereigns will land with military honors.
John R. McLean of Cincinnati is at the Hotel Brunswick.

LEIPSIC, July 9.--Herr Dietz, an Alsacian railway official; Frau Dietz, his wife, and a railway assistant named Appel, who were charged with having sold to the French Government information relative to German military arrangements, have been convicted. Dietz was sentenced to ten years' and his wife to four years' penal servitude.

George W. Armstrong, who arrived in Jorsey City from San Antenia, Texas, two months ago, died yesterday of smallpox in the pest house at Snake Hill. He lived in a boarding house on State-street and had been down with the disease ten days before the case was reported to the authorities.

The Board of Electrical Control yesterday notified Commissioner Newton of the Department of Public Works that in order to facilitate the removal of "dead" poles and wires a notice, printed in black on an orange and crimson card, had been prepared to guide the department workmen.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 9.--Elaborate preparations are being made by the Rondout Social Macnnerchor for the Saengerfest that will be held here next month. Leading German singing societies in this and adjoining States will participate. There will be 700 voices in the chorus. All the singers will be given an outing in the Catskill Mountains.

A Brooklyn paper last evening published a sensational story to the effect that the Dwyer Brothers are so much incensed over what they consider their unfair treatment at the Coney Island Club's recent meeting that they have decided to run races over their Brooklyn track in opposition to the Coney Island Club's Fall meeting.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 9.--The damage to crops and mill races by the break in the canal at Adams Basin Will amount to many thousands of dollars. Had it not been for the prompt closing of the stop-gate half a mile West of the ...

ALBANY, July 9.--Gen. James W. Husted was in Albany to-day on business connected wish the Railroad Commission. He said regarding the extraordinary session of the Legislature that either two days or else two weeks would be consumed.
The effects of the Palmer Chemical Company, at 32 Frankfort-street, were sold out yesterday by Deputy Sheriff Stevens and realized only about $300.

William H. simes, the purser of the steamer Sylvan Shore, reported at the Steamboat Squad station, at Pier A, North River, last night, that at 8:30 P.M., when off Hell Gate, returning with an excursion of the employes of Beneke Brothers, who had been spending the day at Oak Point, one of the excursionists named John Bross of 195 Elmstreet, fell overboard and was drowned. His body was not recovered.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--Late to-night While Mrs. Eva Kensling, aged 47 years, of 3,529 California-street, with her grandchild, aged 6 months was crossing the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Westmoreland-street crossing she was struck by the engine on an express train, and both were instantly killed.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 9.--Late last night there was a great storm in Kansas City. A mass of black, low-hanging clouds spread over the city shortly before midnight and for an hour there was such a downpour of rain as the "oldest inhabitant" had never witnessed.

BELGRADE, July 9.--King Milan has formally invoked the aid of the authorities of the Prussian province of Hesse-Nassau to force his wife, who is now stopping at Wiesbaden, to surrender to him the Crown Prince.
SARATOGA, July 9.--Probably all of the delegates to the State Republican League Convention to be held on Wednesday will arrive here to-morrow with their shouters, brass bands, and banners.

Edward Lesse of Breslau, Suffolk County, Long Island, failed to produce in habeas corpus proceedings in court yesterday, Ellen Guffey, 11 years old, who was apprenticed to him by the Freeholders of Hudson County.

Among the passengers of the Guion steamship Arizona, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, were Mrs. E. Le Breton, the mother of Mrs. Langtry, and her grandchildren, Alice and Mary; T. Greyme Evans. Capt. E. Spicer, G.W. Pilling, Frank W. Ranza, Willis Woodward, R. Fawcus Fawcus, and Clement Gould.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Mrs. Rawson was today denied by Judge Jamison any shortening of her 60-day sentence for contempt of court.
Counting the chickens before the eggs are laid is the pastime of the modern prophet.-- Martha's Vincyard Herald.

Before Judge Van Hoesen in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday arguments were made for and against the confirmation of the report of Thomas Harland as Referee in the contest over the estate of Nathaniel Gilman.

The taking of testimony in the suit of Mrs. Frances S. Walbridge for separation from her husband, Dr. Joseph N.H. Walbridge, a case that has occupied a good deal of attention in the Brooklyn courts by preliminary motions, was finally commenced yesterday.

SARATOGA, July 9.--There was something of a ripple in exclusive circles to-day over a report which came from Ballston Spa that there had been a mutual arrangement and a more or less sad separation in high life in that neighborly watering place.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 9.--Sir John Macdonald is anything but well to-day. His wisdom tooth, strange to say, has been giving him trouble for some time past, and to-day he had it extracted by Dr. A. Martin. Sir James Grant and Lady Macdonald were present. The former administered chloroform to the Premier. Sir John's face is seriously swollen and he is scarcely able to speak. He expects to leave to-morrow for a New Brunswick seaside resort.

MONTREAL, July 9.--The preliminary investigation into the charge against Charles Pitcher, the late Teller of the Union Bank of Providence, R.I., was continued this morning. Mr. Johnson, the Cashier, continued his evidence, ...

Commissioner Hamilton Fish, Jr., occupied the witness stand before the Senatorial committee which is probing the aqueduct secrets the whole of yesterday. By a great deal of effort on the part of the counsel engaged in the investigation Mr. Fish unwillingly testified ...
The funeral of Robert Gilchrist, ex-Attorney-General of New-Jersey, who died on Friday at his home, in Mercer-street, Jersey City, took place yesterday afternoon from St. Mark's ...

TROY, N.Y., July 9.--Guy C. Dusenberry, the defaulting money order clerk at the PostOffice in this city, three years ago, was to-day declared insane. He cannot recognize any one and the physicians state he is hopelessly insane. He will be taken to the Poughkeepsie Asylum tomorrow.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9.--The second of the Casino dances took place this evening, and it waa a miserable failure. The weather was a drawback, but there are no reasons for supposing that the cottagers would have attended even had the stars been out.
A fire broke out a few minutes after 10 o'clock last night in the six-story building on the northeast corner of Spring and Crosby streets, and gave the firemen a hard tussle to extinguish it.

Rabbi Joseph Hardofsky of Brooklyn was a prisoner at the Montrose-avenue police court yesterday, charged with assaulting Butcher Morris Garlin of 83 Siegel-street. The two had a fistic encouster on June 30.
Trinity Church Corporation and the parishes of St. Luke and St. John are considering proposals in relation to same important improvements.

NONQUITT, Mass., July 9.--Gen. Sheridan did not have a good night. He tossed about a good deal, and such sleep as he got was fitful and broken. Toward morning, however, he grew quieter and rested comfortably most of the forenoon, sleeping a good part of the time.

CHICAGO, July 9.--Another raid upon Aurora was made to-day by United States Marshal Marsh and his forces, and another captive was added to the list of men charged with plotting to blow up the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad.
Dominico Vincenzio of 304 East One Hundred and Seventh-street, the Italian who attempted to pass a counterfeit five-dollar ...
Thirty-two certificates of membership in the New-York Metal Exchange were sold at auction on the floor of the Exchange yesterday because the holders of them did not pay their annual dues.
CHICAGO, July 9.--The new schedule of rates on through freight to Colorado points, as promulgated by Commissioner Waldo, is generally satisfactory to the Chicago roads interested in this traffic.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--The bond offerings today were as follows:

Judge Ingraham, sitting in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday heard the argument for and against the removal of the fence around the Polo Grounds, in order that One Hundred and Eleventh-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, may be opened for the use of the public.
ST. LOUIS, July 9.--Next to the MooreNorton elopement the case that is creating the greatest attention in the West is the Maxwell case, which is to be settled this week.

Mr. Amberg said yesterday that no arrangements hid been made by him with Herr Crohuegk, manager of the Saxe-Meiningea Theatrical Company, to bring the troupe over this year. The cost of, transportation, Mr. Amberg believed, would be altogether too heavy.
CHICAGO, July 9.--An extra day's racing was given at Washington Park to-day. The track was deep in mud, the attendance light, and the contending horses of poor quality. The results were as follows:

BOSTON, July 9.--The collection of license fees in Boston is practically completed for the present year, and the returns show in round numbers that 2,650 licenses were issued, including those to clubs. The receipts amount to $615,775. Last year 2,741 licenses were issued, and the receipts amounted to $585,002.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 9.--The Assembly committee, with State Superintendent of Public Instructions A. S. Draper as spokesman, began the inquiry to-day into the tribal, social, moral, religious, and industral condition of the Onondaga Indians.

There were rumors about the Fifth-Avenue Hotel during last evening to the effect that some difficulty had been experienced in finding a Chairman for the Executive Committee of the Democratic National Committee.

To-day the transfer of Admiral Luce and personal staff, consisting of Fleet Gunnery Offleer Lieut. J.F. Meigs and Signal Officer Lieut. Alexander Sharp, will be made, and the Pensacola will hereafter be the flagship of the North Atlantic squadron, ...

SARATOGA, July 9.--It has at length been definitely settled that there will be a billiard tournament here between George F. Slosson, William Sexton, and Maurice Daly, and the little birds are singing quite merrily in the grand garden or the United States Hotel and are chirping as gayly in the parks of the Grand Union, Congress Hall, and the Kensington.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--General Master Workman Powderly has written a letter for this week's Journal of United Labor in which he calls attention to an alleged "corner" in coffee, and advises abstention from the use of coffee until the "corner" is broken.
SARATOGA, July 9.--Among the distinguished arrivals to-day at the Grand Union Hotel for the season were Mr. and Mrs. William Leighton, who live at the Murray Hill Hotel in New-York.
The Democrats of the Twelfth Assembly District held an enthusiastic ratification meeting last night at the Tammany Hall General Committee headquarters, 257 East Third-street.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Annie Shea, a preposcessing child of 7 years of age, was found wandering on Twenty-second-street, near Statestreet, last night.

The change in the programme at Koster Bial's Concert Hall this week seems to be satisfactory. At last evening's performance the audience was particularly large and much given to applause and other demonstrations.

BUFFALO, July 9.--After Sunday's rest and sermons and addresses the delegates to the National Conference of Charities and Corrections came together this morning in good spirits and with brotherly love, but prepared to take a hand in any vocal fight that might come up.

A stable belonging to Isaac Blanchard at 122 Frelinghuysen-avenue, Newark, was destroyed by fire on Wednesday night last. Yesterday William Blanchard, a son of the owner of the stable, and Sterling Parker, a man in Blanchard's employ, were arrested on suspicion of having set fire to it.

Two lads named Michael Fibbs of 95 Mottstreet and Francis J. Cassidy of 539 West-street Sunday night went to the fruit stand kept by Antonio Perazza, at 149 Elizabeth-street, and attempted to rob him in an original manner.
Aqueduct-Commissioner HAMILTON FISH, Jr., seems to be quite unconscious of the disgraceful character of the confessions which he has made before the Senate investigating committee.

A.H. Pride, General Eastern Agent of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway, yesterday made a statement in reference to the "split orders" which passed through Castle Garden on the 3d of July and which were drawn on that road.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 9.--The members of the firm of H.O. Price Co. have issued a notice announcing that the partnership which heretofore existed between them under the above title was dissolved on July 6 by mutual consent.

Ike Vail, a notorious confidence man, was captured on the North German Lloyd dock at Hoboken Saturday while attempting to swindle a steerage passenger who was about to sail on the Werra. Vail's scheme was to dash on the dock in a cab at the hour of a steamer's departure, carrying an empty valise and hat box.
BOSTON, July 9.--Gov. Ames passed a comfortable night, and was considered somewhat better this morning.
Freight rates showed a decided tendency to strengthen yesterday for the first time in several months, and it was believed by many freight agents that the war was drawing to a close.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 9.--The body of Capt. William B. Vaughan of the Bee Line barge Beacon was found floating in the river this morning. He had been missing since Friday night. He was 30 years of age and lived in Brooklyn, N.Y.
The Republican State Committee will meet at 11 A.M. to-day.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 9.--E.L. Kenyon, grocer and dealer in variety goods and notions, made a general assignment this morning to Frank S. Wood. No figures are given, but the failure is believed to be a heavy one. The house of Kenyon was established in 1835 by John Kenyon.
ELBERON, N.J., July 9.--Inter-State Commerce Commissioners Cooley, Morrison, Walker, Schoonmaker, and Bragg arrived at the Elberon Hotel this evening and will be in session here for several days.

SANDWICH, Ill., July 9.--David Clark and his wife were found hanging in a corn crib on A. Gage's farm, near here, last evening. They left a paper signed by each saying that they died for each other. Clark was 30 years old, and had been employed by Gage a few months. He came from Streator, and had been married two years.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 9.--There was trouble with the water supply at West Cornwall yesterday. West Cornwall is a small station on the Housatonic Railroad, important from the fact that water is taken here by the engines of the New-fork and Pittsfield lisited express trains.

The nine men arrested for alleged participation in a riot at Dutch Kills, Long Island, on Saturday night, when Thomas Tierney, a saloon keeper, shot William Owens and Cornelius Walsh, both of whom have since died, were arraigned before Justice Kavanagh, Long Island, yesterday afternoon.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 9.--Mr. Edwin Cowles, editor of the Cleveland Leader, is still in Europe and has quite recovered from his poor health of last Winter. A dispatch, which has been given some circulation, stating that he was attacked with hemorrhage at Lockport is entirely without foundation. It is Eugene H. Cowles, son of Editor Cowles, who is sick here, but he is improving, and will go West in a few days.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 9.--The Executive Board of the Union of Hebrew Congregations held its annual meeting yesterday simultaneously with the annual meetings of the Board of Trustees and Managers of the Jewish Orphan Asylum and the Monteflore Home for Aged and Infirm Israelites.
New-York will play in Pittsburg to-day. Foster and Crane say that they will not agree to play in the Jersey City Club.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 9.--Mrs. Leila Ferdinand, a colored dressmaker, was arraigned to-night on the charge of having stolen on June 22 a writing desk containing $3,000 from the house in Angel-street, of Frederick E.M. Riddell, colored.

PITTSBURG, July 9.--The Amalgamated Association officials received a telegram at noon to-day stating that their scale had been signed for the structural mill at New-Albany, Ind., and also by the Kittanning Iron Company, at Kittanning, Penn.
OMAHA, Neb. July 9.--The President of the United States is referred to as "one Grover Cleveland" in a petition for a partition of real estate filed here yesterday by Alice R. Folsom, Emma Folsom.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., July 9.--James carvey was cut in halves at midnight last night while jumping off a train at the station. The train did not stop where he wished to get off.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 9.--On the Fourth of July a girl, 18 years old, named Cora Eldridge, was arrested in Red Hook on complaint of Mary E. Willisms, who charged her with larceny in stealing a canary bird.

ALBANY, July 9.--The Phoenix Building Company and the Tile Fire-proof Building Company of New-York were incorporated to-day. The former has a capital of $80,000 and the latter of $150,000. The Trustees of the former are Rafael Guastavino, Waffredo Uffreduzi, and James E. Smith. The latter contains the same Directors with these additional ones: Jose Amigo and Jose Sugranes.

There was evidently considerable perturbation in the ranks of the United States Illuminating Company occasioned yesterday by the sudden and combined movement made on their works by the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Electrical Control.

ST. LOUIS, July 9.--Henry W. Moore, the fugitive editor, was arrested this afternoon at Topeka, Kan., and will be brought back to this city to face a warrant for grand larceny. By the advice of friends Mr. Norton last night decided upon prosecuting his false friend. This morning the actor, accompanied by Judge Loughlin, ...
WASHINGTON, July 9.--The President sent to the Senate to-day the nomination of Elliot Sandford to be Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of the Territory of Utah.

Joseph Muhr, the wealthy manufacturing jeweler whose eccentric actions the last few days have caused his relatives deep consern, was taken yesterday afternoon at a little after 3 o'clock from Bellevue Hospital to the Bloomingdale Asylum.

The constant rain of yesterday made matters anything but pleasant for the patrons of the Brighton races. It was uncomfortable to move about and the track was deep in slush. Still, the attendance, though not, of course, up to the average, was fairly good, and speculation ...

NICHOLASVILLE, Ky., July 9.--Last night, after 9 o'clock, Ed Sparks, son of Senater Sparks, called Charles Meyers out of the Coffman House parlor and called him a vile name. Meyers struck Sparks, who then shot Meyers in the abdomen.

The Rev. Harry Baumann, one of the assistant ministers of Trinity Church, said yesterday that the report that the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, Rector of Trinity Church, was about to lose his eyesight was not true, as did also Mr. McEwen, the doctor's secretary.
CARLISLE, Penn., July 9.--This morning Mr. John Grin and wife came to this city, leaving at home their family of children. Mr. Grin has a grist mill on his premises, but it was not running.

There seems to be trouble brewing between some of the city retail grocers and Long Island farmers. The grocers are complaining that the farmers try to use "pony" crates and other short-measure packages in dealing with them.

The records of the District Attorney's office for the half year beginning Jan, 1 and ending June 30, 1888, show that 2,950 eases were received in the office, and that 2,160 were disposes of. This proves very little, however, in favor of the efficiency of the office.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., July 9.--Col. Goshen, the Middlebush giant whom Barnum made famous, lost all the relics of his circus days by a fire which destroyed his barns, stables, and buildings near Middlebush last night.

Vice-President Oakes of the Northern Pacific Railroad, now traveling in the West, telegraphs to Wall-street friends that the crop prospects of all the States through which he has traveled are excellent. The farmers along the Northern Pacific line, he says, have never had had brighter prospects.
The Wilmington Star says that Dr. Benbow, Chairman of the North Carolina Prohibition State Committee, when told that Judge Russell had declined the Republican nomination ...

A phonograph will arrive at Mr. Thomas A. Edison's laboratory at Llewellyn Park within a day or two, which, when it is allowed to give forth the sounds that are contained within it, will create no small degree of sensation.

At the meeting of the Republican Club, held at its clubhouse, 450 Fifth-avenue, last night, James W. Hawes, who had been elected Chairman of the Campaign Committee in the afternoon, made a report recommending the increase of the committee from 24 to 40, with power to add to the number, and drop such members as might fail to attend to their duties.

The New-Jersey State legislative committee, which has been engaged in investigating the charges made against the management of the Morris Plains Asylum, resumed its work yesterday morning in the managers' room of the asylum building. On their way thither the members were somewhat startled by a scene which occurred between George A. Halsey, President ...

This is a tale of a bottle, a New-York bottle, that was cast overboard from an ocean steamship upon the waste of waters and which bobbed and bobbed on the salt sea waves until it glided into a harbor of sunny Spain and was calmly floating inland when it was rescued by a native of that country.

The Kong Chu Company of San Francisco has sent its agent on a tour of the entire country to gather up the bones of defunct Chinamen and ship them back to their respective places of birth in the Flowery Kingdom for interment in their family burial grounds.

St. John's Guild yesterday made its first trip of the season with its floating hospital to the guild's seaside hospital on Staten Island. The floating hospital leaves the foot of West Forty-third-street on Mondays and Thursdays at 8 A.M., stopping at the foot of King-street a half hour later.

DETROIT, Feb. 9.--There has just been brought to public notice here a 16-year-old forger, whose career is almost without a parallel. She is the daughter of Joseph Martin, a respetcable builder, and is known as Ismi Martin and as Miss Bagg, the latter name being assumed for purposes of deceit.

Although the Secretan ring has been successful thus far in maintaining its price for copper in the markets of the world, an impression prevails that it will soon begin to stagger under the great and growing burden which it has undertaken to carry.

HAVANA, June 30.--It is estimated that the onion crop of the island this year will amount to 55,000 quintals. About 15,000 quintals have been exported to the United States. The potato crop is also large. About 70,000 barrels still remain in the country.

CLEVELAND, July 9.--The village of Alliance, Ohio, adopted prohibition some two years ago, and the authorities have since been constantly at war with the saloon keepers. An ordinance was finally adopted imposing a fine of $200 for a violation of the prohibitory enactment and $500 for the second offense. The first trial under the ordinance resulted in a a conviction to-day, and the fine of $200 in the prompt closing of the last saloon.

The rivalry between English and American amateur athletes will be greatly promoted if the suggestion of the Manhattan Athletic Club Chronicle, which is meeting with great favor, is carried into effect.
