The first of the quarterly conferences for the new fiscal year of the Government Appraisers of the principal ports was begun yesterday morning at the Appraiser's office in this city.

The issue to be decided by the Presidential election this year is sharply defined. For so much at least gratitude is due to the framers of the Republican platform. For the first time in the history of this, or probably of any other civilized country, it is ...

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 9.--The work of restoring the old Senate House here has at last been completed, and the historic building presents the appearance it did in the days of long ago. State Architect Perry is expected soon to make an official inspection. It is said that the Hon. Marius Schoonmaker of this city will be appointed keeper.
OCEAN GROVE, July 9.--A gang of professional burglars committed several burglaries here yesterday. During the surf meeting, at 6 P. M., a cottage was ransacked, but little of value was secured.

Owing to the drizzling weather, or some other forlorn circumstance, the bull market of last Friday and Saturday failed to make its appearance in Wall-street yesterday, though anxious watchers waited patiently for some showing of it.
Annie Gottileb, 3 years old, of 161 Rivingtonstreet, was run ever and severely injured last evening by a wagon driven by Frank Morey of 1,907 Second-avenue.
Henry Powell, a retired business man of Cincinnati, 66 years of age, disappeared from the deck of the Cunard steamship Servia on the evening of July 1, some hours after the vessel ...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 9.--Some two months ago, at Shenandoah, Mrs. Reguesser murdered her husband by splitting his skull with a hatchet. She has since been confined in the county prison here awaiting trial. When the District Attorney called the case to-day for trial it was discovered that the woman was a raving maniac. The trial was thereupon suspended, and the woman will be sent to an insane asylum.

A magnificent enterprise is now under consideration in this city, which, if properly inaugurated and wisely managed, may result in a grand success and accomplish a vast amount of good. The plan is unique, feasible, and eminently worthy of favor. It is the establishment of an international Young Men's Christian Association Assembly on Grand Island, resembling in its main features the Chautauqua Assembly at Lake Chautauqua.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 9.--The race between the Xara and the Baboon, two of the latest Burgess-built boats, took place this afternoon, the course being 10 miles--from Halfway Rock to leeward and return. Capt. Hank Haff of the Volunteer sailed the Xara and C.F. Adams the Baboon. A good start was made.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has reached that point in its struggle to obtain a foothold on Staten Island that no secret is any longer made of its real intentions in that direction. The Pennsylvania Company secured an interest in the Staten Island Belt Line Horse Car ...

Henry Fink, Vice-President of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad, said yesterday that all negotiations were off between himself and the road's engineers. The company could not reinstate Mouahan. He did not strike superintendent Jasper, as was reported; but his language was very abusive. The engineers had issued their ultimatum to the effect that Monahan must be reinstated.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 9.--Charles, the 4-year-old son of Charles S. Sterling, was placed in a tub for his usual bath yesterday afternoon by his mother, who then left the room a few moments.

The excursion of the Guerrillas, an organization of the First Ward, to Riverside Grove, on the Hudson yesterday was accompanied by a sad incident. In the afternoon many of the excursionists other went to watch some of the young men in bathing.

LEWISBURG, Penn., July 9.--President David J. Hill of Bucknell University will accept the Presidency of the University of Rochester, with leave of absence to study philosophy and institutions in Europe for one year, with expenses paid.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 8.--Early Thursday morning a Minneapolis preacher had the physical courage to tackle and the strength to conquer a would-be burglar.

LONDON, July 9.--At the session of the Pan Presbyterian Council to-day, the Rev. J. Oswald Dykes presiding, a proposal was made to devote 800 yearly to the working expenses of a Secretary and Assistant Secretary in America. A decision on the question was deferred until to-morrow.

The only references made by the Republican Convention to the financial condition of the country were indirect and were as follows: (1) A declaration "in favor of the use of both gold and silver as money," and condemning "the policy of the Democratic
LONDON, July 9.--The steamship Ambrose,(Br.,) Capt. Bisson, sid. from Menaos for New-York yesterday.
DUBLIN, July 9.--Conneff of the Manhattan Athletic Club and Carter were the only starters in the international championship fivemile race at Ballsbridge to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--The Chief of Engineers of the army has received a report from Lieut.-Col. H.M. Robert. Corps of Engineers, giving a detailed statement of the work performed during the past fiscal year in improving the Delaware and Schuylkill Rivers, the harbors ...
Mr. Edwin Booth is now at Narragansett Pier, where he will pass the Summer with his daughter and son-in law and their children. In September he will occupy his cottage at Newport.
DETROIT, Mich., July 9.--Benjamin Peterson of Grand Marias, north of Marquette, had a little the worst Fourth of July celebration yet recorded.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--The British steamer Tyrian, from Port Antonio, reports, July 2, when 60 miles southwest of Cape May, experienced three consecutive shocks of earthquake at intervals of 10 seconds each.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 9.--A delegation of gentlemen and ladies from Benton Harbor Mich., reached the city at 4 o'clock this afternoon for the purpose of calling on Gen. Harrison. They took quarters at a hotel, and at 7:30 proceeded to the Harrison residence.

At the request of H.F. Hewson and Hamilton Cole, counsel for the National Express Company, Judge Ingraham has granted a writ of certiorari commanding the city authorities to produce before the Special Term of the Supreme Court, ...
CHICAGO, July 9.--The week has opened with a renewal of the war among the Eastern roads over dressed beef and cattle rates.
ROSENDALE, N.Y., July 9.--Many horses are ill and dying along the Delaware and Hudson Canal from pinkeye. Veterinary surgeons seem to be unable to successfully cope with the epidemic.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 9.--The thermometer reached 92 for a few moments this afternoon, the highest point for many years.

Ludwig Risch, a short and ill-favored Prussian, 55 years old, left his native country six years ago under suspicious circumstances. At Grossen he bought a mill belonging to Franz Schanaleutzky and paid him 85,000 marks.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--Major Frederick W. Renteen, Ninth Cavalry, and Sergt. James Hughes, Fifth Infantry, have been placed on the retired list.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 10.--James A. Bradley, the founder of Asbury Park and one of its Municipal Council, was arrested this afternoon on a warrant issued by Justice of the Peace Milo H. Crego of Wall Township on a charge of criminal libel preferred by Joseph C. Patterson, a son of ex-Assemblyman George W. Patterson, and freight agent at this place.

LONDON, July 10.--In the House of Commons this evening Mr. Smith, the Government leader, moved that precedence be given daily to Government business during the remainder of the session. He asked the House to insist in making the Country bill workable. Many clauses of the measure stood entirely apart from party politics and their adoption would result ...

HURON, Dakota, July 10.--The first of the Division and Statehood Conventions was called to order at 2 P.M. to-day by Gen. Hugh J. Campbell of Yankton, who read the call. After the reading of the call, judge Hand of Faulkton moved that the Hon. Waldo M. Potter of Fargo ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 10.--A call was issued to-day for the Prohibition State Convention of Connecticut. The convention will open at 10 o'clock on Wednesday, Aug. 1, in Unity Hall, Hartford. State officers and Presidential Electors will be nominated on Wednesday afternoon. Mrs. Mary T. Lathrop of Michigan will deliver an address. A mass meeting will be held the same evening.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--Senator Hoar addressed the Senate in open executive session to-day in opposition to the fisheries treaty. His speech lasted four hours. He asserted that the controversy was not as to the profit of a few thousand men in their business, but was a struggle on the part of Great Britain and Canada to increase their naval strength at the ...

DUBLIN, July 10.--The funeral of Mr. Mandeville, formerly Chairman of the Mitchellstown Board of Guardians, who was with Mr. William O'Brien in Tullamore Jail and whose death is said to have been caused by the privations he suffered during his incarceration, has been postponed to await the arrival of a number of members of the Irish Parliamentary party ...

At 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon the officers and crew of the Richmond were assembled on her quarterdeck in full-dress uniform, the occasion being the transfer of Rear-Admiral Luce and personal staff to the Pesacola. The Admiral, before passing over the vessel's gangway, made a brief address to the crew, and then getting into his steam barge, Vixen, went ...

CHICAGO, July 10.--The Executive Committee of the Northwestern Democratic Association met to-day at the Palmer House. Chairmen Weston of Michigan and Campbell of Illinois were absent, those present being Chairmen Hunter of Iowa and Usher of Wisconsin and Secretary Wise of Illinois.

There is so much restlessness among Democrats over the delay of the committee in getting to work that D. Cady Herrick and Cord Meyer, Jr., had a long conference with Collector Magone at the Everett House last evening over the situation. It is understood, as a result of the conference, that headquarters will be immediately taken possession of--probably at the ...

LONDON, July 10.--At the Liverpool July meeting to-day the race for the St. George Stakes, for 3-year-olds, was won by Sir R. Jardine's Stronvar, with Mr. Ernest's Van Dieman's Land second, and Mr. A. Taylor's Nether Avon third. The race for the Molyneux Cup was won by Mr. Mackenzie's Upset, with Mr. Naylor's Fulmer second and Lord Ellesmere's Cataract third.

LANCASTER, Penn., July 10.--Execution was issued this morning by Elizabeth Graybill against her husband, Henry K. Graybill of Upper Leacock Township, for $6,000. Graybill is the owner of a farm in Upper Leacock Township containing 79 acres, assessed at $160 per acre, and a hotel property at Martindale assessed ...

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10.--This is the second day's session of the American Institute of Instruction. The meeting was called to order by the President, J. Milton Hall. "Schoolhouse Ventilation" was the subject of the opening address by George D. Kimball. Principal W.H. Lambert of Fall River followed with a paper on "English in the High School."

A committee from the stonecutters associations called yesterday on Deputy Collector McClelland and submitted to him the draft of a bill that the unions will ask Congress to pass. It is an amendment to the contract labor law, and empowers the Collector of the Port of New-York to ...

CHICAGO, July 10.--The suit of Louis M. Cohen against the Washington Park Club was dismissed by Judge Jamieson this morning for want of equity. Cohen is a bookmaker, who, having been ruled off the Louisville track, came to Chicago and was elected from the Washington Park track, and told to do his betting outside.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Executive Committee of the National American Party today issued a call for a National Convention to meet in this city on Aug. 14 next to nominate candidates for President and Vice-President. Governor Isaac Sharp, President of the Executive Committee, said to-day that in all probability the platform to be adopted at this convention will not differ in any essential particular ...
There was a fairy good attendance at the Yonkers track yesterday, and the sport was enjoyable. The course was heavy, but in better condition than had been expected.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The confirmation of Col. Thomas L. Casey as Brigadier-General of Engineers will make the following promotions in that corps: Lieut.-Col. D.C. Houston to be Colonel; Major S.M. Mansfield to be Lieutenant-Colonel; Capt. J.B. Quinn to be Major; First Lieut. F.V. Abbott to be Captain, and Second Lieut. F.E. Craighill to be First Lieutenant.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 10.--On June 30 Elaf Swanson, a Swede, was shot in Branford by a fellow-countryman named Anderson. The injured man died on Saturday. Medical Examiner Gaylord, Deputy Sheriff Nettleton, and Coroner Mix had the body exhumed from the Branford cemetery, where it had been buried. They found the bullet in Swanson's neck, and declare that it caused his death. Anderson has fled.
The United Labor Party desires to form a Young Men's Campaign Club for active work. All in sympathy with the movement are invited to attend a meeting at Cooper Union to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 10.--So strong has the sentiment grown against the abettors of H. W. Moore in his disgraceful conduct that a movement was started to-day to secure the removal of "Pat" Short from the management of Uhrig's Cave, a Summer theatre, and from his position as Treasurer of the Olympic Theatre. Short has come out of the fire hit hard.

Fire broke out yesterday morning about 10 o'olock in William Scott's livery stable on Ramapo-avenue, opposite the Erie Station, Paterson, N.J., and in the course of an hour had spread to 12 or 14 buildings adjoining on Ramapo-avenue and Market-street to the corner of Straight-street.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--During the debate on the tariff in the House of Representatives yesterday much was said about trusts, and the Republicans sought to fasten upon the Democrats the charge that they were standing by the Sugar Trust.

BOSTON, Mass., July 10.--John O'Neal, an engineer on a coal barge in this harbor, made a bet of $5 to-day that he could dive under the barge and come up on the other side. He made the attempt, but struck his head against the barge, which drew 19 feet of water, and was drowned.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 10.--Mr. Edward Elam, a well-known citizen of Buckingham County, in this State, was instantly killed by lightning during the storm of yesterday afternoon. He leaves a widow and four children.

WINNIPEG, July 10.--The half-breed residents of Batoche, the scone of the former rebellion, are out with a manifesto acknowledging Dumont as their leader and threatening the Government if they do not get their rights. Those who took part in the rebellion demand to have their properties restored to them.

CHICAGO, July 10.--An evening paper says that the old trouble in the Boston Baseball Club has broken out again, and once more Capt. Morrill and "Mike" Kelly are at odds. Kelly, it is said, has been doing about as he pleased, and at Indianapolis remained out two nights after hours. For this Morrill fined him $25.

Levi P. Morton, the Republican candidate for Vice-President, Senator Frank Hiscock of Syracuse, and ex-Senator Warner Miller of Herkimer were the reigning attractions at yesterday's meeting of the Republican State Committee. They made no speeches and were compelled to listen to none, for it was not until the committee had completed its work that they were invited into the august presence of Gen. John N. Knapp ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 10.--This afternoon a Deputy Sheriff served papers upon Messrs. Frank Hoover, President of the Typographical Union, and William B. Hammond, member of the Executive Board of the same organization, notifying them to appear in court to-morrow morning to answer an indictment charging them with conspiracy in boycotting ...

John McDonnell of 104 Henry-street was arrested yesterday on a warrant obtained by Thomas Fenelon, an English farmer, who came to this country a few months ago, and who charges McDonnell with having swindled him out of $732.24 Fenelon met the prisoner at Sweeney's Hotel and became friendly with him.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 10.--The time made by the Lurlines of Minneapolis in the great senior four-oared contest of the Minnesota and Winnipeg Amateur Rowing Association Regatta at Lake Minnetofika was 8:15, which breaks the American record for one and a half miles on lake water by about 8 seconds. The Winnipeg crew finished in 8:22, also breaking the record.

Mr. Palmer yesterday gave his pretty little Madison-Square Theatre over to the keeping of the Grand Lodge of the Benevolent Protective Order of Elks. Delegates arrived from almost every large city in the country, until there were 200 of them in attendance when Exalted ...

Theodore Miller, the policeman of the City Hall squad who was charged with extorting $5 from a saloon keeper, had an examination before Justice Gorman at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. The result was that the complaint was dismissed and Miller was discharged.
CHICAGO, July 10.--Minnie Harris, a 13year-old girl, according to her story told in court to-day, had a strange experience in the hands of Laura Henry, a dive keeper, and her husband.

A.S. Emery, Superintendent of the Duplex Steam Heater Company's works, 23 Bethune-street, met a most horrible death at the company's works yesterday. He was overseeing the loading of a boiler upon the elevator and pulled a chain in order to descend a few feet below the floor level. Unfortunately he grasped the wrong chain and the elevator, ...

Mrs. Sophia Levy, aged about 50 and the wife of John J. Levy of the New-York Consolidated Card Company, who lives at 21 West Fiftieth-street, was runover by car No. 6 of the Twenty-third-street railroad yesterday afternoon, near Eighth-avenue, and instantly killed.

LONDON, July 10.--Most of the British journals agree in saying that Mr. Parnell's demand for the appointment of a Parliamentary committee to examine into the authenticity of the letters charging him with crime is unfortunately timed, unhappily conceived, and inadmissible.

John H. Van Loan, the absent and defaulting bookkeeper of the Second National Bank of Jersey City, was heard from yesterday. He wrote a letter to exonerate Nelson Coykendall, his father-in-law, who is charged with conspiracy with him to defraud the bank. Two strange men met Mr. Coykendall's counsel at his office door yesterday morning and handed him the letter, which reads as follows:
Rear-Admiral William E. Le Roy, United States Navy, is at the Victoria Hotel. Gov. C.C. Stevenson of Nevada is at the Hoffman House.

PITTSBURG, July 10.--The situation at the works of Singer, Nimick Co. has assumed a decidedly interesting phase. The members of the Knights of Labor and the Amalgamated Association who refuse to work on non-union principles seem determined to stand together and have their organizations recognized.

State Senator George F. Langbein appeared before Judge Andrews in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, and at his urgent request was relieved from the Receivership of the Co-operative Life and Accident Association of the United States.

In accordance with the provisions of chapter 673 of the Laws of 1887 Maurice B. Flynn filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday a bond of $250 to secure William M. Ivins, the City Chamberlain, for any costs he may be obliged to incur by reason of the suit which Flynn has brought against him in the Superior ...

ALBANY, July 10.--A young man armed with a subpoena for Judge William Muller of the Board of Claims, made his appearance in the Capitol to-day. Mr. Muller, however, was not to be found. Mr. Muller is wanted as a witness in the aqueduct inquiry. It is said that he has planned a trip with the other Commissioners to the Beaver River in the Adirondacks, where claims amounting to nearly $40,000 have arisen.

PITTSBURG, July 10.--The improved Westinghouse air brake was experimented upon to-day by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. The difference between it and the old brakes is a quick-acting valve by which the brakes can be applied at the same moment on all of the cars the train stopped ...

Col. McCaull's company will begin tomorrow morning final rehearsals for "Prince Methusalem," which will be produced at Wallack's next Monday night. When the theatre is reopened the McCaull season will continue without interruption until the beginning of the regular season at Wallack's on Oct. 8. The music of the part of Fiametta in "Boccaccio" has been sent to Miss Laura Moore in Paris, and she is now studying the part under the direction.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 10.--Ex-State Senator William B. Woodin of this city left for Slaterville Springs to-day, but not before he got one of the biggest overhaulings to which he had ever been treated in the course of his long career as a lawyer and a politician. It was as a witness in the celebrated Soule will contest, now in progress before Surrogate John. D. Teller in this city that Senator Woodin was excoriated.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 10.--The midsummer festival in Congress Spring Park bids fair to become one of the greatest society events of the season. The committee under whose auspices the festival will be given was fully made up tonight, and is composed of the following gentlemen: The Hon. James M. Marvin, Willard Lester, Charles Lester, Harry S. Leech, ex-Judge ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 10.--The California delegates won a victory to-day in the National Conference of Charities and Correction, and next year San Diego will be the meeting place of this body. The conference will conclude its work to-morrow.

This is one of HENRY WARD BEECHER'S phrases. He employed it to describe the type of religion which he thought would withstand and survive any possible progress of scientific knowledge, fatal as this might be to mere dogma. He meant very much the same thing by it that MATTHEW ARNOLD meant when he described the Church of England as a national society for the promotion of goodness.

CHICAGO, July 10.--Dispatches from various points in Central and Southern Illinois say that the rainfall for the past 48 hours was the heaviest known for a long time, and coming immediately after the great storm of last week has done a vast amount of damage. Tuscola reports 20,000 acres of corn under water in that ...

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 10.--The raspberry yield along the Hudson River is now at its height. The fruit yet to be shipped is excellent in quality. The crop is a prolific one.

John Schuchardt, an aged saloon keeper, of 689 West Newark-avenue, Jersey City, died suddenly yesterday. A physician summoned to attend him discovered marks of violence on his body after he had died. His sons claim to have evidence that a peddler who had a grudge against him had visited his saloon and beaten him. County Physician Converse will investigate the story. Schuchardt was a widower, and had been in the saloon business for 25 years.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10.--Ebenezer Stanyard, sentenced to be executed early Friday morning, still maintains a cheerful disposition, believing that at the last moment the State Board of Pardons will grant him a new lease of life. Stanyard has had two trials, and in both was found guilty of murder in the first degree. The murder was one of the most unprovoked ever committed in the State.

WHEELING, West Va., July 10.--Reports received to-day from the interior of the State and along the line of the railroads show that the flood of yesterday was one of the most disastrous ever experienced in West Virginia. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad has suffered particularly, and the 100 miles of main line between this city and Grafton and the branch line of the same length between Grafton and Parkersburg ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--Miss Charlotte Walker, who has already been heard here this Summer in connection with the American Opera Company, made her first appearance as Marguerite in Geunod's "Faust" at the Grand Opera House this evening and achieved a decided success. The audience was large and sympathetic and Miss Walker was warmly received, as her impersonation was an artistic piece of which which satisfactorily tested her lyric abilities. Charles Bassett sang the title role.

The long-discussed question of terms and discounts among woolen goods merchants and manufacturers will probably in a few days be definitely settled in a manner calculated to give general satisfaction. The Woolen Goods Association will meet in their new quarters in Leonard-street about July 20, and the plan submitted by the Executive Committee and already ...

MONTREAL, July 10.--The preliminary investigation of the Pitcher case was continued to-day. Robert Terroux, broker, identified the bills of exchange bought by Pitcher. The accused told him on that occasion that he was about to leave for France and would leave as soon as possible, if he could find a vessel leaving for French ports.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 10.--The Chandler resolution to investigate Senator Gibson's election to the United States Senate does not receive the approval of the thoughtful Republicans in Louisiana. They all concede his election. In the recent campaign in this State he led the reform element to victory.

Through the kindness of Mrs. C.M. Hickox of Brooklyn and a party of her talented pupils the patients of the Homeopathic Hospital at Ward's Island were treated to an excellent concert yesterday afternoon. LONDON, July 10.--The British, Austrian, and German Ambassadors to Turkey have asked the Porte to expedite the opening of the international railway to Constantinople.

At the public hearing on the Hudson River Bridge project held by the United States Board of Engineers at the Army Building yesterday a letter was submitted from Gustav Lindenthal, the designer of the bridge, in which Mr. Lindenthal explained the provisions of the bill so far as the proposed structure would affect navigation.

SARATOGA, July 10.--This village assumed something like a convention air to-day, and this evening the trains have brought many members of the Republican clubs from various sections of the State, and the advance guard were in time to witness the raising of the first Harrison banner across Bradway from District Attorney Hamilton's office to the Worden ...

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lewis of 126 East Sixty-first-street were driving through the Park in a phaeton last evening. When near Mt. St. Vincent on the East Drive a vehicle in front of them stopped abruptly, and Mr. and Mrs. Lewis's oarriage was upset.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 10.--A hailstorm of remarkable severity occurred last evening in the vicinity of Stony Creek, Sussex County. The area covered was only about half a mile, and the destruction to growing crops therein was nearly complete. The hailstones were very large and very irregular in shape, ranging from flat and square cakes to oblong and round balls. The storm was unaccompanied by wind. In localities ice could be gathered in large quantities.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--Some time ago an ordinance was introduced in the City Council permitting the Reading Terminal Company, a corporation formed for the purpose of securing better terminal facilities for the different branches of the Reading Railroad to construct elevated roads within the city limits, together with the necessary stations,

The Republican National Committee will meet at 11 A.M. to-day at Parlor D R in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel and will spend one hour in conference with the Executive Committee of the National Republican League of Clubs, consisting of one delegate from every State and Territory. At noon the National Committee will hold a regular business session, at which officers will be elected and an Executive Committee to have charge of the campaign will be appointed.

The track at Guttenberg was alive with trotting people yesterday. It was the first day of the Summer meeting, and it was devoted to the sport which the North Hudson Driving Club was organized to foster. There were two excellent races, and there was very lively betting, ...

JACKSON, Miss., July 10.--B.T. Hobbs, editor of the Brookhaven Leader, and who was indicted by the Grand Jury of the present term of the Circuit Court for using libelous language in his paper against Col. Jones S. Hamilton since and during the trial of the famous Hamilton-Gambrell case, appeared in the court to-day under the custody of Sheriff McNair of Brookhaven.

Should next Saturday prove fine an invitation lacrosse match between the teams of the Staten Island Athletic Club and the Nassau Athletic Club will be played at Washington Park, Brooklyn. The former will consist of the same players who lately won the Oelrichs Cup.

DETROIT, Mich., July 10.--Advance figures from the State monthly crop report, given out by the Secretary of State to-day, show the actual acreage of wheat in 1887 to have been 1,675,598 and the actual yield 22,723,550 bushels, an average of 13.56 bushels per acre. The number of acres of wheat on the ground in May of this year is reported at 1,504,611.

PARIS, July 10.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the committes appointed to inspect the defenses at Cherbourg, Brest, and Toulon submitted its report. The committee suggests that sea banks and other barriers be constructed in the roadsteads at Cherbourg and Brest.
LONDON, July 10.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Rhaetia, Capt. Vogelgesang, sld. from Hamburg for New-York to-day.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 10.--M. Rosenfield, Jr., a patient at Maryland Hospital for the Insane near this city, hanged himself with the rope of a swing on the hospital grounds this afternoon. He was a resident of St. Louis, and as he was not a dangerous patient, was allowed the freedom of the place.

In 1868 a British subject named McDonald failed in Ohio. Thomas J. Phelps was made Assignee. Among McDonald's assets was a claim against the Government for cotton destroyed duriug the war. He did not state the value of this claim, and it was sold for $20 to White, an agent of his. McDonald then recovered $197,191 from the Government.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 10.--No big puffing steamboats left the Monongahela wharf this morning with their precious tows of coal, but if Superintendent Martin of the Davis Island Damgets the wickets lowered to-night there will be a long procession down the Ohio by to-morrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 10.--Drafts--Sight, 20 cents: telegraphic, 25 cents.

There was a very sloppy track at Monmouth Park yesterday, but that did not prevent some fair racing, though with three stakes to be run there was nothing of a really sensational character, unless it was the additional proof that the Haggin string of splendidly-bred racers is a stable just now that isn't much beyond the level of a stable of selling platers.
ROCHESTER, July 10.--Hiram Sibley is seriously ill and not expected to recover. Last evening he suffered a stroke of apoplexy and became unconscious, and remains in that condition.

LONDON, July 10.--In the Conference of the Pan Presbyterian Council to-day the Rev. G.D. Mathews, D.D., of Quebec was appointed permanent Secretary with a salary of 500. He will reside in England and devote his whole time to the work. An honorary Secretary residing in American will also be appointed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10.--The heavy rains of Sunday and yesterday caused a number of wash-outs on the Hocking Valley Railroad, which will not be repaired before to-morrow. In many places the roadbed was washed away for a distance of several hundred feet. The river division is more seriously interrupted than other divisions, and it will require several days to plane the roads in running order again.
CHICAGO, July 10.--A good attendance witnessed the races at Washington Park to-day. The track was very heavy, but a good class of horses contended and speculation was brisk. Results were as follows:

SALTLAKE, Utah, July 9.--Receiver Dyer compromised to-day in the matter of the Mormon Church property, papers being filed in the Territorial court. The Receiver keeps what property he had seized and was paid $157,666.15 in cash. Further proceedings are to be dropped pending the hearing of appeal on questions involved in the United States Supreme Court.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., July 10.--The proprietors of the Hotel Breslin at Lake Hopatcong have given a plot of land for the erection of a Catholic church. The building will face the lake, and will be a handsome structure. The plans are already drawn, and will be approved by the Bishop this week.

It is probable that the Chinese wall formed by Central Park, which now cuts off all means of public transportation across town between Fifty-ninth and One Hundred and Tenth streets, will be pierced by at least one railroad in the near future.

LANCASTER, Penn., July 10.--Augustus Kirchoff, a shoemaker who resides on Claystreet, is in jail serving a term of six days, the result of a prosecution under the blue laws of 1794, which prohibit persons from working on Sunday. Adam Sellers, who is on bad terms with Kirchoff, brought the suit before Alderman Pinkerton, and last evening there was a hearing in the case.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10.--Matters in general are getting very lively at this place, the present activity, however, being occasioned by the fact that the American Institute of Instruction is holding its annual Summer meeting here.

RENOVO, Penn., July 10.--P.M. Christie of this place is a very nervyman. He has had quite an experience which demonstrates conclusively that he is no coward. The other day business called him to Kettle Creek. Much of the road is over mountains and through dense forests, which abound with wild beasts.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., July 10.--An item appeared in a local paper a few days ago referring to an exceptionally heavy steer a farmer in a neighboring county had raised, and stating that it was undoubtedly the heaviest animal of the kind ever raised, its weight being about 2,700 pounds.

The manufacturers and dealers in cotton bagging have formed a combination for the purpose of controlling the market and putting up the prices. Although the association is not exactly in the nature of a trust it will in all probability have much the same effect that the sugar combine has among the refiners.

To-day the managers of the Erie authorized their Western agents to again make a differential rate on dressed beef ...

A real old-fashioned boom tripped into Wall-street yesterday and started such a merrygo-round as the Stock Exchange has not known in many a day. Every stock on the list advanced, and some of them did their advancing with a rush and on a substantial scale.

DECKERTOWN, N.J., July 10.--A fatal fever has broken out among the large herds of dairy cattle in this (Sussex) and Sullivan Counties. The entire herds of Nicholas Dauch and Sylvester Crossman have been destroyed. It is spontaneous in its origin, and acts with great rapidity, the affected cattle dying or recovering within 24 hours after being taken sick. It is thought it is the result of the extremely hot weather.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 10.--The flower stalk, nearly 40 feet high, of a century plant at the Sub-Tropical Exposition Building broke from its own weight to-day and fell to the floor with a crash. The cause of the disaster was that the stalk had been deflected from the perpendicular by the sun's attraction. A magnificent head of blossoms was expected in a few weeks.

BERLIN, July 10.--Dr. Gerhardt, acting under the direction of the other German doctors who attended the late Emperor Frederick, has drawn up a report stating that early in 1887 the German physicians pronounced the disease from which he was suffering to be of a cancerous nature.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 10.--George Parsons Lathrop, who was too ill to read his poem at the Gettysburg celebration, has partially recovered from the gastric trouble with which he was affected. He was out for a ride yesterday and is gaining strength rapidly.

A meeting of the Presidents and other representatives of the chief life insurance companies of the country was held at the Boreel Building yesterday morning to consider the question of "rebates" in life insurance. The meeting was called by Col. Jacob L. Green, President of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Department of Agriculture makes the July general averages of condition as follows: Cotton, 86.7; Winter wheat, 75.8; Spring wheat, 95.9; corn, 93; oats, 95.2; barley, 91; Winter rye, 95.1; Spring rye, 96.6; tobacco, manufacturing leaf, 89.

Koltes Post, No. 32, G.A.R., held its twentyfirst annual picnic and camp fire at Jones's Wood Colosseum yesterday. In the afternoon were games for the girls and pole climbing, shooting, and races for the boys. A Punch and Judy show also furnished amusement for the spectators. In the evening the drums beat the "tattoo" at 9 P.M.
BOSTON, Mass., July 10.--Gov. Ames passed a restless night, but to-day is comfortable. The physicians report him somewhat improved, with a more satisfactory action of the heart.

ST. LOUIS, July 10.--A special dispatch from the city of Mexico says that yesterday the Electoral Collages met throughout the country and voted for President, three members of the Supreme Court, members of Congress, and one Senator in each State. So far no opposition whatever has been made to the re-election of President Diaz.

PITTSBURG, July 10.--The play on both sides here to-day was good and in many instances approached the brilliant. With two pitchers tossing winning ball under ordinary circumstances, and with errorless support on the side of the New-Yorks, the game was only uninteresting to those who like big scores.

The members of the United Order of American Carpenters and Joiners are fighting among themselves about the expediency of an amalgamation with the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America. The United Order is a New-York organization principally.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 10.--The Rev. Andrew Longacre, D.D., Pastor of Mount Vernon Church, Baltimore, has accepted a call from Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, of this eity to take the pulpit now filled by the Rev. Dr. Day, subject to the action of the next Conference.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 10.--A prominent wholesale Hudson River ice dealer, said today that all the Hudson River ice companies are losing money because of the cut rates. He said that they are delivering ice in the New-York market for $1 50 a ton which costs them $2 a ton, and that the cut rates will prevail all the season.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 10.--The middle wheel mill at the Laflin Rand Powder Works, three miles west of this city, was destroyed by an explosion this morning at an early hour. The cause is unknown. Fortunately no lives were lost.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 10.--The fifth annual convention of the Confectioners' Association of the United States assembled this morning at the Grand Union Hotel. The association embraces the leading wholesale manufacturers of confections, and its membership includes every section of the country.

Charles Underwood O'Connell, an attache of the Court of Common Pleas, sailed yesterday in the Guion steamship Wyoming for Ireland, where he will spend several weeks. Mr. O'Connell was an Irish patriot who was convicted of treason against the British Crown in 1865, and was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment. After serving six years he was set free on-condition that he left the country and remained away until his term of imprisonment had expired.

LONDON, July 10.--In an interview published in the Pall Mall Gazette to-night Mr. Parnell unfolds for the first time the plan of the Irish Nationalists with regard to the English Parliament under home rule conditions. His ideal is that England, Ireland, Scotland, and Wales shall each have a Parliament for the administration of local affairs.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 10.--The ninth annual convention of the Sons of Veterans was opened here to-day, more than 200 delegates being present. The organization has at present 110 posts in this State, and the number is on the increase. The convention will be celebrated by parades and camp fires and will end Thursday night.

NONQUITT, Mass., July 10.--Nonquitt air is apparently having a good effect on Gen. Sheridan's condition. He passed the best night he has known for some time, and during the day he has rested quietly and shown a constantly improving appetite, as this evening's bulletin states. His friends and attendants here feel greatly encouraged, but of course his doctors hesitate to state that he is definitely better.

BOSTON, Mass., July 11.--Gov. Ames is still a very sick man. This morning he is rather more comfortable than yesterday, and he is reported to have had a better night than usual. He slept three hours. It is not likely that he will be removed to North Easton this week.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 11.--The total number of stamped envelopes made at the United States Envelope Agency here during the year ending June 30 was 433,629,000. The largest month's total was in June, when 46,672,000 envelopes were manufactured. In 1887 the whole number distributed from the agency was 381,609,100. The increase for the year just closed was 52,000,000. New-York and Chicago are the principal points of distribution throughout the country.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 11.--The farmers at the extensive milk-producing districts of New-York and New-Jersey tributary to the New-York City market are now busy harvesting the most abundant hay crop in many years.
WASHINGTON, July 11.--The Secretary of the Treasury has appointed Edward Manning to be first assistant keeper of the light on the Bartholdi Statue of Liberty.

The stock market drooped a little yesterday, but that didn't discourage the bulls overmuch. "A healthy reaction" they called the sliding off in quotations, vouchsafing the pleasing assurance that hereafter "things are going to be better" right along till a great big boom arrives.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--The schooner Admiral Blake from Beaufort, S.C., with a cargo of "fish scrap", sunk to-day in the Delaware River at the mouth of Mantua Creek. Part of the cargo may be saved, but the vessel will be a total loss. The tug c. Baird with lighters and wreckers will begin work on her tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--The bond offerings today aggregated $552,850 in lots as follows: Four per cents, registered--$2,600 at 127 , $50,000 at 127 , $200,000 at 127 , $22,000 at 127 3/8. Four per cents, coupon--$3,250 at 128. Four and a half per cents, registered--$275,000 at 107 11-16. None of the offers were accepted.

RICHMOND, Va., July 12.--It is reported to-day that an informal conference of members representing both the Republican factions in this State was held at Petersburg last night, for the purpose of effecting a compromise in regard to an Electoral ticket which all could support.

BOSTON, July 12.--Despite the sensational reports sent out relative to the condition of Gov. Ames he is improving slowly, but persistently. He passed a comfortable day and gave signal proof of mental and physical recuperation by reading, the evening papers. His physicians have no fear of the result.

LONDON, July 12.--At the Hamilton Park Summer meeting today the race for the Hamilton Park Stakes was won by Galore by three lengths from Horton, Zest a poor third. There were nine starters. The last betting was 3 to 1 against Galore, 8 to 1 against Horton, and 10 to 1 against Zest.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 12.--News of two more bloody tragedies comes from the wilds of Eastern Kentucky. Monday last Marion Stuart and John Stuart, cousins, living on Martin's Fork, in Harlan County, were playing cards for whisky at Marion Stuart's house. They were seated on the floor, and both were slightly intoxicated.

BERLIN, July 12.--The fleet which will accompany Emperor William as an escort on his visit to Russia will be the largest that Germany has ever put to sea. It will consist of six ironclads, four dispatch ships, four vessels of the training squadron, and a flotilla of torpedo boats.

WOBURN, Mass., July 12.--The inquest in the case of Bessie Hazeltin, who died June 25 last from a pistol-shot wound, and whose case created considerable excitement, was concluded this morning. Judge Littlefield finds that the deceased committed suicide.

NEW-HAVEN , Conn., July 12.--Mrs. Christopher Langley, of 40 Summer-street, this city, while going down her cellar stairs this evening tripped and fell. She had a lamp in her hand, and when she fell it exploded. The burning oil covered her face, shoulders, and neck. Her physicians say her injuries are serious and painful, but not fatal.

The gross earnings of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad for the mouth of May were $103,544, and net earnings were $25,997. The Legislative committee appointed to consider the question of the extension of Greenville shore line 2,500 or 3,000 feet into the channel of New-York Bay met in Jersey City yesterday.

SARATOGA, July 12.--Ex-Senator Warner Miller, who expects to occupy the Gubernatorial Mansion in January next, did not finish his speech in the Casino until 12:30 o'clock this morning, and he was returned to Congress Hall by the torchlight procession which had escorted him to the ratification meeting. The ex-Senator is an early riser, but he did not get out in time...
WASHINGTON, July 12.--Col. Thomas A. McParlin, Surgeon, has been granted one month's extension of leave of absence; Second Lieut. Stephen M. Foots, Fourth Artillery, four months' leave of absence.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 12.--Free ferriage was enjoyed by all who had occasion to cross Wesley Lake, between the Park and Ocean Grove this afternoon. LONDON, July 12.--The steamer Wasp was sunk in the Mersey by a collision with the Norwegian bark Hypatia, Capt. Thomasen, which arrived at Garston yesterday from Parrsborough, Nova Scotia. The Wasp's crew had a narrow eacape from drowning.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 12.--The St. Catharines and Niagara Central Railroad was formally opened for traffic between St. Catharines and Niagara Falls yesterday. The Directors celebrated the occasion by an excursion and champagne dinner at the Falls.
Stilson Hutchins of Washington is at the St. James Hotel.
Surrogate Ransom yesterday allowed the Duchess of Marlborough the extra $100,000 out of the income of her late husband's estate, for which she petitioned three days before her marriage to the Duke.

The Canadian Pacific Railroad continues its policy of extensions and additions to its present lines. Official announcement was made in Wall-street yesterday of its acquisition of the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railroad.

Nearly all the members of the Republican National Committee left this city yesterday, and the corridors of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel were almost deserted during the day. A few prominent Republicans remained in the city until night, however, including the members of the newlyformed Executive Committee of the National Committee.

CHICAGO, July 12.--W.R. Shaw, the rich young married man whose trip East with May Yohe, a member of the Chicago Opera House "Crystal Slipper" company, caused so much talk a few days ago, was sued to-day for divorce. Mrs. Shaw makes the Yohe incident the principal ground of complaint. An injunction was issued restraining young Shaw from disposing of any of his property until the divorce case is heard.

BOSTON, July 12.--The storm that struck New-England last night and raged with peculiar violence early this morning in Eastern Massachusetts was very escentric in its movements. In Boston it was the severest felt for some time, the wind attaining the velocity of 42 miles an hour and carrying desolation and have among the trees and chimney pots in all parts of the city with perfect impartiality.

DETROIT, Mich., July 12.--Yesterday afternoon the wife of William D. Levice, living nerr Baker's Mills, Gladwin County, took her 5year-old boy and visited a neighbor's house half a mile away. Returning she was surrounded by forest fires that were kindled into fierceness by the prevailing high wind, and both mother and child perished.

DETROIT, Mich, July 12.--At 7:10 last evening a dense cloud passed over Marquette and out over Lake Superior. Immediately after the water in the harbor fell 26 inches in a few minutes. The lake and bay were calm at the time. After 33 minutes the water returned again.

Twenty-second and Twenty-third streets, and owns 120 other houses in different parts of the city, from which he derives an income of $10,000 a year.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 12.--This was a busy day with Gen. Harrison. About 10 o'clock he came to the New Denison House, where he remained during the greater part of the day receiving delegates in the parlors. The time previous to the arrival of delegations was spent in conversation with friends at Republican headquarters.

CHICAGO, July 12.--Commander John P. Rea, Grand Army of the Republic, takes exception to the roads in the Western States Passenger Association which, contrary to promises, fixed upon a rate of one fare for the round trip for the meeting of the Grand Army at Columbus, Ohio, in September.

Matters at the new half-mile race track at Yonkers were rather lively yesterday. In the third race two of the horses, Melodrama and Retta, fell, and Weber, who rode the latter, had his leg fractured in the fall.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 12.--New-York met with a defeat here today, but it was not unexpected. The absence of O'Rourke, Slattery, and Tiernan--all the outfielders of the team--weakened the club to such an extent that defeat seemed inevitable.

RUTLAND, Vt., July 12.--The How Scale Works were sold at auction to-day for $441,283. The sum includes the amount of liabilities, ($201,133,) which are assumed by the purchasers. The works were bought by a syndicate of seven Rutland men. The new owners will take possession within 60 days. Work will go on without interruption.

HELENA, Montana, July 12.--A. Frich, a wealthy stockholder of Western Union, was run over and killed by an engine at the Missoula stock yards last night.

RACINE, Wis., July 12.--John Zachar, the Caledonian faster, after an abstinence from food for 53 days, has at last been induced to eat. His story is a most remarkable one, and, although much has been said of it, the true reason for his wonderful fast was not positively known until to-day.

Emperor of Norfolk, "Lucky" Baldwin's great 3-year-old, who won the American Derby with case, is not to do any more racing this year. He pulled up lame at the end of practice yesterday morning at Washington Park, Chicago, and his owner has decided to give him a rest for the balance of the season, as the horse is too valuable to run any risks with.
LONDON, July 12.--The Canard Line steamship Gallia, Capt. Murphy from New-York July 4 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at 10 P.M. to-day.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 12.--The cornerstone of the Administration Building of the Old Soldiers and Sailors' Home, two and a half miles from the city, was laid yesterday with imposing ceremonies. Many of the Grand Army of the Republic posts of the State were represented and an immense crowd was in attendance.

CARLISLE, Penn., July. 12.--George Martin, a resident of Shippensburg,at one time a prominent and influential Republican politician of Southern Pennsylvania, announced to-day that he would support Cleveland and Thurman in the coming campaign, believing their election to be for the country's interest. He is now 88 years of years, and always voted the Whig and Republican tickets.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12.--Drafts-Sight, 20; telegraphic, 25.

CHAUTAUQUA, July 12.--An old-fashioned spelling match was held last evening in the amphitheatre before the largest audience of the season. Fifty or more teachers and advanced students from all parts of the country competed.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 12.--About a thousand people who gathered at Cayuga Lake Park this afternoon to witness the single scull race between George H. Hosmer of Boston, Albert Hamm of Halifax, and John Teemer of McKeesport saw Teemer come in a winner by 10 boat lengths.
BALTIMORE, July 12.--Cardinal Gibbons, who has been overworked the past month, will leave the city to-day for a two week's vacation in North Carolina.

LONDON, July 12.--A dispatch from Cape Town, Africa, says that the Debeers Coal Mine, at Kimberley, caught fire yesterday evening, and 800 men are entombed. The work of rescue, which began at once, still continues, but it is believed that 500 persons have perished, including Mr. Lindsay, the manager of the company. Many of the victims imprisoned in the mines are white people.

CHICAGO, July 12.--A drop of 22 in five minutes is what the Chicago thermometers experienced this morning at 11:20 o'clock. At that time the bulb indicated 86 , and the prospects were very favorable toward a very hot day.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 12.--There were some interesting experiments this afternoon at the torpedo station for the benefit of the members of the American Institute of Instruction.

BOSTON, July 12.--Thousands of cards, simply containing the announcement that a citizens' mass meeting was to be held in Faneuil Hall to discuss the school question, were circulated about the city during the past few days, and as a result Faneuil Hall was crowded last night to overflowing.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 12.--J.T. Morehead was nominated for congress by the Democrats of the Fifth District to-day on the hundred and sixtysecond ballot.

Showers of rain did not prevent the cricket match at Livingston, Staten Island, yesterday between the Pittsburg Club and the home team from being played. The match was very one-sided, the Visitors outbatting, outbowling, and outfielding the Islanders.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 12.--President Hart to-day received an opinion from Chairman Rogers that the New-Orleans, being a chartered association, could transfer its ball players into anothor league, independently of the fact that the Southern League has disbanded.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--The British bark C.E. Robinson, from Wilmington for Ensenada, collided with the schoonor Rebecca M. Walls, from Boothbay, in Delaware Bay last night. The Robinson lost bowsprit, foremast, and part of mainmast, and sustained other damage. The extent of damage to the Walls is not known. Both vessels were towed to this port.
DUBLIN, July 12.--The funeral of Mr. John Mandeville took place at Mitchellstown today. Fully 6,000 persons followed the body to the grave. The most perfect order was preserved.

ST. LOUIS, July 12.--The Cherokee Indian Council, in session at Tahlequah last week, passed a bill leasing the grazing privileges west of the ninetysixth meridian to the Cherokee Strip Live Stock Association...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 12.--Hiram Sibley, Rochester's wealthiest and probably most widely-known citizen, died at 10:30 o'clock this morning after an illness of only five days, at the age of 81 years. Up to last Sunday Mr. Sibley had enjoyed as good health as often fails to the lot of one so advanced in years.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12.--The United States cruiser Charleston, which is being constructed at the Union Iron Works, in this city, will be launched July 19.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 12.--Mrs. Washington Noac, wife of a farmer living near Rosseca, was found this morning in a field dead, with her throat cut from ear to ear. A bloody razor was found in her right hand. Her only son died a short time since, and brooding over her loss is supposed to have caused her to take her life.

DETROIT, Mich., July 12.--The city of Alpena is situated 230 miles north of Detroit at the head of Thunder Bay, Lake Huron, and is a city of 11,000 persons. It is the northern terminus of the Detroit, Bay City and Alpena Railroad, and the fish and lumber industries are its chief sources of wealth.

BALTIMORE, July 12.--At the meeting today of the American Association of Instructors of the Blind, Mr. Huntoon submitted the report of the Executive Committee, which showed a satisfactory condition of affairs.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 12.--Gov. Morehouse gave his decision in the Maxwell case this morning and it has met with general public approval in this city. He refused to commute the murderer's sentence, but in order to allow him time to bid farewell to his relatives and prepare for death respited him until Aug. 10. On that date Maxwell will hang unless he discovers a way to commit suicide.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., July 6.--The longlooked-for schooner yacht Coronet, which left New-York over three months ago for this port, sailed into the harbor at 9 o'clock this morning under a full spread of canvas. At 10 o'clock the vessel cast anchor off the Commercial Wharf.
