WASHINGTON, July 12.--President Cleveland's vetoes of private pension bills continue to serve as a big bugaboo to the Republican Senators. They are never referred to in the Senate without calling out growls and snaris from one or more Republicans, and the whole, party has fit last announced the very remarkable doctrine that the President has no constitutional power to object to the dictum of Congress in the case of a pension bill.

Mayor Hewitt, as a sub-committee, yesterday reported to the Sinking Fund Commissioners a scheme disposing of the worthless plans for a municipal building which had been received from a score or more of architects in response to invitations to compete for prizes. The committee of three architects had awarded the preference to the plan marked "Audaces fortuna juvat," but the author had not compiled with the conditions of the test and could not,

ALBANY, N.Y., July 12.--Ann McMahon, a witness for her husband in a suit against him by Patrick Sherry for assault, growing out of the occupancy of a woodshed, was taken sick in the police court room as she stepped up to take the oath to-day. A court officer led her out of the room and she died on the stairs. Death was from heart disease aggravated by excitement.

LOUISVILLE, July 12.--The special agents of the fire insurance companies doing business in Kentucky and Tennessee met at the Galt House to-day and organized the Kentucky and Tennessee Insurance League. The object is the establishment of rules and regulations for the government of the companies in the field. A.W. Hart of Louisville was chosen President, John Hawley and C.D. Thompson of Louisville Vice-President and Secretary respectively.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 12.--The Board of Commissioners of this place held their regular meeting last night, and by a unanimous vote adopted the resolution offered by Counselor J.E. Lanning, formerly Prosecutor of the Pleas of Monmouth County and one of the officers of...

BOSTON, July 12.--A singular story of moral turpitude and ultimate reparation of wrong comes from Leominster. Four years age the Rev. O.D. Kimball was Pastor of the Baptist church in that place and resigned his pastorate to go to West Newton. Shortly after he left singular stories of unclerical conduct...

CHICAGO, July 12.--Alex Smith is another of the man arrested in the Chicago, Burlington, and Quincy conspiracy proceedings who prefers his present condition to liberty. He is supposed to have given important information to the prosecution, and this probably explains his desire to keep in a safe place, Messrs. Donahue Davis, attorneys for all the defendants in the...

LONDON, July 12.--In the conference of the Pan Presbyterian Council to-day Dr. Turnbull was elected English Treasurer and Dr. E. D. Junkin of Houston. Texas, the American Treasurer. Dr. David Walters of Newark, N. J., advocated the revival of the Catholic Presbyterian. The proposal was referred to the Executive Committee.

CHICAGO, July 12.--The Vanderbilt lines were so slow to-day in meeting the daily cut in the dressed-beef rate to-day that for a time it was believed they had grown tired of the fight and had decided to take no futher part in it.

The departure for London on Wednesday of Mr. Richard Mansfield and his dramatic company recalled among actors the threats against that distinguished actor recently indulged in by Daniel E. Bandmann, the "German tragedian."

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 12.--The Masonic Hall was sold to-day to a number of the stockholders of the Union Building Loan Association, which owned it, for $44,000. It cost originally $275,000. The hall will be maintained by the association as an opera house.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12.--The semi-annual convention of the Retail Grocers' Association of New-Jersey was held in this city yesterday. In his address President Stephen Pell referred to the food laws as being unjust to the retailer. He called attention to the vinegar law passed by the Legislature, which provides that vinegar shall contain no coloring matter.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 12.--At Phillipsburg, this morning, Jacob Billiard, aged 22, attempted suicide by shooting himself in the head, and he is now in a critical condition. Kate Addis, a girl of notorious reputation, last night threatened him with prosecution. She has since left for parts unknown.

MINNNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 12.--At the National Convention of Photographers today action was taken looking to the establishment of a department of photography at the Smithsonian Institution. A scheme for introducing an insurance into the association was defeated by a close vote. The following officers were put in nomination: Presidents--B. McMichael, Buffalo, N.Y., and O.L. Stein, Milwaukee; Vice-Presidents--G.H. Hastings, Boston; J. M. Appleton, Dayton, Ohio; W.H. Jackson, Denver; Secretary and Treasurer--G.M. Carlise, Providence, R.I.

Lovers of justice in this city can lay to Col. Fellows the mistrial of as cruel a case of conspiracy as has at any time been brought to the attention of a court in this city in connection with the tyranny of walking delegates and the Knights of Labor. The case was called before Recorder Smyth yesterday. A foreman in a shop had discharged a man who was detected stealing from his employer.

The prospect seems fair at present that the Manhattan Club will come at last to some conclusion in regard to the occupancy of the Stewart mansion. For some time it has been known that the intention of the Union Club is to move further up town than Thirty-fourthstreet, if it should move at all, ...

CHICAGO, July 13.--Before United States Commissioner Hoyne to-day the Chicago, Burington and Quincy Railroad Company began its task of proving that a dynamite conspiracy exists among its late employes. Technically it was a preliminary examination of J.H. Bowles, ...

DAYTON, Ohio, July 13.--On telegraphic information received from Sheriff McDowell of Crawford County, Penn., three fugitives from justice, D.M. McCord J.S. Tracey, and George Brown, were taken from the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railway train. The charge against them is attempting the gold brick trick on Farmer Hosmer near Meadville. Disguises, jewelry, weapons, and sheets of unsigned national bank notes were captured on them. Requisition papers must be procured before they can be taken back.

A new play called "Grandfather's Clock," based on phases of New-England life, will be given its first production at some point in the New-England circuit on Sept. 3. It will be presented under the management of H.A. D'Arcy, and William C. Cowper will play the leading part, supported by Miss Frankie MacCulloch and a company of 16 people.
Mayor Chapin, Controller Livingston, and Auditor Rutan or Brooklyn yesterday morning appointed the Police Justices to succeed Justices Walsh, Kenna, Massey and Naeher.

VICKSBURG, Miss., July 13.--S. Spengler of Spengler's Mills, which employs about 200 men, also the half owner of the Cooper's Wells property, was thrown from his carriage this morning and died this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--The bond offerings today aggregated $1,118,000 as follows: Coupon fours --$4,000 at 127 $15,000 at 127 3/8. Registered fours--$160,000 at 127 , $80,000 at 127 3/8, $32,000 at 127, $22,000 at 127 3/8, $200,000 at 127 . Registered four and a half--$400,000 at 107 5/8 $275,000 at 107 11-16.

Surrogate Ransom yesterday made a decision sustaining the will of Charles G. Havens, which his nephews and nieces and other next of kin have been endeavoring to invalidate. Mr. Havena was a rich gentleman who lived for many years at 103 East Nineteenth-street, in this city, and left about $2,000,000.

The prospect of a very large appropriation for coast and harbor defense during the present session of Congress is not brilliant. The difficulty does not lie in lack of funds, and there is apparently no drawback from a misplaced frugality of the ...

RALEIGH, N.C., July 13.--W.A. Potts, condemned to be hanged at Washington, N.C., to-day for the murder of Paul Linck, has been respited by the Governor till Tuesday, the Sheriff having telegrahed here that Potts is dying.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 13.--Manager Ted Sullivan of the Washingtons is in town to-day. He asked New-Orleans to put price on Fuller's release. President Hart said $1,500, and the privilege of holding on to him for a few days until he could get a substitute to send to Texas.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 13.--Ebenezer Stanyard, the Youngstown murderer who killed his sweetheart, Alice Hanscock, early in 1887, was hanged in the penitentiary annex at 1 o'clock this afternoon. He played his accordion before going on the scaffold and appeared ...

PANAMA, July 8.--Two or three trifling earthquakes were felt on the Isthmus during last week. A very marked motion was experienced in this city at 2:30 o'clock on the morning of July 3. The weather has also been extremely and oppressively warm.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 13.--The steamer Professor Morse, Capt. Hardie, from Livingston and Spanish Honduras ports, which arrived here yesterday, reports severe storms on the coast of Spanish Honduras, causing great destruction to banana plantations. Capt. Hardie also reports: "On July 3, while at Santo Tomaso, eight distinet shocks of earthquake were felt.

In perusing the recently-published translation of the "Correspondenoe" between Richard Wagner and Franz Liszt, I confess my feelings were diverse. On the one hand arose a certain admiration of the manner in which Mr. Francis Hueffer has, in English which most dramatically reproduces the rugged, eloquence of ...

The latest plea set up on the Republican side of the Senate against the President's vetoes of certain private pension bills is that the sum of money involved is only a few thousand dollars--a sum so small that neither the President nor Congress should stoop to inquire about it.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 13.--Corresponding to advances made in New-York American and California sugar refineries here yesterday advanced the different grades of sugar cent and to-day cent.

What is the right sort of commission, honorarium, douceur, or whatever is the prettiest name to call it by, for an agent who undertakes to introduce one to an eligible marriageable young lady? The question would be variously answered, one will assume, according ...

ROCKVILLE, Conn., July 13.--At 6 o'clock last night two hunters in the North Woods in Ellington found the badly-decomposed body of a woman. It was identified this morning as that of Minnie Piefka, 28 years old, who disappeared last December in a blinding snowstorm. She lived in Rockville with and uncle, who, it is said, treated her cruelly, and she probably ran away.

Dr. Healey of New-Haven is having a curious experience with the maritime laws of this country. Last Spring he bought the steam yacht Nautilus, which the Marquis of Lorne owned when he was Governor-General of Canada.

LONDON, July 13.--One of the British regiments now in Egypt has been ordered to Zululand. A regiment from Aldershot will replace it in Egypt. It is generally believed that serious trouble will soon ensue in South Africa.
Frank Krenkel, 35 years old, since December last an entry clerk in the chair factory of Heywood Brothers, 297 to 303 Cherrystreet, is under arrest at Police Headquarters for forgery.

The Governor-Generalship of Algeria is about to be vacated by its present holder, and a post involving a salary of 6,000 a year with two palaces, one in Algiers and the other delightfully situated at Mustapha, and a smart ...

WHEELING, West Va., July 13.--In answer to appeals for aid from the towns in the flooded districts of the State the Chamber of Commerce met this evening in response to a call by Mayor Seabright and appointed a committee of business man to solicit aid for those in distress. The most destitute point seems to be at Rowlesburg, where two-thirds of the population are in absolute want.

The special committee appointed at the last session of the Legislature to inquire into the moral, physical, and financial condition of the Indians of the State, with particular reference to the claims of the Ogden Land Company to some 60,000 acres of soil now used as reservations, met yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel.

Up in Phillips, about 50 years ago, the scholars in a Sunday school engaged in a contest to see who could commit to memory the most verses from the Bible. Among the pupils was a 13-year-old boy. One Sunday a young lady school teacher beat the previous records by reciting 350.

The forthcoming marriage of the youthful Emperor of China will, it is stated, cost not less than 4,000,000 taels. This little bill will, of course, have to be paid by his subjects somehow. Probably the provincial Viceroys will be requested to make extraordinary contributions to the Imperial Treasury for the purpose.

ST. LOUIS, July 13.--The Missouri Pacific and Iron Mountain Railroads, which control the terminal facilities of St. Louis, decided to-night to do a little gouging. They gave notice that hereafter switching charges would be advanced from $2 to $4 a car.
The New-Yorks will play in Chicago to-day. Elmer Foster joined the Giants yesterday.

Fish Commissioner Blackford has on exhibition the largest German brook trout ever caught in this country. It weighs 5 Pounds. It was taken by Frank G. Amsden of Rochester, N.Y., with a light six-ounce split bamboo rod on Thursday night in Caledonia Creek, which has been stocked from the State hatcheries with trout hatched from eggs received from Herr von Behr, President of the Deutsche Fisherei Verein, Germany.

The trotting meeting at the Guttenberg, N. J., track, which terminated yesterday, has been one of the finest and most interesting affairs of the kind ever held in this vicinity within the last few years.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 13.--Brown Co., owners of the Wayne Iron Works, on Tenthstreet, signed the iron workers' scale this morning. Their mill will be in operation on Monday. The works are large, giving employment to almost 1,000 men when running full.

It is to be hoped, and also to be believed, that the duel with M. FLOQUET insures the disappearance of Gen. BOULANGER from French politics. For some time it has been growing plainer that his support came chiefly from Frenchmen who adhered to one ...

CHATHAM, Mass., July 13.--Capt. Morgan, his wife, and two children were brought from the wrecked schooner F.H. Odiorne at Monomoy this afternoon, the sea having gone down. He reports the vessel lying badly.

CHICAGO, July 13.--Beautiful racing weather and good lists of starters attracted a large crowd to Washington Park to-day. The chief event was the Quickstep Stakes, won by Galen, belonging to Gray Co., after an amazing showing of speed, none of the others being able to approach him. The track was in fine order, and the races were run with these results:

CHICAGO, July 13.--At last the war among the Eastern roads over dressed beef and live stock rates begins to show signs of abating. To be sure, the Erie and the Chicago and Atlantic managed to keep the ball rolling to-day by dropping the rate on dressed beef to 8 cents per 100 pounds to New-York and 18 cents to Boston--a reduction of 1 cent.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 13.--The Giants somewhat retrieved themselves for the defeat of yesterday by shutting out the Hoosiers to-day. Keefe's curves proved enigmas to the local players, who failed to gauge them to any advantage for the nine innings.

SPRINGFILED, Mass., July 13.--The weavers employed by the Glasgow Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of dress goods, at South Hadley Falls, struck to-day for an increase of pay. The company employs 850 hands and pays $10,000 monthly in wages.

CHICAGO, July 13.--The freight officials of the railroads interested in Nebraska traffic have been analyzing the new schedule of rates which the Railroad Commissioners of that State propose to put in force on July 20 on all the lines in the State.

CHICAGO, July 13.--Chairman Faithorn of the Western and Northwestern Freight Association has advised lines doing business between Chicago and Council Bluffs that irregularities in rates on business originating in the East ought to cease so as to prevent further demoralization in rates.

NEW-BEDFORD, July 13.--There is good news from some of the Provincetown whalers. The Rising Sun is reported with 245 barrels of sperm oil and 11 pounds of ambergris; the Gage H. Phillips with 125 barrele of oil, and the Antarctic with 320 barrels. The Rising Sun had a boat stove while chasing a whale off Porto Rico by another whale coming up under it. The boat's crew was saved.

LONDON, July 13.--A dispatch from Cape Town says that they Debeers mine, in Kimberly, the scene of the fire Wednesday night, has been explored by g party ol searchers. Twenty-four whites and 200 natives were found to have been burned to death. The cause of the fire is unknown.

A number of the Railway Telegraph Superintendents pleasantly ended their visit to New-York yesterday by an inspection of the new signal system at Weehawken, and a trip on the Lehigh Valley Road to Easton, Penn., to watch the practical working of the improved methods of inductive telegraphy.

The Rev. Waldo Messaros of Philadelphia, the lively Greece-Roman, catch-as-catch-can ministerial wrestler, will prebably become a Minneapolitan. At any rate, the First Free Baptist Church has extended him a very unanimous and enthusiastic call.
CHICAGO, July 13.--A case of genuine leprosy is reported from Le Grand, Iowa. The patient, Helena Halverson, is a young Norwegian, who was married two years ago, just before coming to this country.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 13.--A committee of Lutheran clergymen are here representing the General Council, General Synod, and United Synod of the South to revise Luther's small catechism and the Augsburg Confession. They are the Revs. Dr. Seiss. Jacobs, and Conrad of Philadelphia, Schmucker or Pottstown. Wedekind of New-York City, Valentine and Wolf of Gettysburg, and Henkel of Newmarket, Va. They will be in session several days.

MONTREAL, Quebec, July 13.--Negotiations are about being closed for the sale of the Harvey Hill copper mines, in the county of Megantic, to the Excelsior Copper Company of London, England, with a capital of 450,000.
HAVANA, Cuba, July 7.--The cornerstone of the building in which will be held an exhibition commemorative of the second centenary of the founding of the city of Santa Clara will be laid on July 15.

CHICAGO, July 13.--The queer shooting case yesterday, in which a boy was wounded by the discharge of a revolver in the handbag of Mrs. J.J. Crane, was given a new turn to-day by the discovery made by the polcie that the woman was a house thief for whom they have been searching for months on varions charges.
The Galena, Commander Colby M. Chester commanding, arrived at the navy yard yesterday morning, and soon after went alongside the coal wharf, taking the berth of the Pensacola, ...

BOSTON, Mass., July 13.--Rutherford B. Hayes, who arrived in Boston to-day to perform his duties as President of the National Prison Congress, is the one man from Ohio who absolutely refuses to say a word about politics.

On the day of Emperor Frederick's death no less than 36,695 telegrams were dispatched from the Central Bureau in Berlin, 1,134 from Potsdam, 177 from Wildpark station, and 578 from Fricdrichskron Palace station.
There was quite a large attendance of veteran cricketers present at Prospect Park yesterday when the Pittsburg and manhattan Clubs faced each other and they cheered every good stroke to the echo.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 13.--Hallenbeck Punch, composing the Geneva Furniture Company, to-night made an assignment to E.A. Walton. The assets are about $10,000; liablities about the same. The assignment is attributed to the action of creditors in attempting, to force collections now, the dullest season of the year.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 13.--Twenty-three years ago the wife of Willlam Hall, a farmer living in Cherokee County, was murdered. Hall was arrested for the crime. He was twice tried, convicted, and sentenced to the penitentiary for life, but each time succeeded in getting a new trial.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13.--David M. Pascoe, formerly Secretary and Treasurer of the International Typographical Union, was arrested this morning on the charge of embezzlement and larceny as bailee. The warrant for his arrest was sworn out by Edward T. Plank of ...

Gen. Isaac S. Catlin, ex-District Attorney of Brooklyn, is charged with raising a lively sort of rumpus on a Rockaway train on Thursday night. Gen. Catlin started from Elatbushavenue station on a fishing trip to Broad Channel. He asked a brakeman.

Graham McAdam talked to the Reform Club last night for nealy an hour about "how to talk to other persons about the tariff." There were fully 150 gentlemen present who expect to do more or less stump speaking during the present campaign, and they followed Mr. McAdam with much interest.

Gov. Hill visited the State camp at Peekskill yesterday, where the Sixty-fifth Regiment and other State troops, including the Elmira Company, were putting the finishing touches on their week of camping. He was received with the Governor's salute of 39 guns, and driven over the camp with an escort from the staff of the commanding General.
The Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee held another meeting yesterday, at which all the members except Chairman Quay were present. Information was received by Chairman pro tem.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 13.--Horsemen will be interested in learning that J.H. Goldsmith's famous young stallion Domestic has just been shod for the first time since the hoofs were removed from his fore feet, in November last, in consequence of the diseased condition of those members.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 13.--NewZealand letters report that George F. Stewart, United States Consular Agent at New-Britain, had had a narrow escape.

The statement originating in Boston, representing that Jay Gould is suffering from a cancer, a Massachusetts doctor expecting to be summoned to Irvington to treat the millionaire invalid, created a sensation in Wall-street yesterday.

Detectives Brown and Donohue of the United States Secret Service, went yesterday to the Bremon pier, and among the passengers that arrived by the steamer Ems they met Marion Hunt, who they suspected was afflicted with artificial corpulence.

There was it ripple of excitement among the ballet girls of Imre Kiralfy's Nero," at St. George, Staten Island, last evening, owing to an elopement of one of their number. Her daylight name is Mary Ann Smiley, and her parents live in West Tenthstreet, this city.

The talking part of Wall-street is very happy. Quotations continue to go up and speculative confidence grows materially stronger. Many a Stock Exchange habitue who scoffed at the prospects of a lull movement a week ago are hurrahing over what they consider its likelihood now.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 13.--The steam yacht Electra sailed hence to-day for Mount Desert.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 13.--It is learned that landlord Scully is about to sell his Illinois holdings. He owns 4,000 acres in Sangamon, 15,000 acres in Logan, and 1,000 acres in McLean and other counties, in which he has for several years carried on the Irish rack-renting system.

SARATOGA, July 13.--The rumor that the physicians of Jay Gould will prevail upon him to come to Saratoga for his health has excited some interest among the hotel proprietors, and Mr. Gould would certainly find unsurpassed accommodations for himself if he should decide to spend the season here.

PARIS, July 13.--The Gambetta statue in the Place du Carrousel was unveiled this afternoon. M. Floquet, the Prime Minister, who fought a duel with Gen. Boulanger this morning, delivered the oration. MM. Leroyer, de Freycinet, Meline, and Spuller also spoke.

At the request of the defense United States Commissioner Shields yesterday postponed till Tuesday the examination of Dominico Vincenzio, charged with trying to pass counterfeit bill. Vincenzio lives at 304 East One Hundred and Seventhstreet. Last Saturday night he journeyed from his home to the saloon of Jacob Ullman at 1,027 Second-avenue and bought a pall of beer. In payment he offered a five-dollar counterfeit bill and was arrested.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 13.--Eli C. Rule, who is in jail on a charge of forging his brother's name to a note for $160, was brought out for a hearing yesterday, and while he was in the Justice's office the news came by telegraph of the death of his wife.

Sixteen little tin boxes, each about the size of a lawyer's deed box, and holding the bones of as many Chinamen, who died between 1870 and 1882, were shipped to San Francisco last night by the National Express Company.

Representative William McKinley of Ohio, by common consent the foremost advocate of the doctrine of protection, and ex-Representative Frank Hurd of Ohio, the notorious free trader, are the closest of personal friends, and famous among their acquaintances for a genuine affection each toward the other.

CHICAGO, July 13.--The freight officials of the railroads interested in Nebraska traffic have been analyzing the new schedule of rates which the Railroad Commissioners of that State propose to put in force on July 20 on all the lines in the State.

All the disinterested reports thus far received from the interior represent plantation affairs to be in a very satisfactory and hopeful condition. There are still a few who pretend to believe that the abolition of slavery is ruining the planters, and that a great part of the present coffee crop will not be picked because of a ...

CHICAGO, July 13.--The committee appointed by the leading clubs of Chicago to arrange for a celebration of the four hundredth anniversary of the discovery of America met at the Iroquois Club rooms to-night and decided to invite outside co-operation in making arrangements for the anniversary. It was decided to appoint a committee of five to outline a plan for presentation at the next meeting, arranging for the celebration in Chicago in 1892.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 13.--At about 1 o'clock this morning the Legislature, having no further business to transact, adjourned sine die.

George P. Swift, a Jersey City street contractor, is accused of haviug improperly secured possession of a city warrant for about $4,600, and payment on it has been stopped at the Second National Bank.

Fifty years ago, on the 28th of June, 1838, the crown of these realms was placed upon the head of Queen Victoria. On the morning of that memorable day the sky was overcast for a time, and between 7 and 8 rain fell.

PITTSBURG, July 13.--The fourth day of the Summer trotting meeting at Homewood Driving Park attracted the largest crowd of the season. The weather was delightfully cool and the track very fast. The races were hotly contested and resulted in several surprises.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--The annual report of Col. D.C. Houston has been received by the Chief Engineers of the army. It contains the following information regarding river and harbor improvements in New-York:

There is a movement on Lord Zetland's estates to "celebrate suitably" the jubiles of his earldom. He is, however, a sensible man, and has written that while he has no objection to the proposal, he must stipulate that there shall be "no fuss" concerning himself.

It is not at all likely that the Fred Remington whose suicidal death at Trinidad, Col., was reported yesterday by telegraph is the artist Frederic Remington whose pictures in the National Academy of Design, in the Century magazine, and in Harper's Weekly have been so generally admired.

An exciting scene was witnessed yesterday in a criminal court here. A railway servant had just been sentenced to six months' imprisonment for ill-treating his wife, when he drew a revolver from his pocket, fired at random among the audience, slightly wounding one of them, and then shot himself in the head, inflicting a wound which, though not immediately fatal, leaves little reason to expect his recovery. The unfortunate man was removed to the hospital.

A correspondent advises us that Mr. Kennedy has paid the $1,000 fine incurred by the Church of the Holy Trinity, this city, for having "imported under contract" its present Rector, the Rav. Mr. Warren, Mr. Kennedy being the party who originally instituted the suit.
When Giralana Zigare, an Italian living at 245 South Fifth-avenue, left his home yesterday morning to attend to his duties as superintendent of a gang of coalheavers he had a wife and two children.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 13.--Ex-School Commissioner Mendel of New-York did a brave thing here yesterday afternoon. Miss Nettie Solomon of New-York, who is stopping at the West End Hotel on Asbury-avenue, was one of the bathers at the Asbury-Avenue Pavilion.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., July 13.--The Relief Committee appointed at the citizens' meeting Wednesday met yesterday afternoon to hear the report of the sub-committees that visted the devastated districts. Terrible suffering is reported, which for exceeds all anticipations.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 13.--Jules V. Charpentier, notary public, has been missing since Saturday, and as he was intrusted with money by a number of creole families it is feared that he has made off with considerable sums.
PHILADELPHIA, July 13.--Thomas Gill, a wealthy man, 77 years of age, who lives at 1,546 Franklin-street, was neatly swindled out of $2,650 this morning by an old-time confidence game.

CANONICUT ISLAND, R.I., July 13.--This Island is situated about five miles west of Newport and it forms the western boundary of Newport's outer harbor. It is about nine miles long and about one mile wide, and with Dutch, Gould, and Rose Islands, comprises the township of Jamestown.

Where Irving Hall now stands, half demolished, entirely dismantled, and altogether forlorn-looking, a new theatre will be seen before the harvests of Autumn are gathered. One hundred and fifty men are laboring assiduously to complete the work of demolition, ...

"Miss Mary Garrett, the daughter of the founder of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad system, is an extraordinary woman," said a gentleman well acquainted with the facts, "and, but that she is a woman, would to-day be President of that road."
CINCINNATI, July 13.--The Grand Jury has not made its final report, and will not do so before to-morrow, and even then its action will not be made known until the indicted persons are arrested.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 13.--William A. Potts, Jr., sentenced to be hanged to-day at Washington, N.C., for the murder of Paul Linoke on June 7, 1887, attempted to escape execution by committing suicide. He was found in his cell by a prisoner at 6 o'clock this ...

Edward P. White, a member of the Union Club and also of the New-York Athletic Club, and his friend C.E. Brown of 100 John-street, visited Everard's Russian Bath establishment in West Twenty-eight-street last evening.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 13.--The Republican political are making a frantic effort to show that Presidbnt Cleveland is hated by the old soldiers and all organizations of old soldiers and yet in this city to-day at a meeting of 150 old soldiers the name of President Cleveland was actually received with applause.
POTTSVILLE, Penn, July 13.--In the criminal court here to-day, Margaret Buegusser of Shenandoah, who killed her husband by splitting his skull with a hatchet, was put on trial for murder.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 13.--Among the earlier settlers in Westchester County, this State, were two brothers named Metzgar, French Huguenots from the Province of Alsace.

The Board of Electrical Control held no meeting yesterday, but spent the morning preparing a petition to Attorney-General Tabor, asking him to begin proceedings to dissolve the United States Illuminating Company.

Another female Munchausen of tender years has been discovered in New-York and the weird remances of the little German maiden who was discovered under the platform of a down-town business house last week pale into ...

Our esteemed Blaineiac contemporary was reasonably very angry a few days ago at the dense ignorance shown by the British press in its comments on the Republican Convention. The absurd British editors somewhere got the idea that Mr. BLAINE ...

CHICAGO, July 13.--Just for a joke, and because it spoiled the set of his coat, Mrs. J.B. Crane on Wednesday night took her husband's revolver out of his pocket and hid the weapon in her handbag. She forgot all about tho transfer to-day when, picking up the little valise, she started down town on a shopping tour.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 13.--The naval court-martial to try the naval cadets for hazing assembled at the Naval Academy to-day. Commander C.D. Sigsbee is President of the board, and Ensign F.J. Haesler is Judge-Advocate.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--Mr. Randall passed an easy night and was stated to be much better this morning, but he had another hemorrhage this morning, and though it was but slight, there is much anxiety manifested concerning his condition.

PANAMA, July 5.--In all 1,405 persons on the isthmus subscribed for canal lottery bonds. These took 3,727 bonds of the value of 1,341,720f. There is considerable disappointment that the loan fell so far short of being a success.

Miss Ida M. Cox, 22 years old, of Classon's Point, Westcheater County, has been missing from her home since Wednesday evening. She is believed to be demented. She went out on Wednesday afternoon to take a walk and did not return.

The Coney Island Jockey Club will celebrate the workingmen's holiday, Monday, Sept. 3, known as Labor Day, by running the first of the Futurity races for 2-year-olds on that day. This will be the richest stake ever run for in this country, 363 of the original 752 entries being eligible, and the probable value of the stake being $50,000.

MOUNT AYR, Iowa, July 13.--A.M. Bruce, proprietor of a large creamery at Wirt, came here Wednesday and cashed several large drafts. He was about town all day transacting business, and frequently displaying his roll of money, amounting to nearly $2,000.

The police of the Sixty-seventh-street station were surprised to learn Thursday night that ex-Alderman Francis McCabe, one of the "boodle" members of the Board of 1884, had suddenly and mysteriously disappeared.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 13.--To-day the Hamilton Lumber Company assigned for the benefit of creditors.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 13.--Chicopee was thrown into great excitement this morning by the discovery of the dead body of Fred G. Reed, Superintendent of one of the departments of the Dwight Company's mill, at the house of L. E. Childs, where he boarded.

OMAHA, Neb., July 13.--The State University of Nebraska is just now involved in a most unsavory and somewhat sensational scandal. A long list of charges preferred against Chancellor Manett by members of the Faculty, graduates, and students, have called the Regents to Lincoln, where the university is situated, and an investigation is in progress.

There was an unusually large crowd at the Brighton Beach track yesterday and some really excellent sport. Old Barnum won the big race of the day, the Jamaica Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, after a rattling good race. That the victory was a popular one was evidenced by ...

Eight races are on the card for to-day's meeting at Monmouth Park, and they should furnish excellent sport, for the fields are amply large to provide good, sharp contests.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 13.--An excursion composed of newspaper men from Ohio and Pennsylvania visited Chautanqua to-day. The following papers had representatives in the party: The Cincinnati Commercial Gazette, Enquirer, Telegram, and Medical, Journal; the Cleveland Leader, Voice, and Plaindealer; the Pittsburg Leader, Post, Telegraph, and Dispatch; the Columbus News, and the Youngstown Telegram.

CHICAGO, July 14--2 A.M.--Eight thousand people crowded into Battery D to-night to attend the opening mass meeting of the Prohibitionists in the campaign. The speakers were Gen. Fisk, the party's candidate for President; Vice-Presidential candidate Brooks, and Miss Frances F. Willard.

MONTREAL, July 13.--The police magistrate's room was overcrowded to-day when the arguments for and against the committal of Pitcher, the fugitive Teller of the Union Bank of Providence, to the Court of Queen's Bench was begun.

The building trades unions will ask the Board of Education to permit representatives of the Board of Walking Delegates to visit all school buildings that are being crected or repaired to see that the work is done according to the plans and specifications.
TROY, N.Y., July 13.--Andrew Willaims, a prominent capitalist of Plattsburg, has failed. Large judgements have been filed against him.

WHEELING, Wast Va., July 13.--The Pittsburg, Cannonsburg and State Line Railroad Company was organized to-day, with a capital stock of $2,000,000, for the construction of a short line from this city to Pittsburg by way of Wellsburg and Bethany, West Va., and Cannonsburg, Penn.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., JulY 13.--Charles Townes was struck by a Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg train at this place to-day and killed instantly.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 13.--The Dwyer Brothers' 20 head of yearlings, all of which were purchased at the Spring sales in Kentucky and Tennessee, were shipped to-day to the Brooklyn Jockey Club track, where they will be broken and handled this Summer and Fall.

The Fassett investigating committee, minus Senator Fassett, held another arduous session yesterday, under the Presidency of Senator Hendricks, and endeavored to worm out a few more secrets concerning the manner in which the new aqueduct is being constructed.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--First Lieuts. C.A.L. Totten, Fourth Artillery; A.B. Dyer, Fourth Artillery, and B.H. Randolph, Third Artillery, have been ordered to visit the encampment of the Connecticut National Guard at Niantic; Second Lieut. C.L. Collins, Twenty-fourth Infantry, has been granted one month's leave of absence.
A census has recently been taken of the public houses and beer houses in the Parliamentary borough of Burnley. The result is most remarkable and instructive.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 13.--George H. Switt is a Republican who was appointed Postmaster at Cuba, Allegany County, by President Arthur, and took office on Cleveland's inauguration.

BOSTON, July 13.--Stanwood Phinney, the brother of Brooklyn's mysterious suicide, left Waltham for New-York this evening to explain the contents of a valise and a letter received from the brother now dead.

The rural letter carriers in Germany are an industrious class of public servants. According to the statistical account of the Postal Department the aggregate number of pieces of postal matter distributed in the rural districts in 1886 was, in round figures, 323,000,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 13.--The State Board of Pardons has signed a recommendation asking President Cleveland to pardon from the Ohio Penitentiary Ben E. Hopkins, one of the officers of the late Fidelity Bank of Cincinnati. The opinion is expressed that Hopkins cannot live more than a year, ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 13.--The race troubles in Crittenden County, Ark., are over. Temporary appointments have been made by the Judge of the Circuit Court to fill the offices vacated by the negro officials driven from the county.

The arrest of the defaulter Pitcher is owing to the fact of his fidelity bond having been guaranteed by the Guarantee Company of North America, and to the prompt action taken by Mr. Edward Rawlings, the Managing Director of that company.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--Believing that half a loaf is better than none, the Republicans in the House of Representatives to-day gave up their attempt to help the Senate put the eight-hundred-thousand-dollar steamship subsidy in the Post Office Appropriation bill ...

Dominico Teuda, a young Italian employed as bookkeeper in the factory of Charles Whitlock Co., 13 Marion-street, yesterday complained at Police Haedquarters that he had been assaulted without provocation by Policeman John F. Poole of the Tenth Precinct.

BERLIN, July 13.--The dinner given by the Emperor at Potsdam last night in honor of the foreign Ambassadors was a brilliant affair. Besides the Ambassadors all the Ministers of the Government were present.

WILMINGTON, N.C., July 13.--The Hon. D.L. Russell, who was a delegate to the Chicago Convention, and who was nominated for the head of the State Republican judicial ticket, has written a letter to the Republican Executive Committee in which he declines the nomination and advises the withdrawal of the entire State ticket.

It is the general opinion among the ticket agents on Broadway that the resumption of the sale of Chicago and Alton tickets by the Baltimore and Ohio Road is a practical beginning of the end of the boycott against the former line.
Vanity Fair, desiring to correct "much misapprehension" about the methods by which the Princess of Wales obtains her partners announces that she chooses them herself.

ROCHESTER, N.Y,, July 13.--The funeral of Hiram Sibley will take place from the family residence, on East-avenue, to-morrow afternoon at 2:30 o'clock. The list of pall bearers has not been completed. It is expected that Don Alonze Watson, D.W. Powers, and Gilman H. Perkins will be among them.
KINGSTON, N.Y., July 13.--Miss Gracie Adams of Highland, Ulster County, accompanied a relative, who is a butcher, on a meatpeddling trip yesterday.

WIESBADEN, July 13.--An officer, attended by 20 policemen, entered Queen Natalie's villa at 10 o'clock this morning and shortly afterward reappeared with young Prince Alexander, the Servian Crown Prince, and a lady of honor of the Queen's suite.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 13.--Information has been received here that among the persons killed in the railroad accident on the Midland Railroad yesterday near Barboursville, in Virginia, was L.E. Cortes of this city.

Otis B. Boise and William G. Morgan, composing the firm of O.B. Boise Co., manufacturers of umbrellas and parasols at 439 Broadway and at 153 Greene-street, made an assignment yesterday to James A. Robinson. Preferences were given for $28,600. George W. Stockley of Cleveland, Ohio, is ...
The magnitude of the scandal which has been developed by the aqueduct investigation makes it imperative that something should be done in behalf of the plundered taxpayers of New-York.

CRESSONA, Penn., July 13.--Laffin Rand's large powder works, near Cresaona, blew up this afternoon, killing three men, George Gilman, Charles Reed, and Henry Bernich, who were the only persons about the place.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13.--All the school teachers who have been attending the meeting of the Institute of Instruction took their departure to-day after enjoying a sail outside as far as Block Island in the steamer Providence of the Fall River Line. A band of music was on board, and all hands were provided with a collation. Many were seasick.

LONDON, July 13.--Notice of the motion to be submitted by Mr. W.H. Smith for leave to introduce a bill providing for an investigating committee in the matter of the Times's charges against Irish members of Parliament was placed upon the paper in the House of Commons tonight.
THE TIMES acknowledges the receipt of $2 from Ed Weitling, Saranac Lake, for the Earle Guild.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14.--The National Council of the National Educational Association met here yesterday, President J.L. Pickard of Iowa City presiding.

The junior single-scull race of the Palisade Boat Club of Yonkers was rowed yesterday afternoon, the contestants, being George P. Holden, E. P. Moffat, and C.P. Marsden, Jr.

LONDON, July 14.--There was the usual Saturday conflict between the police and people in Trafalgar-square to-day arising from the attempts of the people to hold a meeting and the determination of the police to prevent them from doing so.
KINGSTON, N.Y., July 14.--The lot selected for the Catskill Mountain Deer Park consists of 193 acres of land on the banks of the Neversink River.

Gen. Newton said yesterday that he could not obey the order of the Broad of Electrical Control to remove certain "dead" poles of the United States Illuminating Company until he had heard from Corporation Counsel Beekman as to his power in the matter.

CHICAGO, July 14.--An almost errorless game was won here to-day by Chicago because New-York could not hit the ball when hitting was needed. The Chicagoes, on the other hand, sufficiently recovered their muscle to knock out a brace of two-baggers and a home run, the latter by Williamson being one of the longest ever seen here.

PARIS, July 14.--President Carnot attended a grand review of troops at Longchamps to-day. On his arrival on the grounds he was greeted with cries of "Vive Carnot!" followed by "Vive Floquet!" and "Vive la Republique!"

One of the delightful excursions for which the Central Railroad of New-Jersey is deservedly popular will be given on Wednesday to Mauch Chunk, Glen Onoko, and the Switchback by special train leaving this city from the foot of Liberty-street at 8:30 A.M.

Two games of cricket were played yesterday at Central Park--Albions against the Amateur League and the Kings County against the Cosmopolitans. In the former game the Amateur League was victor by a score of 105 to 56. In the latter game the Cosmopolitans won. The score was 39 to 27.

BLACK ROCK, Conn., July 14.--The cruise of the Atlantic Yacht Club began to-day in a most agreeable manner. A few of the vessels of the fleet were towed from Bay Ridge up to Whitestone, Long Island, yesterday evening and lay at anchor there until morning.

LONDON, June 30.--The greatest English military authority said to me on Tuesday: "There will be no war this year; nobody's ready." Now, this was said not only with a certain emphasis on the word "this," but, to my own knowledge, after a conference with some leading members of the Cabinet.

Charles Herold of 244 Avenue A, driver of a Seventh-avenue bobtail car, who ran over and killed 4-year-old Michael Martell of 172 Thompson-street Friday afternoon, was remanded in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to await the action of the Coroner.
WASHINGTON, July 14.--Second Lieut. Walde E. Ayer, Twelfth Infantry, has been granted six months' leave of absence, with permission to go abroad.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., July 14.--By the explosion of a ladle of molten iron at Emau's pipe foundry this forenoon William Stauffer and Jeremiah Reiss were fatally burned, and Jacob Wolf, George Schmoyer, Daniel Acker, and Nathan Barton were severely injured.

Lord Tollemache, who has recently sold three of his family pictures of 44,000, has expended 65,300 in purchasing a steam brewery at Ipswich, with 69 public houses attached, for his tenth son, Mr. Ranulph Tollemache.
ASHLAND, Wis., July 14.--An outrage seldom equaled in this section comes to light in Price County, committed by a father, who was summarily punished by indignant citizens.

SUNBURY, Penn., July 14.--The sixteenth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen will be held here next Wednesday and Thursday. The business meeting of the association will take place Wednesday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 14.--The burial service of the Protestant Episcopal Church was read by the Rev. Algernon S. Cropsey, Rector of St. Andrew's Church, over the body of Hiram Sibley, this afternoon, at 4 o'clock.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 14.--The break in the canal at Adams Basin is nearly repaired, and water will be let in slowly to-night. There is no prospect of the large fleet of boats moving before Monday. On both sides of the break boats have been gathering daily.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14.--Sheriff Krumbhaar to-day announced the special jury selected in the matter of Joseph Muhr, whose erratic actions at Long Branch last week caused his removal to the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14.--When Claus Spreckels announced that he would fight the great Sugar Trust single-handed every one prophesised he would soon come to grief in spite of his millions.
DETROIT, Mich., July 14.--The Grand Trunk limited express No. 5, which left the station at 11 o'clock last night, was derailed at Mount Olivet Cemetery, 14 miles from Detroit.

ALBANY, July 14.--The Court of Appeals room is now ready for the session of the Legislature, which will convene in it next week.

CHICAGO, July 14.--The new tariff recently submitted by Commissioner Waldo of the Texas Traffic Association, who was chosen to arbitrate the question of through rates from New-York, Chicago, St. Louis, Kansas City, , to Denver and common Colorado points, will become effective on Monday.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 14.--George Goeller of Rondout has had another offer of $200 for the violin which was found in a cloister in Germany 278 years ago.
HARRISBURG, July 11.--If there is one thing I like better than another it is the eating of a trout after it is cooked.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 14.--Fire Commissioner Henry D. Purroy and James H. Lyon of New-York, who arrived at the Worden House last night, arose early this morning and went down Broadway toward the Hathorn Spring like a pair of pedestrians spending for a prize.

PARIS, July 14.--Gen. Boulanger is improving. Several friends called upon him today and the General was able to converse with them. He was also able to take bouillon.

Staten Islanders feel more than an ordinary interest in the result of the Presidential election, as Mrs. Levi P. Morton, wife of the Republican nomince for Vice-President, was born and raised on Staten Island.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 14.--A large number of the Summer residents attended the opening polo matches of the season of 1888 this afternoon, and many witnessed the sport from Deadhead Hill.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 14.--The season in the Catskill Mountains is nearing its height. There was a great influx of guests to-day, as there usually is in the middle of July. Trainmen and baggagemen have been severely taxed all the week.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 14.--The various baseball and turf exchanges closed down tonight, in accordance with the order of Chief Brown. An attempt may be made to evade the law by some of the pool sellers, however.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 14.--The State Board of Health are inclined to regard Northern leprosy as contagious, in view of the fact that the two recent cases developing in this State are traceable to the district of Stavangar, Norway, the United States Consul at Christiana has been warned that all leprous cases from that locality will be returned if they venture to settle in Iowa.

TROY, N.Y., July 14.--Joseph Morse, a deserter from the United States Marine Corps at Boston, was arrested in Saratoga Springs this morning.

LENOX, Mass., July 14.--This has been the coldest July week here for many years. The mercury has seldom reached above 65 , and it has been down to 45 and a frost has been feared. The cottagers go out the dine with heavy wraps on and the coachmen are obliged to wear their Winter clothing to keep warm ...

After the representatives in attendance at the convention of the telegraph Superintendents had concluded their labors last Thursday many of them went down to the banquet at Manhattan Beach as the guests of Mr. Austin Cor bin, President of the Long Island Railroad.

COTTAGE CITY, July 14.--The weather here has been frightfully cold for the last two weeks, and those cottagers who have arrived here have found overcoats and wraps comfortable the most of the time. There has been no large increase of visitors as yet, and the season is very backward in all respects.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 14.--Just after the earthquake of Aug. 31, 1886, Joseph Soup, living in Charleston, was crazed by fright and attempted to kill himself by jumping out of a window and cutting his throat.
ORLANDO, Fla., July 14.--The State has resolved to adopt heroic measures to stamp out the so-called yellow or malaria fever at Plant City.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 14.--A romance from Russia comes to light in a petition for a divorce. The petitioner is Isaac Wolberg, and in his petition he tells a very strange story.
Chevalier Blondin began a series of seven performances at Sea Beach yesterday afternoon. Fully 25,000 people were in attendance and the old man's feats were enthusiastically applauded.

MIDDLETOWN, N,Y., July 14.--In the matter of the remarkable longevity attained by their inhabitants, the neighboring towns of Oxford and New-Berlin, in Chenango County, can safely challenge a comparison with any other towns of the State.

The trouble in the Amateur Baseball League, which, until a short time ago, was composed of the Staten Island, Brooklyn, and NewJersey Athletic Clubs and the Staten Island Cricket Club, will not down, because the NewJersey Athletic Club will insist upon standing up for its rights and upon being heard.
BELVIDERE, N.J., July 14.--The huckleberry season along the Blue Mountains has now opened and in a few days will be in full blast.
It is perfectly proper to carve out your own fortune, but you should not chisel other people in doing it.--Boston Bulletin.
ALBANY, July 14.--Burglars ransacked the house of Philo H. Backus, a bookkeeper in the State Treasurer's office, last night.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 14.--The charges of hazing against Naval Cadet R.H. Leigh were resumed this morning before the courtmartial of which Commander Sigsbee is President. Naval Cadet F.R. Payne was the first witness.

Whitelaw Reid's Summer residence, probably the finest in Westchester County, and erected on the famous Ophir farm, about midway between White Plains and Port Chester, was destroyed by fire yesterday. The structure was of granite, three stories high, with cellar and mansard roof. The main building was 70 feet wide by 95 feet deep, and had wings each 35 by 50 feet.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 14.--Frederick Palmatier was struck on the head last night with a beer faucet, and died to-day in the hospital. Palmatier entered a saloon on Water-street, known as the Grand Republic, and called for a drink.

CHICAGO, July 14.--The freight war among the Eastern roads was waged with renewed vigor to-day. The Erie took another cent off the dressed beef rate and the Vanderbilt and Pennsylvania lines met the cut, making the rate 7 cents per 100 pounds of New-York and 17 cents to Boston.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 14.--Throughout Minnesota and Dakota crops of all descriptions are maturing rapidly. Along the main line of the Northern Pacific Railway the outlook is good, expect in the vicinity of Perham. Here the grasshoppers have done much damage, denuding almost 1,200 acres.

The steamship Servia of the Cunard Line carried among her saloon passengers yesterday morning nearly 200 excursionists, of whom about half were members of Dr. Talmage's Tabernacle.

ALBANY, July 14.--Washington Park is a great resort for women and children, and was, as usual, well filled this afternoon. Among those present was the daughter, 5 years old, of Robert Coburn, a painter. She had with her her sister, 20 months old.

Now that the Long Branch Ocean Pier Company have, after several days of suspension of iron Steamboat travel, completed the dredging necessary at the pier, the Taurus and the Pegasus will run to day on the special Sunday time table from West Twenty-third-street.

A wonderfully well contested game of lacrosse was played on the Brooklyn Baseball Ground yesterday by the Brooklyn Lacrosse Club and a team from the Staten Island Athletic Club. In the first half of the game no goal was scored, according to the umpire's decision, although the Islanders thought they had made two goals.

The Pope has decided that all his jubilee presents which are of a sacred nature are to form a Leonine Museum, which he intends to establish in the Basilica of St. John de Lateran. The royal presents and all the secular objects are to be permanently placed in one of the halls of the Vatican, and will be left as heirlooms of the Papacy.

The novels of Mrs. Richard Henry Stoddard are already among the prizes of those who look for first editions of remarkable books. It is well that the present generation can obtain them in new and revised editions, for although their thoughtfulness and simplicity of style belong to a former period, the human nature depicted in them will always move the reader.

CINCINNATI, July 14.--A battery of eight gas tanks in Ludlow, Ky., exploded this afternoon, injuring 15 men, four of them fatally. The gas is generated from naphtha for lighting the railroad shops and for use in the Mann bou doir cars.

BERLIN, July 14.--Emperor William's departure from Kiel presented a spectacle splendid beyond anything ever before witnessed on the German seas. The town and harbor were uniquely decorated. The route from the station to the harbor was lined with masts covered with oak leaves and adorned with weapons and banners. The German, Prussian, and Holstein colors were conspicuous.

Mrs. Witkamp and Bernard Grantish of 241 Washington-street, Jersey City, were seriously bitten by a Newfoundland dog last Tuesday, and though they had their wounds cautorized it is feared they are suffering from hydrophobia. The dog, which was owned by Mr. Witkamp, was rabid and was shot.

CARLISLE, Penn., July 14.--Since the resignation of Dr. John A. McCauley from the Presidency of Dickinson College, a Methodist institution in the city, the name of ex-Gov. Robert E. Pattison of Philadelphia has been most prominently mentioned for the place. It is reported in college circles to-day that the Board of Trustees will tender it to him.

How love is blind to depreciated currency is thus told by a Maine paper: When the banks of Bangor, Me., decided not to take Canadian coin except at a discount a farmer living near by had quite a stock of the depreciated coins.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14.--There has been great interest manifested during the past year in learning more fully the details of the work of the Mitchell raiders, the party that captured a train of cars north of Atlanta in 1862.

PORT HENRY, N.Y., July 14.--This village on the shores of Lake Champlain, 117 miles north of Albany, and near the old fort of Crown Point, is the busy home of about 2,000 people, mostly engaged in or dependent on the iron business.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 14.--The Harrison house was something of a hospital to-day. Mrs. Harrison has been somewhat ill for two days, and was not able to receive the Railroad Club with the General, while, of course, there is concern over the condition of Mrs. McKee, who has just become a mother for the second time. The counterfeit five-dollar bills are still going the rounds. On Friday night Giuseppe Coniglio, a shoemaker, of 592 Third-avenue, was arrested for trying to pass one on Herman Oppenheimer, dealer in leather, of 426 West Fifty-second-street.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 14.--Ted Sullivan did send tickets to Fuller and Werden and they arrived from Texas to-day. Widner took French leave and came along. All three left here with Sullivan to-night and Fuller will join the Washingtons at Indianapolis.

William J. Florence, brown as a berry, and as jovial as a lark is supposed to be in the neighborhood of dawn, returned to his rooms in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday and took a rest.

BOSTON, July 14.--A dispatch from Chatham indicates that those on board the wrecked schooner F.H. Odiorne, which ran on Handkerchief Shoal during the storm of Thursday morning, endured sufferings unusual in this latitude at this season of the year.

Fire broke out at 1 0'clock this morning in the kindling wood factory at 58 and 60 Gregory-street, Jersey City. The factory is situated in the business portion of the city and within a half a block of the City Hall and Police Headquarters. It was thought the flames would spread to adjoining property.

The sixteenth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which is to be held Wednesday and Thursday at Sunbury, Penn., on the Susquehanna, does not appear specially interesting this season to NewYork watermen.

PARIS, July 14.--The most popular man in France would become King or Emperor at once if he could stop the rain and induce the sun to send down that much needed, much coveted, degree of warmth which we have been waiting for since the 1st of May.

CHICAGO, July 14.--J.A. Bowles, one of the men on trial before United States Commissioner Hoyne for complicity in the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy dynamite conspiracy, changed the course of the hearing to-day by deciding to make a confession to the District Attorney.

RACINE, Wis., July 14.--Reports from John Zachar, the faster, are that all attempts to obtain nourishment from the light food administered to him have proved futile. The milk and other food taken is not retained on the stomach. This has left him in a very weak and exhausted condition and he will most probaly suffer death as the penalty of his 53 days' willful fast.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Jerome will celebrate on Monday evening, July 23, at their apartments in the Albany, the fiftieth anniversary of their wedding, and are daily receiving congratulations from their many relatives and friends, both here and abroad.

A fire which started about 7:45 o'clock last night in the show window of John Simpson's dry goods store, 725 and 727 Sixth-avenue, wiped out his stock. Lyric Hall, above the store, was badly scorched.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 14.--Sheriff Werner of Marlon, Crittenden County, telegraphed Gov. Hughes this morning that the troubles in that county were quieting down, and that the alarm was subsiding.

A Lancashire friend tells me that the living of Bury, which is now vacant through the death of Canon Hornby, is really worth about 3,500 a year. It is in the gift of Lord Derby, and has always been held by a member of the family.
PITTSBURG, July 14.--The extra day of the summer trotting meeting at Homewood Driving Park attracted only a small crowd, as there were only two events on the cards.

Buffalo Bill and his partner say they want two or three more seasons of such prosperity as has been attending their efforts this Summer, and then they will buy Staten Island and turn it into an Indian reservation.

Henry Saunders, from Orange County, N.Y., was found near Mount Pleasant Park, Jersey City, yesterday, suffering from the effects of paris green. He said that he was in love with his niece, daughter of Thomas Heslin of 272 Eleventh-street, and her parents would not consent to their marriage. Therefore he attempted to kill himself. His recovery is doubtful.

The will of M. Bord, a manufacturer of pianos in Paris, has given rise to some rather remarkable proceedings on the part of the testator's heris and of the workmen employed in the establishment, which had been organized by the deceased and conducted by him with great prosperity for many years.

Policeman John Cross of the Hoboken police force was oiling the revolver in the station house this afternoon when the hammer suddenly fell, exploding a cartridge. Cross had the revolver pressed against his breast with his left hand before it and pointed downward.
The schooner Paul Boyton, which arrived at Portland from Georges Banks with fish on Tuesday, brought a most remarkable fish, which as yet nobody has been able to name.

PARIS, July 14.--The result of the duel between Boulanger and Floquet surprised no one. It was felt that a mock encounter could not be possible, and in spite of the discretion exercised there was a crowd yesterday morning around the residence of Count Dillon at Neuilly, in whose gardens the duel was fought.

CHICAGO, July 14.--A dispatch from Lincoln, Ill., says that Landlord Scully's agents deny the report that their employer is about to sell all his Illinois estates. They say that the management of the land goes on as before, exception only being made in the matter of the taxes, which are no longer made a separate part of the rent, but the rent is adjusted to meet the requirements of the law in that regard.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., July 14.--The annual rush of tourists to the White Mountains has already assumed large proportions, and the present indications are that the season will be an unusually good one. The method of making a satisfactory visit to the mountain resorts has undergone a notable change, and is rapidly being reduced to a sensible basis.

Although the Manhattan Athletic Club now enjoys very comfortable quarters at 524 Fifth-avenue, it expects by May 1, 1889, to occupy the largest, handsomest, and best appointed clubhouse in the United States.

The condition of the war in freight rates remains the same as for several days past. So far as known, or even believed, all lines are adhering to the rate via rail and lake to Chicago of 35 cents per hundred on a basis of first-class freights, with the exception of the Central Vermont lake line, the rates over that route being on a basis of 27 cents.

NONQUITT, Mass., July 14.--Gen. Sheridan's condition has not changed materially during the last 24 hours. He rests tranquilly, has a good appetite, and says he feels "tip-top." The only event of the day has been the departure of Col. Kellogg, the General's aide-de-camp, for Washington, whither he has been sent on special military duty. He expects to return to Nonquitt in a fortnight.

LONDON, July 14.--What Mr. Parnell is going to do quite transcends in popular interest, at present, what Mr. Parnell has or has not done. His promulgation this week of the Irish party's position with regard to imperial federation is looked upon as the most important political declaration since Gladstone came out for home rule.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 14.--The huckleberry crop on the Shawangunk Mountains is maturing rapidly. The pickers now at work report that the yield is fully up to the average of former seasons, and that the berries are finely flavored. Heavy shipments will be made to New-York City the coming week.

I am sorry to hear that Mr. Walter Besant is suffering from "writer's cramp," an affection of the muscles of the hand and arm which makes the act of writing at first painful and difficult, and afterward impossible.

PARIS, July 14.--The taking of the Bastile was celebrated throughout France to-day. In this city patriotic societies, accompanied by bands and carrying banners, marched to the Strasbury statue and deposited wreaths upon it.

His Highness Prince Bernard of SaxeWeimar, Duke of Saxony, is at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. He arrived in this city yesterday afternoon, and will remain here until July 24, when he sails for Liverpool en route for home.

NORTHFIELD, Mass., July 15.--The Moody Bible School was closed to-night. Much of the day was devoted to farewell exercises. Three hundred students remained throughout the session.

WASHINGTON, July 15.--Mr. Randall has passed a quiet and restful Sunday, and his family and physicians speak hopefully of his condition. There had been no return of the hemorrhages up to a late hour this evening, and this is an encouraging sign. Mr. Randall is still very weak, however, and is by no means out of serious danger.

GETTYSBURG, July 9.--The battlefield of Gettysburg covers 25 square miles and contains 16,000 acres. To the soldiers who fought on this field--to the whole country, almost, it can be said--this ground is sacred, yet of 16,000 acres all but 540 acres is private property.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 15.--Information obtained here shows that J.V. Charpentier, the defaulting notary, has gone to Mexico. Charles Sajony to-day filed a suit against Charpentier for $78,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15.--Chairman Matthew Stanley Quay of the National Republican Committee came up from Atlantic City this afternoon, and expects to leave for NewYork to-morrow morning, although he may be delayed until the afternoon.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 16.--Morris F. Leavitt of New-York, the nephew of President Franklin of the New-York Life Insurance Company, has of late been "doing up" unsuspecting residents of Kansas City. The particulars of his misdeeds have just been made public.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16.--The little village of Malvern, 21 miles out on the Pennsylvania Railroad, has a population of 400, fully 350 of whom are suffering with dysentery. There have been two deaths so far, and more may be expected, as in many cases entire families are prostrated.
The Empire Yacht Club, whose clubhouse has been at the foot of East One Hundred and Second-street, has been disbanded and its clubhouse and float foreclosed on by Harry Hill.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 16.--The second annual championship regatta of the Rhode Island Yacht Club was sailed to-day off Pawtuxet. The courses were twenty miles triangular for the first two classes and 10 miles for the small class.

The only absentee at the meeting of the Board of Electrical Control yesterday afternoon was Mayor Hewitt. He has not attended any of the sessions since it was decided to hold them at the Commissioners' office in the Wallack Theatre building.

EASTON, Penn., July 16.--To-day the one topic of conversation in this thriving city is the remarkable letter received by Mayor Chidsey on last Saturday, in which the heirs of William Penn, the original Quaker owner of Pennsylvania, claim the public square of the town.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 16.--Gen. Harrison passed a very quiet day; indeed, he had fewer callers to-day than on any day since his nomination, and the rest proved very grateful to him. He was at work in his library with his secretaries at his usual early hour this morning.

UTICA, N.Y., July 16.--A.S. Moak, who registered in the County Clerk's office of Fulton County as a practicing physician and as a graduate of Bellevue Hospital, has been arrested for perjury, it having been ascertained that he never received the degree of M.D. from Bellevue. He attempted to practice in Gloversville.

CHICAGO, July 16.--Nearly a month ago Willie and Henry Deichman, aged 10 and 11 years, and sons of William Deichman of 248 Hudson-avenue disappeared. PITTSBURG, Penn., July 16.--The statement that there was danger of a disruption of the Western Iron Association and that Mr. A. F. Keating would resign as President, has caused considerable comment in iron circles. Mr. Keating authorizes a statement which substantiates what was published.
WASHINGTON, July 16.--Judge Cooley, the Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, and Commissioner Morrison have returned to the city from the West, where they have been on official business.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16.--There was a much larger attendance than usual at the Casino dance this evening. A few of the prominent cottagers were present. The greater portion of the dancers was confined to army and navy officers and their families. The night was delightfully cool for dancing, and the music, there being no wind outside, could be heard a long distance.
PORTLAND, Me., July 16.--The Eastern Yacht Club left for Bar Harbor at 8:30 o'clock this morning.

The old unpleasantness between the active members of the Seventh Regiment and the Veterans has broken out in a new shape. About two years ago, in opposition to the Veterans, who are incorporated as the Veterans of the National Guard, Seventh Regiment, an association called the Honorable and Veteran Comrades of the Seventh Regiment was formed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 16.--George A. Macbeth Co., the chimney glass manufacturers of the south side, have about decided to remove their works to Belgium. Macbeth Co. have the largest chimney glass house in the United States, and probably in the world.

CARLISLE, Penn., July 16.--The State Sunday School Convention opened its sessions-- to continue for one week--at Williams Grove this morning by an address of welcome, delivered by the President.

ST. PETERSBURGH, July 16.--The royal yacht bearing the Czar and Czarina, who have been visiting Finland, passed Cronstadt at 5:30 P.M. to-day. The Czar will await the arrival of Emperor William off Cronstadt. The Emperor is expected to arrive about noon on the 19th inst.

MARIETTA, Ohio, July 16.--The second day of the centennial celebration opened with one hundred guns. The early trains and boats brought in great numbers; the attendance today is estimated at 10,000 strangers.

THREE RIVERS, July 6.--The story published regarding the suspension of Jesuit priests here is officially denied by Bishop Lafieche. The true facts simply are that some years ago two priests were engaged to teach at the Three Rivers Seminary at $400 a year.

That there is to be considerable of a shortage in sugar during this year is a certainty, and the sugar men are going to find considerable trouble filling all their orders.

Much excitement exists among the life insurance agents because of a report that the Life Insurance Association is preparing a black list of men in the business who are supposed to be unworthy the confidence of their associates and the companies.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 16.--The skeleton of a man, to which pieces of flesh still clung, was found Sunday afternoon in the woods at Westfield by William Dallas and C.M. Smith. It was that of a man about 5 feet 10 inches in height.

WACO, Texas, July 16.--Conrad Jackson, colored, was hanged here to-day for the murder of John Talley, a prominent white planter one year ago to-day. Talley had applied a strong epithet to Jackson's brother and in revenge Jackson walked up behind Talley while he was plowing and shot him in the head. Jackson was 19 years old. He made a confession this morning.

PARIS, July 16.--Gen-Boulanger's condition to-night is reported as unchanged. The doctors have forbidden him to speak. He wrote on a piece of paper to-day: "I am like the late Emperor." M. Floquet sends twice daily to inquire as to his progress. The doctors do not speak with great confidence as yet.

CARLISLE, Penn., July 16.--Some weeks ago a strike occurred at the only shoe factory in this city, which created considerable sensation, and about 30 of the girls employed left the works on account of the Foreman, Abram Keiter of Philadelphia, who, they alleged, treated them disrespectfully.

William Seward, Jr., will not tender his resignation as Colonel of the Ninth Regiment for three or four weeks yet, or until after all expenses attending the celebration at Gettysburg have been settled.

William Maier, a lamp trimmer, who lived at 97 Stanton-street, and was employed by the Adams Express Company, was found dead yesterday afternoon in the dynamo rooms of the company's building, 59 Broadway.

Plans for the new armory of the Twentysecond Regiment, to be erected on the block between Ninth-avenue and the Boulevard and Sixtyseventh and Sixty-eighth streets, were received yesterday by the regiment's special committee from four architects.

NORFOLK, Va. July 16.--The Chowan and Southern Railroad Company, of which George S. Scott of the Richmond and Danville system is President, to-day paid the $45,000 purchase money for the terminal which the combination of the Richmond and Danville and Atlantic Coast line systems is to use here.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 16.--Another case of the imposition of the insane of the old country upon the charity of this occurred to-day at the office of Chief Elliott of the Department of Charities.

When the steamship Erin of the National Line from London reached Quarantine yesterday Capt. Tyson reported that during the voyage two of the crew had been murdered in their berths in cold blood by one of their shipmates. The murderer was then heavily chained in a room in the after deck house, where he had been ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 16.--Second VicePresident E.B. Thomas of the Erie Railway, whose headquarters are here, was shown to-day the report that President King had resigned the Presidency and was to be succeeded by Mr. Thomas.

BRUSSELS, July 16.--Col. Sir Francis de Winton, President of the Emin Bey Relief Committee, in an interview with the King of the Belgians expressed the belief that the white Pasha reported to have arrived at Bahr-el-Gazel is Henry M. Stanley.

UTICA, N.Y., July 16.--The body of Roscoe Conkling was removed this afternoon from the receiving vault and interred in the Seymour lot in Forest Hill Cemetery. Mrs. Conkling and Judge A.C. Coxe were the only relatives present. The grave was lined with flowers. The coffin was not opened.

On the 4th inst., when Wellington T. Hall, Treasure of the Casino, was dying at 1,558 Broadway, Robert Knox, Jr., of 246 Vanderbilt-avenue, Brooklyn, was left in charge of him, and appropriated his watch and chain, which was worth $250.

PATERSON, N.J., July 16.--General Manager W.W. Evans of the Grant Locomotive Works in this City says it is the present intention of the management to receive no more orders for locomotives and to close the works as soon as the work on hand is finished, which will be in about three weeks.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July. 16.--A yearling chestnut filly, by Onondaga, out of Perhaps, by Australian, made a sensational performance at the association track this morning, she running a quarter of a mile in 0:23 .

From his asylum in the salubrious and peaceful precincts of Canada, where the courts of New-York can't reach him, John Keenan directs and serenely watches the efforts of his counsel, Col. George Bliss, to manipulate the process of those courts in aid of the collection of an interest he claims in the aqueduct contracts of Heman Clark and O'Brien Clark.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 16.--Gen. Chamberlain, Warden of the State prison in Wethersfield, says there is no foundation for the story that Coffey, who is serving a life sentence for the murder of Station Agent Way of the Shore Line Road, has expressed a desire since his imprisonment to make a confession.

A statement that the new Staten Island ferryboat Robert Garrett was a flat failure as far as speed is concerned, and that her paddles are set so low as to impede her, was denied yesterday by Erastus Wiman, the lessee of the ferry.

The usual large number of people attended Koster Bial's Concert Hall last evening. The change of programme was well received, the musical selections being of a popular and pleasing nature.

The 120 acres of level land by the sea, which are used by the New-Jersey National Guard as an encampment at sea Girt during the Summer, are just now being treated as a big hay farm under the paternal care of Quartermater-Gen. Perrine.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 16.--Miss Gertie Smith, youngest daughter of Henry Smith, left this city on Saturday morning and is now in Boston, it is believed, in company with a Baptist minister who has deserted his wife. Mr. Smith is wealthy and a member of the Halifax Club, and his family moves in the very best society.

Mr. J.F. Loubat, formerly of this city, and now residing in Paris, has written a letter in further justification of the position taken by him as regards Henry Turnbull.
