It is not likely that the most sanguine friends of the Mills bill expected so decisive a triumph for its principle as was achieved in the decision of the House by 120 votes to 102 that wool should be put upon the free list. What is especially gratifying is that the Democrats voted solidly in favor of repealing the duty.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 16.--The German Liederkranz Society of New-York, numbering 150 voices, arrived in Saratoga at 6 o'clock this evening from Lake George, where they gave a concert last evening at the Fort William Henry Hotel.

WARSAW, N.Y., July 16.--Five weeks ago to-day a short, round, red-faced man, not propossessing in looks, came to Warsaw and secured board of Mrs. C.H. Dann. He there became acquainted with William H. McConnell, an insurance agent.
Freight agents are now afraid of a still further reduction in rates, and it was said yesterday that in a few days rail and lake rates from New-York to Chicago would go down a few more points.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 16.--Delegates to the convention of the New-York State Hotel Association, to be held in this city to-morrow and Wednesday, are already arriving in the city.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16.--A new tariff bill has been proposed by the New-Zealand Government which will considerably diminish the large free list now in existence there and increase small ad valorem duties.
Yesterday afternoon the Commissioners in the lunacy case of Joseph Muhr, jeweler, junior member of H. Muhr's Sons, Philadelphia, impaneled a Sheriff's jury to determine the man's mental condition.

ALBANY, July 16.--Gov. Hill will be lucky if he does not find, before this special session is ended, that he has been hoist with his own petard. He is represented to be in a more serious frame of mind to-night than at any time since Cleveland was renominated, and he devoted the day to running down that gentleman's luck and belittling him as the leader of the party.

WASHINGTON, July 16.--In the consideration the fishery treaty today in open executive session, the Senate was addressed by Mr. Pugh in favor of its ratification. He said that Republican Senators assailed the treaty, but did not propose any amendment to it. They only proposed to exercise the power of rejecting it and of closing the door to further negotiations.

DENVER, Col., July 16.--The express train on the Fort Worth Road went through a bridge near Clarendon Saturday night. Engineer Nick Smith and Fireman James Wilson were killed. None of the passengers were injured.

CINCINNATI, July 16.--Prosecuting Attorney Pugh and Detective Ryan of the Prosecutor's office left here this evening for NewYork for the purpose of arresting and bringing here Henry C. Ives, George H. Stayner, and E. Wilson Woodruff.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 16.--A pardon was granted to-night to George N. Bumm, convicted of conspiracy to defraud the Shackamaxon Bank in Philadelphia, while President of that institution. His case that been under consideration since its argument before the Board of Pardons in June. The application was strongly endorsed by a great array of names, including those of many prominent citizens and officials.
On the 27th of last month, near Constantinople, the closing exercises of Roberts College took place, with appropriate ceremonies. Mr. Straus, the United States Minister to Turkey, presiding.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 17.--A few weeks ago about 20 warrants were issued by Justice Borland of Cape Vincent, for the arrest of fishermen who, it was alleged, had violated the fish laws by setting nets in the St. Lawrence River.

LONDON, July 17.--Evictions on the Vandeleur estate in West Clare will begin tomorrow, and this will not tend to soothe the present feverish state of party feeling. One hundred and fourteen families, representing 1,000 people, are to be turned out of their homes for refusing to pay what they deem exorbitant rents.

The Poughkeepsie Bridge over the Hudson River will be ready for use by next November, and the announcement is made that the New-York Central Railroad has made a contract by which it acquires right of way for its tracks over the structure.

CHICAGO, July 17.--Telegrams received at the general offices of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad to-day conveyed the intelli gence of the death at San Francisco of H.P. Stanwood, the General Agent of that company on the Pacific Coast. Mr. Stanwood, who was best known to all his railway friends and acquaintances as the "Deacon" had been identified with the service of the Chicago and Northwestern Road for over 25 years.

CARLISLE, Penn., July 17.--About one year ago Richard Murphy, who was employed in an ore bank at Mount Holly, near this city, disappeared from home. Last evening Abraham Lutz of Boiling Springs, while on the South Mountain picking berries, discovered part of his remains. Near by was a coat and hat, and on a tree his shirt was hanging. It is thought that he was foully dealt with.
MONTREAL, July 17.--Charles A. Pitcher, late Teller at the Union Bank of Providence, was arraigned this morning on a charge of bringing stolen money into Canada.
Nicol, Cowlishaw Co., importers of upholstery goods at Broadway and Eighteenthstreet, New-York, and at London and Manchester, England, have failed.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 17.--The weather continues cool and pleasant, but the arrivals are few. Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Morgan of New-York have taken the G.G. King cottage for the remainder of the season.

SARATOGA, July 17.--Police Justice Henry Murray of New-York came here to-day for the purpose of making arrangements for himself and family to spend August at the Grand Union. The Judge was sunburned and happy. He seemed at peace with all the world, until the correspondent of THE TIMES spoke to him concerning the stories published in the New-York morning newspapers relating to his difficulties with the Knights of Labor.

CINCINNATI, July 17.--Judge Goebel of the Probate Court to-day refused the applications of two women for licensee to perform marriages. The women were Spiritualists.

The changes which are in progress at the Star Theatre will make of that house practically a new theatre. An army of workmen are engaged and scarcely a stick of the old interior now remains, except on the stage.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--The fourth report of the Civil Service Commission has been completed and placed in the hands of the President for transmission to Congress. It contains 731 printed pages, and not only covers the transactions of the Commission from Jan. 16, 1886, to June 30, 1887, the period specifically covered by the report, but gives a detailed resume of the work of the commission since Jan. 16, ...

A large number of people attended the annual picnic and games of the Clan-na-Gael, which were held yesterday afternoon and evening at Jones's Wood, Sixty-ninth-street and East River. The athletic games, which began at 3 o'clock, were limited to members.

RED BANK, N.J., July 17.--The first pennant race of the season of the North shrewsbury River Yacht Club was sailed to-day. The wind blew moderately from the southeast. The following yachts started: Herman Duryea's Twilight, John Warden's No Name, Clinton James's Undine, and Charles Burd's Annie B. Duryea's yacht won easily, and holds the championship pennant.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., July 17.--Peter Robbins, a lime-kiln burner, met with a horrible death at Smith's stone quarry, near here, yesterday. He was filling the kiln with lime and somehow fell in the pit. His cries were heard, but he was burned to death before he could be extricated. The body was charred beyond recognition.

Freight business among the different lines is beginning to show signs of still further demoralization. The rates to Colorado points on a basis of $2.24 for first-class, which were to have been raised July 16 to a basis of $2.91, are still in effect.

NORFOLK, Va., July 17.--The British steamship Darwin reports: Last Sunday, about 30 miles south west of Fen wick Island, passed the schooner Ida C. Schoolcraft heading north with all masts gone and proceeding under jury masts and sails. The schooner was loaded with lumber. Although persons were seen on deck, no answer was received when the vessel was hailed.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 17.--Forest fires are doing considerable damage and threatening to do more in the vicinity of Carthage, this (Jefferson) County. Part of the tramway leading from the Carthage and Adirondack Railroad to Rhodes's Mill has been burned, and thousands of feet of logs, besides considerable standing timber, have been destroyed. Gangs of men watch the mills and woods night and day.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 17.--The Government is still dickering with the Northern Pacific people, and so for the contract has not been signed. The contract provides that the Northern Pacific is to purchase the Red River Valley Road, which the Government ...
Mayor Hewitt was at home on sick furlough all day yesterday, suffering from a severe headache.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 17.--The machinery of the great silk mill of the Phoenix Manufacturing Company in this city was started this morning. The mill has been one year in construction, is the most extensive and completely-equipped establishment of the kind in the country, cost $250,000, and will employ 1,000 operatives.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 17.--The second break in the canal at Adams Basin will not be repaired before Thursday night, and boats will not move before Friday evening. Boats continally are congregating on both sides. Water will be let in slowly to-morrow from the level below this city. Superintendent Shanahan intends to move slowly, but surely, this time.

Morris F. Leavitt, the young man who got cash for bogus checks from a boarding house keeper in Kansas City, as related in a dispatch in THE TIMES yesterday, is the son of R.W. Leavitt, who has an office in the Boreel Building.

George F. Murray, Chairman of the Executive Board of District Assembly No. 48, Knights of Labor, has issued a circular to the local assemblies connected with that district assembly, stating that the General Executive Board had decided to sustain Master Workman James E. Quinn against the district court.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 17.--The Union County authorities are making very determined efforts to unravel the mystery surrounding the death of the man whose skeleton was found last Sunday in the woods at Westfield.

SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., July 17.--Six schooners and 17 sloops started in the special race of the Atlantic Yacht Club from New-London to this place to-day. The fleet included the sloops Shamrock, Katrina, and Fanny.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 17.--At Marion, the county seat of Crittenden County, Ark., to-day, Judge J.E. Riddick charged the Grand Jury to discover and indict for conspiracy the persons who sent the treatening letters to white citizens of the county, which gave rise to the recent race troubles. ROCHSTER, N.Y., July 17.--Something new in the line of conventions, a gathering of all the leading Bonifaces of the Empire State, began in this city to-day. President D.W. Garrison of New-York called the first session to order in the Chamber of Commerce rooms at 10 o'clock this morning.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 17.--A fatal collision on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad occurred at 3:55 o'clock this morning, seven miles south of this city.

Hopper, a contractor, engaged in blasting rocks on West One Hundred and Twenty-seventhstreet, and its disastrous effects were widespread. Large pieces of rock were thrown for several blocks and caused great consternation among the residents and considerable damage to the adjacent houses.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17.--The British steamer Benison was sold to-day under the act of Congress limiting the liability of ship owners for $40,500, to John H. Ward of New-York.
MEXICO, Mo., July 17.--W.S. Mosby, the Prosecuting Attorney of this county, was shot and killed in a mysterious manner late last night.

ALBANY, July 17.--The Brooklyn and NewYork Ferry Company reports to the Controller that its earnings for the year ending June 30 were $912,702 68. On this amount the State receives $4,563 51 as taxes.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--"We're getting very weary of the free whisky cry over here," said Mr. Mason of Illinois during the debate on the Tariff bill in the House of Representatives to-day, and before he could say another word the Democrats raised a perfect storm of cheers, cat calls, and derisive laughter.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 17.--Chautauqua has now a population of 5,000. The gate receipts for the first two weeks are $2,000 larger than at any similar period in previous seasons.

LONDON, July 17.--Many English and Scotch Gladstonians are preparing an address expressing sympathy with Mr. John Dillon.

ANNOPOLIS, Md., July 17.--The naval court-martial resumed its inquiry to-das and the case of Naval Cadet B.B. Bierer was taken up. Naval Cadet George Mallison testifled that June 18 he was told by the accused to report to him, which he did. He was told to go and stand on his head in the washroom.
PITTSBURG, July 17.--Glass manufacturers is this city do not take much stock in the statement of George M. McBeth that his firm will remove to Belgium.

A number of active members of the yachting department of the Staten Island Athletic Club propose to give an open-to-all sweepstakes regatta in the Fall.

CHICAGO, July 17.--Hydrophobia cases are becoming comparatively numerous in this city. Elsie Kelly, a child 3 years old, died to-day of the disease at her home, 302 Michigan-avenue. She was bitten a few weeks ago by a dog owned by a carpenter named Everden. Daniel Moriarity, a laborer, died in convulsions at the City hospital a few days ago.
ALBANY, July 17.--Sea Cliff, Queens County, is agitated over the destruction of her oaks, and has sent to State Entomologist Lintner a number of twigs broken off by the wind.

A philosopher sat one day in his easy chair after dinner enjoying a cigar when the idea occurred to him that he would lake to know why people smoke.

The fate of the Madison-Square Theatre has been decided, and within the next four years at least the house will cease to exist except in the memory of the triumphs which have been achieved within its walls, which old playgoers of this city will not soon forget.

CHICAGO, July 17.--An Anarchist plot of the most desperate character was revealed today when the police swooped down upon a band of conspirators and lodged the leaders in jail. They made their raid just in time, for the Anarchists had set the murder of Judge Gary, Judge Grinnell, Inspector Bonfield, and Chief of Police Hubbard for to-morrow night.
TORONTO, July 17.--Last Friday William Lee, a burly follow 25 years of age, was sent to jail by the police magistrate for three months for assaulting his wife.

PARIS, July 17.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Lecointre presented a report on the subject of the revision of the Constitution. He suggested that the report be referred to the Revision Committee, and the suggestion was adopted.

DELAWARE BREAKWATER, Del., July 17 --The schooner Ida C. Schoolcraft, from Darien June 26, for Philadelphia, was towed into this harbor this evening by the United States revenue cutter Hamilton with her masts and all attached carried away. She was taken in tow here by a tug and proceeded to Philadelphia.
The semi-annual meeting of the National Association of General Baggage Agents will be held at the Murray Hill Hotel to-day and to-morrow.
The three feet of George Butchford's shoemaking shop on Webster-street, Newark, which encroached on Mrs. Anna Breslin's grounds, was sawed off by Deputy Sheriff Benedict yesterday.

PARIS, July 17.--The explorer Burton, in an interview here, stated that he believes the White Pasha who has arrived in the Bahr-elGazel Province is Emin Bey, and not Henry M. Stanley. He thinks that Emin Bey is striking northward. Mr. Burton is of opinion that Stanley's force is not strong enough to attempt an attack upon Khartoum.

OTTAWA, July 17.--The Evening Journal semi-officially announces that the United States Executive has intimated a willingness to agree to England's proposition made nearly a year ago for the appointment of a mixed commission ...

DETROIT, July 17.--The assignment of N. Cordary of Ypsilanti was a great surprise to people there. He is an old man, who has been in business there for many years, and was well known. He was supposed to be worth $50,000. Of this sum $30,000 is found to be in his wife's name. His liabilities are reported at $50,000; available assets, $20,000 to $30,000.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 17.--A queer swindle has just been attempted on a Leroy lady. Mrs. C.B. Thomson, widow of the editor of the Leroy Gazette, was left by her husband's death a fine residence in Leroy.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 17.--Most of the delegates to the Republican State Convention arrived in the city-to-night, and indications point to a large attendance upon the session, which will begin at noon to-morrow.

ERIE, Penn., July 17.--At to-day's session of the United States District Court Ryan Dobberman, a leading citizen of Snyder County and an infirm man of 73 years, was convicted of forging papers to secure a pension for another, and was sentenced to one year in the Snyder County Jail. Dobberman was much broken down and is quite ill.
ST. LOUIS, July 17.--H.W. Thurman, son of Allen G. Thurman, arrived in the city to-day. "Does your father expect," he was asked, "that the Democratic ticket will carry Ohio?"

DETROIT, Mich., July 17.--The mystery surrounding the explosion in the City Hall yesterday has been explained to the satisfaction of most people. A careful examination made by the Superintendent of the gas company reveals the probable cause.

CHICAGO, July 17.--Chief Arthur left Chicago to-night without having effected a compromise with the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy officials. That no settlement can be brought about is by no means settled, and, in fact. Mr. Arthur is to come back about the end of the week and renew the negotiations.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 17.--Mr. W.W. Gibbs of Philadelphia, President of the Poughkeepsie Bridge Company, arrived here this afternoon and is the guest of Mr. E.N. Howell, the wealthy shoe manufacturer.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17.--The many people who visited the wharf at Canonicut Island upon the arrival of the steamer from Newport on every trip to-day, hoping to catch a glimpse of Mrs. Cleveland who, it was reported, would arrive at this time, turned away in disappointment ...

Monday's stock market reaction was "healthy," sure enough. Yesterday's activity and buoyancy proved that, for yesterday was the star day of this whole year from a Stock Exchange point of view. There were rising quotations on every side. Not one stock worthy of attention lost even a fraction from its price, save in one or two exceptions, where local and extraordinary influences were exerted. It was a day to make the bear heart sad overwhelmingly.

Democratic meetings were the order of the day in this city yesterday. Last week the Republicans had their inning, and the Democrats who yesterday invaded the city acted in marked contrast with their Republican rivals.

Thirty members were entered for the club tournaments of the Staten Island Cricket and Tennis Club on the ground at Livingston on Monday. The first and second rounds were finished yesterday. Only three of the four numbers in the third could be played on account of darkness, and Messrs. S. Frothingham and P. ...

ALBANY, July 17.--De Lancey Nicoll is here to intercede with Gov. Hill in behalf of the condemned Italian woman, Chiara Cignarale. He has presented a petition urging a commutation of her sentence to imprisonment for life, ...

CONCORD, N.H., July 17.--Charles H. Nudd, the stock broker, who was arrested for keeping a gambling place, was to-day ordered to give bonds for his appearance at the higher court. Judge Badger held that dealing is margins was gambling within the meaning of the statutes.

Charles A. Johnes, the Wall-street speculator whose grave illness was reported in THE TIMES yesterday shows no sign of improvement, being inclined to resent the orders of his physicians to leave the stock market alone.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17.--When the British King sails at 7 o'clock to-morrow morning from this port to Liverpool she will be in charge of a pilot from the pilotboat Turley.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 17.--The prolitic onion-growing belt west of the Hudson River extends in an irregular succession of fields from Madison County southeast through Chenango, Delaware, and Orange Counties, N.Y., and Sussex, Morris, and Warren Counties, N.J.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 17.--Mr. Albert Tower of this city a short time ago gave $60,000 toward paying for the new Christ Church of this city, and he has just given an additional $25,000 for a new tower for the church, making his gift $85,000 in all.

To properly understand the tariff question it must be ever borne in mind that during the 50 years last past the world has been greatly contracted by steam and electricity, and that peoples once widely separated have been brought close togetner. Political and industrial theories that were soundly held by intelligent men 30, 40, or 50 years ago are not sound to-day. Then the country was sparsely settled.

A great many interesting stories are afloat about the sensational testimony which will be given before the Senate Committee when it resumes its investigations into the building of the new aqueduct after the close of the extra session of the Legislature.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 17.--The violators of the Sunday law have thus far taken advantage of the determination of the police authorities to make no arrest on Sunday, and have on Monday had themselves arrested and taken before a Justice of ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 17.--The Shotwell, Clerihew Lothman examination was continued in the Municipal Court to-day with Mr. Shotwell, the firm's financier, on the stand. He made some damaging admissions about the astonishing way in which the firm's liabilities had increased $200,000 between the December and the June statements. It was admitted that the statement given to a commercial agency Feb. 1 was not within $200,000 of the true figures.

BOSTON, July 17.--The session of the National Prison Association to-day began with the address by R.H. Dawson of Alabama, exPresident Hayes being in the Chair. Mr. Dawson said the lease system must go where slavery had gone. The present Governor was in full sympathy with prison reform and the penitentiary is being thoroughly remodeled.

Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry in a general order issued from the flagship Electra, dated July 16, has taken formal command of the squadron of the New-York Yacht Club, and has reappointed Gouverneur Kortright as Fleet Captain.
The North German Lloyd steamship Fulda, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, ran down an unknown fishing schooner on the Banks of Newfoundland last Saturday morning.

ALBANY, July 17.--The extra session opened at 11 o'clock, the Senators occupying their comfortable chamber, the Assemblymen crowding into the chamber of the Court of Appeals, whose carved furniture had been replaced by cane-seated swivel chairs picked so closely together as to admit of no such conveniences as desks.

CARLISLE, Penn., July 17.--A.F. Mullin, the paper manufacturer of Mount Holly Springs, who was nominated for Congress by the Prohibitionists of the Nineteenth Pennsylvania District, composed of the counties of York, Cumberland, and Adams, in a letter to-day to the Chairman of the convention, declined to accept the nomination owing to his large business interests.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 17.--Charles B. Matthews has been one of the most energetic and successful fighters the Standard Oil Company and its various interests has had for years.

LONDON, July 17.--Queen Victoria has purchased the villa Palmieri at Florence, which she occupied during her recent sojourn in that city. The amount paid for the property was 24,000. The report that the villa had been purchased by Queen Natalie was erroneous.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 17.--A St. Augustine special reports that a big waterspout struck that city this afternoon, tearing up things generally.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17.--At a private sitting before Judge Baker this afternoon Mr. John Whippie, charged with assaulting Mr. John Lawrence, was fined $10 and costs, and his partner, Richard C. Derby, was fined $5 and costs.

VERA CRUZ, July 17, via Galveston.--The Government is proceeding with increased energy against editors. Belem Prison now contains seven, including the managing editors and proprietors of the El Nacional and El Tiempo. The courts refuse to accept bail in all cases of offenses by the press.

CHICAGO, July 17.--The lull in the dressed beef war was not broken to-day. The Erie and the Chicago and Atlantic were allowed to quote their differential rate of 6 cents per 100 pounds, while the Vanderbilt and Pennsylvania ...

Michael Dunphy of 133 Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn, while intoxicated shot and killed his half-brother, John Dunphy, yesterday afternoon, and then shot himself.

There was a fairly good attendance at the Yonkers races yesterday. The finishes were close and the betting fair.

The west side merchants, belonging mainly to the Mercantile Exchange, who did effective anti-Blaine work through their organization in the last Presidential campaign, formed the nucleus yesterday of a similar organization, which will be known as the West Side Business Men's Cleveland and Thurman Club.
PITTSBURG, July 17.--The first day at the Exposition Park races was a most brilliant one overhead, but notwithstanding this fact the grand stand and ground contained less than 2,000 people.
BERLIN, July 17.--The yacht Hohenzollern, which has on board Emperor William, passed Memel at 7 o'clock last evening.
BELVIDERE, N.J., July 17.--The contest over the will of Robert Blair, the brother of the railroad millionaire, John I. Blair, was begun in the Warren County Orphans' Court this morning.

There was published in this city last Fall a description of the contents of a tin box in which was stored the property left by a father to his children. There were in the box certificates for 7,744 shares of stock, and nearly all of these shares had been issued and sold by silver or gold mining companies.
The impulse that led the Mayor to make an appeal for HARTT is an honorable one, which everybody must share who has followed the history of HARTT'S case.

SARATOGA, July 17.--The members of the German Liederkranz Society after the concert in Congress Springs Park last evening sat on the rear pinzzas of Congress Hall, sang songs, and drank beer on draught until after midnight.
SCRANTON, Penn., July 17.--The breaker of the Dunn Colliery in Old Forge, on the outskirts of Scranton, caught fire this evening at 7:30 o'clock, and in a short time was burned to the ground.

The Philadelphia correspondent of the New-York Herald has sent to that paper a report of an interview with two members of the firm of WILLIAM AYRES SONS, manufacturers of woolens--chiefly blankets--in that city. The firm does an extensive business and employs from 1,200 to 1,500 men.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 17.--William Astor's steam yacht Nourmahal arrived last evening and sailed on a sea bass fishing cruise.

Boldt, James P. Cooper, Theodore C. Engel, Louis Hammerslough, Richard, Krieg, John B. Lingg, Albert G. Liscomb, the Rev. G.W. Mayer, Charles M. Reynolds, Dr. E. Struve, and J. Lippitt Snow.

The new play written by David Belasco and H.C. De Mille for E.H. Sothern, and to be produced at the Lyceum Theatre next month, has been named "Lord Chumley; or, the Knight of Lummy Tum."

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18.--After a dead-lock of three months the Republican Congressional conferees of the Twenty-fourth District met this afternoon and nominated J. Warren Ray of Greene County. Over 200 ballots were taken before the break occurred.

Pernicious reading and bad company caused seven young boys in the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn, to organize a marauding gang, and they styled themselves the "Young Roosters." For a month they have been committing petty robberies.

JACKSON, Miss., July 18.--The Mississippi State Prohibition Convention met in the hall of the House of Representative at 11:30 A.M., and was called to order by B.T. Hobbs, Secreretary of the State Executive Committee.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 18.--The fleet is assembling at Cronstadt to meet the Emperor Willaim of Germany. The fleet consists of 40 war ships, and among them are the iron-class Minin, carrying flag Admiral Popoff, and the Duke of Edinburgh, carrying flag Admiral ...

BOSTON, July 18.--A Tufts College student rully deserves the title of the Charley Bates of real life. He was recently arrested for picking pockets, and at the police station gave the name of Fisher Thompson.
ST. LOUIS, July 18.--The big tunnel that connects the bridge with the Union Railroad Station was the scene of a terrible accident this evening.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 18.--The biennial meeting of the Expressmen's Mutual Benefit Association began to-day, President Henry W. Dwight of Boston in the chair.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., July 18.--Delegates from every district in the State to the State Prohibition Convention assembled at the Opera House shortly after noon to-day, and were called to order by the State Central Committee promptly at 2 o'clock.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 18.--The ghastly discovery by two Westfield men on Sunday afternoon is likely to prove a murder as mysterious as the famous Rahway case of a year ago. County Physician Westcott came to Casey's morgue in this city to-day and made a careful examination of the skeleton.

JEFFERSON, Ohio, July 18.--A very sad drowning accident occurred here to-day, Gracie Enfield, Myrtee Chandler, and Carrie Bartlett, daughters of Dr. Charles Enfield, W.D. Chandler, and Prof. M. Bartlett, respectively, losing their lives while bathing in Coon River. The two first-named were about 13 years old and Carrie Bartlett about 11. Prof. Bartlett is the conductor of the musical normal now in session.

Thirty-six baggage agents, representing over 50 railroad corporations, assembled at the Murray Hill Hotel for the semi-annual meeting of the National Association of General Baggage Agents. Among them were J.B. Browning of the Louisville and Nashville, (President of the association;) ...

The campaign muse of the Sun swept the string somewhat loudly yesterday morning. The burden of her song was praise of Gov. HILL, who is one of the few Democrats now living with whom the Sun finds itself in sympathy.

LONDON, July 18.--The steamer Sestos from Newport for Bilbao arrived at Falmouth to-day. She has a hole in her starbeard bow, her stem is damaged, and she is otherwise injured. She had been in collision with the British flagship Agincourt of the Channel Squadron, which was engaged in maneuvres. The Agincourt's starboard boats and anchor chain were swept away. She continued her maneuvres.

Otto Alexander pleaded guilty to a charge of forgery in General Sessions yesterday, and was remanded for sentence by Recorded Smyth.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 18.--The outlook for the corn and peanut crops in the adjoining counties is discouraging.

The New-Jersey State legislative committee, which has been engaged for sometime past in investigating the charges made against the management of the Morris Plains Insane Asylum, finished its work at the asylum building at Morris Plains yesterday.

ALBANY, July 18.--Gov. Hill's political career is marked by another extraordinary act. and one which is regarded with amazement by both friends and enemies. He has gone on record as a public man who sympathizes with unlawful acts of Knights of Labor, and who would ...

CARLISLE, Penn., July 18.--There is no change in the situation of the strike at the shoe factory. The Board of Directors, at a meeting held to-day, decided to retain the obnoxious foreman. The strikers say they will not return to work unless Keiter and his wife both go out.

NORWALK, Conn., July 18.--One of the prettiest and most aristocratic society events that have occurred in westport, this season was the marriage this afternoon of Miss Agues May, eldest, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. A.N. Lewis, and Neil Read Mitchell, a rising young artist of New-York City.
WOODSTOCK, New-Brunswick, July 18.-- Grafton, opposite Woodstock, is in flames. Fully 200 people are homeless. The fire is spreading and the entire village seems doomed to destruction.
OLATHE, Kan., July 18.--Deputy Sheriffs Hannibal Campbell and Frank P. Hollenbock were arrested here last night for the murder of John P. Reardon at Round Prairie schoolhouse, nine miles ...

BALTIMORE, July 18.--Dr. W.K. Brooks of Johns Hopkins University has been appointed a naturalist of the United States Fish Commission for the Summer. Major McDonald, the Fish Commissioner, has placed at his disposal one of the vessels belonging to the commission, and a ...

Henry Ebert was hanged in the Hudson County Jail on Jersey City Heights yesterday morning for the murder of his young wife on Nov. 27 last at his home on Paterson-avenue. Ebert has claimed ever since the murder that his wife shot herself and then shot him, or that he had no recollection of the crime.
BOSTON, July 18.--The Boston Citizens' Association won in their first tilt with the junketing element in the City Government.

PARIS, July 18.--Gen. Boulanger is worse to-day and the doctors were summoned to a consultation. The relapse, however, was of a temporary nature, and at midnight he was better. Therefore no bulletin was issued. During the day be received several friends, including M. Roehefort, and conversed at intervals on politics.
FRANKFORT, Ky., July 18.--The most youthful white criminal over confined within the penitentiary was brought here yesterday.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 18.--Halifax has just been visited by a dashing Yankee swindler traveling under the name of M.R. Miller, and pretending to be a son of Judge Miller.

RONDOUT, N.Y., JulY 18.--Driven from port to port, the unhealthy boom of David B. Hill has drifted into harbor, where it ought to be sure of a hearty welcome, and is. Tender hands guided it here to-day, and finally took it in doors, where it could be neither sunburned nor sunstruck.

W.H. Nichols has resigned from the Twentieth Ward Republican Association of Brooklyn because he cannot support the Republican platform on the tariff question. He was President of the Young Men's Republican Club in 1884, when he withdraw to support Cleveland.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18.--To-day's events included a fair number of arrivals, several cottage entertainments, a polo match, and a serious accident to Rudolph Agassiz, son of Prof. Alexander Agassiz, one of the contestants.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 18.--The $5,000 worth of railroad bonds obtained from Thomas Cook of this city four weeks ago by "bunko" men have been returned to him. It is understood the bonds were returned through a compromise.
WASHINGTON, July 18.--The leave of absence of Major Charles T. Wilson, Paymaster, has been extended one month.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., July 18.--A peculiar coincidence in the dates of birth of the whole family of Samuel Shilling of Berks County, Penn., has just received attention, and brought him into such prominence that the name of the corner Post Office has been changed to "Shillington" in his honor.

The Wine and Spirit Traders' Society of New-York held a meeting recently, at which most of the representative wholesale liquor dealers were present, to make arrangements for the convention of the National Protective Association of Wholesale Wine and Spirit Dealers, which will be held at Chickering Hall in this city Sept. 11, 12, and 13.
William Leland, or "Kid" Waring, an ex-convict, was arrested yesterday for burglary, and he had in his pockets articles of jewelry stolen July 2 at 973 Washington-avenue, ...

MONTREAL, July 18.--A grocer named Aidas Renaud made a determined attempt to commit suicide on the Longueuil wharf this afternoon. He beat his head against a snubbing post until he was covered with blood.
The behavior of the Fassett Committee will be watched with great curiosity from this time forth. Thus far the committee has merely scratched the surface of the aqueduct scandal.

CHICAGO, July 18--Alexander Smith, one of the prisoners in the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy dynamite case, waived further examination to-day and dropped out. J.Q. Wilson, another, proved to be John Mulligan, a Pinkerton detective, and the charge against him was dismissed ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 18.--The Secretary of the Board of Agriculture has received information of the action of the farmers of Crawford County, who have resolved not to raise any wheat, barley, or rye for the next three years in an effort to exterminate the chinch bug. These farmers will exert their influence to this end with the farmers of adjoining counties.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 18.--The unusually dry weather that has prevailed throughout Northern New-York for the past six weeks besides ruining the hay crop has resulted in a large loss to farmers and others by fire.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18.--The eighteenth annual session of the New-Jersey Dental Society convened to-day at the West End Hotel. There were nearly 100 dentists present, and many more are expected to-morrow. The President, J. Carlton Brown of Elizabeth, presided. The morning session was devoted to routine business and the afternoon to the clinics.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18.--Jacob Reiff, a gray-haired retired farmer 75 years old, from Centre Square, five miles from Norristown, came to Philadelphia to-day with Chief of Police Rodenbaugh of Norristown to hunt for two fascinating bunko men who had fleeced him out of $10,000 worth of negotiable railroad bonds.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18.--A Director of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad, who is also an official of the New-York Central, says that work on the South Pennsylvania will begin as soon as the minor details of the reorganization of the Reading are completed.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 18.--An explosion ocourred in the Court House of Athens, Tenn., to-day. The County Register was at work with a dental vulcanizer when it exploded. A Mr. Farrington had his arm broken, the building was badly damaged, and the reports as loud as a cannot caused great excitement in the city.

Judge O'Brien has appointed Daniel P. Ingraham, Dr. Cyrus Edson, and Edward C. Sheehy to be a commission to examine into the mental condition of Moritz Trauman. Mr. Trauman was in business in this city.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 18.--Cleveland won again to-day, much to every one's surprise, by good batting and sharp fielding.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 18.--Today at Mooresburg, in this State, a young man named Bird, while drunk, tried to shoot two men and failed. He then shot his own brother, and as the wounded man fell placed a pistol to his own head and blew out his brains.

The amendment to the by-laws of the Cotton Exchange permitting the Managers to order holidays was balloted upon yesterday and defeated by a vote of 61 to 45. Considerable electioneering was done on both sides of the question, and the election was a lively one.
OTTAWA July 18.--Col. Herchmer, Commissioner of the Northwest Mounted Police, is here discussing the Indian question with the Government.

PITTSBURG, July 18.--The conference committee of the Western Iron Association met this afternoon and formally surrendered to the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers in the following resolution, which was adopted without a dissenting voice:

BOSTON, July 18.--The latest developments show that the Rev. O.D. Kimball of West Newton, whose singular confession recently upset the Leominster church people, was moved by fear rather than contrition.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 18.--The city manufacturers are greatly excited over the assessment which has just been placed on city property. New-Brunswick always pays a tax of nearly 4 per cent., but it has been the boast of the city authorities that the 4 per cent. tax means actually, with a three-fifths valuation, not more than 1 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 18.--Dr. Malcolm McNeill, Assistant Professor of Astronomy at Princeton, has accepted a call to the Professorship of Astronomy and Mathematics in Lake Forest University, Illinois. He graduated at Princeton in 1877.
Mrs. Garfield, widow of the President, has given $10,000 to Garfield University at Wichita.

CHICAGO, July 18.--John Hronck, Frank Chapek, and Frank Chleboun or Chibowa, the Anarchists charged with plotting to kill Judge Gary and other public officers, were taken before Justice Lyon to-day and put under $5,000 bonds each.

SARATOGA, July 18.--One of the longest and finest drives about Saratoga is to the White sulphur Springs Hotel at the southern end of the lake. The distance from the Town Hall in the village to the head of the lake is said to be four miles and from the head of the lake to the end it is also four miles.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 18.--A female patient at the lunatic asylum died yesterday, and upon a postmortem examination a bunch of hair 10 inches long and over 1 inch in diameter, twisted like a chignon, was found in her intestings.

DETROIT, July 18.--By losing to-day's game the Chicagos dropped to second place and the champions assumed the lead. Inability to bat Conway's delivery and a wretched exhibition of fielding were the causes that led to their downfall.
HARRISVILLE, N.Y., July 18.--Warren Hume, the well-known guide and hunter of the Oswegatchie region, came out to this place today after a stay of several weeks in the Adirondacks.

NONQUITT, Mass., July 18.--Gen. Sheridan passed rather an uneasy night, but no unfavorable symptoms manifested themselves. In the early part of the forenoon he was quite irritable, owing to the fact that he was not permitted to eat such food as he craved.

NEWBURG, N. Y., July 18.--Henry M. and William Thompson, paper manufacturers at Walsh Mills, a suburb of this city, have made an assignment to W. C. Brown. Assets and liabilities not yet known.

Although but one stake race is to be run at Monmouth Park to-day, the Barnegat, for 3year-olds, the seven other races have filled so well as to provide plenty of good sport to make up for the poor race which the stake race will probably furnish.
The moon will undergo a total eclipse on Sunday night and Monday morning. The eclipse of Jan. 28 was also total, and was observable immediately after sunset.
Gov. HILL has given another exhibition of his quality as an upholder of the laws and defender of the rights of the people against criminal assault.

UTICA, N.Y., July 18.--The Hon. Warner Miller delivered an address at the annual meeting of the Merchants and Mechanics' Association of Central New-York, held at Syivan Beach, Oneida Lake, this afternoon. The Oneida battery fired the Governor's salute of 21 guns on his arrival. His remarks were confined principally to the currency and banking system of the country Hundreds of people wore badges inscribed "Hon. Warner Miller for Governor."

ALBANY, N.Y., July 18.--The verbal agreement entered into between all but two of the ale and porter brewers and the Knights of Labor is not working to the entire satisfaction of the Knights. One condition is that the employers are privileged to discharge any man so long as his place is filled with a Knight.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 18.--The sixth case of hazing, that of Cadet Peter J. Pillott, was taken up to-day by the court-martial at the Naval Academy.

Monotony is not one of the characteristics of the music at the Long Island beaches this Summer. People who long for brisk breezes and sweet sounds find edification in the fine pavilion at Manhattan Beach. Gilmore is there with his famous band.

WASHINGTON, July 18.--Chairman Mills of the Ways and Means Committee let his temper run away with his judgment to-day, and the result was a failure to get through with the Tariff bill and a robbery of the Labor Committee of the evening session, which had been ordered for the consideration of labor bills.

WATERLOO, Iowa, July 18.--Judge Couch has decided that ginger ale "must go" in the cases of certain saloon keepers in Buchanan County who have been selling ginger ale which contains 3 per cent. alcohol.

Yesterday was the sixty-fourth anniversary of old "Live Oak" Engine Company, No. 44, of the Volunteer Firemen's Association. The event was celebrated in a bona fide, old-time fire-laddle picnic at Sulzer's Harlem River Park.

DEADWOOD, Dakota, July 18.--A letter has been received from London which states that the much-talked-of Harney Peak tin deal is closed, and that all the properties belonging to the Harney Peak Company have passed into the hands of the English syndicate.

Col. George Bliss finds it inconvenient to have a New-York client who insists on staying in Canada. Monday he secured from Judge Van Hoesen until to-day to file affidavits from John Keenan, who is trying to have a Receiver ...
United States Commissioner Shields had before him yesterday one of the new counterfeit five-dollar silver certificates, which was so good an imitation of the genuine that one unused to ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 18.--Sarah Meyers, the oldest woman in Delaware County, and the widow of a Revolutionary officer, died on Monday, having survived her husband over twoscore years and living to bless the fourth genertion of her offspring.

OTTAWA, July 18.--The Department of Justice has been notified by Judge Davidson of Montreal that he has issued a warrant for the arrest of Pitcher, the Providence absconder, on a charge of forgery. The American Government has 15 days in which to make application for extradition.
The reported sale of Edison's phonograph has been confirmed, but the statement that it had been sold to an English syndicate for $250,000 was an error.

BALTIMORE, July 18.--Frank A. Tolson, Postmaster at Riverside, Charles County, and his brother, stonewall Jackson Tolson, were before United States Commissioner Rogers to-day, charged with making false official bonds and receiving public money which has not been accounted for.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 18.--To-day has been a notable one in the annals of the Liberal Party of Mexico, being the sixteenth yearly commemoration of the death of President Juarez, whose memory is covered by the Liberals and correspondingly detested by the Clerical Party.

The failure of Nicol, Cowlishaw Co., importers of upholstery at Broadway and Eighteenth-street, and in London and Manchester. England, it is claimed, will be only temporary and the firm expects to resume business as soon as it can arrange matters.

W.R. Foster, counsel for the Produce Exchange, has just sent to the Inter-State Commerce Commissioners his brief or summary of argument in support of the complaint of the Exchange against the principal railroad companies.

A cable dispatch from London yesterday stated that Judge Kay had rendered a decision against the Edison Electric Lighting Company, in which it was declared that the Edison patent for an incandescent lamp is invalid. The action in this case was brought by the Edison Company, nominally against a showman named ...

William Austin Beck, a convict in the Caldwell. (New-Jersey,) Penitentiary, made a bold dash for liberty Tuesday evening. He manages to escape from the office and reach Verona Lake, into which he plunged. Officer William Slayback secured a boat and captured the fugitive, and took him back to the prison. Beck, who is serving a term for malicious mischief, is believed to be insane.
It seldom falls to the lot of the racegoer to witness three more closely contested races than were decided at Brighton Beach yesterday.

The bank sneak "Johnny" Price is in the custody of Chief Detective Byrnes on two charges, which will apparently be proved against him. July 4 a man invited the ticket seller at Terrace Garden to take a drink after buying tickets of admission for the next evening.
Gen. William Cutting has at last been discharged by the Supreme Court from all his liabilities as Executor and Trustee under the wills of Francis B. Cutting and Heyward Cutting.

At 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the balloon Carlotta, charged with 6,000 feet of hydrogen gas, manufactured in a portable generator, rose gracefully from Washington Park ball grounds, Brooklyn, in the presence of several thousand persons.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18.--William Jesser, an emaciated and crippled German youth, limped into Central Station this afternoon and applied for assistance to reach his home in NewYork.
It would be most unfortunate if the impression should come to prevail that the organization of labor in this country meant an organization of foreign criminals.

A meeting of people interested in various ways in the manufacture and trade in tobacco and tobacco machinery was held yesterday at 50 and 52 Exchange-place, for the purpose of arranging for a national exposition of the cigar and tobacco industries, to be held in this city some time during the coming Spring.

NEWPORE, R.I., July 18.--A very exciting polo match took place this afternoon, and just at the finish Rudolph Agassiz was thrown from his pony and quite seriously injured. He rode into E.L. Winthrop with such force as to knock his pony down.

The Mississippi State Railroad Commission is having trouble with its lines, some of whose officials believe it is threatened with dissolution. The commission is supposed to comprise all the Southern lines east of the Mississippi River, but now that the Illinois Central ...

BOSTON, July 18.--The early session of the Prison Reform Association to-day was taken up by a discussion of the report of the Standing Committee on Prison Discipline. Most of the speakers dissented from the report, arguing that the Christian religion was the greatest power that could be used in the reformation of criminals.

ARDMORE, Indian Territory, July 18.-- Fifty-eight armed non-citizens rode into the camp of Collector McList to-day, and presenting their Winchesters' demanded the immediate release of all cattle held by him for taxes.

An informal conference of gentlemen interested in the welfare of the State League of Democratic Clubs was held yesterday afternoon in the office of James E. Graybill, the President of the league, at 229 Broadway. About 50 gentlemen were present.

TORONTO, July 18.--Toronto society circles were considerably excited over the scandal at Cleveland, Ohio, in connection with the doings of George Jarvis and Madeleine Campbell, or Neville both formerlY of this city.

NASHVILLE, Tenn.,July 18.--The Republican State Convention met in the hall of the House of Representatives at noon to-day and was called to order by tha Hon. A.M. Hughes, Chairman of the Executive Committee. It was the most representative body of Republicans that has met at the State Capitol in years, and it ...

For six weeks past freight agents have known that the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Road was doing something irregular to catch business. The all-rail business of this road has been increasing until now it is charged that nine shipments out of every ten to St. Paul and ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 18.--George H. Stayner and Henry S. Ives, the fugitive NewYork financiers, are at Niagara Falls, Ontario. They have rooms at the Clifton House, and since their arrival have hardly left them. They refuse to see any one.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18.--President James Campbell, of the Universal Federation of Window-Glass Workers, Patrick Cleary, and John Phillips, all of this city, leave to-morrow ...
DETROIT, Mich., July 18.--The Democrats and Greenbackers hold their State Conventions to-morrow--the former in this city, the latter at Grand Rapids.
The members of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club will start on their annual cruise up the Sound next Saturday afternoon and anticipate even a better time than they have had in former years.

C.J. Hamlin's mare Belle Hamlin is reported to have trotted a half mile over the Buffalo Driving Park's track on Tuesday afternoon in 1:02 , which is a 2:05 gait. If the report is correct this performance beats any record at the distance.
STRASBURG, Penn., July 18.--Andrew Harnish resides on a farm near this place. Among his fine stock was a valuable cow. She was a good milk producer and highly rated.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 18.--Vegetation in this section is suffering badly from drought. No rain of any duration has occurred in 20 days, and the ground is so parched that even the grass is dying.
James R. Hill of this city has been appointed a customs inspector on Surveyor Beattie's staff at a salary of $4 per day .

Mayor Hewitt yesterday received additional contributions in aid of O.M. Hartt, who was persecuted by the Knights of Labor. One contributor, signing himself "American," sent $1 for Hartt and 1 cent to help erect a monument in commemoration of the business ...

An icehouse on the farm of Mrs. J.T. Gold, just out of West Chester village, in which was stored a quantity of hay and rye belonging to Charles Zimmer, a neighboring farmer, was burned to the ground shortly after 9 o'clock Tuesday night under very suspicious circumstances.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 18.--The threatened strike of the Manitoba switchmen in the Minneapolis yards, owing to the dissatisfaction with Yardmaster Berry, has been avoided.

A petty swindler, whose financial returns have not been heavy so far as heard from, but whose methods are novel, has been operating in the stores of a number of large firms in this city for several days past.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 18.--The hearing of the contest of the will of the late Robert Blair was to-day adjourned until next Tuesday in order to give the court time to decide as to the legality of the appeal papers. John I. Blair, brother of the deceased, was present and listened carefully to the arguments of counsel. Attempts at a compromise were made, but were unsuccessful, and it is thought the case will be bitterly contested.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18.--Magistrate Pole to-day held Henry P. Simons of 2,443 Berkstreet to await a requisition from the New-York authorities on a charge of embezzlement.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 18.--John Vredenburgh, a carpenter of Cornwall, was found in his bed this morning in an insensible condition bound with a clothes-line. He had been chloroformed and robbed. Vredenburgh recovered consciousness during the day. His pantaloons, with $25, were taken.

Marcus W. Robinson, as Receiver of the Samuel Wood College of the city of New-York, has brought suit in the Supreme Court of Queens County against Alfred L. Simonson and Edward T. Schenck, individually and as Executors ...

UTICA, N.Y., July 18.--The State Hop Growers' Association met at Bagg's Hotel in this city this morning. Representatives of the State Brewers' Association were also present. A Committee of six, three each from the Hop Growers' and the Brewers' Association, was appointed to draft resolutions in which the ideas of the associations should be embodied. After recess the following resolutions were submitted:

William Cleveland Cox, a lawyer whose office is at 280 Broadway, and who lives at 11 East Seventeenth-street, appeared before Justice Ford in the Jeffersen Market Police Court yesterday to answer a complaint brought by ...
Charles D. Kellogg, Treasurer of the Bartholdi Crehe on Bellow's Island, acknowledges the receipt of the following contributions in aid of the creche: Mrs. E.H. Chauncey, $5; Thomas ...

The fact that "Prince Methusalem," as presented by Col. McCaull's company at Wallack's Theatre, has proved so decided a success has induced the ticket speculators to take a hand in and see if they cannot turn some of the opera's prosperity into their own pockets.

BOSTON, July 18.--The Republicans are not having the best success in soliciting funds from manufacturers. The Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Holyoke Republican Club recently solicited a contribution from Mr. Arthur T. Lyman, who is the Treasurer of the ...

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 18.--Miss Emma Cotton, a well-known belle of Trenton, N.J., visiting relatives in Bloomsbury, N.J., was riding in a carriage this morning when her horse took fright at a passing train and ran away, throwing her against a post. She received such severe internal injuries that the physicians say she cannot recover.

LONDON, July 18.--At Cambridge to-day the exercises of the university were distinguished by the conferring of honorary degrees upon Bishop Potter of New-York and the Bishops of Minnesots and of Fredericton, NewBrunswick. The Senate was crowded on the occasion, and the conferring of the degrees was greeted with loud cheers. Immediately afterward the Bishops joined the procession to King's Chapol, where a special service was held, and went thence to the banquet in Trinity College.
The aqueduct rascality, as revealed by the Senate investigation, has at last aroused leading citizens to a serious and practical consideration of the situation.
A fire broke out at 11:15 last night among a pile of laths which had been left by some lathers in the five-story tenement house at 379 First-avenue, which is occupied by eight families.

DUBLIN, July 18.--At Kilrush to-day a family namad Cleary, consisting of four brothers and sisters, defended their home against an evicting party until a battering ram was brought into use and the building was demolished. The Clearys were then taken into custody.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 18.--The will of John A. Coen, who in his lifetime was familiarly known in the town of Red Hook as "John Whitey Coon" came before the Surrogate to-day on a motion for its admission to probate. Right away a contestant appeared.

Athletic games under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association will be held to-morrow evening, beginning at 8 o'clock, at the association's grounds, One Hundred and Fiftieth-street and Harlem River.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 19.--The session of the New-Jersey State Dental Society continued today at the West End Hotel. The attendance was large, a number of professional dentists from other States being present.

Measured by street numbers the work done on the Suburban Elevated Railway during the last few days seems scant, but the street blocks above the lower part of Morrisania are as long as avenue blocks below Harlem Bridge, and the road is progressing at the rate of about 200 feet a day.

An impromptu pyrotechnic display was furnished at about 8 o'clock last evening by an electric cable which stretches from the east to the west side of Sixth-avenue at Twenty-second street, running under the elevated railroad structure.

The Board of Health ordered the vacation of the following tenements, which are reported to be in general unsanitary condition, dangerous to life, and detrimental to health: 20 Cherry-street, 147 Cedar-street, and 283 Mott-street.

MEXICO, July 19.--A slight shock of earthquake was felt, here about midnight last night and a high wind sprang up simultaneously. Another shock is expected by Indians who are versed in earthquake lore.

CHICAGO, July 19.--The Board of Trade won a substantial victory in the appellate court to-day, when a decision was given dismissing the suit of the New-York and Chicago Grain and Stock Exchange against the board.

William W. Winans, a veteran of the war of 1812, and who, had he lived till next month, would have been 96 years of age, died in this city yesterday after a brief illness. Mr. Winans's ancestors were among the first of the Dutch settlers in America, and his father was born at what is now Elizabeth, N.J.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 19.--Last evening Mr. Kehoe gave Mrs. Langtry a dinner at the West End cottages. There were seven in the party.
Mrs. Rebecca Shanley, the wife of Frank P. Shanley, Superintendent of the L.M. Palmer works, in Williamsburg, disappeared from her home, 599 Jersey-avenue, Jersey City, last Saturday.
The Board of Electrical Control and the United States Electric Illuminating Company crossed swords yesterday in the examination room at Essex market Police Court, before Justice Gorman.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--"Just our luck," said Manager Mutrie of the Giants as he left the ball grounds with his hat pulled down over his ears to-day, and with anything but a happy look.
The big deal consummated by the NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad in gaining practical control of the Peughkeepsie Bridge continues to agitate Wall-street in a very lively way.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 19.--The Fisheries Department, in response to applications, has issued only 50 licenses to American fishing vessels, giving them the right to fish in Canadian waters under the modus vivendi of the fishery treaty. The license reads as follows:
HAVANA, July 19.--Seven hundred cigarmakers of this city are now on strike. They asked for an increase of wages, and, failing to get it, stopped work.
CHICAGO, July 19.--Thomas W. Hall Co., one of the largest houses in the wool trade in Chicago, made an assignment, to-day. The liabilities are probably $150,000, with assets estimated at $130,000.

For over a year the Water Commissioners of Sing Sing have been prospecting for a supply of water to furnish that village for fire and domestic purposes. Having decided on Indian Brook, they have now given out contracts, and...
The members of the New-York Press Club met yesterday and passed the following resolulions:

A more unpleasant day for racing than yesterday could not be imagined. It rained all the afternoon at Monmouth Park. Yet there was the usual crowd at the track. Not so great a crowd as is on hand on a fair day, but the 5,000 or 6,000 who are at the track rain or shine.

WHEELING, West Va., July 19.--At least 25 lives were lost by this evening's storm in this city and immediate vicinity, and when the full details are in to-morrow it is feared this sad tale will be supplemented by many other facts from the eastern part of the country at present inaccessible.

MONTREAL, July 19.--There is some talk of the banks and telegraph offices fighting the new provincial tax on commercial corporations by closig up all their branch offices in the province. Many of these offices are run at a loss for the benefit of the public, but they are each to be taxed $50.

Detective Sergeant Sheldon has been engaged for nearly two weeks past in a search for Hugh J. McCready, the former President of the Boss Steel Box Band Company of this city, who has been missing since the 6th inst.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 19.--Theodore Hermann, a German, who lives at Highland Park and who had charge of the Phillips place, is missing.
CARLISLE, Penn., July 19.--Owing to the heavy rain the attendance at the State Sunday School Convention at Williams's Grove was not very large. This was temperance day.

The Five Points Mission, at 63 Parkstreet, was a busy scene yesterday morning, and the Rev. O.R. Bouton was a busy man. One hundred and eighteen children, ranging in age from 5 to 13 years, were being prepared for...

CARLISLE, Penn., July 19.--Great excitement prevails among the residents of West Fairview, a little village in the lower end of this county, over the discovery of a vein of coal, 4 feet thick, on a farm near that place. The vein was struck while prospecting for ore.

Fire broke out on the third floor of the six-story brick building at 156 West Twenty-seventh-street at 12:45 this morning. The premises were, occupied by Frederick Doll as a furniture factory. Three alarms were sent out, but the entire building was destroyed before the fire could be controlled. The loss is estimated at $25,000.

In pursuance of his plan of forcing delinquent Executors and Administrators to account for their stewardships Surrogate Ransom summoned before him yesterday Alfred L. Simonson and Edward T. Schenck, the Executors...

Recent investigations in the Storekeepers' Department of the Brooklyn Navy Yard have brought to light a system of fraud that is belived to be extensive and to have covered a period of several years. Information was obtained by the Secretary of the Navy that led him...

LONDON, July 19.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Summers, Liberal, asked whether, in view of the fact that AttorneyGeneral Webster acted for the Times as leading counsel in defending the suit brought against it by O'Donnell, Mr. Smith would undertake that ...

BELVIDERE, N.J, July 19.--Major Tibbells, City Tax Collector of Lambertville, who recently decamped, has been heard from. It was supposed that he was dead. His accounts are now being carefully gone over by the City Finance Committee. A great deal of crookedness is revealed. The shortage will foot up $4,000. His bondsmen are good.

PITTSBURG, July 19.--The probable effects of the disruption of the Association of Manufacturers of iron, steel, and nails is being seriously discussed in industrial circles. There have been erroneous views concerning that association, and its members represented an immense amount of money.
Secretary Coster announces the following weights for the Harvest Handicap at a mile and a quarter, to be run at Monmouth Park on Saturday:

JACKSON, Miss., July 19.--Sheriff L.T. Baskett of Leflore County arrived here this morning with S.H. Whitworth, Ike Hoskins, and Dan McLean, the persons who killed Ivy and Astor and wounded the two McCarty brothers at Rising Sun on the 7th inst.
ALBANY, July 19.--From the reports of the following surface railroads of New-York City made to the State Railroad Commissioners for the quarter ended June 30, the following figures are abstracted:
ALBANY, July 19.--There was a conference between Gov. Hill and a few of his friends at the Executive Mansion last night which had a marked bearing upon events here at the Capitol to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--With the exception of an hour's speech which is to be made by Mr. Mills on Saturday the discussion of the Tariff bill in the House of Representatives has been completed, and nothing remains to be done there but to put the measure on its final passage.

BOSTON, July 19.--Judge Barker of the Superior Court has ordered judgment for the plaintiff in the case of Chancellor Allen against the South Boston Railroad Company a suit involving the legality of the stock illegally issued by the defaulting Treasurer of the road. The defendant will undoubtedly take the case to the full bench of the Supreme Court for final decision.

MONTREAL, July 19.--Mr. J.D.L. Ambrose, special customs officer, narrowly escaped being murdered last night. He was sitting with his son on the veranda of his house on Cathcart-street, when a shot was heard and the ...
DUBLIN, July 19.--The work of evicting tenants was resumed on the Vandeleur estates, in County Clare, to-day. Three tenants were evicted peacefully.

FERGUS FALLS, Minn., July 19.--The grasshopper war at Perham continues unabat ed. Although over 10,000 bushels have been caught, the farmers are still catching them at a lively rate. None to speak of have blown off. A lot rose up and flew five or six miles, and when they alighted the farmers caught 45 bushels of them.

Representatives of three-fourths of all the nut and bolt manufactories in the United States met at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel Wednesday and arranged the preliminaries for an association of all the manufacturers in this country to maintain...

HUTCHINSON, Kan., July 19.--At the second and last day's session of the State Prohibition Convention the following State ticket was nominated. For Governor--J.D. Botkin of Sedgewick County; Lieutenant-Governor--R.J. Finley, Dickinson County; Secretary of State--L.K. McIntyre, ...
DETROIT, July 19.--The examination of the opium smugglers who were arrested a few weeks ago came up before United States Commissioner Harris at Port Huron yesterday.

BOSTON, July 19.--A Providence special says: "The Wickford Summer residence of H.B. Aymer of East Warren, N.J., was entered by burglars between 12 and 1 o'clock this morning, who ransacked the house from top to bottom, taking a large quantity of silver and $15,000 work of certificates of stock."

The headquarters of the Democratic National Committee, at 10 West Twenty-ninthstreet, were visited yesterday by a number of prominent gentlemen, including William E. Griffith, President of the Ohio Society; John S. Moore of Maine, Gen. B.F. Le Fevre, Capt. S.P. Walker. J.W. Flanders of Michigan, and ...

Transactions on the Stock Exchange fell off 100,000 shares yesterday compared with the trading of the day before, and quotations fell, too, most of the conspicuous stocks declining fractionally, a few only dropping a whole point.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 19.--Charles L. Jewett, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee of Indiana, reached his home in NewAlbany last night, having come down from Indianapolis for a few days' rest. Speaking of the campaign in Indiana, Mr. Jewett this morning said:
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July l9.--To-day the spars of the three-masted schooner James B. Pace struck the west trues span of the Poughkeepsie Bridge, and eight feet of the top of each spar were taken off.
The following weights are assigned for two of the handicaps to be decided at the Fall meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association. Declarations are due Aug. 1:

CRONSTADT, July 19.--At 4:30 o'clock this afternoon the German yacht Hohenzollern, with Emperor William on board, entered the roads amid volleys of salutes from the war ships and forts. The Hohenzollern was received by the Russian yacht Djerava, on board of which was the Czar.
HAVANA, July 14.--The cane fields exhibit a good appearance, and unless some untoward event occurs the coming crop of sugar will be a large one.

Elizabeth Hughes, a domestic, recently adveririeod for a situation. She lived at 217 East Twenty-ninth-street with a Mrs. Bridget Kelly, and in the same house resided another domestic, named Annie Fox.

The second dinner of the Hoboken Turtle Club was given yesterday at Gabe Case's. There were 100 of the members present at the breakfast, early in the day, and some of these were able to appear at dinner, where 200 sat down.

"The Mikado," with a German version of Mr. Gilbert's clever libretto, was the opera presented at Terrace Garden last evening. It proved sufficiently attractive to draw a fairly large audience despite the threatening and rainy weather, and few left before the close of the performance, which was near midnight.
CHICAGO, July 19.--Secretary Gade and W.H Gurley, attorneys for the Chicago Rapid Transit Company, the corporation proposing to build an elevated road on the south side, called...
Under the auspices of the Reform Club the publication of a neat 16-page semi-monthly campaign journal called the Tariff Reform has been commenced at 52 William-street.
Mayor Gleason's attack with an axe upon the fence and ticket box of the New-York and Rockaway Beach Railway at Long Island City on Wednesday evening has occasioned a good deal of talk.

LETONIA, Ohio, July 19.--While repairing the Catholic schoolhouse to-day the foundation gave way and the building fell, killing John Maguire instantly and fatally injuring James McKenna. There were 18 men working under the building at the time, but fortunately the others escaped uninjured.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--Negotiations are pending for a sale of $6,500,000 East Tennessee first preferred stock held by Richmond Terminal to the Norfolk and Western, and it is said that an agreement is practically concluded.

BOSTON, July 19.--Dr. Richard S. Rosenthal, author of the Meisterchaft system of learning languages, carries his 60 years very lightly. He is wealthy and learned, but that has not prevented his being particularly unfortunate in his matrimonial ventures.
The joint legislative committee appointed last Winter to consider the advisability of extending the shore line at the Jersey Flats was in session in Jersey City yesterday.

BOSTON, July 19.--The port of Boston had to-day the first case of mutiny that has occurred for several years. It resulted in a brutal assault on Mate Edward C. Snow of the three-masted schooner Harbeson Hickman, who received injuries that may prove fatal.
WASHINGTON, July 19.--The order of July 2, 1888, directing Major Henry G. Thomas, Paymaster, to appear before the Army Retiring Board at Governor's Island, New-York, has been revoked.

For the revival of "The Queen's Mate" by the J.C. Duff Opera Company, which is to mark the reopening of the Broadway Theatre on Aug. 13, Mr. Paulton is now engaged in writing a new topical song, and several changes are so be made in the cast, which Manager Sanger thinks will improve it.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 19.--Will Houston, who shot and killed a negro woman last May, was hanged at Winston this afternoon. The execution, which was public, was witnessed by several thousand people. Houston was captured shortly after the murder, and as the court was in session he was promptly arraigned, tried, and convicted.
The rain of yesterday prevented the carrying out of the programme announced by the Yonkers Racing Association. The entries were declared off, and the regular card will be run tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 19.--To-day's bond offerings amounted to $1,500,000, in lots as follows; Four per cents, registered--$100,000 at 127 7-16, $200,000 at 127 .

ELMIRA, N.Y., July l9.--A fatal stabbing affray took place at Corning this afternoon. Morris Layton of Addison got into a drunken row with Samuel McIntyre, when Charles Knapp interfered as peacemaker.

BOSTON, July 19.--At the opening of the Prison Association congress this morning papers were submitted by title, but without reading, by J.W. Patterson on "Prison Labor," by J.W. Clemmer of the Ohio Penitentiary on "The State's Protection of the Prisoner's Right to Reform," and by the Rev. F.M. Voigt on "Crime and Criminals."

YANKTON, Dakota, July 19.--There has been a mixing up of the Clevelands in the announcements concerning the persons who compose the commission appointed to induce the Sioux of Dakota to surrender half their reservation.

With the launch of the steel war vessel Charleston the Navy Department takes another step toward the supply of a new fleet. Her construction has proceeded so quietly at the Union Iron Works, San Francisco, ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--The Industrial Home and School of St. Francis de Sales, founded by the Misses Drexel, daughters of the late Francis A. Drexel, near Bristol, Penn., was informally opened to-day, 200 boys being transferred to the school from the St. John's Orphan Asylum in this city.

Surrogate Ransom made an order yesterday to deliver to Mrs. Ellen Marcy McClellan, the widow and Executrix of Gen. George B. McClellan, his will, which was probated and has been on file in the Surrogate's Court in this city, ...

RED BANK, N.J., July 19.--Professional cracksmen broke open the safe in the furnishing goods store of Hendrickson Applegate, on Frontstreet, about 2:30 o'clock this morning and stole $130. The house of Charles Quackenbush, at Little Silver was also broken into Tuesday night and $10 was stolen from a writing desk. Detectives have a clue to the burglars and it is thought they will be arrested before many days.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19.--A 10-knot breeze, blowing from the southeast, with a cloudy sky, greeted the Atlantic Club yachtsmen when they tumbled up from their cabins to make sail this morning for their fourth race ...

TROY, N.Y., July 19.--Mr. Fred Mather of the United States and New-York Fish Commissions is making an examination of the Hudson River in order to learn the results of his work in stocking it with salmon.
CORAL, Mich., July 19.--Fires in the woods the past few days have done great damage. A strong west wind yesterday brought the fire into town, and the inhabitants were fighting the flames all day.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 19.--Despite the dispatches sent out that the second break in the Erie Canal at Adam's Basin had been repaired, and that boats would be running by Friday, it is doubtful if any will move before Sunday.
SYDNEY, New South Wales, July 19.--The Captain of the steamer Alameda, plying between this port and San Francisco, has agreed not to employ Chinese in the future, and the steamer is now unloading.

Vice-Commodore Caldwell H. Colt presided at the meeting of the New-York Yacht Club at Delmonico's down-town place yesterday afternoon, Commodore Gerry not having yet returned from his easterly cruise in the Electra.

ALBANY, July 19.--The recent meeting of the State Committee in New-York brought out some discussion and rumors which have been repeated here, and which serve to illustrate some of the peculiar phases of the present campaign of Gov. Hill.

The rainy weather yesterday caused a general aspect of dreariness at Coney Island. Not more than 200 persons went down from New-York, while those who are quartered at the various hotels found it much more comfortable indoors. Coney Island was certainly deserted.
The body of Richard Kearney, who was hanged Wednesday at Freehold, N.J., was interred in a field east of Freehold owned by a colored barber named Brody.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 19.--Word was brought from Monticello to-day of the murder of Moses Davis, an intelligent colored man, by unknown persons. His corpse was found in Miccasukey Lake yesterday.
MARIETTA, Ohio, July 19.--Ohio Day has crowned the centennial jubilee with imposing laurels. Although the weather was forbidding, there have been fully 15,000 people in the streets.

CHICAGO, July 19.--The most important event to-day in connection with the east-bound rate diaturbance was the withdrawal of the Erie from the weighing and inspection bureaus at Buffalo and Salamanca. It was reported yesterday that half the number of locals attached to District Assembly No. 49 had returned Secretary Murray's circular asking them to send new delegates to the District Assembly in the place of those who were inimical to Master Workman Quinn for having suspended the dry goods men's and the car-builders' locals.

DETROIT, Mich., July 19.--The Democratic State Convention in this city and the Greenback State Convention at Grand Bapids have been hard at work all day and this evening in the effort to effect a fusion, and success has finally crowned their efforts.
Miss Jennie Harrison, who for the past 17 years had been a teacher at the New-York Juvenile Asylum, died of apoplexy at Nyack, N.Y., yesterday morning.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 19.--Four years ago to-day Gilbert W. Hazaltine, son of Dr. G. W. Hazeltine of Jamestown, N.Y., killed Mamie Thorpe and wounded May White in a house of ill-fame in this city. Hazeltine came of a most excellent family.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 19.--Charles E. Cross and Samuel C. White, defaulting President and Cashier of the State National Bank of this city, who fled to Canada in March, have been on trial in the Superior Court here yesterday and to-day.

The so-called excessive freight charges on Georgia watermelons by the Pennsylvania Railroad and Ocean Steamship Company have at last had the effect that was predicted, and growers have concluded to let their melons lie on the ground and decay rather than ship them at such runious prices.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 19.--Premier Greenway and Attorney-General Martin of the Manitoba Government left for New-York this morning to consult with General Manager Oaks of the Northern Pacific regarding the purchase by his company of the Red River Valley Railway, Manitobs's new connection with the American system.

Mrs. Charles Dillon died at Portsmouth, England, July 4. She was the widow of Charles Dillon, the English tragedian who made a tour of this country and Australia, opening at the Winter Garden, this city, on Jan. 24, 1861, and finishing at the Broadway Theatre of that period in November, 1866.
