SARATOGA, July 19.--The atmosphere was made remarkably refreshing and the dust on on the roads was laid low to-day by a heavy shower of rain. A grand exhibition of fireworks announced for this evening in Congress Spring Park was postponed until to-morrow evening in order to give a large excursion party from Troy an opportunity to witness it.

Two attempts at suicide were made yesterday by Assistant Superintendent C.B. Smith of the Adams Express Company. He was first found unconscious from the effects of morphine in a room at Ewing's Hotel, Jersey City.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 19.--About two years ago at Jackson, Miss., died very suddenly Edmond Richardson, the richest cotton planter in the world. About six months ago his wife also died.
EUFAULA, Ala., July 19.--M.M. Brannon, editor of the Daily Mail, caused it to be circulated to-day that for two weeks he would decline to speak to comman or plain every-day people.
Our recent dispatches from Minnesota predict that the vote of the Prohibitionists in that State will be very largely increased at the coming election.
NONQUITT, Mass., July 19.--There is absolutely nothing new in regard to Gen. Sheridan's condition. He continuos to gain slowly, but a set-back is still likely to occur at any moment.
A combination excursion and picnic in the rain is not a common event, but if they were all as certain of the success which attended one yesterday they would quickly become popular.

ST. PIERRE, Newfoundland, July 19.--The schooner Jeune Edouard was sunk at anchor on the Grand Banks on the 14th inst. by a large steamer steering west-northwest. The crew can give no accurate description of the steamer owing to the fog that provailed. The schooner was insured for $30,000 in an American agency here.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 19.--A Young Men's Democratic Club was formed here last night of 200 members. David Miller was elected President. A ratification meeting and pole raising were held here to-night and great enthusiasm prevailed. Speeches were made by the Hon. L. P. Gordon, Major Sitts, and others.

DES MOINES, July 19.--Some surprising disclosures are resulting from the course of the attorneys for the Rock Island and Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northorn Roads taking testimony to learn now competent the State Railroad Commissioners are to fix rates.

DETROIT, July 19.--Charles R. Richardson, a boot and shoe dealer, mortgaged his stock at 41 and 43 Monroe-avenue, in this city, on Tuesday for $4,800 and has now made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors. The liabilities are about $55,000, assets not known, but are considerable.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July l9.--At the Democratic Convention of the Seventh District, at Gadsden, Gen. W.H. Forney was renominated for Congress without opposition. This makes his eighth nomination, having been first elected in 1874.

MONTREAL, July 19.--Rumors have been in circulation for the last few days to the effect that a large wholesale house is in financial difficulty. To-day it was stated that a meeting of the creditors would be held in a few days, and if a considerable extension is not granted an assignment will follow. The liabilities of the house are over $100,000.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 19.--At a meeting of the Republican State Central Committee, which adjourned at 2 o'clook this morning, a resolution was adopted declining to put a State ticket in the field and recommending that the Republicans support the Union Labor ticket, headed by C.M. Norwood for Governor. No action was taken concerning the Electoral ticket.

CHICAGO, July 19.--A revival of the freight boycott is threatened by the radicals among the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy strikers. They have practically determined upon attempting the move in case the present negotiations for a settlement of the strike fail, ...
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 19.--Rain began falling copiously along the Hudson Valley last night, and an old-fashioned drizzle has prevailed all day.
A solemn requiem mass was celebrated yesterday at St. Teresa'a Church, at Henry and Rutgers streets, over the remains of the Rev. Michael Riordan, who died at St. Vincent's Hospital last Monday.
VINITA, Indian Territory, July 19.--The trouble that has been pending in the Chickasaw Nation for the last month over the cattle tax seems to have reached a climax near Ardmore.
NEWPORT, R.I, July 19.--Long needed rain keeps off but there was every prospect tonight of an end to the drouhgt before morning.

CARLISLE, Penn., July 19.--The strikers at the shoe factory still remain out. The Board of Directors still refuse to dismiss the obnoxious foreman, Kieter, and the strikers will not work as long as he is in charge.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 19.--A delegation of Englisn students, who have been attending the Northfield conference under Mr. Moody, visited Chautauqua yesterday.

The latest known cut in freight rates has been made by the Missouri Pacific Road on dry goods and cotton piece goods from NewYork to Southwestern Missouri River points. The normal tariff rates of $1 37 on the former commodity and 85 cents on the latter have been reduced to $1 22 and 75 cents respectively.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 20.--The dead-lock in the Third Congressional District Democratic Convention, in session at McMinnville, was broken to-day by the nomination of Creed F. Bates.

MONTREAL, July 20.--Benjamin B. Bergen, aged 24, arrived here from Baltimore a few days ago and registered at the New-York House under the assumed name of White.

CHICAGO, July 20.--George Godding, one of the men charged with conspiring against the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Road, secured a bondsman to-day and was released by United States Commissioner Hoyne. He was immediately rearrested and taken to Aurora, where he was bound over on a State warrant.

Yesterday the Senate went into secret session to consider the nomination of Mr. MELVILLE W. FULLER of Illinois to be Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. What was done during the session is known by the authorized and official report.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 20.--Proceedings will be taken in the Patent Office next September to annul the patents for Edison's system of electric lighting in Canada for non-compliance with the requirements of the Patent act.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 20.--Frank Hossinger, the Superintendent of Warren Ackerman's Summer village at Feltville, Scotch Plains, was drowned today while diving to mend a broken water gate. His head struck a submerged rock. He leaves a widow and six children. He was a prominent Knight of Pythias.
NEW-BEDFORD, July 20.--To-day's 35mile run of the Atlantic Yacht Club fleet from Newport to New-Bedford was the last of the week's cruise and really the most satisfactory one of all.

ISHPEMING, Mich., July 20.--This morning there was brought into this city from the gold shaft of the Lake Superior Iron Company, seven miles northwest of here, nearly 400 pounds of very rich gold-bearing quartz. This quartz was dislodged by one blast fired last night at the bottom of a shaft which is now 22 feet deep.

CARLISLE, Penn., July 20.--It is reported here to-day on good authority that since ex-Gov. Pattison's name has been withdrawn from the number of prominent persons mentioned in connection with the Presidency of Dickinson College, Dr. J.A.M. Chapman of Philadelphia has been selected as Dr. McCauley's successor, and will be tendered the position.

DEEP RIVER, Mich., July 20.--Heavy forest fires are raging over all Arenas County and all the way between this place and Gladwin. Timber of all kinds is being destroyed, fences are being burned, and other property damaged. Many farmers have had to fight for their homes. There has been no rain of consequence here for three months.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 20.--The Commissioners appointed to inspect the asylums of the State have just made their first report to Gov. McGill. The communication dwells in a very serious manner on the requirements of both the Rochester and St. Peter institutions.

There were no new developments in the alleged navy yard frauds yesterday, and the United States Commissioner could not say whether there would be further arrests or not. Daniel Laird, who was a clerk in charge of the stores, has retained Gen. Isaac S. Catlin to defend him.

LONDON, July 20.--At the Kempton Park meeting to-day the race for the Kempton Park Grand Two-year-old Stakes was won by Gay Hampton, with Gulbeyaz second and Dryad II. third. There were twelve starters. Lady Stamford's b.c. Freemason was the favorite in the betting at odds of 5 to 2 against. The betting against the others was 8 to 1 against Gay Hampton, 7 to 2 against Gulbeyaz, and 12 to 1 against Dryad II.

John Kofal of 418 East Fifty-ninth-street returned from Trinidad, Col., yesterday, and was arrested on a warrant for converting mortgaged property, the complainant being John Culbertson of Broadway and Thirty-third-street.

The Bijou Opera House property was sold at auction at the Real Estate Exchange at noon yesterday to Sire Sons for $350,000. The amount realized is considered to be excellent by real estate and theatrical experts.

The bonded debt of Elizabeth is at last in a fair way of settlement at 50 cents on the dollar. Ever since that city went into bankruptcy negotiations of some kind have been in progress to relieve the financial stress.

Shea of the Don Amateur Club of Toronto, with G.A. Strickland of the same club second, H.H. Seaton of the Excelsior Club of Paterson, N.J., third, and W. J. Gugerly of Cohoes, N.Y., fourth. Shea went with ease in 10:09.

On the Stock Exchange business was steady, a prominent feature being an increasing demand for American railroad securities, especially on German account. English investors show little disposition to buy, but the rise in prices is assisted by repurchases by operators for a fall, who conclude that the decline has been checked. The number of people who go on excursions on Sunday in New-York is not regulated by the temperature. It it was, the various Sunday resorts outside the city yesterday would have had but slim patronage. No one complained of the heat, and there were almost as many of the fair sex out in velvets and other heavy dress goods as there were in lawns and like light fabrics.

The Emperor of Brazil, who is residing at the Splendide Hotel, Aix-les-Bains, has made a wonderful cure. He arrived there a few weeks ago apparently a dying man. He now daily takes a drive, walks about the gardens, and generally plays a game of billiards in the public room. He and his suite have 42 rooms in the hotel. The Emperor's dislike of etiquette and his affability have rendered him extremely popular.

A monument to the memory of Matthew Stach, the first missionary of the Moravian Church in America, was dedicated in Forsyth County June 30. He left Germany for Greenland in 1733, where he resided for over 20 years. He then came to North Carolina and died in Forsyth County. The monument, a granite shaft, was dedicated with appropriate ceremonies in the presence of several hundred Moravians.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22.--This has been a dull, stormy Sabbath, the first of the season. Rain fell nearly all day. There were few worshippers at the churches, and the omnibuses used for transporting pleasure seekers from Providence and elsewhere to and from the beach were not needed. The excursion boats had few passengers, as the storm began long before daylight. Business was at a standstill at the beach and elsewhere.

SARATOGA, July 24.--The hotel proprietors of Saratoga intend to vote for all the candidates in the field for President. They belong to every church in Christendom and out of it. They believe everything that everybody tells them, sympathize with those in affliction, and rejoice with those who have anything to rejoice for. They shake hands with men, women, and children, and keep constantly nodding to everybody.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 24.--Charles A. Dana, editor of the New-York Sun, delivered an address this evening at the Academy of Music to the Wisconsin Editorial Association. The hall was crowded and the discourse was warmly applauded.

There was a good attendance at the Yonkkers races yesterday. The weather was delightful and the racing interesting. The favorites were in fine form, winning four of the five events.

The Directors of the Long Island Railroad Company held a meeting yesterday at Maxwell Green's office in the Boreel Building and voted to issue $1,000,000 worth of bonds to build the extension to Oyster Bay.

BOSTON, Mass., July 25.--Jesse Pomeroy, that extraordinary criminal whose death sentence was commuted some years ago to solitary imprisonment for life, has been giving the law officers of the State no end of trouble of late. Pomeroy since his confinement has developed powers of wonderful acuteness.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 25.--The shoe retailers' convention resumed business at 10 o'clock to-day. There was a long discussion over the admission of members from Canada, resulting in an adverse decision.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--Major Henry G. Thomas, Paymaster, has been granted six months' extension of leave of absence; Capt. Charles H. Ingalls, Acting Quartermaster, three months' leave of absence, his duties at Hot Springs, Ark., to be temporarily performed by First Lieut. Wright P. Edgerton; Surgeon David L. Magruder, one month's leave of absence.

DETROIT, Mich., July 25.--Bartley Breen of Menominee, who was nominated by both Democrats and Greenbackers last week for Auditor-General on the State ticket, declines to accept the position. He wanted the Lieutenant-Governorship. Mr. Breen is the man who gave Seymour so close a race last Winter in the upper peninsula to fill Congressman Moffatt's vacancy. He was very popular among the labor element of that region.

ALBANY, July 25.--The Canal Board this afternoon approved of the plans prepared by State Engineer Bogart for enlarging the seven locks on the Erie Canal, near Syracuse, and two on the Oswego Canal, and for dredging the Albany Basin. A resolution providing $13,000 for preliminary surveys for the works called for by chapter 416 of the Laws of 1888 was adopted.

NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., July 25.--William Stanbro, Justice of the Peace at Syracuse, a small town 20 miles west of this city, while on his way home last night was assaulted by a crowd of young men wearing white caps drawn down over their faces and carrying rawhides. Mr. Stanbro was terribly beaten and his face, neck, and shoulders were badly cut. He may lose the sight of one eye.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 25.--At the meeting of the Board of Health to-night President Wilkinson stated that not a single case of yellow fever or anything resembling the same had made its appearance within his jurisdiction on land or water so far this year, and he had every reason to believe the disease would be evaded entirely this year.
MONTREAL, July 25.--Benjamin Bergen, the Baltimore defaulter, was rearrested this morning on a deposition by Detective Gladu.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 25.--From Ship Island it is reported that the cases of Chagres fever in the lazaretto have been discharged, having convalesced. No vessels are at the station now except the brig Carricks, from Rio Janeiro, and the barks Magnolia and John Swan, from Colon.

LONDON, July 25.--Prof. James Bryce, member of Parliament, presided at the banquet given here this evening in honor of American authors. In proposing a toast to "Her Majesty the Queen and President Cleveland," Prof. Bryce said that all felt pleasure in coupling those names as typical of the unity of sentiment existent between the two great branches of the English race.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 25.--While bathing in Black River to-night Fred M. Ehrlicher, a young lawyer of this city, was drowned. He had been in the water several minutes, when a companion who was looking on saw him dive. he did not reappear and his body has not been recovered. Mr. Ehrlicher was about 30 years old and highly esteemed among the members of the Jefferson County Bar.

MONTREAL, July 25.--Three American brokers, Walter Power and Willard H. Jones of New-York and Stephen H. Bacon of Brooklyn, arrived here to-night in their steam yacht Elia, on which they are spending their vacation.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 25.--The American Papermakers' Association held its eleventh annual session at the Grand Union Hotel to-day, Byron Weston presided and ex-Senator Warner Miller made an address. Mr. Miller spoke on the tariff question. In 1879, he said, a movement was made to put news print and wood pulp on the free list.

Jardine's Mosspaul was third. The starters numbered nine. The betting before the start was 5 to 2 against King Monmouth.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 25.--A number of important promotions and changes have occurred recently or are impending in the ministry attached to the Classis of Orange of the Reformed Church. At an adjourned meeting of the Classis, held at Montague, N.J., on the 19th inst., Licentiate Joseph Millett was ordained in the ministry and installed as Pastor of the Reformed Church at that place.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25.--The body of Miss Sophia Clamenz, who was drowned in the bay yesterday, was recovered by a diver and brought here to-day. The diver went down and adjusted a rope to raise the boat and found the body of Miss Clamenz in the cabin, but did not attempt to remove it.

MONTREAL, July 25.--The argument on the writ of habeas corpus in the Pitcher case was heard before Judge Church this morning. CHICAGO, July 25.--"Ed" Corrigan, the racing man, and one of the managers of the West Side Park, who yesterday assaulted Samuel Lavis on the track, was to-day found by the police, who were looking for him. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 25.--At 10:30 o'clock last night George Dippold, a barber, rushed out from his home upon Goffe-street. She was found to be bleeding at the back of the head and badly shaken up generally. Employes of the road helped her to the nearest drug store.

The old State arsenal at Elm and White streets was yesterday the scene of an accident which resulted in the loss of one life and the wounding of several people. "The Arsenal," as it is known, occupies 100 feet on Elm-street and runs through on White to the New-York Dispensary Building on Centre-street. It has several tenants.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25.--The yearling bay filly Simile, by Simmons, out of Miss Wilson, by Sterling, has been sold by W.H. Wilson, Cynthiana, to J.E. Hubinger, NewHaven, Conn., for $1,000. SARATOGA, N.Y., July 25.--Although there was no racing to-day the crowds continued to flock to Saratoaga and the faces of the hotel proprietors wore broad grins. There were largely-attended hops at several of the hotels tonight. The first hop of the season at the Grand Union will be an event of a great deal of interest on Saturday night.

LONDON, July 25.--Mr. Deane, an Englishman, formerly commander at Stanley Falls, was recently killed in the Congo State in an elephant charge.

ALBANY, July 26.--The Directors of the First National Bank of this city have appointed Sidney W. Rowell Cashier. Mr. Rowell has been a resident of New-York City for the past five years, connected with the United States and Brazil Mail Steamship Company as Secretary and Treasurer. He was for 21 years in the National Bank of Rutland, Vt., during 16 years of which he was Cashier.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26.--The statement of business of the Baltimore and Potomac Rail road for June shows gross earnings of $133,869, expenses of $90,867, and net earnings of $43,002. CHICAGO, July 26.--A row of big proportions is shaking up the Chicago Board of Trade just now. It grows out of the trading in put and calls, which the rules of the board forbid but which is indulged in by very many of the members. The Directors have an investigation on hand, and to-day they sum moned a number of leading operators before a committee.

ASBURY PARK, N.Y., July 26.--Hereafter the two sexes will not be allowed to bathe promiscuously in the great swimming tank recently constructed by Proprietor Bradley on the beach.
PIERRE, Dakota, July 26.--Information direct from the Rosebud Indian Agency is to the effect that unanimous feeling exists against the Sioux treaty.
TIPTON, Ind., July 26.--A natural gas explosion occurred at the heading factory of Bowlin Haskell yesterday afternoon. The fireman, Jake Baughman, was dangerously burned, and may not recover.

Book worms and book dealers were attracted to George A. Leavitt Co.'s rooms, at 787 Broadway, yesterday by the auction of a large number of books valued at about $7,000. They composed the library of Meredith Howland, formerly of this city, but now a resident of Paris.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 26.--The observance of the centenary of the adoption of the Constitution of the United States by the State of New-York was enthusiastic in every respect. There were fully 10,000 strangers in the city.

The body of Walter Graham, the child who was thought to have been kidnapped from Coney Island on Monday last, was found in a pond about 100 feet inland from the Brighton Beach bathing pavilion about noon yesterday. The body appeared to have been in the muddy water for some days.

OTTAWA, July 26.--It is understood that a Nova Scotia syndicate has intimated its intention of applying to the Federal Government for a lease of Sable Island. Their scheme includes horse breeding on an extensive scale, there being a large number of horses in a semi-wild state on the island.

BUFFALO, July 26.--Judge Charles Daniels of the Supreme Court, who was the Republican candidate for Judge of the Court of Appeals two years ago, has been mentioned in the same connection this year. Let us inquire why different communities get up trade with each other instead of each trying to live altogether by itself. HARRISBURG, Penn., July 27.--The Knights of Labor in this city and county are making known their political preferences. The latest one to announce himself is Adam W. Hoster of Middletown, who was the Knights' candidate for Register of Wills.

CLINTON, Ohio, July 27.--A frightful wreck occurred on the Pittburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad at this city at 3:30 o'clock this morning. The limited express, east bound, due here at 2:40 A.M., drawn by engine No. 164, struck a defective switch near the Market street crossing.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--The funeral services over the body of the ethnologist, Col. James Stevenson, executive officer of the Geological Survey and Bureau of Ethnology, took place this afternoon from his residence in this city, and were attended by a large number of the intimate friends of the deceased in official, scientific, and military life.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--The accounts of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing for the fiscal year 1888 have just been closed. The results show very clearly the benefits of the application of business principles to this branch of the public service. The quantity of work done was greater than in any preceding year in the history of the bureau.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., July 27.--The horses in Monroe County are affected with glanders, and so universal is the disease that many farmers find trouble in getting the necessary animals to take in their crops.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 27.--It is understood that the Rev S.B. Forbes of Rockville, who was the Prohibition candidate for Governor last campaign, will not head the ticket this year on account of ill health.

LIBERAL, Kan., July 27.--Shorty, a livery stable keeper at Hugoton, gives the following particulars regarding a terrible encounter between Hugoton and Woodsdale men in Stevens County, whereby no less than seven men lost their lives.
Catherine Gafney, the nurse for whom a fortune of something like $100,000 was reported in yesterday's TIMES to be waiting, has not been discovered yot by Silas M. Stillwell, her former employer.
The Brighton Beach Hotel was unwontedly gay last night, for there took place there the first hop of the season, and it was attended by upward of 400 people.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 27.--Another thousand Hoosiers paid their respects to Gen. Harrison to-day. This time the pilgrimage came from the northern portion of the State, principally from Warsaw, Wabash, and other points in Kosciusko and Wabash Counties. Gen. Harrison received the delegation at University Park, where they formed a semi-circle about the speaker's stand and planted their banners conspicuously in front.

A committee of business men called upon Mayor Hewitt yesterday and recommended Robert L. Darragh, Orlando B. Potter, ex-Judge William H. Arnoux, and John Banta or John J. Tucker as Aqueduct Commissioners under the new law legislating all the present Commissioners out of office except Gen. Newton.

ST. LOUIS, July 27.--A scheme to plunder the treasury of the United States Benevolent Association was nipped to-night by the arrest of five alleged conspirators, who are charged with swindling the order out of $10,000.

The Richmond County Country Club held its first "club day" reception on Thursday afternoon. The attendance was large and great interest was displayed by members and their guests in the new house and grounds, which are now in fine order, and which looked most attractive.

The smuggled goods seized by the United States customs officials while in the possession of Bessie Montour and Rose Ludvigh were sold at auction yesterday at the rooms of Burdett Dennis, anctioneers, 29 Burling-slip, by order of Marshal McMahon.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, July 27.--Gen. Franeisco Manigat, who was recently expelled from Hayti, spent several days in this city on his way to Europe. He is a full-blooded negro, and has held many important offices under President Salomon, having been Minister of War, of Foreign Affairs, and of the Interior.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27.--This was Newport's third stormy day this week. Rain fell at intervals nearly all day, and but few of the cottagers came out until evening, when quite a number were seen at the dance at the Casino. A more disagreeable day than this has been cannot be imagined, especially at Newport in July.

PORT EWEN, N.Y., July 27.--James M. Darke died at his residence here this afternoon of dropsy.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27.--Drafts--Sight, 17 cents: telegraphic, 22 cents.

CINCINNATI, July 27.--The Cincinnati National Bank, of which Frank Alter is President, has gone into voluntary liquidation on account of dullness in business. A few months ago its capital was scaled down by the Government inspector below its original $500,000.

It is to be hoped that the Prince of Wales will not too frequently attend city churches. It would seem that the Prince condescended to worship last Trinity Sunday in the Church of St. Botolph Without, Bishopsgate.
For several days past the members of the Cotton Exchange have been more or less excited over what has developed into a corner in August cotton.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 27.--Engene Zinzis was at a prayer meeting at the MeridianStreet Methodist Church last night. During the progress of the services the people present were alarmed by groans.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 27.--George Fredericks, a Chicago Anarchist, spent the day in a cell at the Four Courts because he insisted on claiming his wife.

William McKinney was arrested last evening at his home on a charge of forgery. It is alleged that on the 4th of April last he passed a forged check for $25, drawn on the Maverick National Bank of Boston, on John Francis, the bookkeeper for Keegan Tucker, stationers at 123 Williamstreet. McKinney has been arrested before for forgery.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 27.--Gen. G.T. Beauregard, elected Commissioner of Public Works on the Young Men's Democratic Association ticket, finding it impossible to keep the streets in good condition with the sum of money allowed by the city, has tendered his resignation.
The rain and unpleasant state of the atmosphere prevented many people from going to Coney Island yesterday, and the proprietors of hotels and restaurants wore a lugubrious air.

VIENNA, July 27.--Nineteen emigration agents have been arrested at Cracow for inciting the natives of that district to emigrate to America. Bonds representing 1,000,000 florins were found in their possession. Other agents have been arrested at Brody and Czernowitz.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27.--The arrangements for the grand midsummer festival in Congress Spring Park were completed this evening. It will be the most fashionable society event of the season. A dancing floor 100 feet long by 90 feet wide will be erected on the lawn with an extra stand for the band of 25 musicians.

The Aldermanic Committee on Bridges and Tunnels yesterday heard parties interested in the application of the New-York and Long Island Railroad Company for permission to construct tunnels across the city to connect with the Long Island Railroad Company's line.

PITTSBURG, July 27.--A movement is on foot among the soap manufacturers of the United States to form a Soap Trust. A meeting was held in New-York City recently and the plans of organization discussed, but no definite action was taken. It is proposed to hold another meeting shortly and perfect the organization.

LONDON, July 27.--At the Sandown meeting yesterday the deciding heat of the Surbiton Handicap was won by Deuce of Clubs by a neck. In the first dead heat Sly Shot was only a head behind Deuce of Clubs and Sea Song.
Probate of the will of the late Mr. Henry Hargreaves, of 6 Cleveland-square, who died last year, and who was well known on the turf, has now been granted to the Executors.
Gossip at Englewood was busy yesterday over a scandal which is so far mild and vague, but on which hopes are built that something seasonable may be developed.
ROME, July 27.--The Pope is suffering from a liver complaint, and is losing strength. He has been ordered to take mineral waters before breakfast. He continues to work and to receive visitors.

The first day of this month has seen a remnant of medieval custom abolished in the little Duchy of Saxe-Altenburg, namely, the tollgates and the gatekeepers on the public high roads. Saxe-Meiningen had set the good example, Altonburg followed, and it is to be hoped that the Grand Duchy of Saxe-Weimar and the Principalities of Reuss will soon imitate them.

Joseph Murphy, a shipping clerk in the employ of H.B. Claflin Co., lives with his wife and three children at 449 Greenwich-street. Last nigtht about 7 o'clock Policeman Lakeborn of the Leonard-street station saw smoke coming from the windows of the Murphy apartments.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--O.L. Pruden, assistant secretary to the President, received intelligence this afternoon that his son, a lad 16 years of age, was killed this morning in an accident on a farm in Virginia, where he was spending a short vacation.

Mayor Hewitt visited the members of the Congressional immigration investigation committee last night at their quarters in the Westminster Hotel and had a long and interesting chat with them. He congratulated them upon the manner in which then are getting at the facts of the case, and hoped that their mission would be entiraly successful.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 27.--Burglars raided the Post Office at Orange on Thursday night, breaking open the safe and taking stamps and registered letters to the value of over $500. It is thought they secured some valuables from letters addressed to business firms.
READING, Penn., July 27.--If there is one town in the country where church troubles become public property it is Reading. This time a colored preacher is the target for the tongue of gossip.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 27.--The Commissioners of Appeals of Taxation have settled the difficulty between the city officials and the manufacturers.

Trouble has been brewing for some time in the passenger department of the Trunk Line Commission, and it begins to look as if a still wider breach than that caused by the withdrawal of the Lackawanna and Ontario Roads is imminent.

FIRE ISLAND, Long Island, July 27.--Joseph Stickney's steam yacht Susquehanna, with President Cleveland, Private Secretary Lamont, Postmaster-General Don M. Dickinson, smith M. Weed, James J. Hill, and her owner on board, came to anchor 200 yards off the Surf House, Fire Island, at 9 o'clock this morning.

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., July 27.--Prof. Francis H. Smith of the University of Virginia lectured today before the School of Christian Philosophy. His subject was "The Scientific and Christian Ideals of Humanity." In the afternoon Profs. Fullerton and Tigert and Drs. Battle and Hovey took part in a discussion of Prof. Smith's paper. To-morrow Prof. Fullerton of the University of Pennsylvania will lecture on "Pagan and Christian Religious Sentiment."
TRENTON, N.J., July 27.--The State Railroad Assessors are engaged here in a work affecting the interests of the entire State.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 27.--Near Eden, Yazoo County, Miss., yesterday, Louis Ogle, a white man, killed Frank Guice, colored, and was himself killed by Guice's son. Ogle was out gunning for another white man, whom he accused of having slandered his (Ogle's) family. He met Guice, who has also been spreading the scandal, and opened fire on him, with the result stated.

SHANGHAI, July 27.--A volcanic eruption at Bandaisan, 50 leagues from Yokohama, has destroyed several villages and killed 1,000 persons, including 100 visitors at the thermal springs. A fresh crater has formed and the eruption is still active.

A dispatch from London says that the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough have had the legality of their marriage established in England. They went before the Registrar at the Vestry Hall, Mount Saint Grosvenor-square, London, and had their marriage duly recorded.

Joseph Fletcher, Captain of the Chicago Wanderers' Cricket and Athletic Club, and N.E. Rooker, Captain of the Chicago Football Club, arrived yesterday by the steamer Britannic after a tour of pleasure through Europe.

George Finck, counsel for "Bob" Hilliard's cousin, who has been trying by legal means to compel the actor to pay a debt of borrowed money, has decided to suspend all procedure until "Bob" returns from Long Branch, where he is now summering, and begins his Fall was Winter season.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 27.--Joseph Walsh, the young man convicted of the numerous highway robberies committed in the east end and shady side during the Winter and Spring, was sentenced to 25 years in the penitentiary to-day by Judge Collier.

BOSTON, July 27.--After to-morrow night John L. Sullivan will be without a circus and will once more be left to his own unaided efforts to gain a livelihood. For a time the show was conducted as the Doris Sullivan Circus.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 27.--The Indian Assembly Committee, composed of J.A. Whipple, Cattaraugus, as Chairman; George H. Frost of Chantauqua, Barnet H. Davis of Wayne, George F. Roesch of New-York, and F.P. Demarest of Rockland are making an official visitation and inspection of the Tuscarora and Tonawonda Reservations in this county.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 27.--Orange County bred horses continue to be in good demand at round prices. Among the more important recent sales are the following: To T. A. Disbrow of New-York City, by Peter Goode, Goshen, 6-year-old s. g. Blizzard, by Chester Chief; price, $1,000.

It is not likely that the excursionists who went from Brooklyn to the State Camp at Peekskill on Thursday could be induced to make the trip again under similar circumstances. It was an excursion planned by Company D, Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, now in camp at Peekskill, in order to enable the friends of members of the regiment to visit them in camp.

When the Police Commissioners enter upon the task of appointing the inspectors of election and poll clerks for the coming election they will be confronted with an unprecedented problem to solve growing out of the appointment last year, by order of the Supreme court, of 812 inspectors of election to represent the Labor Party under the provisions of chapter 490 of the Laws of 1887.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--At a meeting of the House Committee on Manufactures to-day Chairman Bacon announced that the committee would proceed to the investigation of the socalled Whisky Trust, and called J.M. Atherton of Louisville, Ky., President of the J.M. Atherton Company, as the first witness. The company's headquarters, witness said, were in La Rue County, Ky.

Thomas Roberts and Thomas Reilly, who robbed William E. Walkley, a lawyer, of his gold watch, were arraigned for sentence yesterday in General Sessions. Reilly had attempted to fasten the crime on Thomas Cooley and William Waloogie, but Roberts pleaded guilty, and confessed that he and Reilly were the thieves.

STOCKHOLM, July 27.--Emperor William, accompanied by King Oscar and Crown Prince Gustaf of Sweden, Prince Henry of Prussia, and Count Herbert Bismarck, drove to a number of points of interest this morning.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 27.--The case of Logan against the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company having been heard and submitted, the Inter-State Commission this forenoon took up the case of Griffith against the Burlington and Missouri River Railroad Company and the case was submitted on depositions previously filed.

A report reached the Health Department yesterday that a child was sick with scarlet fever at 368 Greenwich-street and that its parents were so poor that they has been unable to precure medical attendance.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 27.--The Hill Democratic Club, under the guise of the local branch of the State Liquor Dealers' Association, held a meagrely-attended meeting here to-night, and the question of raising campaign funds, the programme for which had previously been arranged, was talked over. The decision arrived at was that which President Kearns, Secretary McCutcheon, and Financial Secretary Max Stern advised when they were here last week ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 27.--It would seem as if the identity of the person who has given $150,000 for the new dormitory building which is to be erected upon the site of the Yale fence has at last been established.

CHICAGO, July 27.--"Taken to the County Jail" was the song sung by 50 Board of Trade men this afternoon. They stood just outside the room used by the Directors of the board, and raised their chant whenever a fellow-member went in to answer to the charge of dealing in puts and calls. They sang very often, for the investigation committee, after receiving another sick excuse from B.P. Hutchinson, otherwise ...

LONDON, July 27.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. Sexton asked the Government whether, seeing that no Irish member could be summoned in England for offenses committed in Ireland, but must be arrested under a warrant, it would legislate to relieve Irish members from this special penalty. [Parnellite cheers.]

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 27.--Vedder C. Reynolds, Chairman of the Democratic County Committee of Cattaraugus County, renounced his party at a Harrison and Morton meeting at Salamanca to-night. He said he had been a life-long Democrat by honest conviction. Because of honest conviction he declared for Harrison and Morton.

The socond great jubilee over the professed conversion of sinners was hold in the Old John-street Methodist Church yesterday. According to an immense banner prominently displayed at the pulpit, 2,500 souls in this city have been brought to the altar through the exertions of Thomas Harrison, the revivalist.
CHICAGO, July 27.--The promoters of the Gulf and Chicago Railway, many of whom are in this city, are confident that their road will soon be in operation.

The row over the joint lease of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company has culminated in the procuring of an injunction by Brayton Ives, William L. Bull, and their friends, who, as stockholders in the Oregon and Transcontinental Company, are also stockholders in ...
The engine of the limited express which started from Chicago Thursday at 5:30 P.M. jumped the track about a quarter of a mile from Canton, Ohio, at 3:30 yesterday morning.

According to Mr. Holland, Acting Consul at Newchwang, a Chinese port on the extreme north of the Gulf of Pechili, an important industry of Manchuria and Mongolia is the breeding of goats and dogs for their skins.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 27.--The question of the Gubernatorial nomination is still the exciting one here. It is probable that Gov. Porter may not be able to receive a vote by acclamation. Lieut.-Gov. Robertson is out in a public interview this afternoon that attracts much attention.

LONDON, July 27.--Richard Mansfield ever since his arrival here has been industriously at work to suppress rival versions of his chief attraction. There are three versions of "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" in the field, two American and one English.
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27.--Who will be Tammany's candidate for the Mayoralty continues to be a highly-interesting subject among Democrats at this place.

The decision of the police magistrate that Major DOWNS was guilty of disorderly conduct in refusing to pay his fare on a bobtail car is doubtless in accordance with existing law. It has been decided in courts by which Justice FORD is bound that the requirement that passengers shall contribute their own fares where no conductor is ...
DETROIT, July 27.--John Moore, a, carpenter, aged 52 years, who boarded with his brother's family at 120 Napoleon-street, shot and killed his sister-in-law, Mrs. Mary Moore, this afternoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27.--The steamship City of Pekin arrived from Hong-Kong and Yokohama yesterday, but will remain in quarantine three days owing to cholera reports from Hong-Kong.

Harry Wright's team of ball players, the pride of Philadelphia, again fell a victim to the prowess of the New-York Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The visitors played good ball, took advantage of every point, and tried hard to win, but they couldn't. They were overmatched, and the Giants won the game in the easiest possible manner.
MOUNTAIN LAKE PARK, Md., July 27.-- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union, in convention here to-day, elected the following officers to serve for the ensuing year:

ST. PAUL, July 27.--C.J. Wilson, manager of People's Theatre, was last night ejected from the box office of the house and arrested for disorderly conduct at the instance of two members of the syndicate backing the enterprise. The affair grew out of differences regarding the management of the house, and Mr. Wilson, acting under legal advice insisted upon his right to count the receipts.
BOSTON, July 27.--Mrs. Grover Cleveland arrives at Marion to-day as the guest of Richard W. Gilder, editor of the Century. Few of the townspeople knew she was coming.

Francisco Zaponi, in black velvet jacket and knee breeches, a scarlet sash around his waist, a brigandish-looking hat upon his head, his attire decorated with a couple of hundred silver gilt buttons, a stiletto in each boot, a carbine slung across his right shoulder, and both eyes searching for any sort of game that might drift his way among the mountains of Italy ...

The House Committee on Manufactures began yesterday its inquiry concerning the Whisky Trust by examining two or three witnesses from Kentucky, who showed that the distillers of bourbon whisky in that State have not formed a Trust. Certain members of the committee appear to have been misled by Mr. WILLIAM D. KELLEY, and thus to have been induced to look in Kentucky for the Trust.

There is a good card for the racing at Monmouth Park to-day, and there should be some excellent sport, for while the entries are not numerous, still they are of a good class. The Scud Stakes had 23 entries and were therefore divided, so that there will be seven races, in addition to the usual Saturday steeplechase farce.

Mrs. Sophronia Twitchell will probably feel highly flattered when she hears that a Harlem lady, Mrs Lizzie McLaughlin, has imitated her pugilistic example, and has soundly drubbed a gentleman for presuming to interfere with her actions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 27.--Another break in the Erie Canal, similar to but not so disastrous as that at Adam's Basin, was discovered at 1 o'clock this morning at Miller's Lock, a short distance east of Brighton.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 27.--The outlook for the Spring wheat crop can scarcely be said to show any improvement over the condition a week ago. Sensational reports have been pouring out of the Northwest regarding the amount of damage done by rust, and, while many of them are written expressly to affect values in speculative markets, the talk among the more conservative grain men is not so encouraging regarding the outlook.
MADISON, Ind., July 27.--William Riley was accidentally crushed to death by a freight train at Middle Fork, eight miles from Madison, at 6 o'clock this evening. His wife and child reside at Columbus.

WAHPETON, Dakota, July 27.--Deputy Sheriff L.S. Elmer murdered Miss Mollie Kerbell Wednesday night under circumstances of peculiar atrocity. Last night he was taken from a cell in the jail and hanged from the bridge over the Bois de Sioux River.

By deciding that the defendant must pay 6 cents, United States Commissioner John A. Shields, as Master in Chancery, yesterday settled a suit of great interest to the carpet manufacturers of this country, which has been in the courts for 14 years.
WASHINGTON, July 27.--Major A.R. Chafee, Ninth Cavalry, has been ordered to duty in the Department of the Platte.

The changes which the Senate has made in the Naval Appropriation bill as passed by the House are particularly noticeable in the matter of the additions proposed for the new fleet. It has approved and retained the items for the construction of two 3,000-ton 19-knot unarmored cruisers and a 5,300ton 20-knot unarmored cruiser.
The Engineering News to-day contains the following among other notes upon Panama and the De Lesseps Canal:

Steve Brodie, the bridge jumper, was arrested last evening on a charge of abducting Gertrude Lord of Albany, who was 16 years old in April. The charge was made by the parents of the girl through the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. Brodie wanted to marry the girl at the station, but was not permitted to do so. He will be arraigned at the Tombs this morning.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 27.--Benjamin Johnson, 46 years of age, attempted suicide at 402 Atwell-avenue this morning with strychnine. He drank a mixture sufficient to kill 200 men and then told his wife. She seized a kerosene can, thrust the spout down his throat, and filled him up with petroleum. She then ran for a doctor. Johnson will probably recover.

B.T. Babbitt, who is one of the largest soap manufacturers in the United States, was asked by a TIMES reporter yesterday what he thought of the statement of Charles S. Higgins, the Brooklyn soap manufacturer, that should ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 27.--At Drake's store, six miles from here, this morning Dr. Howard Switzer, a well-known young physician, shot and mortally wounded Martin King, a young farmer. The trouble arose about a bill Switzer held against King, and the shooting was in self defense, King making the attack.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 27.--Edward Penn of Ocean Grove, while fishing in Great Pond to-day, was brutally assaulted by two drunken ruffians who beat him so terribly about the head and body that it is feared he will die. Penn is employed as a watchman by the Ocean Grove Association.

PATERSON, N.J., July 27.--An explosion of fireworks this afternoon came very near destroying one of the largest business blocks in Paterson. William Tims, a confectioner and dealer in toys and fireworks, had about $1,000 worth of fireworks stored in a shed in the rear of his store.

There was another good day's racing at Brighton yesterday, and a good crowd was there to see it in spite of the fact that the weather promised to be stormy. All the races brought out good contests, but the best was in that for 2-year-olds, which resulted in a dead heat between Dalesman and Eatontown, the former ...
WASHINGTON, July 27.--Mr. Randall continues to improve rapidly in health. According to the present arrangement he will start for Wayne Post Office, (near Philadelphia,) to-morrow ...

The Reform Club is not resting upon laurels already won. For a full month it has been listening to the words of prominent writers and thinkers upon questions affecting the tariff and has been digesting them for practical use before audiences during the campaign.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 27.--Three boys started out from Brooklyn Tuesday to fight Indians in the Catskill Mountains.

Samuel H. Randail, the lawyer, who at the meeting of the Republican Committee on Wednesday evening said that a client of his had told him of two factories in this city, in which the Democratic workmen "had turned Republicans on account of ...

PITTSBURG, July 27.--There is a movement on foot among a number of delegates to the annual convention of the Miners' National Assembly No. 135, Knights of Laber, that if successfully carried out promises to make it one of the strongest organizations in the country for supporting its members when they are out on a strike.

CHICAGO, July 27.--All the attempts of Chairman Blanchard and others to bring about an amicable adjustment of the difficulties between the Eastern and Western roads in regard to the division of through rates have utterly failed.

STANDING ROCK AGENCY, Dakota, July 27.--Sitting Bull is still absent, but the council over the treaty is going on. Judge Wright occupied most of yesterday explaining the provisions of the proposed treaty.

At the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday Mr. Jacob Hess, President of the Board of Electrical Control, made an affidavit to the effect that the United States Illuminating Company have poles, wires, , above ground ...

The Norfolk and New-Brunswick Hosiery Company of New-Brunswick, N.J., will shut down to-day for an indefinite period and 800 men, women, and children will be thrown out of employment. The mills are of the largest and oldest in the country and have been among the most profitable of American manufacturing enterprises.

The failure of the City Government to enforce the subway law by ordering down the poles on the line of completed subways is annoying to citizens who have been looking forward to the abatement of this nuisance now for nearly four years.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 28.--Edward Penn, a night watchman, employed in Ocean Grove, resides on the new road, leading to Whiteville, West Park.

BOLTON, LAKE GEORGE, July 28.--Bolton is to have a very lively season during August arrangements having been made by the man agement of the Mohican House with J.B. Dick son, manager of the Broad-Street Theatre...
An Italian engineer, Signor Victor Brocca, has just completed the survey of the proposed canal across Italy, the object of which is to save the very long journey round Cape Leuca.
For the week ending at noon yesterday there were reported at Sanitary Headquarters 677 births 174 marriages, and 1,002 deaths, the death rate being 34.07, against 32.76 the week before.

The intense heat which has prevailed for the last six days continues. There is great apprehension that a large portion of the currant crop will be lost, the vines being dried up by a scorching wind, which has brown hot and dry...

SARATOGA, July 28.--George F. Slosson has nearly completed the arrangements for the billiard tournament which is to begin in the Town Hall Aug. 6 and continue for three evenings. Mr. Slosson, William Sexton, and Maurice Daly will be the contestants. Mr. Slosson is constantly practicing in the billiard parlors of the United States Hotel.

Nowhere, perhaps, has the change which has come over Scotch estates been more curiously yet distinctly marked than in Sutherland. Thirty years ago the county was almost a terra incognita to sportsmen and tourists.

On the Cunard steamship Aurania, which sailed yesterday for Liverpool, were Leonard Jerome, Judge J.M. Kelly, H.B. Bradshaw, Major J.P. Curran, Edward Cope, Dr. John Chambers, the Rev. M.J. Dorney. Arthur Early, Robert Butler Hay, Dr. S.S. Koser, C.A. Loomis, W.H. Messen ger, Col. H.A. McNair, Major W.F. Melbourne...

The Comte de Villeneuve is a fortunate person. He is a wine manufacturer at Hyeres and seems to have used considerable quantities of arsenic in the composition of his decoctions, with the result that some 500 people were poisoned, of whom 20 died.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 28.--The ChronicleTelegraph has investigated the Italian labor question in this city and its vicinity, and finds that there are several thousand laborers working here under the padrone system, and that the traffic is regularly carried on by about 15 agents, who operate in connection with the New-York agents.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 28.--The Philadelphia Church Choir Opera Company was booked to play a week's engagement at the Opera House here, but there was no performance to-night. Manager Robert Grau left the town yesterday, taking with him the entire receipts of the week.

Surrogate Weller of Queens County filed yesterday at Jamaica, Long Islands a decision annulling the will of Richard Southard of Ridgewood, who died last February. Mr. Southard's will gave to his son, John W. Southard, about three-fourths of his property and the other fourth to his other children and relatives in small sums.

R.H. Russell has been fortunate in his competition at the Bergen Point tennis nets, inasmuch as he yesterday defeated such good players as C.E. Spencer, (score, 6--0, 6--2) H.F. Fox, (6--1, 6--3,) and E.P. Hatch, (6--3, 6--1.) On Monday finals will be determined.

Hlias Dobray, a Greek, of 16 Baxter-street, was arrested yesterday for trying to pass a counterfeit one-dollar bill upon P. Mauescalco, an Italian dealer in bananas at 54 James-street.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 28.--The steam yacht Meteor from New-York, cruising eastward to Bar Harbor, with her owner, A.E. Bateman, and a party aboard, arrived here this morning. The yacht Nomad is still in the harbor.
BOSTON, July 28.--The tugs Underwriter, Capt. Riley, and Ocean King, Capt. Campan, sailed this morning for Joggins, Nova Scotia, having been engaged to tow the big raft to New-York.

The San Francisco California Demokrat, the leading German daily newspaper on this coast, and heretofore strongly Republican in national politics, has pronounced for Cleveland and Thurman. In a long editorial the reasons for the change of policy are given.

The report of State Factory Inspector James Connolly for the past year recently published has been followed by the visit of Deputy Inspectors John Franey, George Schaubert. Hiram Blanchard, and G.L. Guetig to this city to go on a tour of inspection over the numerous factories, a task that has been altogether too much for Deputy Inspector George McKay, who is stationed here.
Detectives Hanley and Dunn of the Leonard-street station yesterday arrested three men on a charge of robbing the commission house of Austin, Nichols Co. of 57 Hudsonstreet.

Pick and shovel were idle nearly all day yesterday over at the Elysian Fields, for the seekers for buried millions were unable to stand the merry quips and gibes of the unfeeling spectators, who crowded the place all day long, and...

PARIS, July 28.--There is nothing new this week. Redingotes continue to please and to be worn--no one could tell why, for the style is not becoming to one woman in a hundred. Thin women look like sticks and buxom ones are a sight. The severely plain sides of the garment require just so much outline and no more.
LONDON, July 28.--The General Transatlantic Line steamship La Bourgogne, Capt. Franguel, from New-York July 21 for Havre, was signaled off the Lizard at 1:50 A.M. to-day.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 28.--The steamship Knickerbocker of the Cromwell Line, from NewYork, reached her wharf at daylight this morniog, with a full cargo and passenger list.

LONDON, July 29.--Mr. Chamberlain gave a garden party yesterday in honor of the Birmingham Unionist Council. In a speech he dwelt upon the useful work accomplished during the present session of Parliament in spite of Mr. Gladstone's assertion that Ireland blocked the way.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 28.--The First Chautauqua District Republicans to-day at Mayville renominated S. Fred Nixon of Westfield for the Assembly by acclamation. Mr. Nixon also heads the delegation to the State Convention.
At 12:30 o'clock yesterday, 6 days, 3 hours, and 15 minutes from Queenstown, the Etruria of the Cunard Line crossed the bar at Sandy Hook. A little more than two hours later she swung into her dock.
-The streets of Tirnova were gayly decked with flags, but these, I believe, were supplied by the authorities.

Freight agents are now complaining that rates are too low by rail and lake to Chicago and other points, and as no further reductions have been made for several days, a rise is expected at an early day.

By the side of such a whale as a real live Emperor the biggest doctor is a very small minnow indeed, and the thrusting of his personality before the public, which only thinks of him in connection with the patient, is a violation of the laws of perspective which should be punishable as a nuisance.
The quarterly returns of the Eleventh Regiment show a total enrolled of 603 officers and men, a gain of 70 since the last report.

CHICAGO, July 28.--One of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy conspiracy cases came up before Justice Lyon to-day, when Chairmen Hoge and Murphy of the strikers and their Secretaries, Kelly and McGilvary, appeared in court and through their counsel, waived examination.
August cotton went booming up again yesterday and things were lively on the Cotton Exchange. The corner in August is considered more pronounced.

A question which is just now agitating New-Rochelle is whether, as originally laid out, the village shall continue to grow in favor as a desirable residence place, or whether it shall become the prey of the rumseller and lawless element. Just now the rumseller seems to be decidedly in the ascendancy, and unless the law is soon invoked to some purpose there is but slight promise of redemption.

CHICAGO, July 28.--It is a very curious state of affairs when the railroads put out a certain tariff and then are unwilling to do business at that figure, but that is the position the Eastern roads are now in.
-The dinners were conducted on primitive principles. Except in great houses, where the meat and game were carved by the butler, everything was carved on the table.

A commission to inspect the living and dead schools of art in Europe and America left Japan a year or more ago. If memory serves, it was composed of two Japanese and one American domiciled in Japan as a teacher in the University of Tokio.

MEXICO, July 28.--The loan for building the Interoceanic Railway Division between Vera Cruz and the city of Mexico has been issued in London, consisting of 1,300,000 in bonds, and 500,000 in preference stock.
CAPE MAY, July 28.--The inaugural running races of the Cape May Driving Park Association were run this afternoon. The weather was all that could be desired.

The injury that may be done to a political party by one unscrupulous man for whose presence in an important position of public trust it is responsible is strikingly illustrated in the case of the present Governor of this State.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28.--Everybody is saying: "Wait until August." The caterers, florists, boatmen, and hotel keepers are waiting for business as well as for August.

The Prussian Princess who is spoken of, both at Berlin and at St. Petersburg, as a very eligible wife for the Czarevich is the Princess Margaret, the youngest of the four sisters of the present Emperor, who was born in April, 1872.
OMAHA, Neb., July 28.--John Anderson, the man who has been confined in a well under several feet of sand at Johnstown, Neb., for a week, was rescued to-day.

The sixth marksman's badge match of the season was shot at Creedmoor yesterday. The weather was fine and cool, but a strong fishtail wind bothered the shooters in the forenoon. The scores made were very fair.

School Commissioners Randolph Guggenheimer and Miles M. O'Brien visited the Mayor and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment for the purpose of obtaining an appropriation to carry out the act of the Legislature providing for free lectures in the city for workingmen from Oct. 1. The amount applied for was $20,000.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 28.--Judge C.F. Brown of the Supreme Court has denied the application of Messrs. Stokes and Read, proprietors of the Hoffman House, New-York, for a new trial in the case against Capt. Tumbridge of the Hotel St. George, in Brooklyn, who recently recovered a verdict of $20,000 against them, the sum claimed to be due on a five-year lease of the Hoffman House annex, 9 Beaver-street.

The Staten Island and Manhattan Cricket Clubs played a return match at Livingston, Staten Island, yesterday. Many adherents of both parties were present to see the game. The wicket was not of the best description, but played better toward the finish.
The employment of steam in the theatre as a means of representing cloud matter in motion was first made some 10 or 12 years ago at the Munich Opera House.

SARATOGA, July 28.--Jay Gould was one of the large number of guests of the United States Hotel who attended the grand ball in the beautiful dancing hall of that hotel this evening. Mr. Gould did not dance, and merely posed as a wallflower.

The American Yacht Club once more opened its hospitable arms yesterday, and welcomed to its home waters all sizes and kinds of naphtha launches. The weather was absolutely perfect for the trial of speed between the different members of this class of boats which had been induced to enter the races, and 13 of the saucy little craft appeared at the starting line when the signal was given at about 3:10.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 28.--Cooperstown has been decidedly gay this week. Monday evening Mrs. R.V. McKim gave an exceedingly brilliant dancing party at West Ridge, for which 300 invitations were given, and at which the decorations, music, and toilets were surpassingly fine for Cooperstown.

BABYLON, Long Island, July 28.--The new casino at this pleasant resort was formally opened late to-night with an informal ball given by the manager of the Argyle Hotel to his guests, all the cottagers, their friends, and the prominent society people of Babylon.

Last evening as the New-York players left the field after conquering the Philadelphia men for the third time in succession they were a happy set of athletes. They held their heads erect, lifted their caps in acknowledgment of the applause bestowed upon them by the 9,000 spectators present, and, accompanied by the Chicago mascot started for the clubhouse in happy spirits.

DETROIT, July 28.--Judge Jackson met the counsel in the celebrated case of Mary Irene Hoyt against William L. Webber of East Saginaw in the United States court at Grand Rapids this morning and decided to hear the final argument on a motion to restrain the defendant from selling real estate embraced in Jesse Hoyt's will, the hearing to be at Detroit Oct. 10.
CHICAGO, July 28.--Robert Henderson, the Idaho capitalist who blew out the gas in his room at the Ogden House when he retired on Tuesday, died this afternoon at the hotel.
A delegation of 20 pretty little girls called on Buffalo Bill at Erastina, Staten Island, yesterday and presented him with a large basket of flowers.

A good many people will be very sorry to hear of the misfortunes which have overtaken the surviving sisters of the late John Leech. For many years they have supported themselves by keeping a school, but the wave of the "higher...

On a wet, gloomy afternoon in the April of 187--Mr. James Heath sat in a house in Adam-street, Strand, and in the curiouslyfurnished apartment which he called his office. The very dirty window curtains of the room were of the richest silk.

CHICAGO, July 28.--Chairmen Midgely and Faithorn have issued a joint call for a meeting of the General Managers of the Western, Northwestern, and Southwestern Missouri River Roads, to be held next Thursday, to devise...

The State Charities Aid Association has had a number of large boxes placed in the different waiting rooms of the principal ferries and railway stations, to be used by passengers as receptacles for such papers and magazines as have been read and would otherwise be thrown away.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., July 28.--As a party consisting of Joseph M. Greenwood, a Brooklyn lawyer, his daughter, Mrs. C.H. Terry, and granddaughter, Mary L. Greenwood, and...

The usual Saturday afternoon race among boats belonging to the Yonkers Yacht Club was sailed yesterday afternoon. The course was from the clubhouse to Glenwood, thence to Alpine, on the opposite side of the river, thence back to Glenwood, thence to Ludlow, and back to the clubhouse, making a distance of five miles.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 28.--The banks decided to-day that American money cannot go here, and a big discount will be made on the currency of that Nation. The discount is 3 per cent. on all paper money. Silver dollars go for 95 cents, fifty-cent pieces for 40 cents, twentyfive-cent pieces for 20 cents. The city is flooded with American money.

During the recent visit of a Rome committee to Mr. Thurman the conversation naturally turned upon the greatest of Southern statesmen, John C. Calhoun of South Carolina Mr. Thurman was asked if he had known Mr. Calhoun in public life.

Monmouth Park overflowed yesterday afternoon with the customary Saturday crowd. It wasn't a fashionable throng nor was it a particularly refined one, for Long Branch emptied the Summer contingent that has a flavor of the misfit clothing business about it into the crowd.
The Cyclone Boat Club had its annual races yesterday at Communipaw. The wind was strong enough not only to insure brisk sailing but also to provide considerable excitement.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28.--The break in the Erie Canal near Brighton has been repaired and water is being let in as fast as possible. Boats can run as usual this afternoon.
EASTON, Md., July 28.--For six months there has been considerable bitterness of feeling between Martin M. Higgins and Thomas H. Trippe of this place.

UTICA, N.Y., July 28.--The eleventh annual picnic of the hop growers of Central NewYork was held at Sylvan Beach, Oneida Lake, to-day. The perfect weather was taken advantage of beyond precedent, the attendance being estimated at from 15,000 to 20,000 persons.

The ninth annual regatta of the Kill von Kull Association was held off the Staten Island Athletic Club's clubhouse yesterday. Each of the association clubs was on hand with its crack representatives, and first-class races were the result. The course was one mile straightaway from off Port Richmond, finishing at the clubhouse.

EASTON, Penn., July 28.--The threatened suit by the heirs of William Penn for the recovery of the public park in this city was commenced in the United States District Court today by Attorney Taylor of Philadelphia, the papers being served on both city and county authorities by James L. Marshall, a United States Deputy. The-claimant is William Stuart...

I mentioned last week that the Pope's Jubilee gifts included upward of 100,000 bottles of the choicest wines of all sorts. It has just been decided, and very properly, that those and all the other consumable articles, are to be distributed among the hospitals.

PARIS, July 28.--Count Menabrea, the Italian Ambassador, has handed to M. Goblet, Minister of Foreign Affairs, a note addressed to all the European powers, notifying them that Italy has definitively taken possession of Massowah and the adjacent territory.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 28.--Mr. M.H. Arnot, President of the Chemung Canal Bank, brother of Congressman John Arnot, and a man of great influence, has always been a protection Democrat and no little gossip has been floated in reference to how he regards Mr. Cleveland's renomination. In an interview this afternoon Mr. Arnot set all rumors at rest, as will be shown by the following conversation:

NARRAGANSETT, July 28.--The closing days of July find this charming, wind-swept resort holding its own with its sister watering places. The quiet that is said to pervade all the seaside resorts in New-England does certainly rule here, It must be confessed the season thus far, socially and in point of numbers of guests, is behind last year's record.

For some time a warm rivalry has existed for the position in the Board of Finance held by President John Edelstein. His term does not expire till next April, but the recent re-election of Finance Commissioner Joseph Warren, whose term expires at the same time, prompted movements to fill the other vacancy.

WEST POINT, Ga., July 26.--Quite a romantic marriage took place here yesterday afternoon, the contracting parties being Dr. E. Hill and Miss Mattie Pratt of our city. The ceremony took place on the "yellow" waters of the swift rolling Chattahoochee.
The Maharajah Holkar of Indore has just married a damsel in her twelfth year, a proceeding which has excited the keen indignation of his other wives.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 28.--The citizens of Jennings County, Southeastern Indiana, paid their respects to Gen. Harrison to-day. The excursion was under the auspices of the Harrison and Morton Clubs of Vernon and North Vernon, and numbered between 400 and 500, including nearly 100 ladies. Gen. Harrison touched upon the surplus and the tariff issue in his address to them, which was as follows:

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, July 28.--The Eighth Regiment and the Fifth Provisional Battalion, consisting of the Thirty-first Separate Company of Mohawk, the Forty-third of Olean, the Thirty-seventh of Schenectady, and the Twenty-eighth of Utica have driven out the Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn and are now in possession of the camp, their right of occupancy being disputed only by an exceedingly brisk and military thunderstorm, which is reconnoitring and making occasional descents.

The present ball movement in the market began in the early part of June. It showed itself first in a firmness of prices with slow but steady rise which indicated the accumulation of stock by the bull combination.
AUGUSTA, Ga., July 28.--The first taking of human life that has occurred in Warren County in some time happened at a well near tha Sandy Grove colored church to-day.

CHICAGO, July 28.--Inspector Bonfield was given a bit of scare to-day and for a time thought that two of his Anarchist conspirators had disappeared. When the casas of Chapek and Chleboun on the original charges were called in Justice Lyons's court neither of the men appeared.

Dr. Isaac T. White, a well-known wholesale druggist of Evansville, Ind., and President of the city School Board, died yesterday, after a short illness, of paralysis in his fifty-eighth year. He was of distinguished ancestry, his grandfather, Col. Isaac White, having been an aid to Gen. Harrison at the battle of Tippecance, and was killed at that battle alongside of Col. Jo Daviess of Kentucky.

Hamilton Fish, Jr., member of the Board of Aqueduct Commissioners, removed by an act of the Legislature, and whose tenure of office holds only until Mayor Hewitt appoints a new Board of Commissioners, yesterday tendered his resignation to Mayor Hewitt in a brief note.
ALBANY, July 28.--Gov. Hill will sign the Prison Labor bill Wednesday and file with it a long memorandum.
Abram S. Hewitt of New-York, by reason of his fearless, independent American spirit, has rendered himself unavailable for further political honors at the hands of a degenerate Democratic Party.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28.--Detective Geyer took a train this afternoon for Bay Head, N.J., to assist Detective Crawford in his watch over Frederick C. Perpente, the fugitive physician, who was reported to have killed himself, charged with complicity in the death of Andora Troxwell, the pretty milliner who died in this city from criminal malpractiec.
To the many whose time and means allow but brief recreation a trip to the Jersey sea shore by the popular Sandy Hook Line of steamers from Pier 8 North River is one well worth making.

COTTAGE CITY, July 28.--The weather of the past week has been all that one could wish, and the arrivals have been numerous. The National Rifles of Washington, who have been spending 10 days here, left for home on Wednesday. They stopped a day in Boston, where they were the guests of the Lancers. The Massachusetts Wheelmen are expected on the 2d of August, and a series of entertainments is to be given them.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28.--Society was well represented on the polo grounds this afternoon, but thick coats and wraps were necessary. The weather was decidedly cool and the skies were covered with black, wintry clouds.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28.--The Hon. Samuel J. Randall arrived at Wayne Station from Washington this afternoon in President Roberts's private car.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28.--Drafts--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 22 cents.

Several banners bearing the well-known sign of the red star were gayly flung to the breeze yeterday afternoon at 1 o'clock from the flag poles of the steamer Pomona and two barges at the foot of West Tenth-street, indicating that the employes of R.H. Macy Co. were about to start on their annual excursion.
ROUND LAKE, N.Y., July 28.--At the School of Christian Philosophy this morning Prof. Fullerton of the University of Pennsylvania read a lecture on "Pagan and Christian Religious Sentiment."

Some surprise was created among Brooklyn society people yesterday by the announcement that Mrs. Alice Chapin Ferris, a sister of Mayor Chapin, had secured an absolute divorce from her husband, Harvey Ferris.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 28.--It has been before intimated that Gen. Beauregard was anxious to be relieved of the responsibility of the office of Commissioner of Public Works, to which he was elected by the reform Democracy over the regulars in April last.
NONQUITT, Mass., July 28.--The third week of Gen. Sheridan's sojourn at Nonquitt is nearly ended, and his friends say his gain and improvement have been very marked.

James Gurnee, according to a story he told in the police court in Paterson, N.J., yesterday, keeps a saloon in West Seventeenthstreet, this city. Some months ago his wife ran away with $450 in cash, two children, and John Murray.

CHICAGO, July 28.--The grain market was so active to-day that the investigation in the matter of selling privileges was rather forced into the shade. Several members were summoned before the committee.
WASHINGTON, July 28.--The bond offerings today aggregated $572,000, as follows: Four per cents, registered--$175,000 at 127 , $22,000 at 127 5/8.

BRAINERD, Minn., July 28.--Two squads of Indians from the White Earth and Leech Lake Reservations are picking blue berries, the one at Twin Lakes, the other at the thoroughfare between the Upper and Gull Lakes, two or three miles from town.

WASHINGTON, July 28.--Senator Palmer has definitely decided that six years is as long as he cares to represent the State of Michigan in the United States Senate, and he will not be a candidate for re-election.

A party of 10 farmers left Anderson County, S.C., yesterday afternoon on a prospecting trip throughout the Western States in hopes of finding better farming lands.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 28.--There was a great rush of Summer boarders to the Catskill Mountains to-day. The season is now at its height. To-night the houses, big and small, are full of guests. At all the large hotels prominent clergymen are announced to preach to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, July 28.--The 5,300-ton protected cruiser about which there is so much disagreement between the Senate and the House--the former wishing to substitute three smaller 2,000-ton vessels for it, while the latter, with commendable firmness, adheres to the original proposition--is to be a very formidable vessel, at least if she is to be,

SARATOGA, July 28.--Augustus L. Docharty, formerly Register of New-York County and a son-in-law of ex-Sachem Edward Kearney, is paying his usual Summer visit to the Kearney mansion in Caroline-street. Mr. Docharty is very popular in Saratoga, and, although not ambitious to again hold public office, he takes a deep interest in politics.

A demand has been made upon the Selectmen of Milford, Hillsborough County, that the town take out a United States revenue license to enable them to sell liquors under the State law authorizing town agencies. The Seleetmen propose to test the legality of the demand.

"Prince Methusalem" continues to hold the fort at Wallack's, and judging from the hearty reception accerded to the opera during the past week there will be no change of programme just yet, although Col. McCaull is anxious to do Dellinger's opera, "Lorraine,"
FERGUS FALLS, Minn., July 28.--The grasshopper question at Perham is still unsolved. Millions of small ones have hatched out the past two weeks on land that was plowed last Fall and this Spring.
Two capital races were trotted at Waverly, N.J., yesterday. The track was in superb condition, and, as there is no public betting at this track, the races were for blood.
PARIS, July 28.--The Minister of Commerce, M. Pierre Legrand, has been examining for some eight days a new proposition from Italy.

STANDING ROCK AGENCY, Dakota, July 28.--It is believed that John Gross, the ChiefJustice of the Sioux Nation, has been won over to sign the treaty, but as he has been considered a sort of favorite with the whites it is doubtful if his influence with other Indians will amount to much.

GREENPORT, Long Island, July 28.-- News of the violent death of Obed Norcross out on the plains of Arizona has set some of the old people in this community of white houses and salty sedge to talking about the tragedy of "Fiddler's Pond" and the curse which hung over the Norcross family.

BERLIN, July 28.--The movements of Emperor William and his party after their visit to Copenhagen are timed so that they will arrive at Kiel on Monday next. On Tuesday his Majesty will hold a naval review, the leading feat ure of the manoeuvres being a test of the powers of torpedo boats.

With a large attendance the races at Yonkers were continued yesterday. The management wished to raise the bookmakers' daily fee from $75 to $100. The pencilers refused to go on, and after an hour's delay the management decided to let them continue at, their old terms.

Steve Brodie and Gertrude Lord, the pretty girl who accompanied him from Albany during his recent swim down the Hudson River, were arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday before Justice Kilbreth.
Among the passengers who arrived on the North German Lloyd steamer Elbe last week was Godfried Hauser, a stout, aristocratic-looking German.
