Schaefer and Boatswain James Farrell, both of whom are attached to the Swatara, and have been reported to Rear-Admiral Gherardi, the commandant of the navy yard, for serious infractions of the naval regulations.

Since the failure of Levi M. Bates in his unfortunate dry goods venture at Twenty-third-street and Sixth-avenue, his creditors have been divided into two camps, equally hostile to each other, but both regarding Mr. Bates with sentiments of friendship and approaching him with offers of accommodations.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28.--Miss Sarah E. Greenwell, a well-to-do spinster and good-looking woman who lived on a farm in the town of Clarkson, 18 miles from here, committed suicide last night by taking a big dose of poison because she was disappointed in love.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28.--State Game and Fish Protector Schwarz returned this morning from a trip to the Thousand Islands. He reports capturing over three tons of trap nets. Some of the wings of the nets were 20 feet deep and the length of the leaders 20 rods. This is the largest capture of illegal nets ever made on Lake Ontario. The value of the nets is placed at $800.

An Italian immigrant may be sunburned and ragged, penniless and without employment, unable to read or write, and as ignorant as a Zulu of New-York municipal affairs, yet in spite of all these disadvantages his perceptions are so keen that when a well-fed person clad in a blue uniform and carrying a club says, "Move on" in the Irish-American tongue the Italian immigrant catches the drift of the command and instantly moves on.

DUBLIN, July 28.--The jury at Mitchellstown which was investigating the death of Mr. John Mandeville returned a verdict to-day declaring that his death was caused by the unjustifiable treatment to which he was subjected while confined in Tullamore Prison.

LONDON, July 28.--Ferdinand of Bulgaria, must go. ST. PAUL, Minn., July 28.--Judge Brewer's decision granting to the railroad the temporary injunction against the enforcement of the new schedule of freight rates adopted by the Iowa Commissioners last May is generally regarded by the railroad men as a favorable indication of a permanent injunction.

GARDEN CITY, Kan., July 28.--The neutral strip has been the scene of another bloody tragedy, in which five men have lost their lives through enmity engendered by a Southwest Kansas county seat war. Hugoton and Woodsdale have been rival towns in Stevens County ever since the county was laid out.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 28.--P.A. Stout, who shot and killed his eldest son Adolph one day last Spring because the boy sided with his mother, was convicted to-day of murder in the second degree after the jury had been out 48 hours.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 28.--Last evening Spencer Higgins, a farmer, 45 years of age, living at Franklin Park, was instantly killed at Dean's Station. Mr. Higgins, who had been doing business at Dean's, with his horse and wagon started for home.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 28.--A bird about half the size of a robin has appeared in portions of Delaware County. Its mission appears to be to help do away with the potato bug pest. In patches where no paris green has been used these birds do thorough work.

THOUSAND ISLANDS, St. Lawrence River July 28.--The season at this resort is now at it height and thousands are enjoying the delight ful weather that prevails throughout Northern New-York. At all points between Cape Vincent and Alexandria Bay the hotels are well filled and visitors are steadily pouring in.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 28.--Two wellknown Chautauqua Summer schools closed a three weeks' session to-day. The attendance has been unprecedented.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 28.--The only entertainment of any kind which Mrs. Cleveland will attend during her stay in Marion was given this afternoon by A.W. Nickerson at his spacious mansion on the border of the town of Wareham, formerly the Great Hill Hotel.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., July 28.--Charles T. Smith, aged 55 years, a special agent of the Union Mutual Life Insurance Company and formerly of Colchester, Conn., but later of Brookline, Mass., who has been stopping at the Hooker House here for a few days, attempted this morning to manage the elevator. His head was caught under the first floor and he was instantly killed. He was widely known.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 28.--The tenth anniversary of the consecration of Bishop McMahon of the Hartford Diocese will be celebrated at the cathedral, in this city, Friday, Aug. 10, with imposing ceremonies.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 28.--To-day's warm and pleasant weather drew large crowds to the Park and Grove. The travel to the seashore by rail was unusually large, particularly during the afternoon, when several of the incoming trains from NewYork and Philadelphia ran two sections.
DETROIT, July 28.--To-day closed the meeting at the Detroit Driving Park. The 2:40 Class was the race of the day, and thousands of dollars were in the pool boxes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 28.--The officers of the St. Paul and Kansas City Road feel that they made out a good case before the InterState Commission, and the larger proportion of the railroad men in attendance who could be seen to-day are of the same opinion.

ST. LOUIS, July 28.--A case of hydrophobia developed in Brooklyn, a village just north of East St. Louis, a few days ago, which resulted fatally this morning.
The long rivalry between the fast little catboats Jean and Mollie McCarthy led to a 10 mile race between them yesterday for a purse of $100, in which the Mollie came out a glorious winner.

ERIE, Penn., July 28.--A double funeral to-morrow morning has excited great sympathy for the family of Mr. George A. Hart. His death resulted from a fever, and fell with such a crushing effect upon his little daughter Cora, aged 11, that she died of a broken heart within a few hours of her father's death. They will be interred in the same casket.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 29.--W.C. Williams made a successful balloon ascension here to-day. He used a hot air balloon, and after ascending 2,200 feet cut loose and came down by means of a parachute. He fell about 200 feet before the parachute opened.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--In his new abode at "Castanea," surrounded by every convenience conducive to the comfort of an invalid, Mr. Randall was particularly bright and happy to-day. He has entirely recovered from the fatigue incident to his trip from Washington. to Warns.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--The net earnings of the Norfolk and Western Railroad for June were $134,562 88, a net increase of $11,291 26 as compared with the same month last year. The net earnings for the six months ending June 30 show an increase of $172,416 48 over the same period of last year.

FORKSTON, Penn., July 29.--If there ever was an opportunity for bear hunters to distinguish themselves and at the same time become public benefactors that opportunity is now presented in this township, Wyoming County.

BOSTON, July 29.--The new steamer Parthian of the Philadelphia and Boston line, collided with the schooner Ayr last night in entering Vineyard Sound and sustained considarable damage besides giving the passengers a thorough fright.

NEWPORT, July 29.--The cold wave which struck Newport very hard yesterday has departed and the fifth Sunday in July was very pleasant. A very large number of pleasure seekers camp for the day from Providence and the north part of the State.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 29.--A Victoria (British Colombia) special to the Pioneer Press pronounces absurd the news from Ottawa that the steamer Caroline has arrived at the Skeena River and a parley held with the Indians. Not a word has been received at Victoria since the Caroline sailed, and much uneasiness is felt. The steamer was due at Victoria Wednesday or Thursday, but has not yet arrived.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 29.--The steam yacht Sagamon of Providence passed here last evening bound for Boston. PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--Coroner Levy of New-York, who is Grand Master of the Independent Order of Sons of Benjamin, arrived in this city, at Broad-street station, at 11 o'clock this morning. He was received by a committee composed of delegates from each subordinate organization in Philadelphia.

WHEELING, West Va., July 29.--While D.E. Cox and Charles Meadows were on their way to the McDowell County Jail, charged with unlawfully selling liquor. Cox made an attempt to escape and was shot through the heart by D. D. Aldridge and Vinson Wilson, two of his guards. The officers are in jail.

SARATOGA, July 29.--The weather to-day was charming, and the piazzas of the big hotels were alive with New-Yorkers, and people from all parts of the country. The drives were crowded. Gov. Hill, who is at the Grand Union Hotel, was an early riser, and visited the Hathorne Springs.

Judge Thurman's mail brings to him daily dozens of curious presents and mementoes from all parts of the country. He takes great interest in opening his mail and critically examines everything.

BALTIMORE, July 30.--Baltimore has a new enterprise to aid her in capturing a larger share of the peach crop. It is the Fruit and Produce Exchange.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 30.--Mrs. Langtry gave a dinner at her cottage, at Sears and Bath avenues, last night to a few friends, including John Hoev, W.J. O'Brien. Porter Ash, F.P. Collier, William Clark, Leonard Jerome, Capt W.J. Conner, Ira Brown, Fred Gebhard, Frank Burr, George Alfred Townsend, and Fred Hoey. MOBILE, Ala., July 30.--The first bale of new cotton from Florida was received here to-day, classed "strict middling," and sold at 19 1-16 cents. This is the earliest bale received at this port since the war. This first bale of Florida cotton last year was received Aug 18. The price paid for the bale received to-day is the highest since 1874.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 30.--Democratic club of 40 charter members was organized here tonight, several former Republicans signing the roll. David Harvey, a lawyer, was elected President, Charles Borden and Dr. H.S. Kinmouth VicePresidents, Joseph L. Cliver Secretary, and Robert T. Gravatt Treasurer. The club will at once begin a vigorous campaign.

Stocks dropped on the Stock Exchange yesterday morning with something akin to the "dull and sickening thud" that murder reporters have so often celebrated. Everything went down. BELVIDERE, N.J., July 30.--The farmers of Northampton County, Penn., are suffering severely from the depredations of foxes. Hundreds of young chickens and turkeys are destroyed nightly. The farmers are organizing for the purposes of raising a fund for the extermination of the pest.

One or two stocks--unimportant ones-- went down on the Stock Exchange yesterday. All the rest of the long list scored advances, and in some conspicuous cases the advances were of material consequence. There was a renewal of the doleful tales from Chicago reporting wholesale damage to the Western crops, but there was little attention paid to that sort of thing, and prices went up with quite the usual case.

BUFFALO, July 31.--Clingstone, 2:14, and Belle Hamlin, 2:13 , have been matched for a special race at the Grand Circuit meeting here next week. Clingstone is considered one of the best home stretch horses on the turf, and Belle Hamlin made a half mile recently in 1:02 . The race will be one of the trotting features of the season.

Patrick Feeney, a laborer, 31 years old, who lived at 26 Spring-street, died of lockjaw Sunday at Randall's Island. Feeney was at work two weeks ago lifting stone in the cellar of a building on the Bowery, near Houston-street.

BOSTON, July 31.--The stockholders of the Everett Cotton Mills, at Lawrence, took an important step to-day looking toward the improvement and enlargement of the business. It was a practical organization of the company. The stockholders met in this city and, after voting to reduce the original capital stock from $800,000 to $400,000, voted to increase this by issuing $400,000 of new stock and use the amount in renovating and enlarging the mills.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 31.--A large number of horsemen from different sections attended the auction sale, this afternoon of the trotting stallion Bell Boy, 2 years old, record 2:26. The sale took place at Maple Ridge ...

CHICAGO, July 31.--A meeting of the Presidents and General Managers of the Western, Northwestern, and Southwestern roads was held to-day for the purpose of harmonizing the interests of the various lines and improving the rate situation west of Chicago.

Thomas F. Gilroy, Deputy County Clerk and Secretary of Tammany Hall, was presented with a gold-headed snakewood cane yesterday by the record clerks of the office. Mr. Gilroy leaves to-day at noon by the Britannic of the White Star Line, with his family, for a 30 days' trip to Europe.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 31.--Robert Wyley, an old resident of this city, who has been a sufferer from asthma and insomnia, jumped off the ferryboat while it was on route between this city and Fishkill Landing this afternoon, and was drowned in the Hudson River. It was evidently a contemplated suicide. The body was recovered. Ceroner Corwin held an inquest this evening.

LONDON, July 31.--The Goodwood meeting opened to-day. The race for the Ham Stakes, for 2-year-olds, was won by the Duke of Portland's Donovan, the Duke of Westminster's Fleur de Lys second, and Prince Soltykoff's Pantomime third. The betting was 5 to 2 on Donovan.

The Board of Electrical Control yesterday consented to aid Corporation Counsel Beekman in his proceeding on behalf of the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of the city against the United States Illuminating Company.

JACKSON, Miss., July 31.--Rod F. Lowry, who so cruelly beat his wife here last Monday and then fled to evade arrest, was to-day captured in New-Orleans by Chief of Police D.F. Hennessey.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 31.--The new grapevine pest recently identified by State Entomologist Lintner as a beetle, scientifically named Anomala lucicola, has made its appearance in the southern part of this county, in Unionville..

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 31.--THE TIMES correspondent had an opportunity today to interview Prof. E.G. Fowler of Port Jervis, agricultural editor of the Orange County Farmer, concerning his views of the proposed renomination of Gov. D.B. Hill.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 31.--The City Council at its regular meeting tonight accepted the resignation of Gen. G.T. Beauregard of his office of Commissioner of Public Works and elected Edgar T. Leche to fill the vacancy.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 31.--There arrived in the steamer St. Pierre to-day four fishermen of American vessels who have had narrow escapes and suffered severe hardships.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 31.--Mr. John W. Albaugh, Jr., son of the Washington theatrical manager, was married at 10 o'clock this morning to Miss Marie Castner, daughter of the late Samuel J. Castner of Philadelphia, by the Rev. Father McFall, in the Roman Catholic church "Star of the Sea." Only the relatives of the two families were present. After the ceremony the happy pair started for the Hotel Kaaterskill, where they will spend their honeymoon.

MERIDIAN, Miss., July 31.--After an exciting contest of 30 days, the county of Lauderdale has reversed its action of two years ago and to-day went against Prohibition by about 1,000 majority. The result was brought about mainly by negro votes. Nine-tenths of the whites were against the saloons, but the negroes almost unanimously voted for whisky.

In the passionate peroration of his speech on the disestablishment of the Irish Church, delivered now twenty years ago, Mr. GLADSTONE appealed to the House of Commons to "wipe away all those stains which the civilized world has for ages seen, or seemed to see, on the shield of England."

The wife of Supreme Court Justice Jonathan Dixon and the wife of Dr. Dean, sisters, have just passed through an exciting adventure. Some time ago they left their homes in Jersey City for a Summer trip.

WHEELING, West Va., July 31.--The Prohibition State Convention at Parkersburg seems destined to run a long way into the night, something entirely due to a disposition on the part of the hundred or more gentlemen present to talk.

ABERDEEN, Miss., July 31.--At the First Congressional District Convention of Mississippi, held at this city to-day, the Hon. John M. Allen was renominated for Congress by acclamation and with great enthusiasm.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 31.--The Republicans of Henry County, Ind., to the number of about 1,100, paid their respects to Gen. Harrison today. The spokesman for the visitors was Gen. William Grose of New-Castle, a comrade of Gen. Harrison in the eampaign around Atlanta.
WASHINGTON, JULY 31.--First Lieut. Charles W. Foster, Third Artillery, has been ordered to temporary duty at Cincinnati.

FARMERSVILLE, Ont., July 31.--Angus and Thomas Chassels, brothers, young unmarried Scotchmen, were drowned to-day while bathing in Charleston Lake. They had recently arrived from Glasgow.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 31.--Druggist Whitney was "searched" Sunday in a new fashion, under direction of a lawyer. The searchers employed an amateur photographer, who focused his instrument through the druggist's rear window and secured an instantaneous view of a party, all drinking together, in couples and groups. The photographer is likely to have quite a sale for the pictures.
A public meeting was held in the Olive Opera House, Sing Sing, Monday evening for the purpose of inducing the Bay State Shoe and Leather Company to start a factory in the village.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 31.--A local storm of unusual violence struck St. Paul to-day. The wind blew at the rate of a mile a minute. Considerable damage was done to telegraph wires, temporarily suspending communication with Minneapolis, Stillwater, and other suburbs. Peter Strambert, a carpenter, was killed by lightning and a laboring man was rendered insensible.

A meeting of the Brick Manufacturers' Association was held yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Hotel to hear the report of the special committee on the proposition to restrict the production of bricks for some time. BELVIDERE, N.J., Aug. 1.--The Court of Errors and Appeals, at Trenton, today affirmed the Vice-Chancellor's decision setting aside the verdict in the Lindsley case. Mrs. Nichols, a daughter, brought suit to have her mother, Mrs. Lindsley, declared irresponsible, with a view to getting possession of certain property. The case was tried twice, and two appeals were taken. The second trail at Newark, lasted 19 days. There is no further appeal.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1.--Cardinal Gibbons this morning received from Rome the official announcement of the appointment of the Rev. John S. Foley of Baltimore to the vacant bishopric of the Diocese of Detroit. Father Foley is the Pastor of St. Martin's, a thriving parish in the western section of the city. LOUIS, Aug. 2.--Frank Rouche, employed as a salesman at Baird's store, Seventeenth-street and Franklin-avenue, became suddenly insane today and walked up and down Franklin-avenue, performing all sorts of queer anties. WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--Surgeon-General Hamilton this morning received the following telegram from Surgeon Murray at Tampa, Fla.: "House inspection was completed on the 27th with negative result. The first two suspicious cases occurred last evening and two others this morning. Manatee village is guarded by 25 men. Suspicious houses have been disinfected. Probably 100 persons are liable to take the fever. There is no panic among the people."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 2.--The State Board of Health received news to-day of the death of Helena Halverson, the Norwegian leper, diarrahoea followed by obstinate constipation being the active cause. Great care will be taken to render the dwelling and clothing of attendants innocuous.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2.--While Special Officer Street of the Gloucester (N.J.) Police Force was sitting at a table in one of the beer gardens at that place with two young women this afternoon he was accosted by a crowd of young fellows who claimed an acquaintance with the women.
Selina Katt, a kitchen girl at the Buckingham Hotel, fell down the elevator shaft at that place last night and was killed.

SOMERSET, Ky., Aug. 2.--Freight train No. 17 on the Cincinnati Southern Railroad at 10 o'clock last night broke a truck of the second car from the engine, and all the cars tumbled down a 150-foot embankment and were completely wrecked. The conductor and two tramps were killed.
MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 2.--There is a colored woman, Susan Williams, here who in a week's time has combined almost every sensational effort possible. She is evidently crazy.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Aug. 2.--The discovery of human skeletons in East Dubuque, supplemented by other finds, has set the old settlers thinking. Many interesting reminiscences are related, some of which may result in throwing valuable light upon the mystery.

BOSTON, Aug. 2.--New-York's clever ball players scored their fiftieth victory here to-day when they vanquished the Boston men 7 runs to 3. Both sides played brilliant ball, but the New-Yorks won on account of their Superior work at the bat. They seemed to be a able to get hits just when they wanted them, and the Bostons seemed to get them just when they did the least good.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 2.--The train on the Taylor's Falls branch of the Duluth Road due in St. Paul at 9 o'clock this morning did not arrive until 10:36, being detained by a land slide near Taylor's Falls and by a wash-out near Centreville and Forest Lake. Reports from the towns along the line show that last night's storm was one of the most severe ever experienced at Taylor's Falls.

Kate and Annie Wagner, aged, respectively, 18 and 16 years, left their home at 154 Forsythstreet Sunday ostensibly to take a walk. That evening they were seen in an east side concert saloon with two young men, and the four afterward went up town.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 2.--Lieut. Wissmann, the German explorer, has come here from Berlin in response to a summons from King Leopold, who desired to obtain his opinion regarding the whereabouts of Stanley. Lieit. Wissmann informed the King that he did not believe that Stanley was lost, and said that he hoped to hear good news of the explorer at an early date.

The Advisory Committee of the State League of Democratic Clubs met in the Hoffman House yesterday, holding sessions afternoon and evening. James Graybill presided and F.K. Curtiss and W.H. Turrell divided the Secretary's work.

The New-York Press Club held a special meeting yesterday to do honor to the memory of Edward J. O'Reilly, who was Chairman of its Board of Trustees. The 14-months-old infant of J.J. Dooley of 418 West Fifth-street has been missing since Wednesday. The child was taken from the house by Mary McCafferty, a domestic, when she went on an errand, and neither the woman nor the child has since been seen by Mr. Dooley.

I hear that the famous fortress of Gibraltar, deemed so impregnable, is by no means so well armed as it should be. The fortifications were, when constructed, able to defy the then existing ordnance, but guns have improved and the forts are the same.

The closing scenes of the revival services in the old John-Street Methodist Church under the guidance of Mr. Harrison were full of emotion to the people of the church and all who had been engaged in the work.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 2.--There were three deaths from sunstroke here to-day. In addition to this eight cases of prostration were reported, several of which are likely to prove fatal. The standard thermometer registered 98 , although several private instruments showed 102 .
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2.--The Rev. Dr. George McClellan Fiske has declined the Episcopate of Fond du Lac, Wis., to which he was elected last June.

A house belonging to Richard V. Horn, near Lake Mohegan, about four miles from Peekskill, was destroyed by fire at an early hour yesterday morning and Mr. Horn's grandfather. Henry Haight, was burned to death in his room.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 2.--The largest crowd since the grand circuit opened was at the Driving Park this afternoon. Governor Hill failed in the unfinished 2:20 class and Junemont came out and won in one-two-three order, reducing his record a trifle.

BOSTON, Aug. 2.--A few days ago a journey man painter named George Edwards, a Finn, was taken ill with pneumonia. He lived in mean lodgings at the north end, and as he was apparently penniless and friendless he was removed to the City Hospital, where he died Monday.

David Spero, a Broadway feather importer, has had his faith in human nature shaken by the discovery that a confidential clerk and bookkeeper, Adolph Sambalino, is missing under suspicious circumstances. Sambalino was an Italian 40 years old.

LONDON, Aug. 2.--In replying to Mr. Healy in the House of Commons Mr. Goschen said that Mr. W.H. Smith had not interviewed the editor of the Times; that he had not seen him, and that he had held no communications with him regarding the commission.

George Levy of 124 Suffolk-street, who is not 20 years old, has been playing some smart tricks with spurious checks. His method was to go to a store, select a watch or an article of jewelry, say that he was the son of a wellknown business man, and go away to get the money for the article.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--Alvin P. Hovey of the First District of Indiana would like to be the Republican candidate for Governor of his State and may get the nomination if the Republicans permit ex-Gov. Porter to decline the honor. Porter's doubts about Harrison's ability to carry his own State do not depress Hovey and he would jump at the chance of being elected.

Prof. Thomas Hume, D.D., Professor of English in the University of North Carolina, says: "I could have made several hundred dollars lecturing and preaching during this vacation, (had very fine offers,) but I thought that my duty to my classes demanded that I should decline such offers and get ready in body, as well as in mind, for the labors of next session."

All the machinery was idle in the stove and shoe shops in Sing Sing Prison yesterday in consequence of the prison bill having become a law. The citizen employes were told when they appeared ready for work in the morning that there was nothing for them to do.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 2.--Rod F. Lowry is now safe in jail. Deputy Sheriff L.F. Chiles and City Marshal Con Lusk received him from the New-Orleans officers yesterday, and arrived here last night with him and locked, him securely in one of the cages of the county jail.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug 2.--The terms of agreement between the Northern Pacific and the Mantitoba Government were made public to-day. The Northern Pacific agrees to build this year the extension to Port Arthur and next year to continue the line to Brandon.

A cold spell struck Halifax on Saturday and developed into an arctic wave yesterday, which was a bleak and dreary last-of-November day, with heavy rain and high wind rather than a balmy hay day.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2.--Joseph H. Woisard, who keeps a general store at Manville, R.I., made an assignment this morning with liabilities of $75,000. He has transferred real estate at Manville.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 2.--The Board of Education has adopted a sliding scale of salaries for the primary teachers in the public schools, by which, if a teacher remains in this department a year, giving satisfaction to the board, her salary is increased $50. The second year another fifty dollar increase is made, and so on for five years.

LONDON, Aug. 2.--Mr. Edward Cooper, ex-Mayor of New-York, has left London for Paris. After remaining in the latter city for a time he will make a tour of Germany.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2.--The steamship Arabic, which arrived last night from HongKong and Japan, brings advices that the excitement in Corea caused by kidnappers has greatly calmed down.

The factory of the Universal Rubber Company at Hoboken was yesterday seized by Sheriff Davis to satisfy a judgment of $10,000 obtained by the Crossman Rubber Company of New-York. The factory employed 70 hands.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 2.--A span of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad bridge over the Youghiogheny River, near Connellsville, gave way this morning, precipitating a shifting engine and one car into the river. Five train men were on the locomotive, but all escaped with slight injuries. The accident was caused by rotten timbers.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 2.--This afternoon Eddie Bartlett, aged 10 years, was playing with a 50-calibre rifle cartridge, into which he attempted to drive a nail. The cartridge exploded. All the boys fingers of both hands were blown off, his eyes were blasted by the powder, his face was lacerated by the shell, while the ball penetrated his abdomen. He is still living, but his injuries are fatal.

The season has been late, but the landlords can find no fault at present.

ALBANY, Aug. 5.--Miss Jennie Miller, the daughter of Ernest J. The Kansas City Blaine Club, comprising 100 or more men, paid the General an impromptu call this morning while en route to New-York to participate in the reception of Mr. Blaine.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 6.--A change has been made in regard to the proposed soulling race on the bay, Aug. 18, between George Lee and William O'Connor. Persons who raised a purse of $500 will now back Lee for that amount, and O'Connor will put up a like sum in his own behalf.

PORTLAND, Penn., Aug. 6.-Samuel Remaly, aged 48, was killed in a slate quarry at Seemsville, on Sunday. While at work he heard a rumbling noise, and saw that a large rock had become looseened. Instead of standing still he ran right in the track of the falling stone, which fell upon him, crushing his back in a fearful manner. He leaves a widow and several children.

Miss Clara Poole, contralto of the New American Opera Company, has been engaged for the principal mezzo soprano solos at the Worcester Music Festival, which will take place next month.

Dr. John A. Brooks, in his letter, after acknowledging the honor conferred upon him, denounces monopolies and trusts, and says that the latter are against a wholesome revision of the tariff. He then says:
CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 6.--The campaign in this section of this State was opened here today by the Prohibitionists, who had their convention and nominated a fall county ticket.

The number of farms in the 10 States of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, and Missouri was in 1880 1,680,533. To-day they number at least 2,000,000. These farms are mortgaged, ae closely as can be ascertained, for about $3,300,000,000.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 6.--Senator Plumb said to-day that he always thought of Sheridan in connection with a conversation he had with him.

A little girl belonging to an east end family has a tortoise-shell kitten which she describes as a plaid.--Toronto Globe.

Racing will be resumed at Monmouth this afternoon and two stake races, the Camden, for 2-year-olds, and the Eatontown, for all aged horses, will be decided. The "over-night" events will bring together good fields of horses and some excellent sport is a certainty.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 6.--Reports from all parts of the State show that in the State election to-day the Democrats have carried nearly every office by large majorities. The Hon. H.C. Tompkins, Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, estimates that the...

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 6.--E. Comwell, aged about 45 years, a native of New-York State, was killed by a vicious bull on his farm in Prince George County to-day. The body was terribly crushed by the feet of the animal, which jumped upon and stamped the unprotected man after knocking him to the ground.

When the mob was gathered around the jail a week ago and was kept back by a determined Sheriff they cried out, "We'll attend to you on election day." Their threats accomplished nothing, and the people attended to Capt. Lones. He was re-elected Sheriff by a larger majority than was ever before given to a candidate for Sheriff of Knox County.

Application was made yesterday to Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers, by George W. Wilson to have a trial by jury in the case of Ellen Fitzgerald against Lauretta McCabe.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 6.--The sea serpent seen off Watch Hill is reported again in the same district. The sloop Mary Lane, Capt. Delory, was on her homeward trip from NewLondon, where she had taken a load of quahogs.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 6.--Joseph R. Bradley, the proprietor of the Bradley House, 518 State-street, was coming down the stairs leading from the street to the office of his hotel this afternoon when he saw a man advancing to meet him.
The ladies who entered for the invitation tennis tournament of the Staten Island Athletic Club declared, one and all, that it ended "sweetly."
LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 6.--Executions for $5,000 were issued to-day against David Keen, a prominent farmer of Eden Township. His liabilities are $14,000 and his assets $12,000.

Corporation Counsel Beekman has sent to Controller Myers an answer to his questions: (1) Whether the Aqueduct Commissioners had legal authority to adopt the resolution of Dec. 30, 1887, defining the limits of excavation to be paid for to the contractors, and whether, by the ...
"D.L."--Write to Mayor Hewitt about it. There will be music this evening at Tompkins-square by Eben's Military Band.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--The President was informed of the death of Gen. Sheridan this morning, and immediately sent the following dispatch to Mrs. Sheridan.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 6.--A cable message received to-day from the European Union of Astronomers announces the discovery of Encke's comet on its present return at the Royal Observatory of the Cape of Good Hope on Friday evening. The discovery position is the following: Aug. 3, 2 hours 57 minutes 6 seconds, Greenwich mean time; right ascension, 12 hours 12 minutes 54.8 seconds; declination south, 17 27' 46".

EDINBURGH, Aug. 6.--"Flying Scotchman" has been beaten by the "West Coast Flyer." When the London and North western, or West Coast Express, ran into Edinburgh station at 5:52 o'clock this evening it broke all previous records of high railroad speed, not...

BOSTON, Aug. 6.--The steamship Gate City, which grounded on Castle Rock, near the entrance to Boston Harbor, last evening, was floated at high water this evening and arrived up at midnight. She sustained no injury. About 600 tons of cargo were taken out during the day. The accident appears to be attributable solely to carelessness on the part of the officer in charge.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 6.--A large and very aristocratic audience this evening filled the amphitheatre constructed in the Town Hall, the occasion being the first night of the billiard tournament in which George F. Slosson, William Sexton, and Maurice Daly were entered as the contestants.

Two wily-looking but really guilelees Italian bosses were neatly trapped yesterday through a scheme concocted by Chairman Ford of the Congressional investigation committee and Special Treasury Agent George H. Simmons.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6.--A prominent official of the Chicago and Atlantic Road who was in Chicago to-day takes exception to a report that his road has been cutting grain and iron rates to Eastern points.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--Congressman Samuel J. Randall's health is improving day by day. Mr. Randall now sits up the greater part of each day. He read English history to-day for several hours at a stretch.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--The special meeting of the American Association at the Continental Hotel to-morrow promises to be one of the most memorable baseball gatherings ever held. For the first time since all the associations have been under the national agreement...
Ex-Register Augustus T. Docharty was until last night President of the Eleventh Assembly District Cleveland and Thurman Club, and a member of the County Democracy.
MARQUETTE, Mich., Aug. 6.--For several months the Pittsburg and Lake Superior Iron Mining Company has been prospecting with diamond drills on the range midway between this place and Negaunee.
State Commissioner in Lunacy Samuel Wesley Smith has sent to Mayor Hewitt a report containing the result of his examination of the city's insane institutions on Ward's Island, ...

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6.--Typhoid fever of a management type is prevailing as an epidemic in and around the village of Wachapreague, Accomac County, Va., on the seaside, where fully 20 persons are prostrated with this disease. The physicians of the place attribute it to defective drainage and contaminated drinking water. Only one death has been thus far reported.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 6.--Daniel H. Applegate received his commission as Postmaster of Red Bank last week and took possession of the office to-day. The office is a third-class one, the salary being $1,800 per year.

President Edward H. Johnson of the Edison Electric Light Company explained yesterday that the resolutions which he offered at the indignation meeting at Greenwich, Conn., on Saturday night were simply intended as a joke.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 6.--The last four days have seen wonderful changes upon the Yale campus. Thursday morning the axe went into the first elm tree. Four of the trees are now kindling wood and four more will also be so inside of 48 hours.
MINDEN, La., Aug. 6.--G.P. Given, a farmer, came here this morning and gave himself up for killing John Williams, colored. Given claims that he acted in self-defence.

The old Sing Sing Methodist camp meeting grounds on the heights, about a mile from the village, present the appearance of a city of tents, and nearly every tent is occupied. The fifth-seventh camp meeting of the New-York and Hudson River Camp Meeting Association will be begun to-day and continue 10 days.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Aug. 6.--The Prohibitionists of this State fired their first gun today in a grand demonstration held at Packer's Island. Prohibitionists from all parts of the State were present and the utmost enthusiasm prevailed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 6.--Tremendous excitement has been aroused here by the lively crusade which is being waged by the newly organized Law and Order League against the violators of the Sunday laws and the laws against gambling.

Mayor Hewitt arrived at the City Hall from his country residence in New-Jersey yesterday noon, and at once gave orders that the national flag over the City Hall be put at half mast in honor of Gen. Sheridan. Their he received the reporters, who wished to know how he felt about a renomination. He said:
Congressman William L. Scott, who has been sick at Long Branch, is so far convalescent that he expects to resume his work at the National Democratic Headquarters before the end of this week.

A fire started in some unknown way in the cellar of the three-story brick building 110 Division-street shortly before 8 o'clock last night, and for a short time it was thought that a serious fire would be developed.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 6.--The electric light wire claimed another victim to-day. Andrew Reardon, a telegraph lineman, was erecting a cable on Wood-street, near Fifth-avenue, and was perched almost at the top of a telegraph pole about 50 feet above the sidewalk.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6.--It is announced by the Oceanic Steamship Company that the line of steamers now plying between this port and Auckland will be withdrawn upon the expiration in November next of the existing mail contract between Colonial Governments.

A fight occurred about 1 o'clock yesterday morning in the ferryhouse at the foot of Grandstreet. Williamsburg, in which Thomas and John Campbell were stabbed, probably fatally, by Christian Schneider, who was returning with his wife to his home, 65 Delancey-street, from a picnic at Ridgewood Park. All the parties were intoxicated.

TORONTO, Aug. 6.--Supplementary crop reports received to-night from all parts of the province of Ontario show that all the crops, with the exception of Spring and Fall Wheat and bay, will be above the average in yield and quality. Previous reports stated that the outlook was bad, owing to a general drought which prevailed, but since then rain has fallen everywhere, and, instead of a scarcity, there is likely to be an abundance of everything.

Single-tax men who belonged to the United Labor Party and adhered to Henry George and his single-tax doctrine after the political wire pullers had thrown him overboard held a meeting last evening in the small hall in Cooper Institute.

LONDON, Aug. 6.--Oscar Moller, the young man who was arrested at Queenstown on the charge of abducting Miss Elsa Elias, the 16year-old daughter of Henry Elias, once a wealty brewer of New-York, was arraigned in the Bow-Street Police Court to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6.--The first fox hunt of the season of 1888 took place this afternoon, and but for a pelting rain it would have been a grand affair. The event had been looked forward to with peculiar pleasure, and great preparations had been made to show the master...

DUBLIN, Aug. 6.--The court here has confirmed the conviction of Mr. John Dillon, and has refused the application for a writ of habeas corpus for his release from prison. The application was based on the ground that, owing to informalities, the County Court Judge who sentenced him on appeal had no jurisdiction to rehear the case.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 6.--Bergen, the Baltimore forger, will be surrendered by the Canadian Government on the 19th inst. Detective T.B. Hall of the Baltimore force his come here in connection with the matter.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 6.--The latest fad at Chautauqua is Volapuk. Charles E. Sprague, the pioneer of the new language in America and author of a standard work on the subject, lectured to-day to a large audience.

MONTREAL, Aug. 6.--An outbreak of typhoid fever has occurred in the Carmelite Convent at Hochelaga. All postulants (those who have not yet taken the habit) were sent home to their parents. One of the novices has died since, and four others have been prostrated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 6.--Robert Elder, who on Saturday night shot and instantly killed his father, William J. Elder, at Hamilton, and who has been in hiding since, tonight surrendered himself to Judge R.J. Bynes at the latter's residence in Hammonton.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6.--Something more than a hundred union molders in three non-union foundries went out to-day in support of J.W. Foley Co's strikers, who are out because of their objection to a non-union foreman. The object of the strike is to settle this question.

Fire broke out about 12.30 this morning in Company G's room in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, in Fourteenth-street near Sixth-avenue. The room was completely burned out, and Company A's room underneath was badly damaged by water. The loss is about $6,000. The fire is supposed to have started in one of the lockers.

Sunday night two Christian Brothers, who were going from New-York to spend their vacation at Greenlawn, Long Island, while attempting to getoff a train that was in motion, fell between the cars and the platform, and one of them, Brother R.F. Flood, had both feet cut off. He died at 7:10 o'clock yesterday morning. The other was seriously injured, but may recover.

The odors from the fertilizing factories on Barren Island, which occasionally reach Coney Island, proved such a serious nuisance on Sunday night that some of the guests at the hotels were obliged to leave. Austin Corbin has determined that this nuisance shall be promptly abated if possible, and steps have already been taken toward making the manufacturers on the island show cause why they should not be enjoined from keeping up their work.

If Mr. Pool of the Republican Club is right the first reception of Mr. Blaine will be very exclusive indeed. Mr. Pool said last night that the expedition down the harbor on the steamer Sam Sloan was gotten up by the Republican Club, and the only participators therein would be members of the Republican Club and their most select friends.

The knowledge that the suspected murderer, Frederick Baldwin, was to be put upon the witness stand attracted a large crowd to the Town Hall at Westfield, N.J., where Coroner Miller held an inquest yesterday on the mysterious death of Edward L. Miller, whose ...

Everything on the Stock Exchange went up some more yesterday. Not one stock went down. It was a bull jubilee all day long, and the fact that the London market was closed had no sort of damping effect upon the spirits of the Wall-street boomers.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 6.--It is stated upon the authority of one of the leading spirits of the anti-Mahone wing of the Republican Party in this State that the indications are that the two warring factions will harmonize.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6.--The Fisheries Department has been notified of the capture near St. Andrews, New-Brunswick, of an American fishing craft, with two seamen on board, for illegal fishing in Canadian waters.
BUFFALO, Aug. 6.--The second week of the Grand Circuit races opens here to-morrow with one of the best lot sof entries Buffalo has seen in many years.

BOSTON, Aug, 6.--Capt. Mills of the steamer Frostburg, at this port from Baltimore, reports that he passed the Joggins timber raft at 9:30 P.M. Sunday, between Cape Cod and Race Point, making about three miles per hour against a strong tide.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Aug. 6.--About two weeks ago Henry Goetz gave James K. Mosser of Hanover a large farm dog, which was immediately shipped by rail to Williamsport, 140 miles away. Yesterday the dog walked into his former master's house in a starved and worn-out condition. It was learned that he had left Williamsport a week ago and had walked the entire distance. How he found his way back is the wonder of the story.
No information has yet been acquired as to the whereabouts of Henry De Dolters, the electrician and chemist, who disappeared a fortnight ago from his office, at 63 Wall-street.
LONDON, Aug. 7.--The Daily News says: "Sheridan deserves to rank next after the highest. His name will long be a memory and an incentive to a great people."

DETROIT, Aug. 6.--The news of Bishop Harris's illness in London, England, was received here with great sorrow. It was his intention to make a six months' tour of the Continent after the close of the Pan-Anglican Conference to recuperate his strength, which had been overtaxed by the pressing and arduous duties of the diocese.

A very important element in yacht races was lacking at the outset of the regatta of the Hudson River Yacht Club yesterday.

According in the authorities at the Brooklyn Navy Yard Paymaster Yeoman Ramsey and Paymaster's Clerk Mowat, who were locked up on board the Vermont on Saturday, have not been placed under arrest at all.
HASTINGS, Neb., Aug. 6.--The Chief of Police was notified yesterday to look out for Ulysses Nelson, alias George Williams, (colored,) on the charge of robbery.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6.--Walter H. Lennox Maxwell, alias Hugh M. Brooks, is suffering from nervous prostration to-night. This morning his attorneys, Messrs. Martin and Fountelroy were notified by telegraph that Gov. Morehouse was willing to hear a further appeal for a respite if it involved new points.

NONQUITT, Mass., Aug. 6.--The fog bell on Dumpling Rock has been dolefully tolling all day long as if in mourning for Sheridan. Its sombre tones have reached the ears of the stricken family in the bright new cottage by the sea, and have added solemnity to the cheerlessness of the day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6.--To-day's and tonight's pleasures were marred by rains. Many were disappointed at not being able to fill engagements for the fox hunts, but the crowd was able to get out in the evening, to attend the Casino dance. The day in addition to being wet was decidedly hot and sultry.

Since the letter of Dr. STORRS explaining why he might vote for the Republican ticket (and at the same time giving some excellent reasons why he ought not to do so) there has been less sneering in the Republican organs about "Sunday school" politicians.
LONDON, Aug. 6.--It is reported that at a banquet at Kiev, Gen. Ignatieff said: "We will advance Westward despite Austria, of whom we take no account whatever."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--Paymaster Charles McClure has been granted leave of absence for two months.

A new move in shipping circles is the founding of the West India Lloyd Steamship Company of England, whose principal objects are the more rapid transportation of tropical fruits to both New-York and London and a more enjoyable route for voyagers across the ocean.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 6.--Judge Thurman has been busy during the last two weeks with his correspondence, which is very large, and to which, during the absence of his son in Arizona, he gives personal attention.
We see nothing in Gen. CLINTON B. FISK'S letter accepting the nomination of the National Prohibition Party for the Presidency calculated to strengthen the cause which he represents.
Judge Martine opened the August term of the General Sessions yesterday in Part I. and charged the Grand Jury, of which Birdsall Cornell, the iron manufacturer of 143 Centrestreet, is foreman.

The Congressional inquiry concerning immigration has brought out facts which prove that the contract labor law is systematically violated or evaded at this port. The testimony taken yesterday was of considerable importance.

It is reported that after his term as Governor ends, Gov. Scales will establish a bank in Greensborough and superintend a general banking business, as it is his intention to retire permanently from public and political life.

The announcement of Gen. Sheridan's death was a great surprise to residents of this city yesterday. The favorable bulletins for the most part that have been issued during the past two weeks led to the hope that the General was on the road to recovery, and that he would soon be out again.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 6.--The city has decided to consent to judgment against itself before the United States Supreme Court in certain suits on bond coupons. The United States District Court decided in favor of the city on the ground ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--Half-masted flags, flapping listlessly in the light southwest breeze from the tops of all the department buildings and hotels, made most of the Washington people aware of the fact that Gen. Sheridan had at last met an enemy that he could not vanquish.

John I. Davenport, Chief Supervisor of Elections for the Southern District of New-York, has sent THE TIMES a copy of some correspondence in relation to the payment of supervisors in connection with the Congressional election in November.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 6.--A strange disease has broken out among the cattle in this county. Several prominent farmers living along the lake ridge have lost a number of fine cows.

LONDON, Aug. 6.--Clement Scott, in the Daily Telegraph, says: "Richard Mansfield came to win success in this country under conditions the most formidable and arduous ever self-imposed by an ambitious artist. He came, has been seen, and has conquered."
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 6.--Another murder case is occupying the attention of the officials of this county.
Miss Margaret Mather is at the Westminster Hotel.
Thomas Aspin, the English groom who recently ran off with a young heiress of Liverpool, was a second cabin passenger on the Cunard steamship Servia which arrived at Quarantine Sunday evening.
